Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Election Code
===============================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 1 - General Provisions
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(1): "Active voter" means a registered voter who has not been classified as an inactive voter by the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(2): "Automatic tabulating equipment" means apparatus that automatically examines and counts votes recorded on ballots and tabulates the results.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(3)(a): "Ballot" means the storage medium, including a paper, mechanical, or electronic storage medium, that records an individual voter's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(3)(b): "Ballot" does not include a record to tally multiple votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4): "Ballot proposition" means a question, issue, or proposal that is submitted to voters on the ballot for their approval or rejection including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(a): an opinion question specifically authorized by the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(b): a constitutional amendment;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(c): an initiative;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(d): a referendum;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(e): a bond proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(f): a judicial retention question;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(g): an incorporation of a city or town; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(4)(h): any other ballot question specifically authorized by the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(5): "Bind," "binding," or "bound" means securing more than one piece of paper together using staples or another means in at least three places across the top of the paper in the blank space reserved for securing the paper.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(6): 20A-4-301; 20A-4-306 "Board of canvassers" means the entities established by Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(7): "Bond election" means an election held for the purpose of approving or rejecting the proposed issuance of bonds by a government entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(8): "Business reply mail envelope" means an envelope that may be mailed free of charge by the sender.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(9): "Canvass" means the review of election returns and the official declaration of election results by the board of canvassers.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(10): "Canvassing judge" means a poll worker designated to assist in counting ballots at the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(11): "Contracting election officer" means an election officer who enters into a contract or interlocal agreement with a provider election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(12): "Convention" means the political party convention at which party officers and delegates are selected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(13): "Counting center" means one or more locations selected by the election officer in charge of the election for the automatic counting of ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(14): "Counting judge" means a poll worker designated to count the ballots during election day.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(15): "Counting room" means a suitable and convenient private place or room for use by the poll workers and counting judges to count ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(16): "County officers" means those county officers that are required by law to be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(17): "Date of the election" or "election day" or "day of the election":
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(17)(a): means the day that is specified in the calendar year as the day that the election occurs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(17)(b): does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(17)(b)(i): deadlines established for voting by mail, military-overseas voting, or emergency voting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(17)(b)(ii): any early voting or early voting period as provided under Chapter 3a, Part 6, Early Voting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(18): 20A-1-303; 20A-1-206; 20A-1-206 "Elected official" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(18)(a): 20A-1-303 a person elected to an office under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(18)(b): 20A-1-206 a person who is considered to be elected to a municipal office in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(18)(c): 20A-1-206 a person who is considered to be elected to a special district office in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(19): "Election" means a regular general election, a municipal general election, a statewide special election, a local special election, a regular primary election, a municipal primary election, and a special district election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(20): "Election Assistance Commission" means the commission established by the Help America Vote Act of 2002, Pub. L. No. 107-252.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(21): "Election cycle" means the period beginning on the first day persons are eligible to file declarations of candidacy and ending when the canvass is completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(22): "Election judge" means a poll worker that is assigned to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(22)(a): preside over other poll workers at a polling place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(22)(b): act as the presiding election judge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(22)(c): serve as a canvassing judge, counting judge, or receiving judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5; 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5; 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5; 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 "Election officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(a): the lieutenant governor, for all statewide ballots and elections;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(b): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 the county clerk for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(b)(i): a county ballot and election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(b)(ii): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 a ballot and election as a provider election officer as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(c): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 the municipal clerk for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(c)(i): a municipal ballot and election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(c)(ii): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 a ballot and election as a provider election officer as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(d): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 the special district clerk or chief executive officer for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(d)(i): a special district ballot and election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(d)(ii): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 a ballot and election as a provider election officer as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(e): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 the business administrator or superintendent of a school district for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(e)(i): a school district ballot and election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(23)(e)(ii): 20A-5-400.1; 20A-5-400.5 a ballot and election as a provider election officer as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(24): "Election official" means any election officer, election judge, or poll worker.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(25): "Election results" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(25)(a): for an election other than a bond election, the count of votes cast in the election and the election returns requested by the board of canvassers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(25)(b): for bond elections, the count of those votes cast for and against the bond proposition plus any or all of the election returns that the board of canvassers may request.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(26): 20A-3a-401 "Election returns" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(26)(a): the pollbook, the military and overseas absentee voter registration and voting certificates, one of the tally sheets, any unprocessed ballots, all counted ballots, all excess ballots, all unused ballots, all spoiled ballots, the ballot disposition form, and the total votes cast form; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(26)(b): 20A-3a-401 the record, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(27): "Electronic signature" means an electronic sound, symbol, or process attached to or logically associated with a record and executed or adopted by a person with the intent to sign the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(28): 20A-2-505 "Inactive voter" means a registered voter who is listed as inactive by a county clerk under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(29): "Judicial office" means the office filled by any judicial officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(30): "Judicial officer" means any justice or judge of a court of record or any county court judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(31): "Local election" means a regular county election, a regular municipal election, a municipal primary election, a local special election, a special district election, and a bond election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(32): "Local political subdivision" means a county, a municipality, a special district, or a local school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(33): "Local special election" means a special election called by the governing body of a local political subdivision in which all registered voters of the local political subdivision may vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(34): "Manual ballot" means a paper document produced by an election officer on which an individual records an individual's vote by directly placing a mark on the paper document using a pen or other marking instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(35): "Mechanical ballot" means a record, including a paper record, electronic record, or mechanical record, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(35)(a): is created via electronic or mechanical means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(35)(b): records an individual voter's vote cast via a method other than an individual directly placing a mark, using a pen or other marking instrument, to record an individual voter's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(36): 10-3b-102; 10-3b-103 "Municipal executive" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(36)(a): 10-3b-102 the mayor in the council-mayor form of government defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(36)(b): 10-3b-103 the mayor in the council-manager form of government defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(37): 20A-1-202 "Municipal general election" means the election held in municipalities and, as applicable, special districts on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each odd-numbered year for the purposes established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(38): "Municipal legislative body" meansthe council of the city or town in any form of municipal government.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(39): "Municipal office" means an elective office in a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(40): "Municipal officers" means those municipal officers that are required by law to be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(41): "Municipal primary election" means an election held to nominate candidates for municipal office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(42): "Municipality" means a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(43): "Official ballot" means the ballots distributed by the election officer for voters to record their votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44): 20A-6-401; 20A-6-301 "Official endorsement" means  the information on the ballot that identifies:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44)(a): the ballot as an official ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44)(b): the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44)(c): 20A-6-401; 20A-6-301
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44)(c)(i): 20A-6-401 for a ballot prepared by an election officer other than a county clerk, the facsimile signature required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(44)(c)(ii): 20A-6-301 for a ballot prepared by a county clerk, the words required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(45): 20A-5-401 "Official register" means the official record furnished to election officials by the election officer that contains the information required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(46): "Political party" means an organization of registered voters that has qualified to participate in an election by meeting the requirements of Chapter 8, Political Party Formation and Procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(47): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(47)(a): "Poll worker" means a person assigned by an election official to assist with an election, voting, or counting votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(47)(b): "Poll worker" includes election judges.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(47)(c): "Poll worker" does not include a watcher.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(48): "Pollbook" means a record of the names of voters in the order that they appear to cast votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(49): "Polling place" means a building where voting is conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(50): "Position" means a square, circle, rectangle, or other geometric shape on a ballot in which the voter marks the voter's choice.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(51): "Presidential Primary Election" means the election established in Chapter 9, Part 8, Presidential Primary Election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(52): "Primary convention" means the political party conventions held during the year of the regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(53): "Protective counter" means a separate counter, which cannot be reset, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(53)(a): is built into a voting machine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(53)(b): records the total number of movements of the operating lever.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(54): 20A-5-400.1 "Provider election officer" means an election officer who enters into a contract or interlocal agreement with a contracting election officer to conduct an election for the contracting election officer's local political subdivision in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(55): "Provisional ballot" means a ballot voted provisionally by a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(55)(a): whose name is not listed on the official register at the polling place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(55)(b): whose legal right to vote is challenged as provided in this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(55)(c): whose identity was not sufficiently established by a poll worker.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(56): 20A-6-105 "Provisional ballot envelope" means an envelope printed in the form required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(57): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(57)(a): "Public figure" means an individual who, due to the individual being considered for, holding, or having held a position of prominence in a public or private capacity, or due to the individual's celebrity status, has an increased risk to the individual's safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(57)(b): "Public figure" does not include an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(57)(b)(i): elected to public office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(57)(b)(ii): appointed to fill a vacancy in an elected public office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(58): "Qualify" or "qualified" means to take the oath of office and begin performing the duties of the position for which the individual was elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(59): "Receiving judge" means the poll worker that checks the voter's name in the official register at a polling place and provides the voter with a ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(60): "Registration form" means a form by which an individual may register to vote under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(61): "Regular ballot" means a ballot that is not a provisional ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(62): 20A-1-201 "Regular general election" means the election held throughout the state on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year for the purposes established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(63): 20A-1-201.5 "Regular primary election" means the election, held on the date specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(64): "Resident" means a person who resides within a specific voting precinct in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(65): 20A-3a-202 "Return envelope" means the envelope, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(65)(a): into which the voter places the manual ballot after the voter has voted the manual ballot in order to preserve the secrecy of the voter's vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(65)(b): that includes the voter affidavit and a place for the voter's signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(66): 20A-5-405 "Sample ballot" means a mock ballot similar in form to the official ballot, published as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(67): "Special district" means a local government entity under Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts, and includes a special service district under Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(68): "Special district officers" means those special district board members who are required by law to be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(69): 20A-1-203 "Special election" means an election held as authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(70): "Spoiled ballot" means each ballot that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(70)(a): is spoiled by the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(70)(b): is unable to be voted because it was spoiled by the printer or a poll worker; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(70)(c): lacks the official endorsement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(71): "Statewide special election" means a special election called by the governor or the Legislature in which all registered voters in Utah may vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(72): "Tabulation system" means a device or system designed for the sole purpose of tabulating votes cast by voters at an election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(73): "Ticket" means  a list of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(73)(a): political parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(73)(b): candidates for an office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(73)(c): ballot propositions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(74): "Transfer case" means the sealed box used to transport voted ballots to the counting center.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(75): "Vacancy" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(75)(a): except as provided in Subsection (75)(b), the absence of an individual to serve in a position created by state constitution or state statute, whether that absence occurs because of death, disability, disqualification, resignation, or other cause ; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(75)(b): in relation to a candidate for a position created by state constitution or state statute, the removal of a candidate due to the candidate's death, resignation, or disqualification.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76): "Valid voter identification" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a): a form of identification that bears the name and photograph of the voter which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(i): a currently valid Utah driver license;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(ii): a currently valid identification card that is issued by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(ii)(A): the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(ii)(B): a branch, department, or agency of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(iii): a currently valid Utah permit to carry a concealed weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(iv): a currently valid United States passport; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(a)(v): a currently valid United States military identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(b): one of the following identification cards, whether or not the card includes a photograph of the voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(b)(i): a valid tribal identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(b)(ii): a Bureau of Indian Affairs card; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(b)(iii): a tribal treaty card; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c): two forms of identification not listed under Subsection (76)(a) or (b) but that bear the name of the voter and provide evidence that the voter resides in the voting precinct, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(i): a current utility bill or a legible copy thereof, dated within the 90 days before the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(ii): a bank or other financial account statement, or a legible copy thereof;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(iii): a certified birth certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(iv): a valid social security card;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(v): a check issued by the state or the federal government or a legible copy thereof;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(vi): a paycheck from the voter's employer, or a legible copy thereof;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(vii): a currently valid Utah hunting or fishing license;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(viii): certified naturalization documentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(ix): a currently valid license issued by an authorized agency of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(x): a certified copy of court records showing the voter's adoption or name change;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xi): a valid Medicaid card, Medicare card, or Electronic Benefits Transfer Card;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xii): a currently valid identification card issued by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xii)(A): a local government within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xii)(B): an employer for an employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xii)(C): a college, university, technical school, or professional school located within the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(76)(c)(xiii): a current Utah vehicle registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(77): "Valid write-in candidate" means a candidate who has qualified as a write-in candidate by following the procedures and requirements of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(78): "Vote by mail" means to vote, using a manual ballot that is mailed to the voter, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(78)(a): mailing the ballot to the location designated in the mailing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(78)(b): depositing the ballot in a ballot drop box designated by the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(79): "Voter" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(79)(a): meets the requirements for voting in an election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(79)(b): meets the requirements of election registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(79)(c): is registered to vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(79)(d): is listed in the official register book.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(80): 20A-2-102.5 "Voter registration deadline" means the registration deadline provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(81): "Voting area" means the area within six feet of the voting booths, voting machines, and ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(82): "Voting booth" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(82)(a): the space or compartment within a polling place that is provided for the preparation of ballots, including the voting enclosure or curtain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(82)(b): a voting device that is free standing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(83): "Voting device" means any device provided by an election officer for a voter to vote a mechanical ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(84): "Voting precinct" means the smallest geographical voting unit, established under Chapter 5, Part 3, Duties of the County and Municipal Legislative Bodies.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(85): 20A-3a-801 "Watcher" means an individual who complies with the requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(86): "Write-in ballot" means a ballot containing any write-in votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-102(87): "Write-in vote" means a vote cast for an individual, whose name is not printed on the ballot, in accordance with the procedures established in this title.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-103 Severability clause.
----------------------------------------------------
If any provision of

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104 Computation of time.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(1)(a): (1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(1)(b): If a person is required to complete an action in relation to a court proceeding, the rules of the court govern the requirements regarding the time of deadlines.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(2): (3) Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(a): Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays are not included in computations of days if the days are specified in this title as business days or working days.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(b): Unless otherwise expressly provided for in this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(b)(i): when computing any number of days before or after a specified date or event, the specified date or day of the event is not included in the count;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(b)(ii): if the commencement date of a time period preceding a specified date or event falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the following business day shall be used;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(b)(iii): if the last day of a time period following a specified date or event falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the time period is extended to the following business day; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-104(3)(b)(iv): if a deadline that falls before or after a specified date or event falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the deadline shall be considered to fall on the following business day.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105 Chief election officer of the state -- Duties, authority, and enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1): The lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(a): is the chief election officer of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(b): is responsible to oversee, and generally supervise, all elections and functions relating to elections in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c): shall enforce compliance by election officers with all legal requirements relating to elections, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(i): Public Law 103-31, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(ii): Public Law 107-252, the Help America Vote Act of 2002;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(iii): all other applicable provisions of federal law and rule relating to elections;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(iv): state law relating to elections;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(v): the requirements of this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(1)(c)(vi): rules made under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2): (1); 67-1a-2(2); 67-1a-2(2) To the extent that the lieutenant governor determines the following is useful in fulfilling the responsibilities described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(a): full access to closely observe, examine, and copy all records, documents, recordings, and other information in the custody or control of an election officer or a board of canvassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(b): full access to closely observe, examine, and copy all voter registration records, ballots, ballot envelopes, vote tallies, canvassing records, and other election returns in the custody or control of an election officer or a board of canvassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(c): full access to closely observe and examine all facilities, storage areas, and equipment, and to closely observe, examine, or copy all materials, in the custody or control of an election officer or a board of canvassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(d): full access to all staff, including full-time, part-time, and volunteer staff of an election officer or a board of canvassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(e): full access to closely observe, examine, and copy all records and information relating to election audits that are conducted, directed, or commissioned by a county clerk;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(f): 67-1a-2(2) the right to attend any meeting, including a closed meeting, relating to a matter within the scope of authority or responsibility of the lieutenant governor described in this chapter or Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(2)(g): 67-1a-2(2) the right to closely observe and examine any work or other process relating to a matter within the scope of authority or responsibility of the lieutenant governor described in this chapter or Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(3): (1); (2) An election officer shall fully assist, and cooperate with, the lieutenant governor in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(3)(a): (1) fulfillment, by the lieutenant governor, of the responsibilities described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(3)(b): (2) obtaining the access and exercising the rights described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(4): (1)(c) If the lieutenant governor determines that an election officer is in violation of a law or rule described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(4)(a): shall consult with the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(4)(b): may provide training and other assistance to the election officer to the extent the lieutenant governor determines warranted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5): (4)(a); (4) If a violation continues after the lieutenant governor complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(a): describes the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(b): (4) describes the action taken under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(c): directs the election officer to remedy and cease the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(d): describes the specific actions the election officer must take to comply with the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(e): states the deadline for the election officer to comply with the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(5)(f): describes the actions the election officer must take to verify compliance with the order.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-105(8)(b): the court finds that the violation alleged by the lieutenant governor did not occur; or

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106 Duties of a clerk.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(1): As used in this section, "clerk" means an election officer other than the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2): (2)(a) A clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2)(a): comply with all of the following in relation to elections:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2)(a)(i): federal and state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2)(a)(ii): federal and state rules; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2)(a)(iii): the policies and direction of the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-106(2)(b): (2)(a) diligently learn and become familiar with the law, rules, policies, and direction described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108 Audits -- Studies relating to elections.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(1): (2); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act the director of elections within the Office of the Lieutenant Governor shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(1)(b): an election officer shall ensure that, when an audit is conducted of work done during ballot processing, the individual who performs the audit does not audit the individual's own work.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(2): (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(3): The lieutenant governor shall keep the Government Operations Interim Committee informed of advances in election technology that the committee may want to study for use in Utah's elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4): The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(a): study methods to improve post-election audits to confirm that the election correctly identified the winning candidates, including evaluating:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(a)(i): different risk-limiting audit methods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(a)(ii): other confirmation methods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(b): at or before the last 2023 meeting of the Government Operations Interim Committee, report to the committee on:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(b)(i): the methods studied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(4)(b)(ii): recommendations for post-election audit requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5): (5)(a)(i); (5)(a); (5)(a)(i) The Driver License Division shall, in cooperation with the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(a): (5)(a)(i) study:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(a)(i): the options for improving the quality of signatures collected by the Driver License Division that are used for signature verification in an election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(a)(ii): (5)(a)(i) the technology needs and costs associated with the options described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(b): (5)(a); (5)(a)(i) at or before the last 2023 meeting of the Government Operations Interim Committee, report to the committee on:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(b)(i): (5)(a) the options, technology needs, and costs described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-108(5)(b)(ii): (5)(a)(i) recommendations regarding the options described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201 Date and purpose of regular general elections.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(1): A regular general election shall be held throughout the state on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2): (3) At the regular general election, the voters shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a): (3) choose persons to serve the terms established by law for the following offices:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(i): electors of President and Vice President of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(ii): United States Senators;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(iii): Representatives to the United States Congress;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(iv): governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, state treasurer, and state auditor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(v): senators and representatives to the Utah Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(vi): county officers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(vii): State School Board members;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(viii): local school board members;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(ix): (3) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(a)(x): any elected judicial officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(b): approve or reject:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(b)(i): any proposed amendments to the Utah Constitution that have qualified for the ballot under procedures established in the Utah Code;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(b)(ii): any proposed initiatives or referenda that have qualified for the ballot under procedures established in the Utah Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(2)(b)(iii): any other ballot propositions submitted to the voters that are authorized by the Utah Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(3): This section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(3)(a): applies to a special service district for which the county legislative body or the municipal legislative body, as applicable, has delegated authority for the special service district to an administrative control board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201(3)(b): does not apply to a special service district for which the county legislative body or the municipal legislative body, as applicable, has not delegated authority for the special service district to an administrative control board.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5 Primary election dates.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5(1): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 The regular primary election shall be held throughout the state on the fourth Tuesday of June of each even numbered year as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5(2): 53G-3-302 A municipal primary election shall be held, if necessary, on the second Tuesday following the first Monday in August before the regular municipal election to nominate persons for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5(2)(a): municipal offices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5(2)(b): 53G-3-302 local school board office for a new school district or a reorganized new school district under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-201.5(3): A presidential primary election shall be held throughout the state on the first Tuesday in March in the year in which a presidential election will be held.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202 Date and purpose of municipal general election.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(1): 20A-1-206 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2): 53G-3-302 At the municipal general election, the voters shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(a): 53G-3-302
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(a)(i): choose persons to serve as municipal officers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(a)(ii): for a special district that holds an election during an odd-numbered year, choose persons to serve as special district officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(a)(iii): 53G-3-302 choose persons to serve as local school board members for a new school district or a reorganized new school district under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(b): approve or reject:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(b)(i): any proposed initiatives or referenda that have qualified for the ballot as provided by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-202(2)(b)(ii): any other ballot propositions submitted to the voters that are authorized by the Utah Code.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203 Calling and purpose of special elections -- Two-thirds vote limitations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(1): Statewide and local special elections may be held for any purpose authorized by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(2)(a): Statewide special elections shall be conducted using the procedure for regular general elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(2)(b): Except as otherwise provided in this title, local special elections shall be conducted using the procedures for regular municipal elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(3): The governor may call a statewide special election by issuing an executive order that designates:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(3)(a): the date for the statewide special election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(3)(b): the purpose for the statewide special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(4): The Legislature may call a statewide special election by passing a joint or concurrent resolution that designates:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(4)(a): the date for the statewide special election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(4)(b): the purpose for the statewide special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5): 53F-8-402; 53F-8-301; 10-18-204; 17-3-1; 53F-8-402; 10-2a-210; 20A-1-204
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a): 53F-8-402; 53F-8-301; 10-18-204; 17-3-1; 53F-8-402; 10-2a-210 The legislative body of a local political subdivision may call a local special election only for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(i): a vote on a bond or debt issue;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(ii): 53F-8-402; 53F-8-301 a vote on a voted local levy authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(iii): an initiative authorized by Chapter 7, Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(iv): a referendum authorized by Chapter 7, Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(v): if required or authorized by federal law, a vote to determine whether Utah's legal boundaries should be changed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(vi): a vote authorized or required by Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(vii): 10-18-204 a vote on a municipality providing cable television services or public telecommunications services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(viii): 17-3-1 a vote to create a new county under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(ix): 53F-8-402 a vote on a special property tax under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(a)(x): 10-2a-210 a vote on the incorporation of a municipality in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(b): 20A-1-204 The legislative body of a local political subdivision may call a local special election by adopting an ordinance or resolution that designates:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(b)(i): 20A-1-204 the date for the local special election as authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(b)(ii): the purpose for the local special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(c): A local political subdivision may not call a local special election unless the ordinance or resolution calling a local special election under Subsection (5)(b) is adopted by a two-thirds majority of all members of the legislative body, if the local special election is for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(c)(i): a vote on a bond or debt issue as described in Subsection (5)(a)(i);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(c)(ii): a vote on a voted leeway or levy program as described in Subsection (5)(a)(ii); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-203(5)(c)(iii): a vote authorized or required for a sales tax issue as described in Subsection (5)(a)(vi).


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-204 Date of special election -- Legal effect.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-204(1): (1)(d); 20A-1-203; (1)(c); 20A-1-203; (1)(b); (1)(d); 53-2a-102; 53-2a-102; Chapter 9, Part 8, Presidential Primary Election

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-204(1)(d): The legislative body of a local political subdivision may only call a special election for a ballot proposition related to a bond, debt, leeway, levy, or tax on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-204(1)(e): Nothing in this section prohibits:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206 Cancellation of local election or local race -- Municipalities -- Special districts -- Notice.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(a): "Contested race" means a race in a general election where the number of candidates, including any eligible write-in candidates, exceeds the number of offices to be filled in the race.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(b): "Election" means an event, run by an election officer, that includes one or more races for public office or one or more ballot propositions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(c)(i): "Race" means a contest between candidates to obtain the number of votes necessary to take a particular public office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(c)(ii): "Race," as the term relates to a contest for an at-large position, includes all open positions for the same at-large office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(1)(c)(iii): "Race," as the term relates to a contest for a municipal council position that is not an at-large position, includes only the contest to represent a particular district on the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(2): A municipal legislative body may cancel a local election if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(2)(a): the ballot for the local election will not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(2)(b): the municipal legislative body passes, no later than 20 days before the day of the scheduled election, a resolution that cancels the election and certifies that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(2)(b)(i): the ballot for the election would not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(2)(b)(ii): the candidates who qualified for the ballot are considered elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(3): A municipal legislative body may cancel a race in a local election if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(3)(a): the ballot for the race will not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(3)(b): the municipal legislative body passes, no later than 20 days before the day of the scheduled election, a resolution that cancels the race and certifies that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(3)(b)(i): the ballot for the race would not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(3)(b)(ii): the candidate for the race is considered elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(4): (2); (8); 20A-7-801; 63G-30-102 A municipal legislative body that cancels a local election in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(4)(a): (8); 20A-7-801 subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(4)(b): 63G-30-102 providing notice for the municipality, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(5): A special district board may cancel a local election if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(5)(a): the ballot for the local election will not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(5)(b): the special district board passes, no later than 20 days before the day of the scheduled election, a resolution that cancels the election and certifies that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(5)(b)(i): the ballot for the election would not include any contested races or ballot propositions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(5)(b)(ii): the candidates who qualified for the ballot are considered elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(6): A special district board may cancel a special district race if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(6)(a): the race is uncontested; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(6)(b): the special district board passes, no later than 20 days before the day of the scheduled election, a resolution that cancels the race and certifies that the candidate who qualified for the ballot for that race is considered elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(7): (5); (8); 20A-7-801; 63G-30-102 A special district that cancels a local election in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(7)(a): (8); 20A-7-801 subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(7)(b): 63G-30-102 as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-206(8): (4)(a); (7)(a) A municipal legislative body that posts a notice in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-302 Opening and closing of polls on election day.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-302(1): Polls at all elections on the date of the election shall open at 7 a.m. and shall remain open until 8 p.m. of the same day.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-302(2): The election judges shall allow every voter who arrives at the polls by 8 p.m. to vote.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303 Determining results.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(a): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(a)(i): election for any office to be filled at that election is elected to that office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(a)(ii): primary for nomination for any office is nominated for that office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(b): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(b)(i): election for any office to filled at that election are elected to that office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(1)(b)(ii): primary for nomination for any office are nominated for that office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(2): Any ballot proposition submitted to voters for their approval or rejection:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(2)(a): passes if the number of "yes" votes is greater than the number of "no" votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(2)(b): fails if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(2)(b)(i): the number of "yes" votes equal the number of "no" votes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-303(2)(b)(ii): the number of "no" votes is greater than the number of "yes" votes.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304 Tie votes.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(1): This section does not apply to a race conducted by instant runoff voting under Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(2): 20A-4-401(5) Except as provided in Subsection (3), if, after conducting a recount under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(2)(a): determine the winning candidate, by lot, in whatever manner the election officer determines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(2)(b): provide notice and an opportunity for each candidate involved in the tie to observe the casting or drawing of the lot or to send a representative to observe the casting or drawing of the lot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3): 20A-4-401; 20A-4-401
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(a): 20A-4-401 If, after conducting a recount under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(a)(i): determine the winning nominee, by lot, in whatever manner the governor determines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(a)(ii): provide notice and an opportunity for each candidate involved in the tie to observe the casting or drawing of the lot or to send a representative to observe the casting or drawing of the lot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(b): 20A-4-401 If, after conducting a recount under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(b)(i): determine the winning nominee, by lot, in whatever manner the judges determine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-304(3)(b)(ii): provide notice and an opportunity for each candidate involved in the tie to observe the casting or drawing of the lot or to send a representative to observe the casting or drawing of the lot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-305 Compilation and distribution of election laws.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-305(1): The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-305(1)(a): make an electronic compilation of Title 20A, Election Code, and any other provisions of law that govern elections; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-305(1)(b): transmit an electronic copy of the compilation to each county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-305(2): Each county clerk shall furnish each election officer in the county with a copy of the compilation described in Subsection (1)(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-306 Electronic signatures prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding Title 46, Chapter 4, Uniform Electronic Transactions Act, and SubsectionsUtah Code Annotated § 20A-1-306(1): 20A-21-201 except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-306(2): organize and register a political party under Chapter 8, Political Party Formation and Procedures; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-306(3): 20A-21-201 except as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-307 Residency requirements for person who verifies a signature on a petition.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any other provision in this title that requires a person who signs the verification on a petition to be a resident, a person who is not a resident may sign the verification on a petition if:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-307(1): the person signing the petition is a resident who is temporarily located outside the state at the time of signing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-307(2): the person signing the verification meets all the requirements in the verification, except for the residency requirement.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308 Elections during declared emergencies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act; Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act As used in this section, "declared emergency" means a state of emergency that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(a): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act; Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act is declared by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(a)(i): the president of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(a)(ii): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act the governor in an executive order under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(a)(iii): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 2, Disaster Response and Recovery Act the chief executive officer of a political subdivision in a proclamation under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b): affects an election in the state, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b)(i): voting on election day;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b)(ii): early voting;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b)(iii): the transmittal or voting of a ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b)(iv): the counting of a ballot; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(1)(b)(v): the canvassing of election returns.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(2): (1)(b) During a declared emergency, the lieutenant governor may designate a method, time, or location for, or relating to, an event described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(3): (2); 20A-7-801 The lieutenant governor shall notify a voter or potential voter of a different method, time, or location designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(3)(a): 20A-7-801 posting a notice on the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(3)(b): notifying each election officer affected by the designation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-308(3)(c): notifying a newspaper of general circulation within the state or a local media correspondent.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-402 Election officer to render interpretations and make decisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The election officer shall render all interpretations and make all initial decisions about controversies or other matters arising under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403 Errors or omissions in ballots.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(1): The election officer shall, without delay, correct any errors in ballots that the election officer discovers, or that are brought to the election officer's attention, if those errors can be corrected without interfering with the timely distribution of the ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(a)(i): If an error or omission has occurred in the publication of the names or description of the candidates nominated for office, in the publication of sample ballots, or in the printing of official ballots, a candidate or the candidate's agent may file, without paying any fee, a petition for ballot correction with the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(a)(ii): If a petition is filed, the petitioner shall serve a copy of the petition on the respondents on the same day that the petition is filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(b): The petition shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(b)(i): an affidavit signed by the candidate or the candidate's agent identifying the error or omission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(2)(b)(ii): a request that the court issue an order to the election officer responsible for the ballot error or omission to correct the ballot error or omission.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3)(a): After reviewing the petition, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3)(a)(i): issue an order commanding the respondent named in the petition to appear before the court to answer, under oath, under penalty of perjury, to the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3)(a)(ii): summarily hear and dispose of any issues raised by the petition to obtain substantial compliance with the provisions of this title by the parties to the controversy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3)(a)(iii): enter appropriate orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-403(3)(b): The court may assess costs, including reasonable attorney fees, against either party.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404 Election controversies.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(1)(a)(i): Whenever any controversy occurs between any election officer or other person or entity charged with any duty or function under this title and any candidate, or the officers or representatives of any political party, or persons who have made nominations, either party to the controversy may file a verified petition with the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(1)(a)(ii): If a petition is filed, the petitioner shall serve a copy of the petition on the respondents on the same day that the petition is filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(1)(b): The verified petition shall identify concisely the nature of the controversy and the relief sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2): 10-3-208; 17-16-6.5; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 2, State Office Candidates - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 3, Candidates for Legislative Office - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 4, Officeholder Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 5, Political Party Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 6, Political Action Committee Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 7, Campaign Financial Reporting by Corporations; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 8, Political Issues Committees - Registration and Financial Reporting; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 13, State School Board Candidates; Title 20A, Chapter 12, Part 3, Campaign and Financial Reporting Requirements for Judicial Retention Elections After reviewing the petition, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(a): issue an order commanding the respondent named in the petition to appear before the court to answer, under oath, to the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b): 10-3-208; 17-16-6.5; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 2, State Office Candidates - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 3, Candidates for Legislative Office - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 4, Officeholder Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 5, Political Party Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 6, Political Action Committee Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 7, Campaign Financial Reporting by Corporations; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 8, Political Issues Committees - Registration and Financial Reporting; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 13, State School Board Candidates; Title 20A, Chapter 12, Part 3, Campaign and Financial Reporting Requirements for Judicial Retention Elections summarily hear and dispose of any issues raised by the petition to obtain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(i): 10-3-208; 17-16-6.5; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 2, State Office Candidates - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 3, Candidates for Legislative Office - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 4, Officeholder Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 5, Political Party Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 6, Political Action Committee Registration and Financial Reporting Requirements; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 7, Campaign Financial Reporting by Corporations; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 8, Political Issues Committees - Registration and Financial Reporting; Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 13, State School Board Candidates; Title 20A, Chapter 12, Part 3, Campaign and Financial Reporting Requirements for Judicial Retention Elections strict compliance with all filing deadlines for financial disclosure reports under:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(i)(A): 10-3-208 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(i)(B): 17-16-6.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(i)(C): Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 2, State Office Candidates - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(i)(D): Title 20A, Chapter 11, Part 3, Candidates for Legislative Office - Campaign Organization and Financial Reporting Requirements

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(b)(ii): substantial compliance with all other provisions of this title by the parties to the controversy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-404(2)(c): make and enter orders and judgments, and issue the process of the court to enforce all of those orders and judgments.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502 Midterm vacancy in office of United States senator.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1): (2); (3); (1)(a)(i); (iv); (1)(a); (1)(b); 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408; Chapter 16, Uniform Military and Overseas Voters Act Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(a): sets a date for a primary congressional special election, and a later date for a general congressional special election, on the same day as one of the following elections:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(a)(i): a municipal general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(a)(ii): a presidential primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(a)(iii): a regular primary election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(a)(iv): a regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(b): (1)(a)(i); (iv) sets the date of the primary congressional special election on the same day as the next election described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(c): (1)(a); (1)(b) sets the date of the general special congressional election on the same day as the next election described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(d): provides each registered political party that is not a qualified political party at least 21 days, but no more than 28 days, to select one candidate, in a manner determined by the registered political party, as a candidate for the registered political party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(e): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 for each qualified political party, provides at least 21 days, but no more than 28 days:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(e)(i): 20A-9-407 for the qualified political party to select one candidate, using the convention process described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(e)(ii): 20A-9-408 for a member of the qualified political party to submit signatures to qualify as a candidate for the qualified political party using the signature-gathering process described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(f): consistent with the requirements of this section, establishes the deadlines, time frames, and procedures for filing a declaration of candidacy, giving notice of an election, and other election requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(1)(g): Chapter 16, Uniform Military and Overseas Voters Act requires an election officer to comply with the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(2): (1)(a); (1); (1); (1); (2)(a); (1); (1); (1)(a)(i); (iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(2)(a): (1)(a); (1); (1); (1) The governor may set a date for a primary special congressional election or a general special congressional election on a date other than a date described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(2)(a)(i): (1) on the same day on which the governor issues the proclamation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(2)(a)(ii): (1); (1) if the governor issues the proclamation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(2)(b): (2)(a); (1); (1); (1)(a)(i); (iv) If the Legislature does not, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(3): (3)(a) A special congressional election to fill a vacancy in the office of United States senator will not be held if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(3)(a): the next regular general election that occurs after the day on which the vacancy occurs is the regular general election that occurs immediately before the six-year term for the senate office ends; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(3)(b): (3)(a) the vacancy occurs after August 1 of the year before the regular general election described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(4): (4)(a); (1); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(4)(a): The governor shall appoint an individual to temporarily fill a vacancy in the office of United States senator from one of three individuals nominated by the Legislature, each of whom is a member of the political party of which the prior officeholder was a member at the time the prior officeholder was elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(4)(b): (4)(a); (1); (2) The individual appointed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(4)(b)(i): (1); (2) the vacancy is filled by election under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(4)(b)(ii): the six-year term for the senate office ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(5): An individual elected to fill a vacancy under this section shall serve until the end of the current term in which the vacancy filled by the election occurs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(6): A vacancy in the office of United States senator does not occur unless the senator:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(6)(a): has left the office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502(6)(b): submits an irrevocable letter of resignation to the governor or to the president of the United States Senate.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5 Midterm vacancy in office of United States representative.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1): (2); (4); (1)(a)(i); (iv); (1)(a); (1)(b); 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408; Chapter 16, Uniform Military and Overseas Voters Act Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(a): sets a date for a primary congressional special election, and a later date for a general congressional special election, on the same day as one of the following elections:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(a)(i): a municipal general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(a)(ii): a presidential primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(a)(iii): a regular primary election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(a)(iv): a regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(b): (1)(a)(i); (iv) sets the date of the primary congressional special election on the same day as the next election described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(c): (1)(a); (1)(b) sets the date of the general special congressional election on the same day as the next election described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(d): provides each registered political party that is not a qualified political party at least 21 days, but no more than 28 days, to select one candidate, in a manner determined by the registered political party, as a candidate for the registered political party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(e): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 for each qualified political party, provides at least 21 days, but no more than 28 days:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(e)(i): 20A-9-407 for the qualified political party to select one candidate, using the convention process described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(e)(ii): 20A-9-408 for a member of the qualified political party to submit signatures to qualify as a candidate for the qualified political party using the signature-gathering process described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(1)(f): consistent with the requirements of this section, establishes the deadlines, time frames, and procedures for filing a declaration of candidacy, giving notice of an election, and other election requirements; and

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(2): (1)(a); (1); (1); (1) The governor may set a date for a primary special congressional election or a general special congressional election on a date other than a date described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(4): A special congressional election to fill a vacancy in the office of United States representative will not be held if the vacancy occurs fewer than 180 days before the next regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(5): An individual who fills a vacancy under this section shall serve until the end of the current term in which the vacancy occurs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(6): A vacancy in the office of United States representative does not occur unless the representative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(6)(a): has left the office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-502.5(6)(b): submits an irrevocable letter of resignation to the governor or to the speaker of the United States House of Representatives.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-503(2): When a vacancy occurs for any reason in the office of representative in the Legislature, the governor shall fill the vacancy by immediately appointing the person whose name was submitted by the party liaison of the same political party as the prior representative.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504 Midterm vacancies in the offices of attorney general, state treasurer, state auditor, State Board of Education member, and lieutenant governor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1): 20A-14-103; 20A-14-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(a): When a vacancy occurs for any reason in the office of attorney general, state treasurer, state auditor, or State Board of Education member, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term at the next regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b): 20A-14-103; 20A-14-103 The governor shall fill the vacancy until the next regular general election by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b)(i): appointing a person who meets the qualifications for the office from three persons nominated by the state central committee of the same political party as the prior officeholder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b)(ii): 20A-14-103; 20A-14-103 for a State Board of Education vacancy, if the individual who is being replaced:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b)(ii)(A): 20A-14-103 was elected at a nonpartisan State Board of Education election, by appointing, with the advice and consent of the Senate, an individual who meets the qualifications and residency requirements for filling the vacancy described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b)(ii)(B): 20A-14-103 was elected at a partisan State Board of Education election, but is not a member of a political party, by appointing, with the advice and consent of the Senate, an individual who meets the qualifications and residency requirements for filling the vacancy described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(1)(b)(ii)(C): was elected at a partisan State Board of Education election, and is a member of a political party, by appointing an individual who meets the qualifications for the office from three persons nominated by the state central committee of the same political party as the prior officeholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-504(2): If a vacancy occurs in the office of lieutenant governor, the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoint a person to hold the office until the next regular general election at which the governor stands for election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506 Vacancy in the office of justice court judge.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(a): "Appointing authority" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(a)(i): for a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(a)(i)(A): the chair of the county commission in a county having the county commission or expanded county commission form of county government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(a)(i)(B): the county executive in a county having the county executive-council form of government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(a)(ii): for a city or town, the mayor of the city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(b): "Local legislative body" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(b)(i): for a county, the county commission or county council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(1)(b)(ii): for a city or town, the council of the city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(2): 78A-7-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(2)(a): 78A-7-202 If a vacancy occurs in the office of a municipal justice court judge before the completion of the judge's term of office, the appointing authority:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(2)(a)(i): 78A-7-202 shall fill the vacancy by following the procedures and requirements for appointments in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(2)(a)(ii): may contract with a justice court judge of the county, an adjacent county, or another municipality within those counties for judicial services until the vacancy is filled.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(2)(b): The appointing authority shall notify the Administrative Office of the Courts in writing of an appointment of a municipal justice court judge under this section within 30 days after the appointment is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(3): 78A-7-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(3)(a): 78A-7-202 If a vacancy occurs in the office of a county justice court judge before the completion of the judge's term of office, the appointing authority shall fill the vacancy by following the procedures and requirements for appointments in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(3)(b): The appointing authority shall notify the Administrative Office of the Courts in writing of an appointment of a county justice court judge under this section within 30 days after the appointment is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4): Title 52, Chapter 3, Prohibiting Employment of Relatives
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(a): Title 52, Chapter 3, Prohibiting Employment of Relatives When a vacancy occurs in the office of a justice court judge, the appointing authority shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(a)(i): advertise the vacancy and solicit applications for the vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(a)(ii): appoint the best qualified candidate to office based solely upon fitness for office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(a)(iii): Title 52, Chapter 3, Prohibiting Employment of Relatives comply with the procedures and requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(a)(iv): submit the name of the appointee to the local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-506(4)(b): If the local legislative body does not confirm the appointment within 30 days of submission, the appointing authority may either appoint another of the applicants or reopen the vacancy by advertisement and solicitations of applications.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(a)(ii): if the vacant office has an unexpired term of two years or more but 65 days or less remain before the day of the next regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(b): (7)(a); (7)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(b)(i): (7)(a) When the conditions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(b)(ii): (7)(b)(i) That party liaison shall, before 5 p.m. within 30 days after the day on which the party liaison receives the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(b)(iii): The county legislative body shall, no later than five days after the day on which a party liaison submits the name of the individual to fill the vacancy, appoint the individual to serve out the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(c): (7)(b)(iii); (7)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(c)(i): (7)(b)(iii) If the county legislative body fails to appoint an individual to fill the vacancy in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(c)(i)(A): informs the governor that the county legislative body has failed to appoint an individual to fill the vacancy within the statutory time period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(c)(i)(B): contains the name of the individual submitted by the party liaison to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(c)(ii): (7)(c)(i) The governor shall, within 10 days after the day on which the governor receives the letter described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(7)(d): (7) An individual appointed to fill the vacancy under this Subsection
