Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(8): Except as otherwise provided by law, the county legislative body may appoint replacements to fill all vacancies that occur in those offices filled by appointment of the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(9): Nothing in this section prohibits a candidate that does not wish to affiliate with a political party from filing a certificate of nomination for a vacant office within the same time limits as a candidate that is affiliated with a political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(10): (4); (5); (6); 17-16-6
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(10)(a): (4); (5); (6) Each individual elected under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-508(10)(b): 17-16-6 Nothing in this section may be construed to contradict or alter the provisions of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509 Definitions applicable to Sections 20A-1-509.1, 20A-1-509.2, and 20A-1-509.3.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509(1): "County clerk" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509(1)(a): for a single county, the county clerk of that county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509(1)(b): for a prosecution district, the county clerk of the most populous county within the prosecution district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509(2): "County legislative body" includes each legislative body with the power to participate in the selection of a district attorney as provided in the interlocal prosecution district agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1 Procedure for filling midterm vacancy in county or district with 15 or more attorneys.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(1): When a vacancy occurs in the office of county or district attorney in a county or district having 15 or more attorneys who are licensed active members in good standing with the Utah State Bar and registered voters, the vacancy shall be filled as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2): (2); 20A-9-201.5; (2)(a); Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy; Chapter 9, Candidate Qualifications and Nominating Procedures; 20A-9-201.5; 20A-9-202; 20A-9-201.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(a): (2); 20A-9-201.5 The requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(a)(i): the vacant office has an unexpired term of two years or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(a)(ii): 20A-9-201.5 the vacancy occurs before the first day of the declaration of candidacy filing period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(b): (2)(a) When the conditions established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(c): Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy; Chapter 9, Candidate Qualifications and Nominating Procedures All persons intending to become candidates for the vacant office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(c)(i): Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy file a declaration of candidacy according to the procedures and requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(c)(ii): Chapter 9, Candidate Qualifications and Nominating Procedures if nominated as a party candidate or qualified as an independent or write-in candidate under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(c)(iii): if elected, complete the unexpired term of the person who created the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(d): 20A-9-201.5; 20A-9-202; 20A-9-201.5 If the vacancy occurs during the declaration of candidacy filing period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(d)(i): 20A-9-202; 20A-9-201.5 the time for filing a declaration of candidacy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(2)(d)(ii): the county clerk shall notify the public and each registered political party that the vacancy exists.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3): (3); (3)(a); (3)(b)(i); Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(a): (3) The requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(a)(i): the vacant office has an unexpired term of two years or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(a)(ii): the vacancy occurs after the third Thursday in March of the even-numbered year but more than 75 days before the regular primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(b): (3)(a) When the conditions established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(b)(i): notify the public and each registered political party that the vacancy exists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(b)(ii): identify the date and time by which a person interested in becoming a candidate shall file a declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(c): (3)(b)(i); Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy All persons intending to become candidates for the vacant office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(c)(i): (3)(b)(i); Chapter 9, Part 2, Candidate Qualifications and Declarations of Candidacy before 5 p.m. within five days after the day on which the county clerk gives the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(c)(ii): if elected, complete the unexpired term of the person who created the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(d): The county central committee of each party shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(d)(i): select a candidate or candidates from among those qualified candidates who have filed declarations of candidacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(d)(ii): certify the name of the candidate or candidates to the county clerk:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(d)(ii)(A): before 5 p.m. no later than 60 days before the day of the regular primary election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(3)(d)(ii)(B): electronically, before midnight no later than 60 days before the day of the regular primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4): (4); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4)(a): (4) The requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4)(a)(i): the vacant office has an unexpired term of two years or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4)(a)(ii): 75 days or less remain before the regular primary election but more than 65 days remain before the regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4)(b): (4)(a) When the conditions established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(4)(c): The candidate elected shall complete the unexpired term of the person who created the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5): (5); (5)(a); (5)(b); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(a): (5) The requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(a)(i): the vacant office has an unexpired term of less than two years; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(a)(ii): the vacant office has an unexpired term of two years or more but 65 days or less remain before the next regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(b): (5)(a) When the conditions established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(c): (5)(b) That county central committee shall, within 30 days after the day on which the county legislative body gives the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(d): The county legislative body shall, within 45 days after the vacancy occurs, appoint one of those nominees to serve out the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(e): If the county legislative body fails to appoint a person to fill the vacancy within 45 days, the county clerk shall send to the governor a letter that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(e)(i): informs the governor that the county legislative body has failed to appoint a person to fill the vacancy within the statutory time period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(e)(ii): contains the list of nominees submitted by the party central committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(f): The governor shall appoint a person to fill the vacancy from that list of nominees within 30 days after receipt of the letter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(5)(g): (5) A person appointed to fill the vacancy under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.1(6): Nothing in this section prevents or prohibits independent candidates from filing a declaration of candidacy for the office within the required time limits.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2 Procedure for filling vacancy in county or district with fewer than 15 attorneys.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(1): When a vacancy occurs in the office of county or district attorney, including a vacancy created by the failure of a person to file as a candidate for the office of county or district attorney in an election, in a county or district having fewer than 15 attorneys who are licensed, active members in good standing with the Utah State Bar and registered voters, the vacancy shall be filled as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(2): The county clerk shall send a letter to each attorney residing in the county or district who is a licensed, active member in good standing with the Utah State Bar and a registered voter that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(2)(a): informs the attorney of the vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(2)(b): invites the attorney to apply for the vacancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(2)(c): informs the attorney that if the attorney has not responded before 5 p.m. within 10 calendar days after the day on which the county clerk sends the letter, the attorney's candidacy to fill the vacancy will not be considered.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3): (2)(c); (3)(a)(ii); (3)(a); (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(a): (2)(c); (3)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(a)(i): (2)(c); (3)(a)(ii) If, before the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(a)(ii): In multicounty prosecution districts, the clerk shall submit the applications to the county central committee of each county within the prosecution district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(b): (3)(a) The central committee shall nominate three of the applicants and forward the applicants' names to the county legislative body before 5 p.m. within 20 days after the day on which the county clerk submits the applicants' names under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(c): The county legislative body shall appoint one of the nominees to fill the vacant position.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(d): (3)(b) If the central committee of the political party fails to submit at least three names to the county legislative body before the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(e): If the county legislative body fails to appoint a person to fill the vacancy within 120 days after the day on which the vacancy occurs, the county clerk shall mail to the governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(e)(i): a letter informing the governor that the county legislative body has failed to appoint a person to fill the vacancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(e)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(e)(ii)(A): the list of nominees, if any, submitted by the central committee of the political party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(e)(ii)(B): if the party central committee has not submitted a list of at least three nominees within the required time, the names of the persons who submitted applications for the vacant position to the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(3)(f): The governor shall appoint, within 30 days after the day on which the governor receives the letter, a person from the list to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4): (2)(c); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(a): (2)(c); (4)(b) If, before the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(a)(i): appoint one of them to be county or district attorney; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(a)(ii): (4)(b) solicit additional applicants and appoint a county or district attorney as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(b)(i): If three or fewer attorneys who are licensed members in good standing of the Utah State Bar and registered voters in the county or district submit applications, the county legislative body may publicly solicit and accept additional applications for the position from licensed, active members in good standing of the Utah State Bar who are not residents of the county or prosecution district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(b)(ii): The county legislative body shall consider the applications submitted by the attorneys who are residents of and registered voters in the county or prosecution district and the applications submitted by the attorneys who are not residents of the county or prosecution district and shall appoint one of the applicants to be county attorney or district attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(c): If the legislative body fails to appoint a person to fill the vacancy within 120 days after the day on which the vacancy occurs, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(c)(i): notify the governor that the legislative body has failed to fill the vacancy within the required time period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(c)(ii): provide the governor with a list of all the applicants.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(4)(d): The governor shall appoint a person to fill the vacancy within 30 days after the day on which the governor receives the notification.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.2(5): The person appointed to fill the vacancy shall serve for the unexpired term of the person who created the vacancy.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3 Procedure for making interim replacement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(1): 20A-1-509.1; 20A-1-509.2; (1) Until the vacancy is filled as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(1)(a): The county legislative body shall appoint a deputy county or district attorney to serve as acting county or district attorney if there are at least three deputies in the office that has the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(1)(b): The county legislative body may contract with any member of the Utah State Bar in good standing to be acting county or district attorney if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(1)(b)(i): there are not at least three deputies in the office that has the vacancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(1)(b)(ii): there are three or more deputies in the office but none of the deputies is willing to serve.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-509.3(2): An individual appointed as interim replacement under this section shall hold office until a successor is selected and has qualified.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510 Midterm vacancies in municipal offices.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1): 20A-1-102; 10-3-301
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(a): 20A-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(a)(i): 20A-1-102 "Vacancy," subject to Subsection (1)(a)(ii), means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(a)(ii): "Vacancy," if due to resignation, occurs on the effective date of the resignation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(b): 10-3-301 Except as otherwise provided in this section, if any vacancy occurs in the office of municipal executive or member of a municipal legislative body, the municipal legislative body shall, within 30 calendar days after the day on which the vacancy occurs, appoint a registered voter in the municipality who meets the qualifications for office described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c): Before acting to fill the vacancy, the municipal legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(i): give public notice of the vacancy at least 14 calendar days before the day on which the municipal legislative body meets to fill the vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(ii): identify, in the notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(ii)(A): the date, time, and place of the meeting where the vacancy will be filled;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(ii)(B): the person to whom an individual interested in being appointed to fill the vacancy may submit the interested individual's name for consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(ii)(C): the deadline for submitting an interested individual's name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(c)(iii): in an open meeting, interview each individual whose name is submitted for consideration, and who meets the qualifications for office, regarding the individual's qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(i): The municipal legislative body shall take an initial vote to fill the vacancy from among the names of the candidates interviewed under Subsection (1)(c)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(ii)(A): If no candidate receives a majority vote of the municipal legislative body in the initial vote described in Subsection (1)(d)(i), the two candidates that received the most votes in the initial vote, as determined by the tie-breaking procedures described in Subsections (1)(d)(ii)(B) through (D) if necessary, shall be placed before the municipal legislative body for a second vote to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(ii)(B): If the initial vote results in a tie for second place, the candidates tied for second place shall be reduced to one by a coin toss conducted in accordance with Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(D), and the second vote described in Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(A) shall be between the candidate that received the most votes in the initial vote and the candidate that wins the coin toss described in this Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(B).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(ii)(C): If the initial vote results in a tie among three or more candidates for first place, the candidates tied for first place shall be reduced to two by a coin toss conducted in accordance with Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(D), and the second vote described in Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(A) shall be between the two candidates that remain after the coin toss described in this Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(C).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(ii)(D): A coin toss required under this Subsection (1)(d) shall be conducted by the municipal clerk or recorder in the presence of the municipal legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(d)(iii): If, in the second vote described in Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(A), neither candidate receives a majority vote of the municipal legislative body, the vacancy shall be determined by a coin toss between the two candidates in accordance with Subsection (1)(d)(ii)(D).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(e): If the municipal legislative body does not timely comply with Subsections (1)(b) through (d), the municipal clerk or recorder shall immediately notify the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(f): After receiving notice that a municipal legislative body has failed to timely comply with Subsections (1)(b) through (d), the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(f)(i): notify the municipal legislative body of the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(f)(ii): direct the municipal legislative body to, within 30 calendar days after the day on which the lieutenant governor provides the notice described in this Subsection (1)(f), appoint an eligible individual to fill the vacancy in accordance with Subsections (1)(c) and (d).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(g): If the municipality fails to timely comply with a directive described in Subsection (1)(f):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(g)(i): the lieutenant governor shall notify the governor of the municipality's failure to fill the vacancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(1)(g)(ii): the governor shall, within 45 days after the day on which the governor receives the notice described in Subsection (1)(g)(i), provide public notice soliciting candidates to fill the vacancy in accordance with Subsection (1)(c) and appoint an individual to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(a): A vacancy in the office of municipal executive or member of a municipal legislative body shall be filled by an interim appointment, followed by an election to fill a two-year term, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(a)(i): the vacancy occurs, or a letter of resignation is received, by the municipal executive at least 14 days before the deadline for filing for election in an odd-numbered year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(a)(ii): two years of the vacated term will remain after the first Monday of January following the next municipal election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(b): In appointing an interim replacement, the municipal legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(b)(i): comply with the notice requirements of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(2)(b)(ii): in an open meeting, interview each individual whose name is submitted for consideration, and who meets the qualifications for office, regarding the individual's qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3): 10-3b-102
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(a): 10-3b-102 In a municipality operating under the council-mayor form of government, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(a)(i): the council may appoint an individual to fill a vacancy in the office of mayor before the effective date of the mayor's resignation by making the effective date of the appointment the same as the effective date of the mayor's resignation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(a)(ii): if a vacancy in the office of mayor occurs before the effective date of an appointment under Subsection (1) or (2) to fill the vacancy, the remaining council members, by majority vote, shall appoint a council member to serve as acting mayor during the time between the creation of the vacancy and the effective date of the appointment to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(b): A council member serving as acting mayor under Subsection (3)(a)(ii) continues to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(b)(i): act as a council member; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(3)(b)(ii): vote at council meetings.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(a)(i): For a vacancy of a member of a municipal legislative body as described in this section, the municipal legislative body member whose resignation creates the vacancy on the municipal legislative body may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(a)(i)(A): interview an individual whose name is submitted for consideration under Subsection (1)(c)(iii) or (2)(b)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(a)(i)(B): vote on the appointment of an individual to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(a)(ii): Notwithstanding Subsection (4)(a)(i), a member of a legislative body who is removed from office in accordance with state law may not cast a vote under Subsection (4)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(b): A member of a municipal legislative body who submits his or her resignation to the municipal legislative body may not rescind the resignation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(4)(c): A member of a municipal legislative body may not vote on an appointment under this section for himself or herself to fill a vacancy in the municipal legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(5): In a municipality operating under the council-mayor form of government, the mayor may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(5)(a): participate in the vote to fill a vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(5)(b): veto a decision of the council to fill a vacancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(5)(c): vote in the case of a tie.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(6): A mayor whose resignation from the municipal legislative body is due to election or appointment as mayor may, in the case of a tie, participate in the vote under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510(7): A municipal legislative body may, consistent with the provisions of state law, adopt procedures governing the appointment, interview, and voting process for filling vacancies in municipal offices.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1 Candidate vacancies in local office.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1): A vacancy that occurs in a candidacy for an elected office in a local political subdivision may be filled in accordance with the requirements of this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1)(a): a nonpartisan primary election is held for the office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1)(b): the vacancy occurs after the date of the primary election but before:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1)(b)(i): for a county office, August 31; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1)(b)(ii): for all other offices, 65 days before the day of the applicable general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(1)(c): after the vacancy occurs, the number of remaining candidates for the office is less than or equal to the number of open positions to be filled for that office in the applicable general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(2): (1); (2)(a) An election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(2)(a): (1) fill a candidate vacancy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-510.1(2)(b): (2)(a) immediately notify the candidate described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511 Midterm vacancy on a local school board.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1): (1)(b); (2); (1)(b)(ii); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1)(a): (1)(b); (2) A local school board shall fill a vacancy on the local school board by appointment, except as otherwise provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1)(b): (1)(b)(ii) The county legislative body, or municipal legislative body in a city district, shall fill a vacancy on a local school board by appointment if the local school board fails to make an appointment to fill the vacancy:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1)(b)(i): (1)(b)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1)(b)(ii): within 45 days after a vacancy occurs on the local school board due to the death of a local school board member.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(1)(c): (1) A member appointed and qualified under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(2)(a): A vacancy on the board shall be filled by an interim appointment, followed by an election to fill a two-year term if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(2)(a)(i): the vacancy on the board occurs, or a letter of resignation is received by the board, at least 14 days before the deadline for filing a declaration of candidacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(2)(a)(ii): two years of the vacated term will remain after the first Monday of January following the next school board election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(2)(b): (2) A member elected under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3): Before appointing an individual to fill a vacancy under this section, the local school board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3)(a): give public notice of the vacancy at least two weeks before the local school board meets to fill the vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3)(b): identify, in the public notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3)(b)(i): the date, time, and place of the meeting where the vacancy will be filled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3)(b)(ii): the person to whom and the date and time before which an individual interested in being appointed to fill the vacancy may submit the individual's name for consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(3)(c): in an open meeting, interview each individual whose name is submitted for consideration and who meets the qualifications for office, regarding the individual's qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(4): (4)(b); (1); (2); (4)(a); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(4)(a): (4)(b); (1); (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(4)(b): (4)(a) An individual appointed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-511(4)(c): (4)(a) A member of a local school board who submits a letter of resignation under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512 Midterm vacancies on local district boards -- Notice.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1): 17B-1-102; 63G-30-102; 17B-2a-1005; 17B-2a-1005
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(a): 17B-1-102 When a vacancy occurs on any special district board for any reason, the following shall appoint a replacement to serve out the unexpired term in accordance with this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(a)(i): the special district board, if the person vacating the position was elected; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(a)(ii): 17B-1-102 the appointing authority, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b): 63G-30-102 Except as provided in Subsection (1)(c) or (d), before acting to fill the vacancy, the special district board or appointing authority shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b)(i): 63G-30-102 give public notice of the vacancy for at least two weeks before the special district board or appointing authority meets to fill the vacancy by publishing the notice, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b)(ii): identify, in the notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b)(ii)(A): the date, time, and place of the meeting where the vacancy will be filled;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b)(ii)(B): the individual to whom an individual who is interested in an appointment to fill the vacancy may submit the individual's name for consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(b)(ii)(C): any submission deadline.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(c): An appointing authority is not subject to Subsection (1)(b) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(c)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(c)(i)(A): the appointing authority appoints one of the appointing authority's own members; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(c)(i)(B): that member meets all applicable statutory board member qualifications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(c)(ii): the vacancy is on the board of trustees of an infrastructure financing district with no residents within the district's boundary.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(d): 17B-2a-1005; 17B-2a-1005 When a vacancy occurs on the board of a water conservancy district located in more than one county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(d)(i): 17B-2a-1005 the board shall give notice of the vacancy to the county legislative bodies that nominated the vacating trustee as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(d)(ii): the county legislative bodies described in Subsection (1)(d)(i) shall collectively compile a list of three nominees to fill the vacancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(1)(d)(iii): 17B-2a-1005 the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoint an individual to fill the vacancy from nominees submitted as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(2): If, 90 days after a vacancy occurs, the special district board has failed to appoint an individual to complete an elected board member's term, the vacancy shall be filled:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(2)(a): in accordance with the procedure for a special district described in Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(2)(b): by, as applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(2)(b)(i): the legislative body of the county or municipality that created the special district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-512(2)(b)(ii): for a vacancy on a board of trustees of an infrastructure financing district, the legislative body of the county whose unincorporated area contains or the municipality whose boundary contains more of the area within the infrastructure financing district than is contained within the unincorporated area of any other county or within the boundary of any other municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513 Temporary absence in elected office of a political subdivision for military service.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(a)(i): "Armed forces" means the United States Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, Space Force, and Coast Guard.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(a)(ii): "Armed forces" includes the National Guard.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(b)(i): "Elected official" means an individual who holds an office of a political subdivision that is required by law to be filled by an election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(b)(ii): "Elected official" includes an individual who is appointed to fill a vacancy in an office described in Subsection (1)(b)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(c): "Elected official reservist" means an elected official who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(c)(i): a member of the armed forces reserves component;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(c)(ii): a member of the National Guard; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(c)(iii): a retired member of the armed forces who may be called to active, full-time duty in the armed forces under Title 10, U.S.C., Armed Forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(i): "Military leave" means the temporary absence from an office:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(i)(A): by an elected official reservist called to active, full-time duty in the armed forces; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(i)(B): for a period of time that exceeds 30 days and does not exceed 400 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(ii): "Military leave" includes the time an individual on leave, as described in Subsection (1)(d)(i), spends for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(ii)(A): out processing;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(ii)(B): an administrative delay;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(ii)(C): accrued leave; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(d)(ii)(D): on rest and recuperation leave program of the armed forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 "Political subdivision's governing body" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(i): for a county, city, or town, the legislative body of the county, city, or town;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(ii): for a special district, the board of trustees of the special district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(iii): for a local school district, the local school board;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(iv): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 for a special service district:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(iv)(A): 17D-1-301 the legislative body of the county, city, or town that established the special service district, if no administrative control board has been appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(iv)(B): 17D-1-301 the administrative control board of the special service district, if an administrative control board has been appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(e)(v): for a political subdivision not listed in Subsections (1)(e)(i) through (iv), the body that governs the affairs of the political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(1)(f): "Temporary replacement" means the individual appointed by the political subdivision's governing body in accordance with this section to exercise the powers and duties of the office of an elected official reservist who takes military leave.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(2): An elected official reservist who takes military leave in accordance with this section does not create a vacancy in the elected official's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(a): An elected official reservist who is called to active, full-time duty in the armed forces under Title 10, U.S.C., Armed Forces, shall notify the political subdivision's governing body of the elected official's orders no later than five days after the day on which the elected official receives the orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b): An elected official reservist described in Subsection (3)(a) may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(i): if the period of active, full-time duty does not exceed 270 days:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(i)(A): continue to carry out the elected official's duties if possible while on active, full-time duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(i)(B): take military leave if the elected official submits to the political subdivision's governing body written notice of the intent to take military leave and the expected duration of the military leave; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(ii): if the period of active, full-time duty exceeds 270 days but does not exceed 400 days, take military leave if the elected official submits to the political subdivision's governing body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(ii)(A): written notice of the intent to take military leave and the expected duration of the military leave; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(3)(b)(ii)(B): written certification that the secretary of the armed force of which the elected official is a member granted the elected official permission under U.S. Department of Defense Directive 1344.10 to continue to hold the elected official's office while on active, full-time duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(4)(a): An elected official reservist who chooses to continue to carry out the elected official's duties under Subsection (3)(b)(i)(A) shall, no later than 10 days after the day of the elected official's deployment, confirm in writing to the political subdivision's governing body that the elected official has the ability to carry out the elected official's duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(4)(b): If an elected official reservist does not submit the confirmation to the political subdivision's governing body before the deadline described in Subsection (4)(a), the political subdivision's governing body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(4)(b)(i): place the elected official in military leave status; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(4)(b)(ii): appoint a temporary replacement in accordance with Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(5)(a): An elected official reservist who chooses to take military leave under Subsection (3)(b)(ii) shall, no later than 21 days after the date of the elected official's deployment, submit to the political subdivision's governing body the written notice and certification described in Subsection (3)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(5)(b): If an elected official reservist does not submit the notice and certification to the political subdivision's governing body before the deadline described in Subsection (5)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(5)(b)(i): the political subdivision's governing body may not appoint a temporary replacement under Subsection (8); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(5)(b)(ii): the elected official reservist creates a vacancy in the elected official's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(6): An elected official reservist who is called to active, full-time duty in the armed forces under Title 10, U.S.C., Armed Forces, for a period of more than 400 days creates a vacancy in the elected official's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7): An elected official reservist's military leave:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a): begins:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a)(i): for an elected official reservist described in Subsection (3)(b)(i), the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a)(i)(A): the day after the day on which the elected official notifies the political subdivision's governing body of the intent to take military leave;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a)(i)(B): 11 days after the day of the elected official's deployment if no confirmation is received by the political subdivision's governing body in accordance with Subsection (4)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a)(i)(C): the day on which the elected official begins active, full-time duty in the armed forces; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(a)(ii): for an elected official reservist described in Subsection (3)(b)(ii), the day after the day on which the elected official submits to the political subdivision's governing body the written notice and certification described in Subsection (3)(b)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(b): ends the sooner of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(b)(i): the expiration of the elected official reservist's term of office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(7)(b)(ii): the day on which the elected official reservist ends active, full-time duty in the armed forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8): 20A-1-508 A temporary replacement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(a): meet the qualifications required to hold the office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b): 20A-1-508 be appointed:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(i): when an elected official reservist:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(i)(A): takes military leave under Subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) or (b)(ii); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(i)(B): is placed in military leave status under Subsection (4)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(ii): 20A-1-508 by the political subdivision's governing body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(ii)(A): 20A-1-508 if a registered political party nominated the elected official reservist as a candidate for the office, in the same manner as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(8)(b)(ii)(B): if a registered political party did not nominate the elected official reservist as a candidate for the office, after submitting an application in accordance with Subsection (10)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(9)(a): A temporary replacement shall exercise the powers and duties of the office for which the temporary replacement is appointed for the duration of the elected official reservist's military leave.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(9)(b): An elected reservist may not exercise the powers or duties of the office while on military leave.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(9)(c): If a temporary replacement is not appointed as required by Subsection (8)(b), no individual may exercise the powers and duties of the elected official reservist's office during the elected official's military leave.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(10): The political subdivision's governing body shall establish:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(10)(a): the distribution of the emoluments of the office between the elected official reservist and the temporary replacement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(10)(b): an application form and the date and time before which an individual shall submit the application to be considered by the political subdivision's governing body for appointment as a temporary replacement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-513(11): This section does not apply to an elected official who is not an elected official reservist.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601 Bribery in elections -- Paying for votes -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1): A person may not, directly, indirectly, or through any other person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a): pay, loan, or contribute, or offer or promise to pay, loan, or contribute any money or other valuable consideration to or for any voter or to or for any other person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a)(i): to induce the voter to vote or refrain from voting at any election provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a)(ii): to induce any voter to vote or refrain from voting at an election for any particular person or measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a)(iii): to induce a voter to go to the polls or remain away from the polls at any election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a)(iv): because a voter voted or refrained from voting for any particular person, or went to the polls or remained away from the polls; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(a)(v): to obtain the political support or aid of any person at an election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(b): give, offer, or promise any office, place, or employment, or to promise or procure, or endeavor to procure, any office, place, or employment, to or for any voter, or to or for any other person, in order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(b)(i): induce a voter to vote or refrain from voting at any election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(b)(ii): induce any voter to vote or refrain from voting at an election for any particular person or measure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(b)(iii): obtain the political support or aid of any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(c): advance or pay, or cause to be paid, any money or other valuable thing to, or for the use of, any other person with the intent that the money or other valuable thing be used in bribery at any election provided by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(1)(d): knowingly pay, or cause to be paid, any money or other valuable thing to any person in discharge or repayment of any money expended wholly or in part in bribery at any election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-601(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602 Receiving bribe -- Receiving payments for votes -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1): A person may not, for the person or for any other person, directly or indirectly, or through any person, before, during, or after any election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(a): receive, agree to receive, or contract for any money, gift, loan, or other valuable consideration, office, place, or employment for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(a)(i): voting or agreeing to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(a)(ii): going or agreeing to go to the polls;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(a)(iii): remaining or agreeing to remain away from the polls; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(a)(iv): refraining or agreeing to refrain from voting, or for voting or agreeing to vote, or refraining or agreeing to refrain from voting, for any particular person or measure at any election provided by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(b): receive any money or other valuable thing because the person induced any other person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(b)(i): vote or refrain from voting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(1)(b)(ii): vote or refrain from voting for any particular person or measure at any election provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-602(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603 Fraud, interference, disturbance -- Tampering with ballots or records -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1): 20A-4-107
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a): 20A-4-107 An individual may not fraudulently vote on the individual's behalf or on behalf of another, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(i): voting more than once at any one election, regardless of whether one of the elections is in a state or territory of the United States outside of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(ii): knowingly handing in two or more ballots folded together;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(iii): changing any ballot after the ballot is cast or deposited in the ballot box, or ballot drop box, or mailed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(iv): adding or attempting to add any ballot or vote to those legally polled at any election by fraudulently introducing the ballot or vote into the ballot box or vote tally, either before or after the ballots have been counted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(v): adding to or mixing or attempting to add or mix, other ballots with the ballots lawfully polled while those ballots are being counted or canvassed, or at any other time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(a)(vi): 20A-4-107 voting in a voting district or precinct when the individual knew or should have known that the individual was not eligible for voter registration in that district or precinct, unless the individual is legally entitled to vote the ballot under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b): A person may not fraudulently interfere with an election by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(i): willfully tampering with, detaining, mutilating, or destroying any election returns;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(ii): in any manner, interfering with the officers holding an election or conducting a canvass, or with the voters lawfully exercising their rights of voting at an election, so as to prevent the election or canvass from being fairly held or lawfully conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(iii): engaging in riotous conduct at any election, or interfering in any manner with any election official in the discharge of the election official's duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(iv): inducing any election officer, or officer whose duty it is to ascertain, announce, or declare the result of any election or to give or make any certificate, document, or evidence in relation to any election, to violate or refuse to comply with the election officer's duty or any law regulating the election officer's duty;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(v): taking, carrying away, concealing, removing, or destroying any ballot, pollbook, or other thing from a polling place, or from the possession of the person authorized by law to have the custody of that thing;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(vi): taking, carrying away, concealing, removing, or destroying a ballot drop box or the contents of a ballot drop box; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(1)(b)(vii): aiding, counseling, providing, procuring, advising, or assisting any person to do any of the acts described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1)(b)(vi); (1)(b)(vi); (1); (2)(a) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(2)(a): (1)(b)(vi); (1)(b)(vi) a person who commits an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(2)(b): (1); (2)(a) a person who commits an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(3): 20A-2-102.5(2)(a) The lieutenant governor shall take, and store for at least 22 months, a static copy of the official register made at the following times:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(3)(a): 20A-2-102.5(2)(a) the voter registration deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(3)(b): the day of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-603(3)(c): the last day of the canvass.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604 Destroying or altering voter instructions, sample ballots, or election paraphernalia -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(1): A person may not, without lawful authority granted by an election officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(1)(a): willfully alter, deface, or destroy any list of candidates posted in accordance with the provisions of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(1)(b): willfully alter, deface, tear down, remove or destroy any voter instructions or sample ballot, printed or posted for the instruction of voters during an election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(1)(c): willfully alter, remove, or destroy any of the supplies or conveniences furnished to enable a voter to prepare the voter's ballot during an election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(1)(d): willfully hinder the voting of others.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-604(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605 Mutilating certificate of nomination -- Forging declination or resignation -- Tampering with ballots.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(a): falsely mark or willfully deface or destroy:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(a)(i): any certificate of nomination or any part of a certificate of nomination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(a)(ii): any letter of declination or resignation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(b): file any certificate of nomination or letter of declination or resignation knowing it, or any part of it, to be falsely made;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(c): suppress any certificate of nomination, or letter of declination or resignation, or any part of a certificate of nomination or letter of declination or resignation that has been legally filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(d): forge any letter of declination or resignation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(e): falsely make the official endorsement on any ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(f): willfully destroy or deface any ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(g): willfully delay the delivery of any ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(h): examine any ballot offered or cast at the polls or found in any ballot box or ballot drop box for any purpose other than to determine which candidate was elected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(1)(i): make or place any mark or device on any ballot in order to determine the name of any person for whom the elector has voted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-605(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606 Wagering on elections forbidden.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1)(a): A candidate may not, before or during any primary or election campaign:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1)(a)(i): make any bet or wager anything of pecuniary value on the result of the primary or election, or on any event or contingency relating to any pending primary or election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1)(a)(ii): become a party to any bet or wager on the result of a primary or election or on any event or contingency relating to any pending primary or election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1)(a)(iii): provide money or any other valuable thing to be used by any other person in betting or wagering upon the results of any impending primary or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(1)(b): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (1) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(2): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(2)(a): A person who is not a candidate may not make any bet or wager anything of pecuniary value on the result of any primary or election, or on any event or contingency relating to any primary or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(2)(b): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (2)(a) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(3): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(3)(a): A person may not directly or indirectly make a bet or wager with any voter that is dependent upon the outcome of any primary or election with the intent to subject that voter to the possibility of challenge at a primary or election or to prevent the voter from voting at a primary or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-606(3)(b): 20A-1-609(2); (3); (3)(a) In addition to the penalties established in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607 Inducing attendance at polls -- Payment of workers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(1): (1)(a); 20A-3a-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(1)(a): It is unlawful for a person to pay another for a loss incurred because an individual voted or registered to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(1)(b): (1)(a); 20A-3a-105 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(2)(a): A person may not pay for personal services performed or to be performed on the day of a caucus, primary, convention, or election, or for any purpose connected with a caucus, primary, convention, or election that directly or indirectly affect the result of the caucus, primary, convention, or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-607(2)(b): (2)(a) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-608 Promises of appointment to office forbidden.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-608(1): An individual may not, in order to aid or promote the individual's nomination or election, directly or indirectly appoint or promise to appoint an individual or secure or promise to secure, or aid in securing the appointment, nomination, or election of an individual to any public or private position or employment, or to any position of honor, trust, or emolument.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-608(2): Nothing contained in this section prevents:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-608(2)(a): a candidate from stating publicly the candidate's preference for, or support of, any other candidate for any office to be voted for at the same primary or election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-608(2)(b): a candidate for any office in which the individual elected will be charged with the duty of participating in the election or nomination of an individual as a candidate for any office from publicly stating or pledging the candidate's preference for, or support of, an individual for that office or nomination.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609 Omnibus penalties.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(1): (1)(b); (1)(a); 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xx)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(1)(a): (1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(1)(b): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(1)(c): 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xx); 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xx) An individual is not guilty of a crime for, by signing a petition for an initiative or referendum, falsely making the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(2): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 Except as provided by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(2)(a): file a declaration of candidacy for any office or appear on the ballot as a candidate for any office during the election cycle in which the violation occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(2)(b): take or hold the office to which the individual was elected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(2)(c): receive the emoluments of the office to which the individual was elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(3): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5; (3)(a); 20A-3a-803
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(3)(a): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 Any individual convicted of any offense under this title forfeits the right to vote at any election unless the right to vote is restored as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-609(3)(b): (3)(a); 20A-3a-803 Any person may challenge the right to vote of a person described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-610 Abetting violation of chapter -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the penalties established in Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-611 Cost of defense of action.
----------------------------------------------------------
Nothing contained in this chapter prevents any candidate from employing counsel to represent the candidate in any action or proceeding affecting the candidate's rights as a candidate or from paying all costs and disbursements arising from that representation.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-701 Prosecutions -- Venue.
------------------------------------------------------
Violations of the provisions of this title concerning expenditure of money or making contributions or providing services may be prosecuted in the county where the expenditure or contribution was made, or where the services were provided, or in any county where the money was paid or distributed.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705 Supplemental judgment after criminal conviction.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(1)(a): If any person, in a criminal action, is found guilty of any violation of this chapter while a candidate for the offices of governor, lieutenant governor, state auditor, state treasurer, or attorney general, the court, after entering the finding of guilt, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(1)(a)(i): enter a supplemental judgment declaring that person to have forfeited the office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(1)(a)(ii): transmit a transcript of the supplemental judgment to the state auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(1)(b): Upon issuance of the order, the office is vacant and shall be filled as provided by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(2)(a): If any person, in a similar action, is found guilty of any violation of this chapter committed while a member of the personal campaign committee of any candidate for the offices of governor, lieutenant governor, state auditor, state treasurer, or attorney general, the court before which the action is tried shall, immediately after entering the finding of guilt:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(2)(a)(i): enter a supplemental judgment declaring the candidate to have forfeited the office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(2)(a)(ii): transmit a transcript of the supplemental judgment to the state auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(2)(b): Upon issuance of the order, the office is vacant and shall be filled as provided by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-705(3): If any person, in a criminal action, is found guilty of any violation of this chapter, committed while a candidate for the office of state senator or state representative, the court, after entering the finding of guilt, shall transmit a certificate setting forth the finding of guilt to the presiding officer of the legislative body for which the person is a candidate.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-801 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Civil Action for Election Code Violation."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(1): 20A-1-803(1) "Bad faith" means that a person files a petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(1)(a): under circumstances where a reasonable person would not believe that the allegations are true; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(1)(b)(i): within 60 days before an election that the candidate to which the petition relates will appear on the ballot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(1)(b)(ii): under circumstances where a reasonable person would not believe that the allegations constitute a significant violation of a provision of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(2): 20A-1-803(1) "Defendant" means each person against whom an allegation is made in the verified petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(3): 20A-1-803; 20A-1-803 "Receiving official" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(3)(a): 20A-1-803 the lieutenant governor, unless the verified petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(3)(b): 20A-1-803 the attorney general, if the verified petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(4): (4)(b); 20A-1-803(3)(a); 20A-1-803(3)(a) "Reviewing official" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(4)(a): (4)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(4)(b): 20A-1-803(3)(a); 20A-1-803(3)(a) the reviewing official appointed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(5): "Significant violation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(5)(a): a violation that, if known by voters before the election, may have resulted in a candidate, other than the candidate certified as having won the election, winning the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-802(5)(b): a violation that, had the violation not occurred, may have resulted in a candidate, other than the candidate certified as having won the election, winning the election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803 Verified petition by registered voter -- Receiving and reviewing official -- Special investigation -- Special counsel -- Civil action.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(1): A registered voter may file a verified petition alleging a violation of any provision of this title, if the registered voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(1)(a): has information relating to the alleged violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(1)(b): the allegation is against a candidate for whom the registered voter had the right to vote, a personal campaign committee of that candidate, or a member of a personal campaign committee of that candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(2): (1) The registered voter described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3): If the receiving official determines, in writing, that the receiving official has a conflict of interest in relation to taking an action required in this part, the receiving official shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(a): designate as the reviewing official an individual who does not have a conflict of interest, in the following order of precedence:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(a)(i): the attorney general;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(a)(ii): the state auditor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(a)(iii): the state treasurer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(a)(iv): the governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(3)(b): forward the petition to the reviewing official for further action.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(a): The reviewing official shall gather information and determine whether, in the discretion of the reviewing official, a special investigation is necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b): (4)(a) In making the determination described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(i): whether, based on the information available to the reviewing official, the reviewing official is able to determine that a violation did not occur;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(ii): the seriousness of the alleged violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(iii): whether the alleged violation was intentional or accidental;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(iv): whether the alleged violation could be resolved informally;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(v): whether the petition is frivolous or filed for the purpose of harassment;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(vi): whether the alleged violation should be addressed in, or is being adequately addressed in, another forum, including a criminal investigation or proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(vii): whether additional investigation, as part of a civil proceeding in relation to the petition, is desirable;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(viii): the likelihood that an action, based on the allegations, is likely to be successful; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(4)(b)(ix): other criteria relevant to making the determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(5): (5)(b); Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code If the reviewing official determines that a special investigation is necessary, the reviewing official shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(5)(a): (5)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(5)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code if the verified petition alleges that the attorney general violated a provision of this title, or if the reviewing official determines that the Office of the Attorney General has a conflict of interest in relation to the verified petition, appoint a person who is not an employee of the Office of the Attorney General as special counsel, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6): (6)(c) The special counsel:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(a): shall review the petition and any evidence relative to determining whether a defendant committed a violation of a provision of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(b): may interview individuals or gather additional evidence relative to determining whether a defendant committed a violation of a provision of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(c): shall advise the reviewing official whether, in the opinion of the special counsel, sufficient evidence exists to establish that a defendant committed a significant violation of a provision of this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d): (6)(c) shall, within three days after the day on which the special counsel complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d)(i): states whether, in the opinion of the special counsel, sufficient evidence exists to establish that a defendant committed at least one significant violation of a provision of this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d)(ii): if the special counsel is of the opinion that sufficient evidence exists to establish that a defendant committed at least one significant violation of a provision of this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d)(ii)(A): states the name of each defendant for which, in the opinion of the special counsel, sufficient evidence exists to establish that the defendant committed at least one significant violation of a provision of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d)(ii)(B): states each provision of this title for which, in the opinion of the special counsel, sufficient evidence exists to establish that the defendant violated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(6)(d)(ii)(C): may not include a description of the evidence supporting the opinion of the special counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7): (6)(d); (6)(c) The reviewing official shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(a): (6)(d) within three days after the day on which the reviewing official receives the document described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(b): (6)(c) within seven days after the day on which the special counsel complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(b)(i): determine whether, in the opinion of the reviewing official, sufficient evidence exists to establish that a defendant committed a significant violation of a provision of this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(b)(ii): if the reviewing official is of the opinion that sufficient evidence exists to establish that a defendant committed at least one significant violation of a provision of this title, direct the special counsel to file a civil action and serve summons in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(b)(ii)(A): against each defendant for whom the reviewing official determines that sufficient evidence exists that the defendant committed a significant violation of this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(7)(b)(ii)(B): that includes each significant violation for which the reviewing official determines that sufficient evidence exists.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(8): (7)(b)(ii); (7)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(8)(a): (7)(b)(ii) The purpose of the civil action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(8)(b): (7)(b)(ii) For a civil action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(8)(c): The special counsel may amend the complaint at any time after the complaint is filed, including by adding allegations to the complaint or amending allegations already made in the complaint, if the court determines that the amendment will not violate the due process rights of the defendant against whom the added or amended allegation is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(9)(a): An action brought under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(9)(a)(i): be heard without a jury, with the court determining all issues of fact and issues of law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(9)(a)(ii): have precedence over any other civil actions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-803(9)(b): The court shall schedule discovery and hearings, and shall otherwise conduct proceedings relating to an action brought under this section, in an expedited manner while preserving the rights of the parties and the integrity of the proceedings.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804 Judgment and findings -- Appeal -- Criminal prosecution not affected by judgment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1): (2); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1)(a): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1)(a)(i): declaring void the election of the candidate to that office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1)(a)(ii): ousting and excluding the candidate from office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1)(a)(iii): declaring the office vacant.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(1)(b): (1)(a) A vacancy created by an order described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(2)(a): As it relates to a candidate for either house of the Legislature, if the court finds that the candidate, the candidate's personal campaign committee, or a member of the candidate's personal campaign committee has committed a significant violation of any provision of this title, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(2)(a)(i): prepare and sign written findings of fact and conclusions of law relating to the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(2)(a)(ii): without issuing an order, transmit those findings and conclusions to the reviewing official.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(2)(b): The reviewing official shall transmit the judge's findings and conclusions to the house of the Legislature for which the person is a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3)(a): A party may appeal the determination of the court in the same manner as appeals may be taken in civil actions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3)(b): A judge may not issue an injunction suspending or staying the proceeding unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3)(b)(i): application is made to the court or to the presiding judge of the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3)(b)(ii): all parties receive notice of the application and the time for the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(3)(b)(iii): the judge conducts a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-804(4): Any judgment or findings and conclusions issued as provided in this section may not be construed to bar or affect in any way any criminal prosecution of any candidate or other person.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-805 Costs and attorney fees -- Other actions or remedies not foreclosed -- Grant of immunity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-805(1): If judgment is in favor of the plaintiff in a civil action brought under this part, the special counsel may petition the judge to recover the reviewing official's taxable costs and attorney fees against the person whose right to the office is contested.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-805(2): The judge may not award costs or attorney fees to the defendant, unless it appears that the petitioner filed the petition in bad faith.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-805(3): Nothing in this section may be construed to prohibit any other civil or criminal actions or remedies against alleged violators.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-805(4): 77-22b-1(1)(a)(i); (iii); Title 77, Chapter 22b, Grants of Immunity In the event a witness asserts a privilege against self-incrimination, the special counsel may request a person described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-806 Special counsel on appeal.
----------------------------------------------------------
If either party appeals the judgment of the trial court, the reviewing official shall appoint a person to appear as special counsel in the appellate court in the matter.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807 Compensation of special counsel.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(1): The special counsel authorized by this chapter shall receive reasonable compensation for the special counsel's services.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(2): The compensation shall be audited by the reviewing official and paid out of the state treasury upon the written statement of the reviewing official that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(2)(a): the appointment has been made;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(2)(b): the person appointed has faithfully performed the duties of special counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(2)(c): the special counsel's bill is accurate and correct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-807(3): Compensation for special counsel shall be audited and paid in the same manner as other claims against the state are audited and paid.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-808 Transition clause.
--------------------------------------------------
Any petition that is filed or pending under this part on or after March 1, 2013, shall be subject to the provisions of this part, including any amendments to this part made by Senate Bill 289, passed in the 2013 General Session.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(1): "Applicable office" means the office held by the subject officer.
