Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(2): "Mental capacity evaluation" means an evaluation by a qualified medical professional to determine whether the subject officer has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(3): "Officer" means a county officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(4): "Results of the mental capacity evaluation" means a statement by the qualified medical professional who conducts the mental capacity evaluation that the subject officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(4)(a): has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, without reasonable accommodations;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(4)(b): has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with specified reasonable accommodations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(4)(c): lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(5): "Subject officer" means the officer who is subject to proceedings under this part to determine whether the officer has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the officer's office, with or without reasonable accommodations.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-901(6): "Unanimous" means a vote of all members of a county legislative body where all members of the county legislative body, not including the subject officer, vote on the same side of the motion.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902 Removal of officer from office -- Initial determination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1): (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(a): A county legislative body may remove an officer from office in accordance with this part if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(a)(i): the county legislative body adopts the provisions of this part by ordinance, without additions, deletions, or modifications;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(a)(ii): the officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(a)(iii): the county legislative body consists of at least five members.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(b): (1)(a)(i) This section does not apply to a county, unless the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(b)(i): (1)(a)(i) has adopted the ordinance described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(1)(b)(ii): has at least five members on the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(2): (1); 52-4-205(1)(a) Before removing the subject officer from office under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(3): (2) At the meeting described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(3)(a): the county legislative body shall give the subject officer the opportunity to discuss the subject officer's mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office and any reasonable accommodations that would enable the subject officer to continue to function in the applicable office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(3)(b): the subject officer may bring one individual to the meeting to assist the subject officer in the discussion.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4): (3); (3)(b); (3)(b); (4)(a); Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4)(a): (3); (3)(b) After the discussion described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4)(b): (3)(b); (4)(a) If the subject officer is a member of the county legislative body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4)(b)(i): (3)(b); (4)(a) the county legislative body may exclude the subject officer and the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4)(b)(ii): the subject officer is recused from voting on any decision, described in this part, of the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(4)(c): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act Notwithstanding the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5): If the county legislative body reaches a unanimous preliminary conclusion that the subject officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations, the county legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(a): confidentially inform the subject officer of the vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b): allow the subject officer five calendar days, after the day on which the county legislative body makes the conclusion, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b)(i): resign from the applicable office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b)(ii)(A): voluntarily agree to undergo a mental capacity evaluation at the expense of the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b)(ii)(B): sign a waiver to disclose only the results of the mental capacity evaluation to the county legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(5)(b)(iii): refuse to take any action.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(6): If the county legislative body does not reach a unanimous preliminary conclusion that the subject officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(6)(a): the county legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(6)(a)(i): publicly announce that the vote failed, without disclosing the number of votes for or against and without disclosing the vote of individual members of the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(6)(a)(ii): provide any necessary reasonable accommodations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-902(6)(b): the subject officer may continue to function in the applicable office.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903 Voluntary evaluation.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(1): 20A-1-902(1)(a)(i) This section does not apply to a county, unless the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(1)(a): 20A-1-902(1)(a)(i) has adopted the ordinance described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(1)(b): has at least five members on the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(2): 20A-1-902(5)(b); 20A-1-902(5)(b)(ii) At the end of the five-day period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(2)(a): the county legislative body and the subject officer shall mutually agree on a qualified medical professional to conduct the mental capacity evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(2)(b): the subject officer shall undergo the mental capacity evaluation within 15 calendar days after the day on which the subject officer agrees to undergo the mental capacity evaluation, or longer if the county legislative body and the subject officer agree to an extended period.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(3): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act; (2) Notwithstanding the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(4): If the qualified medical professional concludes that the subject officer has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(4)(a): the county legislative body shall provide any necessary reasonable accommodations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(4)(b): the subject officer may continue to function in the applicable office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(5)(a): If the qualified medical professional concludes that the subject officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations, the subject officer may resign from office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-903(5)(b): (5)(a) If the subject officer does not resign from office within five calendar days after the day on which the qualified medical professional makes the conclusion described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904 Court order for involuntary evaluation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(1): 20A-1-902(1)(a)(i) This section does not apply to a county, unless the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(1)(a): 20A-1-902(1)(a)(i) has adopted the ordinance described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(1)(b): has at least five members on the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2): 20A-1-902; 20A-1-902(2); (5); 20A-1-902(5)(b); 20A-1-903(2)(b) The county legislative body may file an action against the subject officer in district court for an order to undergo a mental capacity evaluation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(a): 20A-1-902; 20A-1-902(2); (5) the county legislative body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(a)(i): 20A-1-902 unanimously concludes that the subject officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(a)(ii): 20A-1-902(2); (5) complies with the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b): 20A-1-902(5)(b); 20A-1-903(2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b)(i): 20A-1-902(5)(b) the subject officer does not, within the five-day period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b)(i)(A): resign from the applicable office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b)(i)(B): agree to undergo a voluntary mental capacity evaluation and sign a waiver to disclose only the results of the mental capacity evaluation to the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b)(ii): 20A-1-903(2)(b) the subject officer does not complete the mental capacity evaluation within the 15-day period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(2)(b)(iii): the subject officer and the county legislative body cannot mutually agree on a qualified medical professional to conduct the mental capacity evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(3): The district court shall order the subject officer to undergo a mental capacity evaluation by a qualified medical professional appointed by the court, and shall provide only the results of the mental capacity evaluation to the county legislative body, if the court finds that there is reasonable cause to believe that the subject officer may lack the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(4): If the qualified medical professional concludes that the subject officer has the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(4)(a): the county legislative body shall provide any necessary reasonable accommodations;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(4)(b): the subject officer may continue to function in the applicable office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(4)(c): the court shall order the county legislative body to pay the court costs and reasonable attorney fees of the subject officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(5)(a): If the qualified medical professional concludes that the subject officer lacks the mental capacity to fulfill the essential functions of the applicable office, with or without reasonable accommodations, the subject officer may resign from office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(5)(b): (5)(a) If the subject officer does not resign from office within five calendar days after the day on which the qualified medical professional makes the conclusion described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(6): The court shall dismiss an action filed under this section, and rescind any order to undergo a mental capacity evaluation, if the subject officer resigns from the applicable office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-904(7): The court may order sanctions against the county legislative body if the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the county legislative body filed or pursued an action described in this section in bad faith.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(1): Title 17B, Chapter 1, Provisions Applicable to All Special Districts
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(1)(a): "Clerk" means the lieutenant governor, a county clerk, municipal clerk, town clerk, city recorder, or municipal recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(1)(b): Title 17B, Chapter 1, Provisions Applicable to All Special Districts "Clerk" includes a board of trustees under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(2): Chapter 7, Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures; Chapter 7, Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures "Local petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(2)(a): Chapter 7, Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures a manual or electronic local initiative petition described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(2)(b): Chapter 7, Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures a manual or electronic local referendum petition described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(3): 10-2-601; 10-2-701; 10-2a-208; 17-2-103; 17-2-203; 17-3-1; 17-11-2; 17-52a-303; 17-52a-505; 17B-1-203; 17B-1-504; 17B-1-1303; 17D-2-502; 20A-8-103; 20A-9-203; 20A-9-403(3)(a); 20A-9-405; 20A-9-404; 20A-9-408; 20A-9-502; 20A-15-103; 53G-3-301; 53G-3-401; 53G-3-501; 73-10d-4 "Petition" means one of the following written requests, signed by registered voters, appealing to an authority with respect to a particular cause:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(3)(a): a local petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(3)(b): 10-2-601 a petition to consolidate two or more municipalities under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(3)(c): 10-2-701 a petition for disincorporation of a municipality under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(4)(a): Chapter 7, Part 2, Statewide Initiatives a manual or electronic statewide initiative petition described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(4)(b): Chapter 7, Part 3, Statewide Referenda a manual or electronic statewide referendum petition described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(a): "Substantially similar name" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(a)(i): the given name, the surname, or both, provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature, contain only minor spelling differences when compared to the given name and surname shown on the official register;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(a)(ii): the surname provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature exactly matches the surname shown on the official register, and the given names differ only because one of the given names shown is a commonly used abbreviation or variation of the other;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(a)(iii): the surname provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature exactly matches the surname shown on the official register, and the given names differ only because one of the given names shown is accompanied by a first or middle initial or a middle name which is not shown on the other record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(a)(iv): the surname provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature exactly matches the surname shown on the official register, and the given names differ only because one of the given names shown is an alphabetically corresponding initial that has been provided in the place of a given name shown on the other record.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1001(5)(b): "Substantially similar name" does not include a name having an initial or a middle name provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature that does not match a different initial or middle name shown on the official register.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002 Verification of voter registration.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1): (1)(b)(i); (1)(c)(i) A clerk shall use the following procedures to determine whether a signer of a petition is a registered voter and to determine the address where the voter is registered to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(a): if a signer's name and address provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature exactly match a name and address shown on the official register and the signer's signature appears substantially similar to the signature on the statewide voter registration database, the clerk shall declare the signature valid for the district or jurisdiction in which the signer is registered to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(b): (1)(b)(i) if there is no exact match of an address and a name, the clerk shall declare the signature valid for the district or jurisdiction in which the signer is registered to vote, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(b)(i): the address provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature matches the address of an individual on the official register with a substantially similar name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i) the signer's signature appears substantially similar to the signature on the statewide voter registration database of the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(c): (1)(c)(i) if there is no match of an address and a substantially similar name, the clerk shall declare the signature valid for the district or jurisdiction in which the signer is registered to vote if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(c)(i): the birth date or age provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature matches the birth date or age of an individual on the official register with a substantially similar name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(1)(c)(ii): (1)(c)(i) the signer's signature appears substantially similar to the signature on the statewide voter registration database of the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1002(2): (1)(a); (b); (c) If a signature is not declared valid under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003 Signature removal -- Statement required.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(1): A voter who signs a petition may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by submitting to the clerk a statement requesting that the voter's signature be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-216; 20A-7-314; 20A-7-515; 20A-7-615
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a): 20A-7-106
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i): 20A-7-106 The statement described in Subsection (1) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i)(A): the name or description of the petition from which the voter seeks to remove the voter's signature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i)(B): the name of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i)(C): the resident address at which the voter is registered to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i)(D): 20A-7-106 except as otherwise provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(i)(E): the date of the signature described in Subsection (2)(a)(i)(D).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(a)(ii): To increase the likelihood of the voter's signature being identified and removed, the statement may include the voter's birth date or age.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(b): 20A-7-216; 20A-7-314; 20A-7-515; 20A-7-615 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(c): In order for the signature to be removed, the clerk must receive the statement described in Subsection (1) no later than the deadline described in the provision of law governing the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(d): A voter may only remove a signature from a petition in accordance with this section and the provision of law governing the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(2)(e): A clerk shall analyze a signature, for purposes of removing a signature from a petition, in accordance with Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3): 20A-7-106 Except to the extent otherwise required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(a): if the signer's name and address shown on the statement and the petition exactly match a name and address shown on the official register and the individual's signature on the statement is reasonably consistent with the individual's signature on the statewide voter registration database, the clerk shall remove the signature from the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(b): if there is no exact match of an address and a name, the clerk shall remove the signature from the petition if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(b)(i): the address on the statement and the address provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature match the address of an individual on the official register with a substantially similar name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(b)(ii): the individual's signature on the statement is reasonably consistent with the signature on the statewide voter registration database of the individual described in Subsection (3)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(c): if there is no match of an address and a substantially similar name, the clerk shall remove the signature from the petition if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(c)(i): the birth date or age on the statement and the birth date or age provided by the individual with the individual's petition signature match the birth date or age of an individual on the official register with a substantially similar name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(3)(c)(ii): the individual's signature on the statement is reasonably consistent with the signature on the statewide voter registration database of the individual described in Subsection (3)(b)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-1-1003(4): 20A-7-106 If a signature does not qualify for removal under Subsection (3)(a), (b), or (c), or, if applicable, Section


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 2 - Voter Registration
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101 Eligibility for registration.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(a): is a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(b): has been a resident of Utah for at least the 30 days immediately before the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(c): will be:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(c)(i): at least 18 years of age on the day of the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(c)(ii): if the election is a regular primary election, a municipal primary election, or a presidential primary election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(c)(ii)(A): 17 years of age on or before the day of the regular primary election, municipal primary election, or presidential primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(c)(ii)(B): 18 years of age on or before the day of the general election that immediately follows the regular primary election, municipal primary election, or presidential primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(1)(d): currently resides within the voting district or precinct in which the individual applies to register to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5; 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2)(a)(i): An individual who is involuntarily confined or incarcerated in a jail, prison, or other facility within a voting precinct is not a resident of that voting precinct and may not register to vote in that voting precinct unless the individual was a resident of that voting precinct before the confinement or incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2)(a)(ii): An individual who is involuntarily confined or incarcerated in a jail or prison is a resident of the voting precinct in which the individual resided before the confinement or incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2)(b): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 An individual who has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor for an offense under this title may not register to vote or remain registered to vote unless the individual's right to vote has been restored as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(2)(c): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 An individual whose right to vote has been restored, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3): An individual who is eligible to vote and who resides within the geographic boundaries of the entity in which the election is held may register to vote in a:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(a): regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(b): regular primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(c): municipal general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(d): municipal primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(e): statewide special election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(f): local special election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(g): special district election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(h): bond election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101(3)(i): presidential primary election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1 Preregistering to vote.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1): 20A-2-101(1)(c) An individual may preregister to vote if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1)(a): is 16 or 17 years of age;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1)(b): 20A-2-101(1)(c) is not eligible to register to vote because the individual does not comply with the age requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1)(c): is a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1)(d): has been a resident of Utah for at least 30 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(1)(e): currently resides within the voting district or precinct in which the individual preregisters to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(2): (1); 20A-2-101(1)(c); (4) An individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(2)(a): 20A-2-101(1)(c) the individual is otherwise eligible to register to vote because the individual complies with the age requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(2)(b): (4) the county clerk registers the individual to vote under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(3): An individual who preregisters to vote shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(3)(a): complete a voter registration form, including an indication that the individual is preregistering to vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(3)(b): submit the voter registration form to a county clerk in person, by mail, or in any other manner authorized by this chapter for the submission of a voter registration form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4): (3)(b); 20A-2-102.5; (4)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a): (3)(b); 20A-2-102.5 A county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(i): (3)(b) retain the voter registration form of an individual who meets the qualifications for preregistration and who submits a completed voter registration form to the county clerk under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(ii): 20A-2-102.5 register the individual to vote in the next election in which the individual will be eligible to vote, before the voter registration deadline established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(iii): send a notice to the individual that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(iii)(A): informs the individual that the individual's voter registration form has been accepted as an application for preregistration;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(iii)(B): informs the individual that the individual will be registered to vote in the next election in which the individual will be eligible to vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(a)(iii)(C): indicates in which election the individual will be registered to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(b): (4)(a)(ii) An individual who the county clerk registers under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(b)(i): the day of the voter registration deadline immediately preceding the election day on which the individual will be at least 18 years of age; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(b)(ii): the day on which the individual turns 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(4)(c): A county clerk shall refer a voter registration form to the county attorney for investigation and possible prosecution if the clerk or the clerk's designee believes the individual is attempting to preregister to vote in an election in which the individual will not be legally entitled to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(5): (5)(a); 63G-2-301(2)(l)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(5)(a): The lieutenant governor or a county clerk shall classify the voter registration record of an individual who preregisters to vote as a private record until the day on which the individual turns 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(5)(b): (5)(a); 63G-2-301(2)(l) On the day on which the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.1(6): If an individual who is at least 18 years of age erroneously indicates on the voter registration form that the individual is preregistering to vote, the county clerk shall consider the form as a voter registration form and shall process the form in accordance with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3 Convicted misdemeanants -- Restoration of right to vote or hold office.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(1): As used in this section, "misdemeanant" means a person convicted of a misdemeanor for an offense under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(2): A misdemeanant's right to register to vote and to vote in an election is restored when the misdemeanant:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(2)(a): is sentenced to probation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(2)(b): has successfully completed the term of incarceration to which the misdemeanant was sentenced.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3): A misdemeanant's right to hold elective office is restored when:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(a): the misdemeanor for an offense under this title is expunged as provided in Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement of Criminal Records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b)(i): five years have passed since the date of the misdemeanant's most recent misdemeanor conviction of an offense under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b)(ii): the misdemeanant has paid all court-ordered restitution and fines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b)(iii): for each misdemeanor conviction that has not been expunged, the misdemeanant has:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b)(iii)(A): completed probation in relation to the misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.3(3)(b)(iii)(B): successfully completed the term of incarceration associated with the misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5 Convicted felons -- Restoration of right to vote and right to hold office.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(1): As used in this section, "convicted felon" means a person convicted of a felony in any state or federal court of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(2): Each convicted felon's right to register to vote and to vote in an election is restored when:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(2)(a): the felon is sentenced to probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(2)(b): the felon is granted parole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(2)(c): the felon has successfully completed the term of incarceration to which the felon was sentenced.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3): (4) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(a): all of the felon's felony convictions have been expunged; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(i): 10 years have passed since the date of the felon's most recent felony conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(ii): the felon has paid all court-ordered restitution and fines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(iii): for each felony conviction that has not been expunged, the felon has:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(iii)(A): completed probation in relation to the felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(iii)(B): been granted parole in relation to the felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(3)(b)(iii)(C): successfully completed the term of incarceration associated with the felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-101.5(4): 76-1-101.5 An individual who has been convicted of a grievous sexual offense, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102 Registration a prerequisite to voting.
----------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102(2): 20A-2-307 A person may vote a provisional ballot for an election as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102.5 Voter registration deadline.
--------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102.5(2): 20A-2-201; 20A-2-202; 20A-2-204; 20A-2-205; 20A-2-206; 20A-3a-601; 20A-2-207; 20A-2-207 The voter registration deadline is as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102.5(2)(a): 20A-2-201; 20A-2-202; 20A-2-204; 20A-2-205; 20A-2-206 the voter registration must be received by the county clerk, the municipal clerk, or the lieutenant governor no later than 5 p.m. 11 calendar days before the date of the election, if the individual registers to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-102.5(2)(a)(i): 20A-2-201 at the office of the county clerk, in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103 Special elections -- Lists of voters.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(1)(a): A special registration of voters is not required for a statewide or local special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(1)(b): The last official or revised register is the register for the statewide or local special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(2): If a statewide or local special election is held at the same time and place as a regular general election, a municipal general election, or a primary, persons qualified to vote at those elections may also vote in the statewide or local special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(3): If a statewide or local special election is held on a date other than the date of a regular or municipal general election, the county clerk of each county in which the municipality or entity is wholly or partly located shall register persons to vote in that election during regular office hours in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-103(4): The county clerk of each county in which the entity holding the statewide or local special election is located shall make registration lists or copies of those lists available at each polling place for use by registered voters entitled to use those polling places.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(i): a single hash code, generated from a string of data that includes both the voter's voter identification number and residential address;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(ii): the voter's residential address;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(iii): the voter's mailing address, if different from the voter's residential address;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(vii)(A): 25 or younger;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(vii)(B): 26 through 35;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(vii)(C): 36 through 45;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(o)(vii)(G): 76 or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(4)(p): (4)(o); (4)(o)(iii) The lieutenant governor or a county clerk may not disclose:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(6): Upon receipt of a voter registration form from an applicant, the county clerk or the clerk's designee shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(9): An election officer or an employee of an election officer may not encourage an individual to submit, or discourage an individual from submitting, a withholding request form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10): (10); (10)(a); (10)(a); 63A-16-601; (10)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a): The lieutenant governor shall make and execute a plan to provide notice to registered voters who are protected individuals, that includes the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a)(i): that the voter's classification of the record as private remains in effect;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a)(ii): that certain non-identifying information from the voter's voter registration record may, under certain circumstances, be released to political parties and candidates for public office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a)(iii): that the voter's name, driver license or identification card number, social security number, email address, phone number, and the voter's day, month, and year of birth will remain private and will not be released to political parties or candidates for public office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a)(iv): that a county clerk will only release the information to political parties and candidates in a manner that does not associate the information with a particular voter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-104(10)(a)(v): that a county clerk may, under certain circumstances, withhold other information that the county clerk determines would reveal identifying information about the voter.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105 Determining residency.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(1)(a): "Principal place of residence" means the single location where an individual's habitation is fixed and to which, whenever the individual is absent, the individual has the intention of returning, as evidenced by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(1)(a)(i): the intent expressed by the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(1)(a)(ii): acts of the individual that are consistent or inconsistent with the intent expressed by the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(1)(b): "Resident" means an individual whose principal place of residence is within a specific voting precinct in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(2): Election officials and judges shall apply the standards and requirements of this section when determining whether an individual is a resident for purposes of interpreting this title or the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(3): (2) An individual may request that an election official or election judge assist the individual in determining the individual's principal place of residence for a purpose described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4): (4)(d); (4)(e)(ii); (iii); (4)(e)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(a): An individual resides in Utah if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(a)(i): the individual's principal place of residence is within Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(a)(ii): the individual has a present intention to maintain the individual's principal place of residence in Utah permanently or indefinitely.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(b): An individual resides within a particular voting precinct if, on the date of registering to vote, the individual's principal place of residence is in that voting precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(c): An individual's principal place of residence does not change solely because the individual is present in Utah, present in a voting precinct, absent from Utah, or absent from the individual's voting precinct because the individual is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(c)(i): employed in the service of the United States or of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(c)(ii): a student at an institution of learning;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(c)(iii): incarcerated in prison or jail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(c)(iv): residing upon an Indian or military reservation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(d): (4)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(d)(i): A member of the armed forces of the United States is not a resident of Utah merely because that member is stationed at a military facility within Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(d)(ii): (4)(d) In order to be a resident of Utah, a member of the armed forces described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(e): (4)(e)(ii); (iii); (4)(e)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(e)(i): (4)(e)(ii); (iii) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(e)(ii): If an individual leaves the state or a voting precinct and votes or registers to vote in another state or voting precinct, the individual is no longer a resident of the state or voting precinct that the individual left.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(e)(iii): (4)(e)(i) An individual loses the individual's principal place of residence in Utah or in a precinct, if, after the individual moves to another state or another precinct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(f): An individual is not a resident of a county or voting precinct if the individual comes to the county or voting precinct for temporary purposes and does not intend to make that county or voting precinct the individual's principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(g): An individual loses the individual's principal place of residence in Utah or in a precinct if the individual moves to another state or precinct with the intention of making the other state or precinct the individual's principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(4)(h): If an individual moves to another state or precinct with the intent of remaining in the other state or precinct for an indefinite time as the individual's principal place of residence, the individual loses the individual's principal place of residence in Utah, or in the precinct, even though the individual intends to return at some future time.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5): 20A-3a-803; 20A-3a-804; 20A-3a-805; (2); (5)(b); (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(a): 20A-3a-803; 20A-3a-804; 20A-3a-805 An individual may challenge a determination by a voter, election official, or election judge of a voter's principal place of residence, for the purpose of voting, in accordance with the applicable provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(b): (2) If an election official or election judge has reasonable, articulable grounds to question the principal place of residence of an individual for a purpose described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(c): (5)(b) Reasonable, articulable grounds to question an individual's principal place of residence, and require additional information under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(c)(i): that the individual has a driver license or other identification from outside Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(c)(ii): that the address claimed as the individual's principal place of residence does not match the address on the individual's driver license or other identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(c)(iii): that the individual owns residential property outside the location claimed as the individual's principal place of residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(c)(iv): other articulable grounds that would lead a reasonable individual to question an individual's principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(d): (5)(b) If an election official or election judge requires, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(d)(i): enter the voter registration into the statewide voter registration database; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(5)(d)(ii): indicate, in the statewide voter registration database, that the voter must provide additional information before the voter's ballot may be accepted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6): (10); (5) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(a): where the individual's family resides;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(b): whether the individual is single, married, separated, or divorced;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(c): the age of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(d): where the individual usually sleeps;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(e): where the individual's minor children attend school;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(f): the location of the individual's employment, income sources, or business pursuits;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(g): the location of real property owned by the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(h): the individual's residence for purposes of taxation or tax exemption;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(i): the location where the individual's motor vehicles are registered;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(j): the address for which the individual pays utility services;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(k): the address associated with the individual's hunting or fishing license;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(l): the address associated with the individual's professional licenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(6)(m): other relevant factors.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(a): An individual changes the individual's principal place of residence if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(a)(i): acts affirmatively to move from the state or a precinct in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(a)(ii): has the intent to remain in another state or precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(b): An individual may not have more than one principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(c): An individual does not lose the individual's principal place of residence until the individual establishes another principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(d): An individual who moves from one county in Utah to another county in Utah retains the right to vote in the county from which the individual moved for 30 days after the day on which the individual moved from the county, unless the individual votes in the new county for that election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(7)(e): An individual who is homeless may, in accordance with the other provisions of this section, establish a nontraditional location, including a location without a structure, as the individual's principal place of residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(8): (2) In computing the period that a person is a resident for a purpose described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(8)(a): begins on the day on which the individual establishes the individual's principal place of residence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(8)(b): ends on the day before the day of the next applicable election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(9): (12); (12); (9)(a); (9)(a); (9)(a); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(9)(a): (12) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(9)(b): (12); (9)(a); (9)(a); (9)(a); (5) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(9)(b)(i): the individual's principal place of residence is not in Utah or not in the applicable precinct or district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(9)(b)(ii): the individual is incarcerated in prison or jail and did not, before the individual was incarcerated in prison or jail, establish the individual's principal place of residence in the voting precinct where the prison or jail is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(10)(a): The criteria described in this section for establishing an individual's principal place of residence for voting purposes do not apply in relation to the individual's location while the individual is incarcerated in prison or jail.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(10)(b): For voting registration purposes, the principal place of residence of an individual incarcerated in prison or jail is the state and voting precinct where the individual's principal place of residence was located before incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(11): If an individual's principal place of residence is a residential parcel of one acre in size or smaller that is divided by the boundary line between two or more counties, that individual shall be considered a resident of the county in which a majority of the residential parcel lies.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12): (12)(a); (12)(a); (12)(b)(ii); (12)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(a): If an individual seeking to become a candidate for a political office that includes a durational residency requirement has been absent from the state for a period of more than 180 consecutive days during the applicable residency period, the individual may, at the time that the candidate files a declaration of candidacy, submit evidence to the filing officer to show that the individual intended to return to the state during the time of the individual's absence from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b): (12)(a) There is a rebuttable presumption that an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b)(i): the individual submits evidence of the individual's intent to the filing officer at the time that the individual files a declaration of candidacy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b)(ii): the individual was absent from the state because the individual was:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b)(ii)(A): employed in the service of the United States or of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b)(ii)(B): a student at an institution of learning; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(b)(ii)(C): engaged solely in religious, missionary, philanthropic, or humanitarian activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(c): (12)(a); (12)(b)(ii) If a valid written objection to an individual's declaration of candidacy is filed, there is a rebuttable presumption that an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(c)(i): the individual did not submit evidence of the individual's intent to the filing officer at the time that the individual filed a declaration of candidacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(c)(ii): (12)(b)(ii) the individual's absence from the state was not for one of the reasons described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-105(12)(d): (12) An individual must rebut the presumption described in this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107 Designating or changing party affiliation -- Times permitted.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(1): 20A-9-201.5(2)(b) As used in this section, "change of affiliation deadline" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(1)(a): 20A-9-201.5(2)(b) for an election held in an even-numbered year in which a presidential election will be held, the day after the declaration of candidacy deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(1)(b): for an election held in an even-numbered year in which a presidential election will not be held, April 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2): (6); 20A-2-107.5(3); (2)(b)(ii) The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(a): (6); 20A-2-107.5(3) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b): (2)(b)(ii) if no political party affiliation is designated by the voter on the voter registration form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b)(i): (2)(b)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b)(ii): record the voter's party affiliation as "unaffiliated" if the voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b)(ii)(A): did not previously designate a party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b)(ii)(B): most recently designated the voter's party affiliation as "unaffiliated"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(2)(b)(ii)(C): did not previously register.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(3): (3); (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(3)(a): (3) Any registered voter may designate or change the voter's political party affiliation by complying with the procedures and requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(3)(b): A registered voter may designate or change the voter's political party affiliation by filing with the county clerk, the municipal clerk, or the lieutenant governor a voter registration form or another signed form that identifies the registered political party with which the voter chooses to affiliate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(3)(c): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(3)(d): The party affiliation of a voter who changes party affiliation, or who becomes unaffiliated from a political party, at any time on or after the change of affiliation deadline and on or before the date of the regular primary election, takes effect the day after the statewide canvass for the regular primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(4): (3)(d); (3)(c); 20A-2-206 For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(4)(a): the individual submits the form in person at the county clerk's office no later than 5 p.m. on the day before the change of affiliation deadline;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(4)(b): 20A-2-206 the individual submits the form electronically through the system described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(4)(c): the individual's form is clearly postmarked before the change of affiliation deadline.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(5): (3)(d); (6) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(5)(a): the voter has not previously been registered to vote in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(5)(b): (6) the voter's most recent party affiliation was changed to "unaffiliated" by a county clerk under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(6): If the most recent party affiliation designated by a voter is for a political party that is no longer a registered political party, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(6)(a): change the voter's party affiliation to "unaffiliated"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(6)(b): notify the voter electronically or by mail:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(6)(b)(i): that the voter's affiliation has been changed to "unaffiliated" because the most recent party affiliation designated by the voter is for a political party that is no longer a registered political party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107(6)(b)(ii): of the methods and deadlines for changing the voter's party affiliation.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5 Designating or changing party affiliation -- Regular primary election and presidential primary election -- Voting in primaries of multiple parties prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(1): 20A-2-107(1) As used in this section, "change of affiliation deadline" means the same as that term is defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(2)(a): affiliate with a political party by completing a change of party affiliation form or voter registration form and submitting the form to the county clerk or a poll worker; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(2)(b): vote in that party's primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(3): The party affiliation of a voter who changes party affiliation, or who becomes unaffiliated from a political party, at any time on or after the change of affiliation deadline and on or before the date of the regular primary election, takes effect the day after the statewide canvass for the regular primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(4)(a): A voter who votes in the presidential primary election of a registered political party may not, for the same election, vote in the presidential primary election of another registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-107.5(4)(b): A voter who votes in the regular primary election of a registered political party may not, for the same election, vote in the regular primary election of another registered political party.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108 Driver license or state identification card registration form -- Transmittal of information.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(1): As used in this section, "qualifying form" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(1)(a): a driver license application form; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(1)(b): a state identification card application form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(2): The lieutenant governor and the Driver License Division shall design each qualifying form to include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(2)(a): the following question, which an applicant is required to answer: "Do you authorize the use of information in this form for voter registration purposes? YES____ NO____";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(2)(c): a section in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3): 20A-2-104; (2)(a); 20A-8-101; (3)(e)(i) The lieutenant governor and the Driver License Division shall ensure that a qualifying form contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(a): a place for an individual to affirm the individual's citizenship, voting eligibility, and Utah residency, and that the information provided in the form is true;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(b): 20A-2-104 a records disclosure that is similar to the records disclosure on a voter registration form described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(c): a statement that if an applicant declines to register or preregister to vote, the fact that the applicant has declined to register or preregister will remain confidential and will be used only for voter registration purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(d): a statement that if an applicant does register or preregister to vote, the office at which the applicant submits a voter registration application will remain confidential and will be used only for voter registration purposes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(e): (2)(a); 20A-8-101; (3)(e)(i) if the applicant answers "yes" to the question described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(e)(i): 20A-8-101 indicate the individual's desired political affiliation from a listing of each registered political party, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(e)(ii): (3)(e)(i) specify a political party that is not listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-108(3)(e)(iii): indicate that the individual does not wish to affiliate with a political party.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201 Registering to vote at office of county clerk.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(1): (3); 20A-2-101 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2): 20A-2-101.1 If an individual who is registering to vote submits a registration form in person at the office of the county clerk no later than 5 p.m. 11 calendar days before the date of the election, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2)(a): accept and process the voter registration form;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2)(b): unless the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2)(b)(i): enter the individual's name on the list of registered voters for the voting precinct in which the individual resides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2)(b)(ii): notify the individual that the individual is registered to vote in the upcoming election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(2)(c): 20A-2-101.1 if the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote, comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-201(3): (2); 20A-2-207(6); 20A-2-207 If an individual who is registering to vote and who will be legally qualified and entitled to vote in a voting precinct in the county on the date of an election appears in person, during designated office hours, and submits a registration form after the deadline described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202 Registration by mail.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(a): An individual who will be qualified to vote at the next election may register by mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(b): To register by mail, an individual shall complete and sign the registration form and mail or deliver the form to the county clerk of the county in which the citizen resides.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(c): In order to register to vote in a particular election, the citizen shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(c)(i): address the voter registration form to the county clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(c)(ii): ensure that the voter registration form is received by the county clerk no later than 5 p.m. 11 calendar days before the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(1)(d): The citizen has effectively registered to vote under this section only when the county clerk's office has received a correctly completed voter registration form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2): 20A-2-101.1 Upon receipt of a timely, correctly completed voter registration form, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2)(a): accept and process the voter registration form;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2)(b): unless the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2)(b)(i): enter the applicant's name on the list of registered voters for the voting precinct in which the applicant resides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2)(b)(ii): notify the individual that the individual is registered to vote in the upcoming election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(2)(c): 20A-2-101.1 if the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote, comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(3): (1)(c); 20A-2-207 If the county clerk receives a correctly completed voter registration form after the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(3)(a): accept the application for registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(3)(b): 20A-2-207 if possible, promptly mail a notice to, or otherwise notify, the individual before the election, informing the individual that the individual will not be registered to vote in the pending election, unless the individual registers to vote by provisional ballot during the early voting period, if applicable, or on election day, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-202(4): If the county clerk determines that a registration form received by mail or otherwise is incorrect because of an error or because the registration form is incomplete, the county clerk shall mail notice to the individual attempting to register or preregister, stating that the individual has not been registered or preregistered because of an error or because the registration form is incomplete.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(a)(ii): 20A-2-101.1 if the individual is preregistering to vote, comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(b): 20A-2-101.1 If the county clerk receives a correctly completed voter registration form under this section no later than 5 p.m. or, if submitting the form electronically, midnight, 11 calendar days before the date of an election, the county clerk shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(b)(iii): 20A-2-101.1 if the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote, comply with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(c)(i): accept the application for registration of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(c)(ii): process the voter registration form; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(6)(c)(iii): 20A-2-207(6); 20A-2-207 unless the individual is preregistering to vote, and except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(7)(a): If the county clerk determines that an individual's voter registration form received from the Driver License Division is incorrect because of an error, because the form is incomplete, or because the individual does not meet the qualifications to be registered to vote, the county clerk shall mail notice to the individual stating that the individual has not been registered or preregistered because of an error, because the registration form is incomplete, or because the individual does not meet the qualifications to be registered to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-204(7)(b): If a county clerk believes, based upon a review of a voter registration form, that an individual, who knows that the individual is not legally entitled to register or preregister to vote, may be intentionally seeking to register or preregister to vote, the county clerk shall refer the form to the county attorney for investigation and possible prosecution.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205 Registration at voter registration agencies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
"REGISTERING TO VOTEUtah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(1): 20A-2-300.5; 20A-2-300.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(1)(a): 20A-2-300.5 "Discretionary voter registration agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(1)(b): 20A-2-300.5 "Public assistance agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(2): An individual may obtain and complete a registration form at a public assistance agency or discretionary voter registration agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(3): Each public assistance agency and discretionary voter registration agency shall provide, either as part of existing forms or on a separate form, the following information in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(4): Unless an individual applying for service or assistance from a public assistance agency or discretionary voter registration agency declines, in writing, to register or preregister to vote, each public assistance agency and discretionary voter registration agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(4)(a): distribute a voter registration form with each application for service or assistance provided by the agency or office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(4)(b): assist applicants in completing the voter registration form unless the applicant refuses assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(4)(c): accept completed forms for transmittal to the appropriate election official; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(4)(d): transmit a copy of each voter registration form to the appropriate election official within five days after the division receives the voter registration form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(5): An individual in a public assistance agency or a discretionary voter registration agency that helps an applicant complete the voter registration form may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(5)(a): seek to influence an applicant's political preference or party registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(5)(b): display any political preference or party allegiance;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(5)(c): make any statement to an applicant or take any action that has the purpose or effect of discouraging the applicant from registering to vote; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(5)(d): make any statement to an applicant or take any action that has the purpose or effect of leading the applicant to believe that a decision of whether to register or preregister has any bearing upon the availability of services or benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6): 20A-2-101.1 If the county clerk receives a correctly completed voter registration form under this section no later than 5 p.m. 11 calendar days before the date of an election, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6)(a): accept and process the voter registration form;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6)(b): unless the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6)(b)(i): enter the applicant's name on the list of registered voters for the voting precinct in which the applicant resides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6)(b)(ii): notify the applicant that the applicant is registered to vote in the upcoming election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(6)(c): 20A-2-101.1 if the individual named in the form is preregistering to vote, comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(7): (6); 20A-2-207(6); 20A-2-207 If the county clerk receives a correctly completed voter registration form after the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(7)(a): accept the application for registration of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(7)(b): 20A-2-207(6); 20A-2-207 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-2-205(8): If the county clerk determines that a voter registration form received from a public assistance agency or discretionary voter registration agency is incorrect because of an error or because the voter registration form is incomplete, the county clerk shall mail notice to the individual attempting to register or preregister to vote, stating that the individual has not been registered or preregistered to vote because of an error or because the voter registration form is incomplete.
