Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-801(7)(c): An administering election officer may provide a watcher a badge that identifies the watcher and require the watcher to wear the badge while acting as a watcher.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-802 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-802(1): "Challenged voter" means an individual whose right to vote is challenged as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-802(2): 20A-3a-804 "Filer" means an individual who files a written statement challenging another individual's right to vote as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803 Challenges to a voter's eligibility -- Basis for challenge -- Procedures.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 An individual may challenge another individual's eligibility to vote on any of the following grounds:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(a): the individual is not the individual in whose name the individual tries to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(b): the individual is not a resident of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(c): the individual is not a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(d): the individual has not or will not have resided in Utah for 30 days immediately before the date of the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(e): the individual's principal place of residence is not in the voting precinct that the individual claims;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(f): the individual's principal place of residence is not in the geographic boundaries of the election area;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(g): the individual has already voted in the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(h): the individual is not at least the minimum age required to vote in the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(i): 20A-2-101.3 the individual has been convicted of a misdemeanor for an offense under this title and the individual's right to vote in an election has not been restored under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(j): 20A-2-101.5 the individual is a convicted felon and the voter's right to vote in an election has not been restored under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(1)(k): in a regular primary election or presidential primary election, the individual does not meet the political party affiliation requirements for the ballot the individual seeks to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(2): 20A-3a-804; 20A-3a-805 An individual who challenges another individual's right to vote in an election shall make the challenge in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(2)(a): 20A-3a-804 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-803(2)(b): 20A-3a-805 Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804 Pre-election challenges to a voter's eligibility in writing -- Procedure -- Form of challenge.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1): (1)(b); 20A-3a-803; 20A-3a-803; (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a): (1)(b); 20A-3a-803; 20A-3a-803 An individual may challenge an individual's eligibility to vote by filing a written statement with the election officer in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(i): lists the name and address of the individual filing the challenge;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii): 20A-3a-803 for each individual who is challenged:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii)(A): identifies the name of the challenged individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii)(B): lists the last known address or telephone number of the challenged individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii)(C): 20A-3a-803 provides the basis for the challenge, as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii)(D): provides facts and circumstances supporting the basis provided; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(ii)(E): may include supporting documents, affidavits, or other evidence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(iii): 20A-3a-803 includes a signed affidavit, which is subject to penalties of perjury, swearing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(iii)(A): the filer exercised due diligence to personally verify the facts and circumstances establishing the basis for the challenge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(a)(iii)(B): 20A-3a-803 according to the filer's personal knowledge and belief, the basis for the challenge under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(b): (1)(a) An individual who files a written statement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(b)(i): at least 45 days before the day of the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(b)(ii): if the challenge is to an individual who registered to vote between the day that is 45 days before the election and the day of the election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(b)(ii)(A): on or before the day of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(b)(ii)(B): before the individual's ballot is removed from a ballot envelope or otherwise separated from any information that could be used to identify the ballot as the individual's ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(c): The challenge may not be based on unsupported allegations or allegations by an anonymous individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(1)(d): An election officer may require an individual who files a challenge under this section to file the challenge on a form provided by the election officer that meets the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(2): If the challenge is not in the proper form, is incomplete, or if the basis for the challenge does not meet the requirements of this part, the election officer shall dismiss the challenge and notify the filer in writing of the reasons for the dismissal.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3): (3)(b); (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii); (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(a): (3)(b); (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii) Upon receipt of a challenge that meets the requirements for filing under this section, the election officer shall attempt to notify each challenged individual in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(a)(i): (1)(b)(i) at least 28 days before the date of the election, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(a)(ii): (1)(b)(ii) within one business day, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii) The election officer shall attempt to notify each challenged individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(i): that a challenge has been filed against the challenged individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(ii): that the challenged individual may be required to cast a provisional ballot at the time the individual votes if the individual votes in person;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(iii): that if the individual votes by mail, the individual's ballot will be treated as a provisional ballot unless the challenge is resolved;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(iv): of the basis for the challenge, which may include providing a copy of the challenge the filer filed with the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(v): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii) that the challenged individual may submit information, a sworn statement, supporting documents, affidavits, or other evidence supporting the challenged individual's eligibility to vote in the election to the election officer no later than:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(v)(A): (1)(b)(i) 21 days before the date of the election, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(3)(b)(v)(B): (1)(b)(ii) five days before the day on which the canvass is held, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(a): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii) The election officer shall determine whether each challenged individual is eligible to vote before the day on which:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(a)(i): (1)(b)(i) early voting commences, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(a)(ii): (1)(b)(ii) the canvass is held, if the election officer receives the challenge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(b)(i): The filer has the burden to prove, by clear and convincing evidence, that the basis for challenging the individual's eligibility to vote is valid.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(4)(b)(ii): The election officer shall resolve the challenge based on the available facts and information submitted, which may include voter registration records and other documents or information available to the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(5): 76-8-503; 76-8-504 An individual who files a challenge in accordance with the requirements of this section is subject to criminal penalties for false statements as provided under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6): (1)(a); (3)(b)(v)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(a): A challenged individual may appeal an election officer's decision regarding the individual's eligibility to vote to the district court having jurisdiction over the location where the challenge was filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(b): The district court shall uphold the decision of the election officer unless the district court determines that the decision was arbitrary, capricious, or unlawful.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(c): (1)(a); (3)(b)(v) In making the district court's determination, the district court's review is limited to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(c)(i): (1)(a) the information filed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(c)(ii): (3)(b)(v) the information submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(6)(c)(iii): any additional facts and information used by the election official to determine whether the challenged individual is eligible to vote, as indicated by the election official.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(7): A challenged individual may register to vote or change the location of the individual's voter registration if otherwise permitted by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-804(8): A document pertaining to a challenge filed under this section is a public record.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805 Challenges to a voter's eligibility at polling place -- Procedure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(1): 20A-3a-803
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(1)(a): A poll worker, a watcher, or an individual who resides in the jurisdiction to which the election relates may, at a polling place, challenge an individual's eligibility to vote a particular ballot or to vote in that election if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(1)(a)(i): the individual making the challenge and the challenged individual are both present at the polling place at the time the challenge is made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(1)(a)(ii): the challenge is made before the challenged individual applies for a ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(1)(b): 20A-3a-803 An individual may make a challenge by orally stating the challenged individual's name and the basis for the challenge, as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(2): The poll worker shall record a challenge in the official register or on the challenge sheets in the pollbook, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(2)(a): the name of the challenged individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(2)(b): the name of the individual making the challenge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(2)(c): the basis upon which the challenge is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-805(3): 20A-3a-205 If an individual's eligibility to vote is challenged under this section, the poll worker shall follow the procedures and requirements of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-806 Election official or watcher revealing vote.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-806(1): It is unlawful for an election official or watcher to reveal to another person the name of a candidate or ballot proposition for whom a voter has voted or to communicate to another person the election official or watcher's opinion, belief, or impression regarding for whom or what a voter has voted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-806(2): A person who violates this section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807 Notification of ballot processes.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1): As used in this section, "ballot process" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(a): signature verification;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(b): opening ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(c): scanning ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(d): adjudicating ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(e): replicating damaged or defective ballots; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(1)(f): tabulating votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(2): A county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(2)(a): beginning at least three days before the day on which the county clerk begins mailing ballots for an election, and ending on the first day of the canvass, post on the county clerk's website a schedule of the hours, over the next three days, during which the county clerk plans to conduct one or more ballot processes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-3a-807(2)(b): update any changes to the schedule at least 24 hours before the clerk modifies the hours.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 4 - Election Returns and Election Contests
************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101 Manual ballots cast at a polling place -- Counting manual ballots at polling place on day of election before polls close.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(1): Each county legislative body, municipal legislative body, and each poll worker shall comply with the requirements of this section when counting manual ballots on the day of an election, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(1)(a): the ballots are cast at a polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(1)(b): the ballots are counted at the polling place before the polls close.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2): (2)(f); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; (2)(f)(i); Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(a): Each county legislative body or municipal legislative body shall provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(a)(i): two sets of ballot boxes for all voting precincts where both receiving and counting judges have been appointed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(a)(ii): a counting room for the use of the poll workers counting the ballots during the day.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(b): At any election in any voting precinct in which both receiving and counting judges have been appointed, when at least 20 votes have been cast, the receiving judges shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(b)(i): close the first ballot box and deliver it to the counting judges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(b)(ii): prepare and use another ballot box to receive voted ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(c): (2)(f) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(c)(i): take the ballot box to the counting room;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(c)(ii): count the votes on the regular ballots in the ballot box;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(c)(iii): place the provisional ballot envelopes in the envelope or container provided for them for return to the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(c)(iv): when they have finished counting the votes in the ballot box, return the emptied box to the receiving judges.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(d)(i): During the course of election day, whenever there are at least 20 ballots contained in a ballot box, the receiving judges shall deliver that ballot box to the counting judges for counting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(d)(ii): the counting judges shall immediately count the regular ballots and segregate the provisional ballots contained in that box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(e): The counting judges shall continue to exchange the ballot boxes and count ballots until the polls close.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(f): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; (2)(f)(i); Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(f)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project The director of elections within the Office of the Lieutenant Governor shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(2)(f)(ii): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; (2)(f)(i); Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project When counting ballots in an instant runoff voting race described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(3): 20A-4-105; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-603(3); (5) To resolve questions that arise during the counting of ballots, a counting judge shall apply the standards and requirements of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(3)(a): 20A-4-105 to the extent applicable, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-101(3)(b): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-603(3); (5) as applicable, for an instant runoff voting race under


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102 Manual ballots cast at a polling place -- Counting manual ballots at polling place on day of election after polls close.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1): (2); 20A-4-101(2)(f)(i); 20A-4-105; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-603(3); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(a): This section governs counting manual ballots on the day of an election, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(a)(i): the ballots are cast at a polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(a)(ii): the ballots are counted at the polling place after the polls close.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(b): (2); 20A-4-101(2)(f)(i) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(c): 20A-4-105; Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-603(3); (5) To resolve questions that arise during the counting of ballots, a counting judge shall apply the standards and requirements of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(c)(i): 20A-4-105 to the extent applicable, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(1)(c)(ii): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-603(3); (5) as applicable, for an instant runoff voting race under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(a): First, the election judges shall count the number of ballots in the ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(b)(i): If there are more ballots in the ballot box than there are names entered in the pollbook, the judges shall examine the official endorsements on the ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(b)(ii): If, in the unanimous opinion of the judges, any of the ballots do not bear the proper official endorsement, the judges shall put those ballots in an excess ballot file and not count them.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(c)(i): If, after examining the official endorsements, there are still more ballots in the ballot box than there are names entered in the pollbook, the judges shall place the remaining ballots back in the ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(c)(ii): One of the judges, without looking, shall draw a number of ballots equal to the excess from the ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(c)(iii): The judges shall put those excess ballots into the excess ballot envelope and not count them.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(2)(d): When the ballots in the ballot box equal the number of names entered in the pollbook, the judges shall count the votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(3): The judges shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(3)(a): place all unused ballots in the envelope or container provided for return to the county clerk or city recorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(3)(b): seal that envelope or container.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(4): The judges shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(4)(a): place all of the provisional ballot envelopes in the envelope provided for them for return to the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(4)(b): seal that envelope or container.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5)(a): In counting the votes, the election judges shall read and count each ballot separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5)(b): In regular primary elections the judges shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5)(b)(i): count the number of ballots cast for each party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5)(b)(ii): place the ballots cast for each party in separate piles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(5)(b)(iii): count all the ballots for one party before beginning to count the ballots cast for other parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-101(2)(f)(i); 20A-9-601; 20A-4-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 20A-4-101(2)(f)(i); 20A-9-601; 20A-4-105 In all elections, the counting judges shall, except as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(i): count one vote for each candidate designated by the marks in the squares next to the candidate's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(ii): 20A-9-601 count each vote for each write-in candidate who has qualified by filing a declaration of candidacy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(iii): read every name marked on the ballot and mark every name upon the tally sheets before another ballot is counted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(iv): 20A-4-105 evaluate each ballot and each vote based on the standards and requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(v): write the word "spoiled" on the back of each ballot that lacks the official endorsement and deposit it in the spoiled ballot envelope; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(a)(vi): read, count, and record upon the tally sheets the votes that each candidate and ballot proposition received from all ballots, except excess or spoiled ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(b): Election judges need not tally write-in votes for fictitious persons, nonpersons, or persons clearly not eligible to qualify for office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(c): The judges shall certify to the accuracy and completeness of the tally list in the space provided on the tally list.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(6)(d): When the judges have counted all of the voted ballots, they shall record the results on the total votes cast form.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(7): (7)(b); 36-12-15.2
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(7)(a): (7)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(7)(b): 36-12-15.2
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(7)(b)(i): 36-12-15.2 An auditor conducting an audit described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-102(7)(b)(ii): The lieutenant governor may be present at the place where counting is conducted, regardless of whether the count is completed.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103 Preparing ballots cast at a polling place for the counting center.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(1): This section governs the preparation of ballots for the counting center when the ballots are cast at a polling place.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(2)(a): As soon as the polls have been closed and the last qualified voter has voted, the poll workers shall prepare the ballots for delivery to the counting center as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(2)(b): The poll workers, election officers, and other persons may not manually count any votes before delivering the ballots to the counting center.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3): (3)(a); (3)(a); (c) The poll workers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(a): complete the statement of disposition of ballots and all other forms required by the election officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(b): (3)(a) place a copy of the forms described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(c): place all provisional ballots in the container provided for returning provisional ballots to the counting center and seal the container; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(d): (3)(a); (c) deliver to the counting center:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(d)(i): (3)(a); (c) the items described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-103(3)(d)(ii): any other items required by the election officer.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104 Counting ballots electronically -- Notice of testing tabulating equipment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1): 63G-30-102; 20A-1-108(1)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(a): Before beginning to count ballots using automatic tabulating equipment, the election officer shall test the automatic tabulating equipment to ensure that it will accurately count the votes cast for all offices and all measures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(b): 63G-30-102 The election officer shall provide public notice of the time and place of the test by publishing the notice, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(c): The election officer shall conduct the test by processing a preaudited group of ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(d): The election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(d)(i): a predetermined number of valid votes for each candidate and measure are recorded on the ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(d)(ii): for each office, one or more ballots have votes in excess of the number allowed by law in order to test the ability of the automatic tabulating equipment to reject those votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(d)(iii): a different number of valid votes are assigned to each candidate for an office, and for and against each measure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(e): If any error is detected, the election officer shall determine the cause of the error and correct it.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(f): 20A-1-108(1) The election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(f)(i): the automatic tabulating equipment produces an errorless count before beginning the actual counting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(1)(f)(ii): 20A-1-108(1) before the election returns are approved as official , the automatic tabuating equipment passes a post election audit conducted in accordance with the rules described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2)(a): The election officer or the election officer's designee shall supervise and direct all proceedings at the counting center.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2)(b)(i): Proceedings at the counting center are public and may be observed by interested persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2)(b)(ii): Only those persons authorized to participate in the count may touch any ballot or return.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(2)(c): The election officer shall deputize and administer an oath or affirmation to all persons who are engaged in processing and counting the ballots that they will faithfully perform their assigned duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3): (3)(a); (3)(b); (3)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(a): If any ballot is damaged or defective so that it cannot properly be counted by the automatic tabulating equipment, the election officer shall  ensure that two counting judges jointly:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(a)(i): make a true replication of the ballot with an identifying serial number;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(a)(ii): substitute the replicated ballot for the damaged or defective ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(a)(iii): label the replicated ballot "replicated"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(a)(iv): record the replicated ballot's serial number on the damaged or defective ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(b): (3)(a) The lieutenant governor shall provide to each election officer a standard form on which the election officer shall maintain a log of all replicated ballots, that includes, for each ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(b)(i): (3)(a) the serial number described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(b)(ii): the identification of the individuals who replicated the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(b)(iii): the reason for the replication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(b)(iv): any other information required by the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(c): (3)(b); (3)(c)(ii) An election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(c)(i): (3)(b) maintain the log described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(c)(ii): at the end of each day during which one or more ballots are replicated, make an electronic copy of the log; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(3)(c)(iii): (3)(c)(ii) keep each electronic copy made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(4): The election officer may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(4)(a): conduct an unofficial count before conducting the official count in order to provide early unofficial returns to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(4)(b): release unofficial returns from time to time after the polls close; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(4)(c): report the progress of the count for each candidate during the actual counting of ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(5): (4) Beginning on the day after the date of the election, if an election officer releases early unofficial returns or reports the progress of the count for each candidate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(6): 20A-4-107 The election officer shall review and evaluate the provisional ballot envelopes and prepare any valid provisional ballots for counting as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(7)(a): The election officer or the election officer's designee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(7)(a)(i): separate, count, and tabulate any ballots containing valid write-in votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(7)(a)(ii): complete the standard form provided by the clerk for recording valid write-in votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(7)(b): In counting the write-in votes, if, by casting a valid write-in vote, a voter has cast more votes for an office than that voter is entitled to vote for that office, the poll workers shall count the valid write-in vote as being the obvious intent of the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(8)(a): The election officer shall certify the return printed by the automatic tabulating equipment, to which have been added write-in and absentee votes, as the official return of each voting precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(8)(b): Upon completion of the count, the election officer shall make official returns open to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(9): If for any reason it becomes impracticable to count all or a part of the ballots with tabulating equipment, the election officer may direct that they be counted manually according to the procedures and requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-104(10): 20A-4-202 After the count is completed, the election officer shall seal and retain the programs, test materials, and ballots as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105 Standards and requirements for evaluating voter's ballot choice.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(1): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(1)(a): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project An election officer shall ensure that when a question arises regarding a vote recorded on a manual ballot, two counting judges jointly adjudicate the ballot, except as otherwise provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(1)(b): If the counting judges disagree on the disposition of a vote recorded on a ballot that is adjudicated under this section, the counting judges may not count the vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(1)(c): An election officer shall store adjudicated ballots separately from other ballots to enable a court to review the ballots if the election is challenged in court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(2): (10); 20A-3a-204(6); Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(3): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as otherwise provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(3)(a): the defective or incomplete mark  is in the proper place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(3)(b): there is no other mark or cross on the ballot indicating the voter's intent to vote other than as indicated by the incomplete or defective mark.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(4): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as otherwise provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(5): Chapter 3a, Voting
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(5)(a): In counting the ballots, the counting judges shall give full consideration to the intent of the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(5)(b): Chapter 3a, Voting The counting judges may not invalidate a ballot because of mechanical or technical defects in voting or failure on the part of the voter to follow strictly the rules for balloting required by
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(6): The counting judges may not reject a ballot because of an error in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(6)(a): stamping or writing an official endorsement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(6)(b): delivering the wrong ballots to a polling place.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(7): The counting judges may not count a manual ballot that does not have the official endorsement by an election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(8): 20A-4-107 The counting judges may not count a ballot proposition vote or candidate vote for which the voter is not legally entitled to vote, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(9): If the  counting judges discover  that the name of a candidate is misspelled on a ballot, or that the initial letters of a candidate's given name are transposed or omitted in whole or in part on a ballot, the counting judges shall count a voter's vote for the candidate if it is apparent that the voter intended to vote for the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(10): The counting judges shall count a vote for the president and the vice president of any political party as a vote for the presidential electors selected by the political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-105(11): Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project Except as otherwise provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106 Manual ballots -- Sealing.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(1): After the official canvas of an election, the election officer shall store all election returns in containers that identify the containers' contents.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2): (1); 20A-4-401; Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project; 36-12-15.2 After the ballots are stored under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(a): 20A-4-401; Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project when examined during a recount conducted under the authority of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(b): 36-12-15.2 an auditor conducting an audit described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(b)(i): if the audit uncovers evidence that raises a substantial doubt regarding the accuracy of the results of an election, the auditor may examine the ballots until the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(b)(i)(A): the end of the calendar year in which the election was held; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(b)(i)(B): if the election is contested, when the contest is resolved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(b)(ii): at any time via a subpoena or other legal process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(c): the lieutenant governor may examine the ballots:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(c)(i): until the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(c)(i)(A): the end of the calendar year in which the election was held; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(c)(i)(B): if the election is contested, when the contest is resolved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-106(2)(c)(ii): at any time via a subpoena or other legal process.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107 Review and disposition of provisional ballot envelopes.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1): As used in this section, an individual is "legally entitled to vote" if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(a): the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(a)(i): is registered to vote in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(a)(ii): votes the ballot for the voting precinct in which the individual resides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(a)(iii): provides valid voter identification to the poll worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b): the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b)(i): is registered to vote in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b)(ii)(A): provided valid voter identification to the poll worker; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b)(ii)(B): either failed to provide valid voter identification or the documents provided as valid voter identification were inadequate and the poll worker recorded that fact in the official register but the county clerk verifies the individual's identity and residence through some other means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(b)(iii): did not vote in the individual's precinct of residence, but the ballot that the individual voted was from the individual's county of residence and includes one or more candidates or ballot propositions on the ballot voted in the individual's precinct of residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c): the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c)(i): is registered to vote in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c)(ii): either failed to provide valid voter identification or the documents provided as valid voter identification were inadequate and the poll worker recorded that fact in the official register; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c)(iii)(A): the county clerk verifies the individual's identity and residence through some other means as reliable as photo identification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(1)(c)(iii)(B): the individual provides valid voter identification to the county clerk or an election officer who is administering the election by the close of normal office hours on Monday after the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2): 20A-2-207; 20A-4-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(a): Upon receipt of a provisional ballot form, the election officer shall review the affirmation on the provisional ballot form and determine if the individual signing the affirmation is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(a)(i): registered to vote in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(a)(ii): legally entitled to vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(a)(ii)(A): the ballot that the individual voted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(a)(ii)(B): if the ballot is from the individual's county of residence, for at least one ballot proposition or candidate on the ballot that the individual voted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(b): 20A-2-207; 20A-4-202 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(c): If the election officer determines that the individual is registered to vote in this state and is legally entitled to vote in the county and for at least one of the ballot propositions or candidates on the ballot that the individual voted, the election officer shall place the provisional ballot with the regular ballots to be counted with those ballots at the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(2)(d): The election officer may not count, or allow to be counted a provisional ballot unless the individual's identity and residence is established by a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(3): 20A-2-207 If the election officer determines that the individual is registered to vote in this state, or if the voter registers to vote in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(4): 20A-2-207 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(4)(a): consider the provisional ballot form a voter registration form for the individual's county of residence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(4)(b)(i): register the individual if the individual's county of residence is within the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(4)(b)(ii): forward the voter registration form to the election officer of the individual's county of residence, which election officer shall register the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5): (5)(a)(ii)(B) Notwithstanding any provision of this section, the election officer shall place a provisional ballot with the regular ballots to be counted with those ballots at the canvass, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a): (5)(a)(ii)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(i): the election officer determines, in accordance with the provisions of this section, that the sole reason a provisional ballot may not otherwise be counted is because the voter registration was filed less than 11 days before the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(ii): 11 or more days before the election, the individual who cast the provisional ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(ii)(A): completed and signed the voter registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(ii)(B): provided the voter registration to another person to file;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(iii): (5)(a)(ii)(B) the late filing was made due to the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(a)(iv): the election officer receives the voter registration before 5 p.m. no later than one day before the day of the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-107(5)(b): the provisional ballot is cast on or before election day and is not otherwise prohibited from being counted under the provisions of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109 Ballot reconciliation -- Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1): In accordance with this section and rules made under Subsection (2), an election officer whose office processes ballots shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(a): conduct ballot reconciliations every time ballots are tabulated;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(b): conduct a final ballot reconciliation when an election officer concludes processing all ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(c): document each ballot reconciliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(d): publicly release the results of each ballot reconciliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(e): in conducting ballot reconciliations:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(e)(i): ensure that the sum of the number of uncounted verified ballots and the number of ballots tabulated is equal to the number of voters given credit for voting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(1)(e)(ii): if the sum described in Subsection (1)(e)(i) is not equal to the number of voters given credit for voting, account for and explain the differences in the numbers.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-109(2): The director of elections within the Office of the Lieutenant Governor may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, establishing procedures and requirements for conducting, documenting, and publishing a ballot reconciliation.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201 Delivery of election returns.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(1): 20A-4-103(3)(d) At least two poll workers shall deliver the ballots and other items described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(1)(a): the election officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(1)(b): the location directed by the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(2)(a): Before they adjourn, the poll workers shall choose two or more of their number to deliver the election returns to the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(2)(b): The poll workers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(2)(b)(i): deliver the unopened envelopes to the election officer or counting center immediately but no later than 24 hours after the polls close; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(2)(b)(ii): if the polling place is 15 miles or more from the county seat, mail the election returns to the election officer by registered mail from the post office most convenient to the polling place within 24 hours after the polls close.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(3): The election officer shall pay each poll worker reasonable compensation for travel that is necessary to deliver the election returns and to return to the polling place.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-201(4): The requirements of this section do not prohibit transmission of the unofficial vote count to the counting center via electronic means, provided that reasonable security measures are taken to preserve the integrity and privacy of the transmission.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202 Election officers -- Disposition of ballots -- Release of number of provisional ballots cast.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1): Upon receipt of the election returns from the poll workers, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(a): ensure that the poll workers have provided all of the ballots and election returns;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(b): inspect the ballots and election returns to ensure that they are sealed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(c): for manual ballots, deposit and lock the ballots and election returns in a safe and secure place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(d): for mechanical ballots:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(d)(i): count the ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(d)(ii): deposit and lock the ballots and election returns in a safe and secure place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(1)(e): for bond elections, provide a copy of the election results to the board of canvassers of the local political subdivision that called the bond election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(2): Each election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(2)(a): before 5 p.m. on the day after the date of the election, determine the number of provisional ballots cast within the election officer's jurisdiction and make that number available to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(2)(b): preserve ballots for 22 months after the election or until the time has expired during which the ballots could be used in an election contest;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(2)(c): preserve all other official election returns for at least 22 months after an election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(2)(d): after that time, destroy them without opening or examining them.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(a): The election officer shall package and retain all tabulating cards and other materials used in the programming of the automatic tabulating equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(b): The election officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(b)(i): may access these tabulating cards and other materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(b)(ii): may make copies of these materials and make changes to the copies;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(b)(iii): may not alter or make changes to the materials themselves; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(3)(b)(iv): within 22 months after the election in which they were used, may dispose of those materials or retain them.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4): (4)(c); (4)(c); 36-12-15.2; (4); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(a): (4)(c) If an election contest is begun within 12 months, the election officer shall, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(a)(i): keep the ballots and election returns unopened and unaltered until the contest is complete; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(a)(ii): surrender the ballots and election returns to the custody of the court having jurisdiction of the contest when ordered or subpoenaed to do so by that court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(b): (4)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(b)(i): retain the ballots and election returns until the time for preserving them under this section has run; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(b)(ii): destroy the ballots and election returns remaining in the election officer's custody without opening or examining them if the time for preserving them under this section has run.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(c): 36-12-15.2; (4); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(c)(i): 36-12-15.2; (4) An auditor conducting an audit described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(4)(c)(ii): (4) The lieutenant governor may examine the ballots and election returns described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(5): (5)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(5)(a): Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the legislative auditor general:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(5)(a)(i): may make and keep copies of ballots or election returns as part of a legislative audit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(5)(a)(ii): may not examine, make copies, or keep copies, of a ballot in a manner that identifies a ballot with the voter who casts the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-202(5)(b): (5)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act A copy described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301 Board of canvassers.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a): Each county legislative body is the board of county canvassers for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a)(i): the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a)(ii): each special district whose election is conducted by the county if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a)(ii)(A): the election relates to the creation of the special district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a)(ii)(B): the county legislative body serves as the governing body of the special district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(a)(ii)(C): there is no duly constituted governing body of the special district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(b): The board of county canvassers shall meet to canvass the returns at the usual place of meeting of the county legislative body, at a date and time determined by the county clerk that is no sooner than seven days after the election and no later than 14 days after the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(c): If one or more of the county legislative body fails to attend the meeting of the board of county canvassers, the remaining members shall replace the absent member by appointing in the order named:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(c)(i): the county treasurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(c)(ii): the county assessor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(c)(iii): the county sheriff.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(d): Attendance of the number of persons equal to a simple majority of the county legislative body, but not less than three persons, shall constitute a quorum for conducting the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(1)(e): The county clerk is the clerk of the board of county canvassers.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2)(a): The mayor and the municipal legislative body are the board of municipal canvassers for the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2)(b): The board of municipal canvassers shall meet to canvass the returns at the usual place of meeting of the municipal legislative body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2)(b)(i): for canvassing of returns from a municipal general election, no sooner than seven days after the election and no later than 14 days after the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2)(b)(ii): for canvassing of returns from a municipal primary election, no sooner than seven days after the election and no later than 14 days after the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(2)(c): Attendance of a simple majority of the municipal legislative body shall constitute a quorum for conducting the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(3): 11-14-207
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(3)(a): The legislative body of the entity authorizing a bond election is the board of canvassers for each bond election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(3)(b): 11-14-207 The board of canvassers for the bond election shall comply with the canvassing procedures and requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(3)(c): Attendance of a simple majority of the legislative body of the entity authorizing a bond election shall constitute a quorum for conducting the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(4)(a): If a board of trustees or an administrative control board is the governing body of a special district, the board of trustees or the administrative control board is the board of special district canvassers for the special district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(4)(b): The board of special district canvassers shall meet to canvass the returns at the usual place of meeting for the board of trustees or the administrative control board, as applicable, at a date and time determined by the special district clerk that is no sooner than seven days after the day of the election and no later than 14 days after the day of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(4)(c): Attendance of a simple majority of the board of trustees or the administrative control board is a quorum for conducting the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(5): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4; 53G-3-302 In relation to an election for the creation of a new school district under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(5)(a): if the voters permitted to vote in the election are all residents of the same municipality, the mayor and the municipal legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(5)(b): if the voters permitted to vote in the election are not all residents of the same municipality, but are all residents of the same county, the county legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-301(5)(c): if the voters permitted to vote in the election are not all residents of the same municipality and are not all residents of the same county, the county legislative body of the county where the majority of the voters permitted to vote in the election are residents.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302 Duties of the board of canvassers -- Receiving returns.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(1): If the election returns from each voting precinct in which polls were opened have been received at the time the board of canvassers convenes, the board of canvassers shall canvass the election returns as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(2): If all of the election returns have not been received, the board shall postpone the canvass from day to day, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, until:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(2)(a): all of the election returns are received; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(2)(b): the board has postponed the canvass seven times.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(3)(a): If the election officer has not received the election returns from any voting precinct within seven days after the election, the election officer shall send a messenger to the judges to obtain the missing election returns.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(3)(b): The messenger shall obtain the election returns from the judges and return the election returns to the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(3)(c): The election officer shall pay the messenger 10 cents per mile for the distance necessarily traveled.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(4): If the board determines that election returns were not received from a voting precinct because the polls did not open in that precinct, the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(4)(a): sign a certificate attesting to that fact; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-302(4)(b): file the certificate with the election officer.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303 Duties of the board of canvassers -- Canvassing the returns.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a): Before the board of canvassers convenes, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a)(i): count the ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a)(ii): prepare a certified summary of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a)(ii)(A): all ballots counted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a)(ii)(B): all ballots not counted, with an explanation regarding the reason the ballots were not counted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(a)(iii): make available to the board of canvassers for inspection, all ballots, registers, books, and forms related to the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(b): The board of canvassers shall canvass the election returns by publicly:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(b)(i): reviewing the summary reports prepared by the election officer and any ballots, registers, books, or forms requested by the board of canvassers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(b)(ii): certifying the votes cast:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(b)(ii)(A): each person voted for; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(b)(ii)(B): for and against each ballot proposition voted upon at the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(1)(c): The board of canvassers shall, once having begun the canvass, continue until it is completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2): In canvassing returns, the board of canvassers may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(a): reject any election returns if the board can determine the number of votes cast for each person from it;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(b): reject any election returns if the election returns:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(b)(i): do not show who administered the oath to the judges of election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(b)(ii): show that the election judges failed to fill out all the certificates in the pollbooks; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(b)(iii): show that the election judges failed to do or perform any other act in preparing the returns that is not essential to determine for whom the votes were cast; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(2)(c): reject any returns from any voting precinct that do not conform with the requirements for making, certifying, and returning the returns if those returns are sufficiently explicit to enable the board of canvassers to determine the number of votes cast for each person and for and against each ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(3)(a): If it clearly appears to the election officer and board of canvassers that certain matters are omitted or that clerical mistakes exist in election returns received, the election officer shall correct the omissions and mistakes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(3)(b): The clerk and the board of canvassers may adjourn from day to day to await receipt of corrected election material.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-303(4): 20A-4-401; 20A-4-401 If a recount is conducted as authorized by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304 Declaration of results -- Canvassers' report.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(a): Except as provided in Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, a board of canvassers shall declare "elected" or "nominated" those persons who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(a)(i): had the highest number of votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(a)(ii): sought election or nomination to an office completely within the board's jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(b): Except as provided in Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, a board of canvassers shall declare a "tie vote" if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(b)(i): two or more candidates for an office receive an equal and the highest number of votes for that office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(b)(ii): in a race for an at-large office:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(b)(ii)(A): two or more candidates receive an equal number of votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(b)(ii)(B): a recount is necessary to determine which candidates are elected to the at-large office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c): A board of canvassers shall declare:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(i): "approved" those ballot propositions that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(i)(A): had more "yes" votes than "no" votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(i)(B): were submitted only to the voters within the board's jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(ii): "rejected" those ballot propositions that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(ii)(A): had more "no" votes than "yes" votes or an equal number of "no" votes and "yes" votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(c)(ii)(B): were submitted only to the voters within the board's jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(d): A board of canvassers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(d)(i): certify the vote totals for persons and for and against ballot propositions that were submitted to voters within and beyond the board's jurisdiction and transmit those vote totals to the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(1)(d)(ii): if applicable, certify the results of each special district election to the special district clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2): The election officer shall submit a report to the board of canvassers that includes the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(a): the total number of votes cast in the board's jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(b): the names of each candidate whose name appeared on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(c): the title of each ballot proposition that appeared on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(d): each office that appeared on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(e): from each voting precinct:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(e)(i): the number of votes for each candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(e)(ii): for each race conducted by instant runoff voting under Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, the number of valid votes cast for each candidate for each potential ballot-counting phase and the name of the candidate excluded in each ballot-counting phase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(e)(iii): the number of votes for and against each ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(f): the total number of votes given in the board's jurisdiction to each candidate, and for and against each ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(g): standardized statistics, on a form provided by the lieutenant governor, disclosing:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(g)(i): the number of ballots counted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(g)(ii): provisional ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(g)(iii): the number of ballots rejected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(h): a final ballot reconciliation report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(i): other information required by law to be provided to the board of canvassers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(2)(j): a statement certifying that the information contained in the report is accurate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(3): The election officer and the board of canvassers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(3)(a): review the report to ensure that the report is correct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(3)(b): sign the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(4): The election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(4)(a): record or file the certified report in a book kept for that purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(4)(b): prepare and transmit a certificate of nomination or election under the officer's seal to each nominated or elected candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(4)(c): publish a copy of the certified report in accordance with Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(4)(d): file a copy of the certified report with the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(5): 63G-30-102 Except as provided in Subsection (6), the election officer shall, no later than seven days after the day on which the board of canvassers declares the election results, publicize the certified report described in Subsection (2) for the jurisdiction, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6): Instead of including a copy of the entire certified report, a notice required under Subsection (5) may contain a statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6)(a): includes the following: "The Board of Canvassers for [indicate name of jurisdiction] has prepared a report of the election results for the [indicate type and date of election]."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6)(b): specifies the following sources where an individual may view or obtain a copy of the entire certified report:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6)(b)(i): if the jurisdiction has a website, the jurisdiction's website;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6)(b)(ii): the physical address for the jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(6)(b)(iii): a mailing address and telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(7): When there has been a regular general or a statewide special election for statewide officers, for officers that appear on the ballot in more than one county, or for a statewide or two or more county ballot proposition, each board of canvassers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(7)(a): prepare a separate report detailing the number of votes for each candidate and the number of votes for and against each ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(7)(b): transmit the separate report by registered mail to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(8): In each county election, municipal election, school election, special district election, and local special election, the election officer shall transmit the reports to the lieutenant governor within 14 days after the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(9): In a regular primary election and in a presidential primary election, the board shall transmit to the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(9)(a): the county totals for multi-county races, to be telephoned or faxed to the lieutenant governor not later than the second Tuesday after the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-304(9)(b): a complete tabulation showing voting totals for all primary races, precinct by precinct, to be mailed to the lieutenant governor on or before the third Friday following the primary election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-305 Delivery of checked official register to county clerk after canvass.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Within 10 days after the canvass of a November municipal election, special district election, bond election, or special election, the clerk or recorder shall transmit the checked official register to the county clerk.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306 Statewide canvass.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1)(a): The state board of canvassers shall convene:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1)(a)(i): on the fourth Monday of November, at noon; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1)(a)(ii): at noon on the day following the receipt by the lieutenant governor of the last of the returns of a statewide special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1)(b): The state auditor, the state treasurer, and the attorney general are the state board of canvassers.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(1)(c): Attendance of all members of the state board of canvassers is required to constitute a quorum for conducting the canvass.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(a): The state board of canvassers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(a)(i): meet in the lieutenant governor's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(a)(ii): compute and determine the vote for officers and for and against any ballot propositions voted upon by the voters of the entire state or of two or more counties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b): The lieutenant governor, as secretary of the board shall file a report in the lieutenant governor's office that details:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i): for each statewide officer and ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i)(A): the name of the statewide office or ballot proposition that appeared on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i)(B): the candidates for each statewide office whose names appeared on the ballot, plus any recorded write-in candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i)(C): the number of votes from each county cast for each candidate and for and against each ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i)(D): the total number of votes cast statewide for each candidate and for and against each ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(i)(E): the total number of votes cast statewide; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(ii): for each officer or ballot proposition voted on in two or more counties:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(ii)(A): the name of each of those offices and ballot propositions that appeared on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(ii)(B): the candidates for those offices, plus any recorded write-in candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(ii)(C): the number of votes from each county cast for each candidate and for and against each ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(b)(ii)(D): the total number of votes cast for each candidate and for and against each ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(d), the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(i): prepare certificates of election for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(i)(A): each successful candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(i)(B): each of the presidential electors of the candidate for president who received a majority of the votes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(ii): authenticate each certificate with the lieutenant governor's seal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(iii): deliver a certificate of election to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(iii)(A): each candidate who had the highest number of votes for each office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(c)(iii)(B): each of the presidential electors of the candidate for president who received a majority of the votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(d): The lieutenant governor shall, in the report described in Subsection (2)(b), declare a tie vote if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(d)(i): two or more officers receive an equal and the highest number of votes for an office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(d)(ii): in a race for an at-large office:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(d)(ii)(A): two or more candidates receive an equal number of votes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(2)(d)(ii)(B): a recount is necessary to determine which candidates are elected to the at-large office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(3): 20A-4-304 If the lieutenant governor has not received election returns from all counties on the fifth day before the day designated for the meeting of the state board of canvassers, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(3)(a): send a messenger to the clerk of the board of county canvassers of the delinquent county;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(3)(b): 20A-4-304 instruct the messenger to demand a certified copy of the board of canvasser's report required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(3)(c): pay the messenger the per diem provided by law as compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(4): The state board of canvassers may not withhold the declaration of the result or any certificate of election because of any defect or informality in the returns of any election if the board can determine from the returns, with reasonable certainty, what office is intended and who is elected to it.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(5)(a): At noon on the fourth Monday after the regular primary election, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(5)(a)(i): canvass the returns for all multicounty candidates required to file with the office of the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(5)(a)(ii): publish and file the results of the canvass in the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(5)(b): Not later than the August 1 after the primary election, the lieutenant governor shall certify the results of the primary canvass to the county clerks.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(6)(a): At noon on the fourth Tuesday in March of a year in which a presidential election will be held, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(6)(a)(i): canvass the returns of the presidential primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(6)(a)(ii): publish and file the results of the canvass in the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-306(6)(b): The lieutenant governor shall certify the results of the presidential primary election canvass to each registered political party that participated in the primary not later than the April 15 after the primary election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401 Recounts -- Procedure.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(1): This section does not apply to a race conducted by instant runoff voting under Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(2): The election officer shall conduct a recount of votes cast in a race if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(2)(a): two or more candidates for an office receive an equal and the highest number of votes for that office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(2)(b): in a race for an at-large office, two or more candidates receive an equal number of votes and at least one of the candidates must be eliminated to determine which candidates are elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(3)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2) or (3)(b), for a race between candidates, if the difference between the number of votes cast for a winning candidate in the race and a losing candidate in the race is equal to or less than .25% of the total number of votes cast for all candidates in the race, the losing candidate may file a request for a recount in accordance with Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(3)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (2), for a race between candidates where the total of all votes cast in the race is 400 or less, if the difference between the number of votes cast for a winning candidate in the race and a losing candidate in the race is one vote, the losing candidate may file a request for a recount in accordance with Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4): A losing candidate who files a request for a recount under Subsection (3)(a) or (b) shall file the request:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(a): for a municipal primary election, with the municipal clerk, before 5 p.m., no later than three days after the day on which the canvass is completed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(b): for all other elections, before 5 p.m., no later than seven days after the day on which the canvass is completed, with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(b)(i): the municipal clerk, if the election is a municipal general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(b)(ii): the special district clerk, if the election is a special district election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(b)(iii): the county clerk, for a race voted on entirely within a single county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(4)(b)(iv): the lieutenant governor, for a statewide race or multi-county race.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5): 20A-1-304
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(a): The election officer shall conduct the recount:
