Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(a)(i): for a race described in Subsection (2), no later than 10 days after the day on which the board of canvassers certifies the vote totals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(a)(ii): for a race described in Subsection (3), no later than seven days after the day on which the losing candidate requests the recount.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b): 20A-1-304 In conducting the recount, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(i): supervise the recount;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(ii): recount all ballots cast in the race;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iii): reexamine all uncounted ballots to ensure compliance with Chapter 3a, Part 4, Disposition of Ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iv): 20A-1-304
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iv)(A): for a race between candidates for a single office, declare elected the candidate who receives the highest number of votes on the recount;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iv)(B): for a race for an at-large office, declare elected the candidate who receives the highest number of votes on the recount, until all offices are filled by the candidates who received the highest number of votes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iv)(C): for a race described in Subsection (5)(b)(iv)(A) in which two or more candidates receive an equal and the highest number of votes, declare a tie vote; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(5)(b)(iv)(D): 20A-1-304 for a race described in Subsection (5)(b)(iv)(B) in which two or more candidates receive an equal number of votes, declare a tie vote if the selection of the winning candidate by lot under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(6): The cost of a recount under Subsection (5) shall be paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(6)(a): for a statewide race or multi-county race, the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(6)(b): for all other races:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(6)(b)(i): the political subdivision that conducts the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(6)(b)(ii): the political subdivision that enters into a contract or interlocal agreement under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, with a provider election officer to conduct the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(7)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(b), for a ballot proposition or a bond proposition, if the proposition passes or fails by a margin that is equal to or less than .25% of the total votes cast for or against the proposition, any 10 voters who voted in the election where the proposition was on the ballot may file a request for a recount before 5 p.m. within seven days after the day of the canvass with the person described in Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(7)(b): For a ballot proposition or a bond proposition where the total of all votes cast for or against the proposition is 400 or less, if the difference between the number of votes cast for the proposition and the number of votes cast against the proposition is one vote, any 10 voters who voted in the election where the proposition was on the ballot may file a request for a recount before 5 p.m. within seven days after the day of the canvass with the person described in Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(8): The 10 voters who file a request for a recount under Subsection (7)(a) or (b) shall file the request with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(8)(a): the municipal clerk, if the election is a municipal election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(8)(b): the special district clerk, if the election is a special district election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(8)(c): the county clerk, for a proposition voted on entirely within a single county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(8)(d): the lieutenant governor, for a statewide proposition or multi-county proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(a): In conducting the recount, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(a)(i): supervise the recount;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(a)(ii): recount all ballots cast for the ballot proposition or bond proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(a)(iii): reexamine all uncounted ballots to ensure compliance with Chapter 3a, Part 4, Disposition of Ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(a)(iv): declare the ballot proposition or bond proposition to have "passed" or "failed" based upon the results of the recount.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(9)(b): Proponents and opponents of the ballot proposition or bond proposition may designate representatives to witness the recount.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(10): The voters requesting a recount under Subsection (7)(a) or (b) shall pay the costs of the recount.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11): 20A-4-304; 20A-4-306; 20A-4-304
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(a): Upon completing a recount described in Subsection (5) or (9), the election officer shall immediately convene the board of canvassers.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(b): 20A-4-304; 20A-4-306 The board of canvassers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(b)(i): canvass the election returns for the race or proposition that was the subject of the recount; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(b)(ii): 20A-4-304; 20A-4-306 with the assistance of the election officer, prepare and sign the report required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(c): 20A-4-304 If the recount is for a statewide race, multi-county race, or a statewide proposition, the board of county canvassers shall prepare and transmit a separate report to the lieutenant governor as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-401(11)(d): The canvassers' report prepared as provided in this Subsection (11) is the official result of the race or proposition that is the subject of the recount.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402 Election contests -- Grounds.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1): The election or nomination of any person to any public office, and the declared result of the vote on any ballot proposition or bond proposition submitted to a vote of the people may be contested according to the procedures established in this part only:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(a): for malconduct, fraud, or corruption on the part of the judges of election at any polling place, or of any board of canvassers, or any judge or member of the board sufficient to change the result;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(b): when the person declared elected was not eligible for the office at the time of the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(c): when the person declared elected has:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(c)(i): given or offered to any registered voter, judge, or canvasser of the election any bribe or reward in money, property, or anything of value for the purpose of influencing the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(c)(ii): committed any other offense against the elective franchise;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(d): when illegal votes have been received or legal votes have been rejected at the polls sufficient to change the result;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(e): for any error of any board of canvassers or judges of election in counting the votes or declaring the result of the election, if the error would change the result;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(f): when the election result would change because a sufficient number of ballots containing uncorrected errors or omissions have been received at the polls;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(g): when the candidate declared elected is ineligible to serve in the office to which the candidate was elected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(h): when an election judge or clerk was a party to malconduct, fraud, or corruption sufficient to change the result of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(1)(i): for any other cause that shows that another person was legally elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(2): Any irregularity or improper conduct by the election judges does not void an election unless the irregularity or improper conduct would result in the election of a person who did not receive the highest number of legal votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-402(3): When any election held for any office is contested because of any irregularity or improper conduct on the part of a judge of any voting precinct, a court, upon proof of the irregularity or improper conduct may not set aside the election unless the irregularity or improper conduct would change the result for that office.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403 Election contest -- Petition and response.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1): 20A-4-402; (1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(a): In contesting the results of all elections, except for primary elections and bond elections, a registered voter may contest the right of an individual declared elected to office by filing a verified written complaint with the district court of the county in which the registered voter resides within 40 days after the day on which the canvass concludes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b): 20A-4-402 The complaint shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(i): the name of the voter contesting the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(ii): a statement that the voter is a registered voter in the jurisdiction in which the election was held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(iii): the name of the individual whose right to the office is contested;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(iv): the office to which the individual was ostensibly elected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(v): 20A-4-402 one or more of the grounds for an election contest specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(vi): the individual who was purportedly elected to the office as respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(b)(vii): if the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a ground for the contest, the name and address of all individuals who allegedly cast illegal votes or whose legal vote was rejected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(c): When the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a cause of contest, it is sufficient to state generally that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(c)(i): illegal votes were given in one or more specified voting precincts to an individual whose election is contested, which, if taken from the individual, would reduce the number of legal votes for the individual below the number of legal votes given to another individual for the same office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(c)(ii): legal votes for another individual were rejected, which, if counted, would raise the number of legal votes for that individual above the number of legal votes cast for the individual whose election is contested.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(d): (1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(d)(i): (1)(c) The court may not take or receive evidence of any of the votes described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(1)(d)(ii): The court may not take or receive any evidence of contested votes except those that are specified in that list.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2): (1); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(a): In contesting the results of a primary election, when contesting the petition nominating an independent candidate, or when challenging any person, election officer, election official, board, or convention for failing to nominate an individual, a registered voter may contest the right of an individual declared nominated to office by filing a verified written complaint within 10 days after the day on which the canvass for the primary election concludes, after the date of filing of the petition, or after the date of the convention, respectively, with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(a)(i): the district court of the county in which the registered voter resides if the registered voter is contesting a nomination made only by voters from that county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(a)(ii): the Utah Supreme Court, if the registered voter is contesting a nomination made by voters in more than one county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b): (1) The complaint shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(i): the name of the voter contesting the nomination;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(ii): a statement that the voter contesting the nomination is a registered voter in the jurisdiction in which the election was held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(iii): the name of the individual whose right to nomination is contested or the name of the individual who failed to have their name placed in nomination;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(iv): the office to which the individual was nominated or should have been nominated;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(v): (1) one or more of the grounds for an election contest specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(vi): the individual who was purportedly nominated to the office as respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(b)(vii): if the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a ground for the contest, the name and address of all individuals who allegedly cast illegal votes or whose legal vote was rejected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(c): When the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a cause of contest, it is sufficient to state generally that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(c)(i): illegal votes were given to an individual whose election is contested, which, if taken from the individual, would reduce the number of legal votes given to the individual below the number of legal votes given to another individual for the same office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(c)(ii): legal votes for another individual were rejected, which, if counted, would raise the number of legal votes for that individual above the number of legal votes cast for the individual whose election is contested.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(d): (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(d)(i): (2)(c) The court may not take or receive evidence of any votes described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(2)(d)(ii): The court may not take or receive any evidence of contested votes except those that are specified in that list.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3): 11-14-207; 20A-4-402; (3)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(a): 11-14-207 In contesting the results of a bond election, a registered voter may contest the validity of the declared results by filing a verified written complaint with the district court of the county in which the registered voter resides within 40 days after the date of the official finding entered under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b): 20A-4-402 The complaint shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b)(i): the name of the voter contesting the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b)(ii): a statement that the voter is a registered voter in the jurisdiction in which the election was held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b)(iii): the bond proposition that is the subject of the contest;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b)(iv): 20A-4-402 one or more of the grounds for an election contest specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(b)(v): if the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a ground for the contest, the name and address of all individuals who allegedly cast illegal votes or whose legal vote was rejected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(c): When the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a cause of contest, it is sufficient to state generally that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(c)(i): illegal votes were counted in one or more specified voting precincts which, if taken out of the count, would change the declared result of the vote on the proposition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(c)(ii): legal votes were rejected in one or more specified voting precincts, which, if counted, would change the declared result of the vote on the proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(d): (3)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(d)(i): (3)(c) The court may not take or receive evidence of any of the votes described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(3)(d)(ii): The court may not take or receive any evidence of contested votes except those that are specified in that list.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(4): The court may not reject any statement of the grounds of contest or dismiss the proceedings because of lack of form, if the grounds of the contest are alleged with sufficient certainty as will advise the defendant of the particular proceeding or cause for which the election is contested.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(a): The petitioner shall serve a copy of the petition on the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(b)(i): If the petitioner cannot obtain personal service of the petition on the respondent, the petitioner may serve the respondent by leaving a copy of the petition with the clerk of the court with which the petition was filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(b)(ii): The clerk shall make diligent inquiry and attempt to inform the respondent that the respondent has five days to answer the complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(c): The respondent shall answer the petition within five days after the day of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(d): If the reception of illegal votes or the rejection of legal votes is alleged as a ground for the contest, the defendant shall include in the answer the name and address of all individuals whom the respondent believes were properly or improperly admitted or denied the vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(5)(e): If the answer contains a counterclaim, the petitioner shall file a reply within 10 days after the day of service of the counterclaim.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6): (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(a): (6) The provisions of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(b): Municipal election contests shall be filed, tried, and determined in the district court of the county in which the municipality is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(i): As a condition precedent to filing a municipal election contest, the petitioner shall file a written affidavit of intention to contest the election with the clerk of the court within seven days after the day on which the votes are canvassed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii): The affidavit shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(A): the petitioner's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(B): the fact that the petitioner is a qualified voter of the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(C): the respondent's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(D): the elective office contested;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(E): the time of election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(c)(ii)(F): the grounds for the contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(d)(i): Before the district court takes jurisdiction of a municipal election contest, the petitioner shall file a bond with the clerk of the court with the sureties required by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-403(6)(d)(ii): The bond shall name the respondent as obligee and be conditioned for the payment of all costs incurred by the respondent if the respondent prevails.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404 Election contest -- Calendaring and disposition.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(a): Upon receipt of the petition, the clerk shall inform the chief judge of the court having jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(b): The chief judge shall issue an order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(b)(i): assigning the case to a district court judge, if the district court has jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(b)(ii): setting a date and time, not less than 10 nor more than 30 days from the date the petition was filed to hear and determine the contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(c): The clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(c)(i): issue a subpoena for the person whose right to the office is contested to appear at the time and place specified in the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(1)(c)(ii): cause the subpoena to be served.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(2): The court shall meet at the time and place designated to determine the contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(3)(a): If it is necessary for the court to inspect the ballots of any voting precinct in order to determine any election contest the judge may order the proper officer to produce them.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(3)(b): The judge shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(3)(b)(i): open and inspect the ballots in open court in the presence of the parties or their attorneys; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(3)(b)(ii): immediately after the inspection, seal them in an envelope and return them, by mail or otherwise, to their legal custodian.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4)(a): If the petition, response, or counterclaim alleges an error in the canvass sufficient to change the result, the court may order and conduct a recount of the ballots or vote tabulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4)(b): The court may also require the production of any documents, records, and other evidence necessary to enable it to determine the legality or illegality of any vote cast or counted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4)(c)(i): After all the evidence in the contest is submitted, the court shall enter its judgment, either confirming the election result or annulling and setting aside the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-404(4)(c)(ii): If the court determines that a person other than the one declared elected received the highest number of legal votes, the court shall declare that person elected.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405 Election contests -- Costs.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(1): The court shall enter judgment for costs against the party contesting the election if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(1)(a): the proceedings are dismissed for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(1)(a)(i): insufficiency of pleading or proof; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(1)(a)(ii): want of prosecution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(1)(b): the election is confirmed by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(2): The court shall enter judgment for costs against the party whose election was contested if the election is annulled and set aside.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(3)(a): Each party is liable for the costs of the officers and witnesses that appeared on the party's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-405(3)(b): The party may pay, and the officers and witnesses may collect, those costs in the same manner as similar costs are paid and collected in other cases.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-406 Election contests -- Appeal.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-406(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-406(1)(a): Either party may appeal the district court's judgment to the Supreme Court as in other cases of appeal from the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-406(1)(b): When an appeal is taken, the district court may not stay execution or proceedings, except execution for costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-406(2): Whenever an election is annulled or set aside by the judgment of a court and no appeal is taken within 10 days, the certificate of election, if any has been issued, is void, and the office is vacant.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501 Election returns -- Forgery.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501(1): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501(1)(a): forge or counterfeit any election returns from any election purporting to have been held at any voting precinct where no election was in fact held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501(1)(b): willfully substitute any forged or counterfeit election returns in the place of the true return for a voting precinct where any election was actually held; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501(1)(c): commit or cause any fraud in any election in any manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-501(2): A violation of this section is a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-502 Altering vote count or returns.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-502(1): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-502(1)(a): willfully add to or subtract from the votes actually cast at an election in any election returns; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-502(1)(b): alter any election returns.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-502(2): Any person who violates this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-504 Interfering with count.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-504(1): It is unlawful for any person to intentionally ascertain, or attempt to ascertain, the progress or state of the count before the ballot count is completed in the voting precinct, or before 8 p.m., whichever is later.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-504(2): Any person who violates this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-505 Communicating about the count.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-505(1): It is unlawful for any poll worker to communicate in any manner, directly or indirectly, by word or sign, the progress of the count, the result so far, or any other information about the count.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-505(2): Any person who violates this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(1): "Candidate amplifier" means the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(1)(a): two less than the total number of candidates in a given ballot-counting phase of a multi-candidate race; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(1)(b): .02%.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(2): "First preference ranking" means the candidate selected as the candidate most preferred by a voter, as indicated by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(2)(a): the number one; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(2)(b): if the voter does not assign the number one to any candidate, the number two.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(3): "Multi-candidate race" means a nonpartisan municipal race where:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(3)(a): for the election of at-large officers, the number of candidates who qualify for the race exceeds the total number of seats to be filled; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(3)(b): for the election of an officer other than an at-large officer, more than two candidates qualify to run for one office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(4): 20A-4-602(3) "Participating municipality" means a municipality that is participating in the pilot project, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(5): 20A-4-602 "Pilot project" means the Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6): "Recount threshold" means the sum of the candidate amplifier and the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(a): for a ballot-counting phase in which fewer than 100 valid rankings are counted, 0.21%;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(b): for a ballot-counting phase in which at least 100, but fewer than 500, valid rankings are counted, 0.19%;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(c): for a ballot-counting phase in which at least 500, but fewer than 1,000, valid rankings are counted, 0.17%;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(d): for a ballot-counting phase in which at least 1,000, but fewer than 5,000, valid rankings are counted, 0.15%;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(e): for a ballot-counting phase in which at least 5,000, but fewer than 10,000, valid rankings are counted, 0.13%; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(6)(f): for a ballot-counting phase in which 10,000 or more valid rankings are counted, 0.11%.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-601(7): "Valid" means that the ballot is marked in a manner that permits the ranking to be counted during the applicable ballot-counting phase.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602 Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project -- Creation -- Participation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(1): There is created the Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(2): The pilot project begins on January 1, 2019, and ends on January 1, 2026.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(3)(a): A municipality may participate in the pilot project, in accordance with the requirements of this section and all other applicable provisions of law, during any odd-numbered year that the pilot project is in effect, if, before May 1 of the odd-numbered year, the legislative body of the municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(3)(a)(i): votes to participate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(3)(a)(ii): provides written notice to the lieutenant governor and the county clerk stating that the municipality intends to participate in the pilot project for the year specified in the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(3)(b): (3)(a) The legislative body of a municipality that provides the notice of intent described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(4): The lieutenant governor shall maintain, in a prominent place on the lieutenant governor's website, a current list of the municipalities that are participating in the pilot project.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(5): 20A-4-603(9); (5)(a); 20A-9-404(3); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(5)(a): An election officer of a participating municipality shall, in accordance with the provisions of this part, conduct a multi-candidate race during the municipal general election using instant runoff voting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(5)(b): 20A-4-603(9); (5)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(5)(c): 20A-9-404(3); (4) A municipality that has in effect an ordinance described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-602(6): 20A-4-603(9); 10-3-301 Except for an election described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603 Instant runoff voting.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1): (6); (1)(b)(ii); (1)(b)(ii); (1)(b); (6) In a multi-candidate race, the election officer for a participating municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(a)(i): conduct the first ballot-counting phase by counting the valid first preference rankings for each candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(a)(ii): if one of the candidates receives more than 50% of the valid first preference rankings counted, declare that candidate elected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b): (6); (1)(b)(ii) if, after counting the valid first preference rankings for each candidate, no candidate receives more than 50% of the valid first preference rankings counted, conduct the second ballot-counting phase by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b)(i): (6) excluding from the multi-candidate race:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b)(i)(A): the candidate who received the fewest valid first preference rankings counted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b)(i)(B): (6) in the event of a tie for the fewest valid first preference rankings counted, one of the tied candidates, determined by the election officer by lot, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b)(ii): adding, to the valid first preference rankings counted for the remaining candidates, the next valid preference rankings cast for the remaining candidates by the voters who cast a valid first preference ranking for the excluded candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(b)(iii): (1)(b)(ii) if, after adding the rankings in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(c): (1)(b)(ii); (1)(b); (6) if, after adding the next valid preference rankings in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(c)(i): (6) excluding from consideration the candidate who has the fewest valid rankings counted or, in the event of a tie for the fewest valid rankings counted, excluding one of the tied candidates, by lot, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(1)(c)(ii): adding the next valid preference ranking cast by each voter whose ranking was counted for the last excluded candidate to one of the remaining candidates, in the order of the next preference indicated by the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(2): (1) The election officer shall declare elected the first candidate who receives more than 50% of the valid rankings counted under the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3): A ranking is valid for a particular ballot-counting phase of a multi-candidate race if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(a): the voter indicates the voter's preference for that ballot-counting phase and all previous ballot-counting phases; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(b): in the event that the voter skips a number in filling out the rankings on a ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(b)(i): the voter clearly indicates an order of preference for the candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(b)(ii): the voter does not skip two or more consecutive numbers at any point before the preference ranking that would otherwise be counted for the current ballot-counting phase;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(b)(iii): the candidate next preferred by the voter is clearly indicated by a subsequent number that most closely follows the number assigned by the voter for the previously-ranked candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(3)(b)(iv): the voter did not give the same rank to more than one candidate for the applicable ballot-counting phase or a previous ballot-counting phase.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(4): A ranking is not valid for a particular ballot-counting phase of a multi-candidate race, and for all subsequent ballot-counting phases, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(4)(a): the voter indicates the same rank for more than one candidate for that ballot-counting phase; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(4)(b): the voter skips two or more consecutive numbers before ranking another candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(5): If, for a ballot-counting phase, a voter ranks a candidate who has withdrawn from the race, the next-ranked candidate who has not withdrawn from the race will be counted for that ballot-counting phase.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6): For each ballot-counting phase after the first phase, if two or more candidates tie as having received the fewest valid rankings counted at that point in the ballot count, the election officer shall eliminate one of those candidates from consideration, by lot, in the following manner:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6)(a): determine the names of the candidates who tie as having received the fewest valid rankings for that ballot-counting phase;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6)(b): cast the lot in the presence of at least two election officials and any counting poll watchers who are present and desire to witness the casting of the lot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6)(c): sign a public document that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6)(c)(i): certifies the method used for casting the lot and the result of the lot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(6)(c)(ii): includes the name of each individual who witnessed the casting of the lot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(7): (8); (1); (6); (7)(a); (7)(b) In a multi-candidate race for an at-large office, where the number of candidates who qualify for the race exceeds the total number of at-large seats to be filled for the office, the election officer shall count the rankings by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(7)(a): (8); (1); (6) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(7)(b): (7)(a) repeating the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(7)(c): (7)(b) continuing the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(8): (7); (1); (6) After a candidate is declared elected under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(9): (1); (6); (9)(a) An election officer for a participating municipality may choose to conduct a primary election by using instant runoff voting in the manner described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(9)(a): instead of determining whether a candidate receives more than 50% of the valid preference rankings for a particular ballot-counting phase, the election officer shall proceed to a subsequent ballot-counting stage, and exclude the candidate who receives the fewest valid preference rankings in that phase, until twice the number of seats to be filled in the race remain; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(9)(b): (9)(a) after complying with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10): After completing all ballot-counting phases in a multi-candidate race, the election officer shall order a full recount of the ballots cast for that race if, in one or more of the ballot-counting phases:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(a): the difference between the number of rankings counted for a candidate who is declared elected and the number of rankings counted for any other candidate in the same ballot-counting phase is equal to or less than the product of the following, rounded up to the nearest whole number:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(a)(i): the total number of voters who cast a valid ranking counted in that ballot-counting phase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(a)(ii): the recount threshold; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(b): the difference between the number of rankings counted for the candidate who received the fewest valid rankings in a ballot-counting phase and the number of rankings counted for any other candidate in the same ballot-counting phase is equal to or less than the product of the following, rounded up to the nearest whole number:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(b)(i): the total number of voters who cast a valid ranking counted in that ballot-counting phase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(10)(b)(ii): the recount threshold.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(11): (10) A recount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(11)(a): requires rescanning and tabulating all valid ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(11)(b): provides for only one recount.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-603(12): 20A-4-301; (10) Notwithstanding Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-604 Batch elimination.
--------------------------------------------------
In any ballot count conducted under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 20A-4-604(1): for which the number of remaining candidates with more valid rankings than that candidate is greater than or equal to the number of offices to be filled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-604(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-604(2)(a): for which the number of valid rankings counted for the candidate in the ballot-counting phase plus the number of rankings counted for all candidates with fewer valid rankings in the ballot-counting phase is less than the number of valid rankings for the candidate with the next highest amount of valid rankings in the ballot-counting phase; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-4-604(2)(b): (2)(a) who has fewer valid rankings in the ballot-counting phase than a candidate who is excluded under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 5 - Election Administration
*********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101 Notice of election.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(1): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 On or before November 15 in the year before each regular general election year, the lieutenant governor shall prepare and transmit a written notice to each county clerk that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(1)(a): designates the offices to be filled at the next year's regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(1)(b): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 identifies the dates for filing a declaration of candidacy, and for submitting and certifying nomination petition signatures, as applicable, under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(1)(c): contains a description of any ballot propositions to be decided by the voters that have qualified for the ballot as of that date.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(2): (1); 63G-30-102; (3); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(2)(a): (1); 63G-30-102; (3) No later than seven business days after the day on which the lieutenant governor transmits the written notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(2)(b): (2)(a) The county clerk shall prepare an affidavit of the posting under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(3): (2) The notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(3)(a): designate the offices to be voted on in that election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(3)(b): identify the dates for filing a declaration of candidacy for those offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4): (6) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(a): the date of election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(b): the hours during which the polls will be open;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(c): the polling places for each voting precinct, early voting polling place, and election day voting center;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(d): the address of the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website and, if available, the address of the election officer's website, with a statement indicating that the election officer will post on the website any changes to the location of a polling place and the location of any additional polling place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(e): a phone number that a voter may call to obtain information regarding the location of a polling place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(f): the qualifications for persons to vote in the election: and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(4)(g): instructions regarding how an individual with a disability, who is not able to vote a manual ballot by mail, may obtain information on voting in an accessible manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(5): (4); 63G-30-102 The election officer shall provide the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6): (4); (4) Instead of including the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(a): is entitled "Notice of Election";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(b): includes the following: "A [indicate election type] will be held in [indicate the jurisdiction] on [indicate date of election]. Information relating to the election, including polling places, polling place hours, and qualifications of voters may be obtained from the following sources:"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(c): (4) specifies the following sources where an individual may view or obtain the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(c)(i): if the jurisdiction has a website, the jurisdiction's website;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(c)(ii): the physical address of the jurisdiction offices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-101(6)(c)(iii): a mailing address and telephone number.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102 Voting instructions.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1): Each election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(a): print instructions for voters;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(b): ensure that the instructions are printed in English, and any other language required under the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended, in large clear type; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c): ensure that the instructions inform voters:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(i): about how to obtain ballots for voting;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(ii): about special political party affiliation requirements for voting in a regular primary election or presidential primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(iii): about how to prepare ballots for deposit in the ballot box;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(iv): about how to record write-in votes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(v): about how to obtain a new ballot in the place of one spoiled by accident or mistake;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(vi): about how to obtain assistance in marking ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(vii): about obtaining a new ballot if the voter's ballot is defaced;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(viii): that identification marks or the spoiling or defacing of a ballot will make it invalid;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(ix): about how to obtain and vote a provisional ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(x): about whom to contact to report election fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(xi): about applicable federal and state laws regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(xi)(A): voting rights and the appropriate official to contact if the voter alleges that the voter's rights have been violated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(xi)(B): prohibitions on acts of fraud and misrepresentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(xii): about procedures governing mail-in registrants and first-time voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(1)(c)(xiii): about the date of the election and the hours that the polls are open on election day.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2): Each election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2)(a): provide the election judges of each voting precinct with sufficient instruction cards to instruct voters in the preparation of the voters' ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2)(b): direct the election judges to post:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2)(b)(i): general voting instructions in each voting booth;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2)(b)(ii): at least three instruction cards at other locations in the polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-102(2)(b)(iii): at least one sample ballot at the polling place.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103 Constitutional amendments -- Posting.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(1): Whenever a constitutional amendment is submitted to a vote of the people for their approval or rejection, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(1)(a): cause the original section of the constitution to be printed on cards in large clear type with the changes to it indicated by bracketing and interlining any language proposed to be repealed and underlining any new language proposed to be inserted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(1)(b): place the question as it appears upon the official ballot after the original section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(2): If there is more than one amendment submitted, the clerk shall ensure that the proposed amendments are placed upon the cards in columns in the same order as they will appear upon the official ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(3): Each county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(3)(a): provide the election judges for each voting precinct with two constitutional amendment cards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-103(3)(b): direct the election judges to post the two constitutional amendment cards in and about the polling place.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-204 Duplicate registration.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-204(1): Upon finding duplicate registration, the county clerk shall first check for errors in the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-204(2): If duplicate registration does exist, the clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-204(2)(a): eliminate one registration entry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-204(2)(b): change the date of voter registration on the voter's file to the most recent registration date.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205 Delivery of official register.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205(1): Before delivering the official register to the poll workers, the county clerk shall verify the accuracy and completeness of the official register.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205(2): The county clerk shall, before the polls open at an early voting center or any other polling place:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205(2)(a): deliver the official register to each polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205(2)(b): provide verification of the official register's accuracy and completeness.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-205(3): This section does not prohibit a county clerk from updating an official register as necessary.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-206 Change of precinct boundaries -- Revising list.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-206(1): Whenever the boundaries of any voting precinct are changed, or a new voting precinct is created, the county clerk shall ensure that the names of all voters residing within the territory affected by the change are updated in the official register.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-206(2): Any registered voter whose name has been erroneously updated in the official register, or erroneously not updated in the official register, may vote in the voting precinct in which the voter resides if the voter uses a provisional ballot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-207 Donated funding prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------
An election officer may not solicit, accept, or use any funds for an election if those funds are donated by any person other than a government entity.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301 Combined voting precincts -- Municipalities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(1)(a): The municipal legislative body of a city of the first or second class may combine up to four regular county voting precincts into one municipal voting precinct for purposes of a municipal election if they designate the location and address of each of those combined voting precincts.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(1)(b): The polling place shall be within the combined voting precinct or within 1/2 mile of the boundaries of the voting precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(2)(a): The municipal legislative body of a city of the third, fourth, or fifth class or a town may combine two or more regular county voting precincts into one municipal voting precinct for purposes of an election if it designates the location and address of that combined voting precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(2)(b): If only two precincts are combined, the polling place shall be within the combined precinct or within 1/2 mile of the boundaries of the combined voting precinct.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-301(2)(c): If more than two precincts are combined, the polling place should be as near as practical to the middle of the combined precinct.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302 Automated voting system.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(1)(a): Any county or municipal legislative body or special district board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(1)(a)(i): adopt, experiment with, acquire by purchase, lease, or otherwise, or abandon any automated voting system that meets the requirements of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(1)(a)(ii): use that system in any election, in all or a part of the voting precincts within its boundaries, or in combination with manual ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(1)(b): Nothing in this title shall be construed to require the use of electronic voting devices in local special elections, municipal primary elections, or municipal general elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2): 20A-3a-208; 20A-5-802 Each automated voting system shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(a): 20A-3a-208 provide for voting in secrecy, except in the case of voters who have received assistance as authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(b): permit each voter at any election to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(b)(i): vote for all persons and offices for whom and for which that voter is lawfully entitled to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(b)(ii): vote for as many persons for an office as that voter is entitled to vote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(b)(iii): vote for or against any ballot proposition upon which that voter is entitled to vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(c): permit each voter, at presidential elections, by one mark, to vote for the candidates of that party for president, vice president, and for their presidential electors;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(d): at elections other than primary elections, permit each voter to vote for the nominees of one or more parties and for independent candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(e): at primary elections:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(e)(i): permit each voter to vote for candidates of the political party of the voter's choice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(e)(ii): reject any votes cast for candidates of another party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(f): prevent the voter from voting for the same person more than once for the same office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(g): provide the opportunity for each voter to change the ballot and to correct any error before the voter casts the ballot in compliance with the Help America Vote Act of 2002, Pub. L. No. 107-252;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(h): include automatic tabulating equipment that rejects choices recorded on a voter's ballot if the number of the voter's recorded choices is greater than the number which the voter is entitled to vote for the office or on the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(i): be of durable construction, suitably designed so that it may be used safely, efficiently, and accurately in the conduct of elections and counting ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(j): when properly operated, record correctly and count accurately each vote cast;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k): for voting equipment certified after January 1, 2005, produce a permanent paper record that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(i): shall be available as an official record for any recount or election contest conducted with respect to an election where the voting equipment is used;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(ii)(A): shall be available for the voter's inspection prior to the voter leaving the polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(ii)(B): shall permit the voter to inspect the record of the voter's selections independently only if reasonably practicable commercial methods permitting independent inspection are available at the time of certification of the voting equipment by the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(iii): shall include, at a minimum, human readable printing that shows a record of the voter's selections;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(iv): may also include machine readable printing which may be the same as the human readable printing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(k)(v): allows a watcher to observe the election process to ensure the integrity of the election process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(2)(l): 20A-5-802 meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(3): For the purposes of a recount or an election contest, if the permanent paper record contains a conflict or inconsistency between the human readable printing and the machine readable printing, the human readable printing shall supercede the machine readable printing when determining the intent of the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-302(4): Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, the election officers shall ensure that the ballots to be counted by means of electronic or electromechanical devices are of a size, layout, texture, and printed in a type of ink or combination of inks that will be suitable for use in the counting devices in which they are intended to be placed.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303 Establishing, dividing, abolishing, and changing voting precincts -- Common polling places -- Combined voting precincts.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(1): 63A-16-505
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(1)(a): After receiving recommendations from the county clerk, the county legislative body may establish, divide, abolish, and change voting precincts.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(1)(b): 63A-16-505 Within 30 days after the establishment, division, abolition, or change of a voting precinct under this section, the county legislative body shall file with the Utah Geospatial Resource Center, created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(2): (2)(a); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(2)(a): The county legislative body shall alter or divide voting precincts so that each voting precinct contains not more than 1,250 active voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(2)(b): (2)(a); (3) The county legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) identify those precincts that may reach the limit of active voters in a precinct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(2)(b)(ii): (3) except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(3): (2)(b)(i) A county legislative body shall divide a precinct identified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(4): (2)(a); (5) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(4)(a): establish or abolish any voting precinct after January 1 of a regular general election year;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(4)(b): alter or change the boundaries of any voting precinct after January 1 of a regular general election year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(4)(c): establish, divide, abolish, alter, or change a voting precinct between January 1 of a year immediately preceding the year in which an enumeration is required by the United States Constitution and the day on which the Legislature divides the state into districts in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(5): A county legislative body may establish, divide, abolish, alter, or change a voting precinct on or before January 31 of a regular general election year that immediately follows the calendar year in which the Legislature divides the state into districts in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6): (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6)(a): For the purpose of voting in an election, the county legislative body may establish a common polling place for two or more whole voting precincts.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6)(b): At least 90 days before the election, the county legislative body shall designate:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6)(b)(i): the voting precincts that will vote at the common polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6)(b)(ii): the location of the common polling place.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(6)(c): (6) A county may use one set of election judges for the common polling place under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(7): Each county shall have at least two polling places open for voting on the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-303(8): Each common polling place shall have at least one voting device that is accessible for individuals with disabilities in accordance with Public Law 107-252, the Help America Vote Act of 2002.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1 Contracting with an election officer to conduct elections -- Fees -- Contracts and interlocal agreements -- Private providers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(1): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; (1)(a); (1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(1)(a): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act In accordance with this section, a local political subdivision may enter into a contract or interlocal agreement as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(1)(b): If the boundaries of a local political subdivision holding the election extend beyond a single local political subdivision, the local political subdivision may have more than one provider election officer conduct an election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(1)(c): (1)(a) Upon approval by the lieutenant governor, a municipality may enter into a contract or agreement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(1)(d): (1)(c) If a municipality enters into a contract or agreement, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(2): A provider election officer shall conduct an election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(2)(a): under the direction of the contracting election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(2)(b): in accordance with a contract or interlocal agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(3): A provider election officer shall establish fees for conducting an election for a contracting election officer that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(3)(a): are consistent with the contract or interlocal agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(3)(b): do not exceed the actual costs incurred by the provider election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(4): The contract or interlocal agreement under this section may specify that a contracting election officer request, within a specified number of days before the election, that the provider election officer conduct the election to allow adequate preparations by the provider election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.1(5): An election officer conducting an election may appoint or employ an agent or professional service to assist in conducting the election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5 Election officer for bond and leeway elections.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(1): When a voted leeway or bond election is held on the regular general election date, the county clerk shall serve as the provider election officer to conduct that election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2): 20A-1-204; (3); 20A-1-204; (3); 20A-1-204; (3); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2)(a): 20A-1-204; (3) When a voted leeway or bond election is held on the municipal general election date or any other election date permitted for special elections under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2)(b): 20A-1-204; (3) When a voted leeway or bond election is held on the municipal general election date or any other election date permitted for special elections under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2)(c): 20A-1-204; (3); (3) When a voted leeway or bond election is held on the municipal general election date or any other election date permitted for special elections under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2)(c)(i): (3) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(2)(c)(ii): (3) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(3): When a voted leeway or bond election is held on a date when no other election, other than another voted leeway or bond election, is being held in the entire area comprising the local political subdivision calling the voted leeway or bond election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(3)(a): the clerk or chief executive officer of a special district or the business administrator or superintendent of the school district, as applicable, shall serve as the election officer to conduct the bond election for those portions of the local political subdivision in which no other election, other than another voted leeway or bond election, is being held, unless the special district or school district has contracted with a provider election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-5-400.5(3)(b): the county clerk, municipal clerk, or both, as determined by the local political subdivision holding the bond election, shall serve as the provider election officer to conduct the bond election for those portions of the local political subdivision in which another election, other than another voted leeway or bond election, is being held.
