Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-108(2): (1) Beginning on the effective date of the rules described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203 Ballots for regular primary elections.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(1): Title 20A, Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403 The lieutenant governor, together with county clerks, suppliers of election materials, and representatives of registered political parties, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(1)(a): develop ballots to be used in Utah's regular primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(1)(b): Title 20A, Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots ensure that the ballots comply generally, where applicable, with the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(1)(c): 20A-5-403 provide voting booths, election records and supplies, ballot boxes, and as applicable, voting devices, for each voting precinct as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2): (1)(b); (c); Title 20A, Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403; 20A-6-401; 20A-6-401.1; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(a): (1)(b); (c); Title 20A, Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403; 20A-6-401; 20A-6-401.1 Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(a)(i): facilitate the distribution, voting, and tallying of ballots in a primary where not all voters are authorized to vote for a party's candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(a)(ii): simplify the task of poll workers, particularly in determining a voter's party affiliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(a)(iii): minimize the possibility of spoiled ballots due to voter confusion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(a)(iv): protect against fraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(b): (2) To accomplish the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(b)(i): mark ballots as being for a particular registered political party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203(2)(b)(ii): instruct individuals counting the ballots to count only those votes for candidates from the registered political party whose ballot the voter received.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203.5 Instant runoff voting ballot.
---------------------------------------------------------------
If, in an election, at least one of the races is conducted by instant runoff voting underUtah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203.5(1): list each candidate who qualifies to be placed on the election ballot for that race;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203.5(2): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project opposite each candidate's name, include a place where a voter can indicate the voter's vote in order of preference for each candidate, as described in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-203.5(3): provide the ability for a voter to enter a write-in candidate's name and indicate the voter's ordered preference for the write-in candidate.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301 Manual ballots -- Regular general election.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5); 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5); 20A-6-305; 20A-9-601 Each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(a): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) all manual ballots furnished for use at the regular general election contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(a)(i): no captions or other endorsements except as provided in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(a)(ii): 20A-9-403 no symbols, markings, or other descriptions of a political party or group, except for a registered political party that has chosen to nominate its candidates in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(a)(iii): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) no indication that a candidate for elective office has been nominated by, or has been endorsed by, or is in any way affiliated with a political party or group, unless the candidate has been nominated by a registered political party in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(b): at the top of the ballot, the following endorsements are printed in 18 point bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(b)(i): "Official Ballot for ____ County, Utah";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(b)(ii): the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(b)(iii): the words "certified by the Clerk of __________ County" or, as applicable, the name of a combined office that includes the duties of a county clerk;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(c): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5); 20A-6-305 unaffiliated candidates, candidates not affiliated with a registered political party, and all other candidates for elective office who were not nominated by a registered political party in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(d): each ticket containing the lists of candidates, including the party name and device, are separated by heavy parallel lines;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(e): the offices to be filled are plainly printed immediately above the names of the candidates for those offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(f): the names of candidates are printed in capital letters, not less than one-eighth nor more than one-fourth of an inch high in heavy-faced type not smaller than 10 point, between lines or rules three-eighths of an inch apart; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(g): 20A-9-601 on a ticket for a race in which a voter is authorized to cast a write-in vote and in which a write-in candidate is qualified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(g)(i): the ballot includes a space for a write-in candidate immediately following the last candidate listed on that ticket; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(1)(g)(ii): for the offices of president and vice president and governor and lieutenant governor, the ballot includes two spaces for write-in candidates immediately following the last candidates on that ticket, one placed above the other, to enable the entry of two valid write-in candidates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5); Chapter 9, Part 5, Candidates not Affiliated with a Party An election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(a): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) each individual nominated by any registered political party under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(a)(i): under the registered political party's name, if any; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(a)(ii): under the title of the registered political party as designated by them in their certificates of nomination or petition, or, if none is designated, then under some suitable title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(b): Chapter 9, Part 5, Candidates not Affiliated with a Party the names of all unaffiliated candidates that qualify as required in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(c): the names of the candidates for president and vice president are used on the ballot instead of the names of the presidential electors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(2)(d): the ballots contain no other names.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3): 20A-6-305 When the ballot contains a nonpartisan section, the election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(a): the designation of the office to be filled in the election and the number of candidates to be elected are printed in type not smaller than eight point;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(b): the words designating the office are printed flush with the left-hand margin;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(c): the words, "Vote for one" or "Vote for up to _____ (the number of candidates for which the voter may vote)" extend to the extreme right of the column;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(d): the nonpartisan candidates are grouped according to the office for which they are candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(e): 20A-6-305 the names in each group are placed in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(3)(f): each group is preceded by the designation of the office for which the candidates seek election, and the words, "Vote for one" or "Vote for up to _____ (the number of candidates for which the voter may vote)," according to the number to be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(4): 20A-6-107; 20A-6-107; 11-14-206; 20A-12-201(4) Each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(4)(a): 20A-6-107 proposed amendments to the Utah Constitution are listed on the ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(4)(b): 20A-6-107 ballot propositions submitted to the voters are listed on the ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(4)(c): 11-14-206 bond propositions that have qualified for the ballot are listed on the ballot under the title assigned to each bond proposition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-301(4)(d): 20A-12-201(4) the judicial retention section of the ballot includes a statement at the beginning directing voters to the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission's website in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302 Manual ballots -- Placement of candidates' names.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(1): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5); 20A-6-305 An election officer shall ensure, for manual ballots in regular general elections, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(1)(a): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) each candidate is listed by party, if nominated by a registered political party under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(1)(b): candidates' surnames are listed in alphabetical order on the ballots when two or more candidates' names are required to be listed on a ticket under the title of an office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(1)(c): 20A-6-305 the names of candidates are placed on the ballot in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2): (2); 20A-1-509.2; (2)(f); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(a): When there is only one candidate for county attorney at the regular general election in counties that have three or fewer registered voters of the county who are licensed active members in good standing of the Utah State Bar, the county clerk shall cause that candidate's name and party affiliation, if any, to be placed on a separate section of the ballot with the following question: "Shall (name of candidate) be elected to the office of county attorney? Yes ____ No ____."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(b): If the number of "Yes" votes exceeds the number of "No" votes, the candidate is elected to the office of county attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(c): If the number of "No" votes exceeds the number of "Yes" votes, the candidate is not elected and may not take office, nor may the candidate continue in the office past the end of the term resulting from any prior election or appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(d): (2) When the name of only one candidate for county attorney is printed on the ballot under authority of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(e): 20A-1-509.2 If no qualified individual files for the office of county attorney or if the candidate is not elected by the voters, the county legislative body shall appoint the county attorney as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(f): (2)(f); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a) If the candidate whose name would, except for this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(f)(i): (2)(a) requests the procedure set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(2)(f)(ii): contains the signatures of registered voters in the county representing in number at least 25% of all votes cast in the county for all candidates for governor at the last election at which a governor was elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3): (3); 20A-1-509.2; (3)(f); (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(a): When there is only one candidate for district attorney at the regular general election in a prosecution district that has three or fewer registered voters of the district who are licensed active members in good standing of the Utah State Bar, the county clerk shall cause that candidate's name and party affiliation, if any, to be placed on a separate section of the ballot with the following question: "Shall (name of candidate) be elected to the office of district attorney? Yes ____ No ____."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(b): If the number of "Yes" votes exceeds the number of "No" votes, the candidate is elected to the office of district attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(c): If the number of "No" votes exceeds the number of "Yes" votes, the candidate is not elected and may not take office, nor may the candidate continue in the office past the end of the term resulting from any prior election or appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(d): (3) When the name of only one candidate for district attorney is printed on the ballot under authority of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(e): 20A-1-509.2 If no qualified individual files for the office of district attorney, or if the only candidate is not elected by the voters under this subsection, the county legislative body shall appoint a new district attorney for a four-year term as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(f): (3)(f); (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(a) If the candidate whose name would, except for this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(f)(i): (3)(a) requests the procedure set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-302(3)(f)(ii): contains the signatures of registered voters in the county representing in number at least 25% of all votes cast in the county for all candidates for governor at the last election at which a governor was elected.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304 Regular general election -- Mechanical ballots.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) Each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(a): the format and content of a mechanical ballot is arranged in approximately the same order as manual ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(b): the titles of offices and the names of candidates are displayed in vertical columns or in a series of separate displays;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(c): the mechanical ballot is of sufficient length to include, after the list of candidates:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(c)(i): the names of candidates for judicial offices and any other nonpartisan offices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(c)(ii): any ballot propositions submitted to the voters for their approval or rejection;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(d): the office titles are displayed above or at the side of the names of candidates so as to indicate clearly the candidates for each office and the number to be elected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(e): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) the party designation of each candidate who has been nominated by a registered political party under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(1)(f): if possible, all candidates for one office are grouped in one column or upon one display screen.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(2): 20A-6-107; 20A-6-107; 11-14-206; 20A-12-201(4) Each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(2)(a): 20A-6-107 proposed amendments to the Utah Constitution are displayed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(2)(b): 20A-6-107 ballot propositions submitted to the voters are displayed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(2)(c): 11-14-206 bond propositions that have qualified for the ballot are displayed under the title assigned to each bond proposition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-304(2)(d): 20A-12-201(4) the judicial retention section of the ballot includes a statement at the beginning directing voters to the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission's website in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305 Master ballot position list -- Random selection -- Procedures -- Publication -- Surname -- Exemptions -- Ballot order.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(1): (2) As used in this section, "master ballot position list" means an official list of the 26 characters in the alphabet listed in random order and numbered from one to 26 as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2): (2)(c) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(a): (2)(c) within 30 days after the candidate filing deadline in each even-numbered year, conduct a random selection to create a master ballot position list for all elections in accordance with procedures established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(b): publish the master ballot position list on the lieutenant governor's election website no later than 15 days after creating the list; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(c): establish written procedures for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(c)(i): the election official to use the master ballot position list; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(c)(ii): the lieutenant governor in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(c)(ii)(A): conducting the random selection in a fair manner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(2)(c)(ii)(B): providing a record of the random selection process used.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(3): (2)(c)(i) In accordance with the written procedures established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(4): (3) To determine the order in which to list candidates on the ballot required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(4)(a): the candidate's surname;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(4)(b): for candidates with a surname that has the same spelling, the candidate's given name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(4)(c): the surname of the president and the surname of the governor for an election for the offices of president and vice president and governor and lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(5): (1); (4); 20A-12-201 Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(5)(a): an election for an office for which only one candidate is listed on the ballot; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(5)(b): 20A-12-201 a judicial retention election under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(6)(d)(i): mayor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-305(6)(d)(ii): city or town council member;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401 Ballots for municipal primary elections.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1): 20A-6-305 Each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(a): the following endorsements are printed in 18 point bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(a)(i): "Official Primary Ballot for ____ (City or Town), Utah";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(a)(ii): the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(a)(iii): a facsimile of the signature of the election officer and the election officer's title in eight point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(b): immediately below the election officer's title, two one-point parallel horizontal rules separate endorsements from the rest of the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(c): immediately below the horizontal rules, an "Instructions to Voters" section is printed in 10 point bold type that states: "To vote for a candidate, mark the space adjacent to the name(s) of the person(s) you favor as the candidate(s) for each respective office." followed by two one-point parallel rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(d): after the rules, the designation of the office for which the candidates seek nomination is printed and the words, "Vote for one" or "Vote for up to _____ (the number of candidates for which the voter may vote)" are printed in 10-point bold type, followed by a hair-line rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(e): 20A-6-305 after the hair-line rule, the names of the candidates are printed in heavy face type between lines or rules three-eighths inch apart, in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(f): a square with sides not less than one-fourth inch long is printed immediately adjacent to the names of the candidates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(1)(g): the candidate groups are separated from each other by one light and one heavy line or rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401(2): A municipal primary ballot may not contain any space for write-in votes.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1 Ballots for partisan municipal primary elections.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1): 20A-6-305; 20A-6-305 An election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(a): all manual ballots furnished for use at the regular primary election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(a)(i): separate the candidates of one political party from those of the other political parties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(a)(ii): contain no captions or other endorsements except as provided in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(b): the names of all candidates from each party are listed on the same ballot in one or more columns under their party name and emblem;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(c): 20A-6-305 the political parties are printed on the ballot in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(d): the following endorsements are printed in 18-point bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(d)(i): "Official Primary Ballot for ____ (name of municipality), Utah";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(d)(ii): the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(d)(iii): a facsimile of the signature of the election officer and the election officer's title in eight point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(e): after the facsimile signature, the political party emblem and the name of the political party are printed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(f): after the party name and emblem, the ballot contains the following printed in not smaller than 10-point bold face, double leaded type: "Instructions to Voters: To vote for a candidate, mark the space following the name of the person for whom you wish to vote and in no other place.  Do not vote for any candidate listed under more than one party or group designation.", followed by two one-point parallel horizontal rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(g): after the rules, the designation of the office for which the candidates seek nomination is printed flush with the left-hand margin and the words, "Vote for one" or "Vote for up to _____ (the number of candidates for which the voter may vote)" are printed to extend to the extreme right of the column in 10-point bold type, followed by a hair-line rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(h): 20A-6-305 after the hair-line rule, the names of the candidates are printed in heavy face type between lines or rules three-eighths inch apart, in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(i): a square with sides not less than one-fourth inch long is printed immediately adjacent to the names of the candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(j): the candidate groups are separated from each other by one light and one heavy line or rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(k): the nonpartisan candidates are listed as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(k)(i): immediately below the listing of the party candidates, the word "NONPARTISAN" is printed in reverse type in an 18 point solid rule that extends the full width of the type copy of the party listing above; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(1)(k)(ii): below "NONPARTISAN," the office, the number of candidates to vote for, the candidate's name, the voting square, and any other necessary information is printed in the same style and manner as for party candidates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(2): For mechanical ballots, the election officer may require that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(2)(a): the ballot for a regular primary election consist of several groups of pages or display screens, so that a separate group can be used to list the names of candidates seeking nomination of each qualified political party, with additional groups used to list candidates for other nonpartisan offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(2)(b): the separate groups of pages or display screens are identified by color or other suitable means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-401.1(2)(c): the ballot contains instructions that direct the voter how to vote the ballot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402 Ballots for municipal general elections.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1): 20A-6-305; 20A-9-601; 20A-6-107; 11-14-206 Except as otherwise required for a race conducted by instant runoff voting under Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, for a manual ballot at a municipal general election, an election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(a): the names of the two candidates who received the highest number of votes for mayor in the municipal primary are placed upon the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(b): if no municipal primary election was held, the names of the candidates who filed declarations of candidacy for municipal offices are placed upon the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(c): for other offices:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(c)(i): twice the number of candidates as there are positions to be filled are certified as eligible for election in the municipal general election from those candidates who received the greater number of votes in the primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(c)(ii): the names of those candidates are placed upon the municipal general election ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(d): 20A-6-305 the names of the candidates are placed on the ballot in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(e): 20A-9-601 in an election in which a voter is authorized to cast a write-in vote and where a write-in candidate is qualified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(e)(i): a blank, horizontal line to enable a voter to submit a valid write-in candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(e)(ii): a square or other conforming area that is adjacent to or opposite the blank horizontal line to enable the voter to indicate the voter's vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(f): 20A-6-107 ballot propositions that have qualified for the ballot, including propositions submitted to the voters by the municipality, municipal initiatives, and municipal referenda, are listed on the ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(1)(g): 11-14-206 bond propositions that have qualified for the ballot are listed on the ballot under the title assigned to each bond proposition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2): 20A-6-305; 20A-9-601 Except as otherwise required for a race conducted by instant runoff voting under Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, when using a mechanical ballot at municipal general elections, each election officer shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(a): the following endorsements are displayed on the first portion of the ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(a)(i): "Official Ballot for ____ (City or Town), Utah";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(a)(ii): the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(a)(iii): a facsimile of the signature of the election officer and the election officer's title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(b): immediately below the election officer's title, a distinct border or line separates the endorsements from the rest of the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(c): immediately below the border or line, an "Instructions to Voters" section is displayed that states: "To vote for a candidate, select the name(s) of the person(s) you favor as the candidate(s) for each respective office." followed by another border or line;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(d): after the border or line, the designation of the office for which the candidates seek election is displayed, and the words, "Vote for one" or "Vote for up to _____ (the number of candidates for which the voter may vote)" are displayed, followed by a line or border;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(e): 20A-6-305 after the line or border, the names of the candidates are displayed in the order specified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(f): a voting square or position is located adjacent to the name of each candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(g): 20A-9-601 following the name of the last candidate for each office in which a write-in candidate is qualified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(2)(h): the candidate groups are separated from each other by a line or border.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-6-402(3): When a municipality has chosen to nominate candidates by convention or committee, the election officer shall ensure that the party name is included with the candidate's name on the ballot.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 7 - Issues Submitted to the Voters
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(1): 20A-21-201 "Approved device" means a device described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(2): 17-36-3; 10-6-106 "Budget officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(2)(a): 17-36-3 for a county, the person designated as finance officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(2)(b): 10-6-106 for a city, the person designated as budget officer in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(2)(c): for a town, the town council.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(3): "Certified" means that the county clerk has acknowledged a signature as being the signature of a registered voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(4): "Circulation" means the process of submitting an initiative petition or a referendum petition to legal voters for their signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(5): 20A-7-215; 20A-21-201; 20A-7-514; 20A-21-201 "Electronic initiative process" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(5)(a): 20A-7-215; 20A-21-201 as it relates to a statewide initiative, the process, described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(5)(b): 20A-7-514; 20A-21-201 as it relates to a local initiative, the process, described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(6): 20A-7-313; 20A-21-201; 20A-7-614; 20A-21-201 "Electronic referendum process" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(6)(a): 20A-7-313; 20A-21-201 as it relates to a statewide referendum, the process, described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(6)(b): 20A-7-614; 20A-21-201 as it relates to a local referendum, the process, described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(7): "Eligible voter" means a legal voter who resides in the jurisdiction of the county, city, or town that is holding an election on a ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(8): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-502.5 "Final fiscal impact statement" means a financial statement prepared after voters approve an initiative that contains the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(9): 20A-7-202.5 "Initial fiscal impact statement" means a financial statement prepared under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(10): 20A-7-502.5; 20A-7-602.5 "Initial fiscal impact and legal statement" means a financial and legal statement prepared under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(11): "Initiative" means a new law proposed for adoption by the public as provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(12): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 "Initiative application" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(12)(a): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202 for a statewide initiative, an application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(12)(b): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 for a local initiative, an application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(13): "Initiative packet" means a copy of the initiative petition, a copy of the proposed law, and the signature sheets, all of which have been bound together as a unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14): 20A-7-203; 20A-7-203; 20A-7-215; 20A-7-215; 20A-7-503; 20A-7-503; 20A-7-514; 20A-7-514 "Initiative petition":
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(a): 20A-7-203; 20A-7-203 as it relates to a statewide initiative, using the manual initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(a)(i): 20A-7-203 means the form described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(a)(ii): 20A-7-203 if the initiative proposes a tax increase, includes the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(b): 20A-7-215; 20A-7-215 as it relates to a statewide initiative, using the electronic initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(b)(i): 20A-7-215 means the form described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(b)(ii): 20A-7-215 if the initiative proposes a tax increase, includes the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(c): 20A-7-503; 20A-7-503 as it relates to a local initiative, using the manual initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(c)(i): 20A-7-503 means the form described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(c)(ii): 20A-7-503 if the initiative proposes a tax increase, includes the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(d): 20A-7-514; 20A-7-514 as it relates to a local initiative, using the electronic initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(d)(i): 20A-7-514 means the form described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(14)(d)(ii): 20A-7-514 if the initiative proposes a tax increase, includes the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(15): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(15)(a): "Land use law" means a law of general applicability, enacted based on the weighing of broad, competing policy considerations, that relates to the use of land, including land use regulation, a general plan, a land use development code, an annexation ordinance, the rezoning of a single property or multiple properties, or a comprehensive zoning ordinance or resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(15)(b): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103 "Land use law" does not include a land use decision, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(16): "Legal signatures" means the number of signatures of legal voters that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(16)(a): meet the numerical requirements of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(16)(b): have been obtained, certified, and verified as provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(17): "Legal voter" means an individual who is registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(18): 20A-7-502.7; 20A-7-602.7 "Legally referable to voters" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(18)(a): 20A-7-502.7 for a proposed local initiative, that the proposed local initiative is legally referable to voters under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(18)(b): 20A-7-602.7 for a proposed local referendum, that the proposed local referendum is legally referable to voters under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(19): "Local attorney" means the county attorney, city attorney, or town attorney in whose jurisdiction a local initiative or referendum petition is circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(20): "Local clerk" means the county clerk, city recorder, or town clerk in whose jurisdiction a local initiative or referendum petition is circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21): 10-9a-103; 10-9a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a): 10-9a-103 "Local law" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a)(i): an ordinance;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a)(ii): a resolution;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a)(iii): a land use law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a)(iv): 10-9a-103 a land use regulation, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(a)(v): other legislative action of a local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(21)(b): 10-9a-103 "Local law" does not include a land use decision, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(22): "Local legislative body" means the legislative body of a county, city, or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(23): "Local obligation law" means a local law passed by the local legislative body regarding a bond that was approved by a majority of qualified voters in an election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(24): "Local tax law" means a law, passed by a political subdivision with an annual or biannual calendar fiscal year, that increases a tax or imposes a new tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(25): "Manual initiative process" means the process for gathering signatures for an initiative using paper signature packets that a signer physically signs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(26): "Manual referendum process" means the process for gathering signatures for a referendum using paper signature packets that a signer physically signs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(27): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(27)(a): "Measure" means a proposed constitutional amendment, an initiative, or referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(27)(b): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4 "Measure" does not include a ballot proposition for the creation of a new school district under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(28): "Presiding officers" means the president of the Senate and the speaker of the House of Representatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(29): "Referendum" means a process by which a law passed by the Legislature or by a local legislative body is submitted or referred to the voters for their approval or rejection.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(30): 20A-7-302; 20A-7-302; 20A-7-602; 20A-7-602 "Referendum application" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(30)(a): 20A-7-302; 20A-7-302 for a statewide referendum, an application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(30)(b): 20A-7-602; 20A-7-602 for a local referendum, an application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(31): "Referendum packet" means a copy of the referendum petition, a copy of the law being submitted or referred to the voters for their approval or rejection, and the signature sheets, all of which have been bound together as a unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(32): 20A-7-303; 20A-7-313; 20A-7-603; 20A-7-614 "Referendum petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(32)(a): 20A-7-303 as it relates to a statewide referendum, using the manual referendum process, the form described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(32)(d): 20A-7-614 as it relates to a local referendum, using the electronic referendum process, the form described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(33)(b)(ii)(C): does not include an electronic signature;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(33)(d)(ii)(C): does not include an electronic signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(34): "Signature sheets" means sheets in the form required by this chapter that are used under the manual initiative process or the manual referendum process to collect signatures in support of an initiative or referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(35): "Special local ballot proposition" means a local ballot proposition that is not a standard local ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(36): "Sponsors" means the legal voters who support the initiative or referendum and who sign the initiative application or referendum application.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(37): 20A-7-613
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(37)(a): "Standard local ballot proposition" means a local ballot proposition for an initiative or a referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(37)(b): 20A-7-613 "Standard local ballot proposition" does not include a property tax referendum described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(38): "Tax percentage difference" means the difference between the tax rate proposed by an initiative or an initiative petition and the current tax rate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(39): "Tax percentage increase" means a number calculated by dividing the tax percentage difference by the current tax rate and rounding the result to the nearest thousandth.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-101(40): 20A-7-105 "Verified" means acknowledged by the person circulating the petition as required in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102 Initiatives and referenda authorized -- Restrictions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
By following the procedures and requirements of this chapter, Utah voters may, subject to the restrictions of Article VI, Sec. 1, Utah Constitution and this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102(1): initiate any desired legislation and cause it to be submitted to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102(1)(a): the Legislature or to a vote of the people for approval or rejection if it is a proposed state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102(1)(b): a local legislative body or to a vote of the people if it is a local law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102(2): require any law passed by the Legislature, except those laws passed by a two-thirds vote of the members elected to each house of the Legislature, to be referred to the voters for their approval or rejection before the law takes effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-102(3): require any law or ordinance passed by a local legislative body to be referred to the voters for their approval or rejection before the law takes effect.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103 Constitutional amendments and other questions submitted by the Legislature -- Publication -- Ballot title -- Procedures for submission to popular vote.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(1): The procedures contained in this section govern when the Legislature submits a proposed constitutional amendment or other question to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(2): 63G-30-102 The lieutenant governor shall, not more than 60 days or less than 14 days before the date of the election, publish the full text of the amendment, question, or statute for the state, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3): 20A-6-107; 20A-6-107 The presiding officers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(a): 20A-6-107 entitle each proposed constitutional amendment "Constitutional Amendment __" and assign a letter to the constitutional amendment in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(b): 20A-6-107 entitle each proposed question "Proposition Number __" with the number assigned to the proposition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(c): draft and designate a ballot title for each proposed amendment or question submitted by the Legislature that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(c)(i): summarizes the subject matter of the amendment or question; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(c)(ii): for a proposed constitutional amendment, summarizes any legislation that is enacted and will become effective upon the voters' adoption of the proposed constitutional amendment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(3)(d): deliver each letter or number and ballot title to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(4): The lieutenant governor shall certify the letter or number and ballot title of each amendment or question to the county clerk of each county no later than 65 days before the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(5): The county clerk of each county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(5)(a): ensure that the letter or number and the ballot title of each amendment and question prepared in accordance with this section are included in the sample ballots and official ballots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103(5)(b): publish the sample ballots and official ballots as provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103.1(16)(b): each rebuttal argument follows immediately after the direct argument which the rebuttal argument seeks to rebut;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103.1(17): if, after the lieutenant governor determines that an argument or a rebuttal argument mischaracterizes the position of a state entity, the lieutenant governor and the authors of the argument or rebuttal argument cannot jointly agree on a modification to correct the mischaracterization, the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103.1(17)(a): shall publish the argument or rebuttal argument with the mischaracterization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-103.1(17)(b): may, immediately following the argument or rebuttal argument, publish a brief description of the position of the state entity;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104 Signature gatherers -- Payments -- Badges -- Information -- Requirement to provide initiative or referendum for reading.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"You may view the initiative, its fiscal impact, and information on removing your signature from the petition at [list a uniform resource locator that links directly to the information described in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(1): A person may not pay a person to gather signatures under this chapter based on a rate per signature, on a rate per verified signature, or on the initiative or referendum qualifying for the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(2): A person that pays a person to gather signatures under this section shall base the payment solely on an hourly rate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(3): A person may not accept payment made in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4): An individual who is paid to gather signatures for a petition described in this chapter shall, while gathering signatures, wear a badge on the front of the individual's torso that complies with the following, ensuring that the information on the badge is clearly visible to the individual from whom a signature is sought:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(a): the badge shall be printed in black ink on white cardstock and laminated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b): the information on the badge shall be in at least 24-point type and include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(i): an identification number that is unique to the individual gathering signatures, assigned by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(i)(A): for a statewide initiative or referendum, the lieutenant governor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(i)(B): for a local initiative or referendum, the local clerk;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(ii): the title of the initiative or referendum;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(iii): the words "Paid Signature Gatherer"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(4)(b)(iv): the name of the entity paying the signature gatherer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(5): 20A-7-202.7; 20A-7-502.6; 20A-7-304.5; 20A-7-604.5 An individual who gathers signatures under this chapter shall offer a paper document to each individual who signs the petition that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(5)(a): is printed in black ink on white paper, white cardstock, or a white sticker, in at least 12-point type; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(5)(b): 20A-7-202.7; 20A-7-502.6; 20A-7-304.5; 20A-7-604.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(5)(b)(i): 20A-7-202.7; 20A-7-502.6 for an initiative, includes the name of the initiative and the following statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(5)(b)(ii): 20A-7-304.5; 20A-7-604.5 for a referendum, includes the name of the referendum and the following statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(6): An individual who gathers signatures under this chapter shall, before collecting a signature from an individual, present to the individual a printed or digital copy of the initiative or referendum and wait for the individual to read the initiative or referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-104(7): A person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105 Manual petition processes -- Obtaining signatures -- Verification -- Submitting the petition -- Certification of signatures -- Transfer to lieutenant governor -- Removal of signature.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"You signed a petition for the following initiative:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process and the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a): "Local petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a)(i): a manual local initiative petition described in Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a)(ii): a manual local referendum petition described in Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(b): "Packet" means an initiative packet or referendum packet.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(c): "Petition" means a local petition or statewide petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d): "Statewide petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d)(i): a manual statewide initiative petition described in Part 2, Statewide Initiatives; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d)(ii): a manual statewide referendum petition described in Part 3, Statewide Referenda.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(a): A Utah voter may sign a statewide petition if the voter is a legal voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b): A Utah voter may sign a local petition if the voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b)(i): is a legal voter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b)(ii): resides in the local jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a): The sponsors shall ensure that the individual in whose presence each signature sheet was signed:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(i): is at least 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(ii): verifies each signature sheet by completing the verification printed on the last page of each packet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii): is informed that each signer is required to read and understand:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii)(A): for an initiative petition, the law proposed by the initiative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii)(B): for a referendum petition, the law that the referendum seeks to overturn.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(b): An individual may not sign the verification printed on the last page of a packet if the individual signed a signature sheet in the packet.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-604; 20A-7-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-604 The sponsors, or an agent of the sponsors, shall submit a signed and verified packet to the county clerk of the county in which the packet was circulated before 5 p.m. no later than the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i): 20A-7-202 for a statewide initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the initiative packet;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(B): 316 days after the day on which the application for the initiative petition is filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(C): 20A-7-202 the February 15 immediately before the next regular general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii): for a statewide referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the referendum packet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii)(B): 40 days after the day on which the legislative session at which the law passed ends;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 for a local initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the initiative packet;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(B): 316 days after the day on which the application is filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(C): 20A-7-502 the April 15 immediately before the next regular general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(D): 20A-7-502 the April 15 immediately before the next municipal general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv): 20A-7-604 for a local referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the referendum packet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv)(B): 20A-7-604 45 days after the day on which the sponsors receive the items described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(b): A person may not submit a packet after the applicable deadline described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c): Before delivering an initiative packet to the county clerk under this Subsection (5), the sponsors shall send an email to each individual who provides a legible, valid email address on the signature sheet that includes the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c)(i): the subject of the email shall include the following statement, "Notice Regarding Your Petition Signature"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c)(ii): the body of the email shall include the following statement in 12-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d): 20A-7-105 For a statewide initiative, the sponsors shall, no later than 5 p.m. on the day on which the sponsors submit the last initiative packet to the county clerk, submit to the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i): a list containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i)(A): the name and email address of each individual the sponsors sent, or caused to be sent, the email described in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i)(B): the date the email was sent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(ii): a copy of the email described in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(iii): 20A-7-105 the following written verification, completed and signed by each of the sponsors:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(e): For a local initiative, the sponsors shall, no later than 5 p.m. on the day on which the sponsors submit the last initiative packet to the local clerk, submit to the local clerk the items described in Subsection (5)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(f): Signatures gathered for an initiative petition are not valid if the sponsors do not comply with Subsection (5)(c), (d), or (e).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6): 20A-1-1002; 20A-7-106; 20A-7-507; 20A-7-607
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a): 20A-1-1002; 20A-7-106 Within 21 days after the day on which the county clerk receives the packet, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(i): 20A-1-1002; 20A-7-106 use the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii): for a statewide initiative or a statewide referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(A): certify on the petition whether each name is that of a legal voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(B): post the name, voter identification number, and date of signature of each legal voter certified under Subsection (6)(a)(ii)(A) on the lieutenant governor's website, in a conspicuous location designated by the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(C): deliver the verified packet to the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii): for a local initiative or a local referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii)(A): certify on the petition whether each name is that of a legal voter who is registered in the jurisdiction to which the initiative or referendum relates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii)(B): post the name, voter identification number, and date of signature of each legal voter certified under Subsection (6)(a)(iii)(A) on the lieutenant governor's website, in a conspicuous location designated by the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii)(C): deliver the verified packet to the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(b): 20A-7-507; 20A-7-607 For a local initiative or local referendum, the local clerk shall post a link in a conspicuous location on the local government's website to the posting described in Subsection (6)(a)(iii)(B):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(b)(i): 20A-7-507 for a local initiative, during the period of time described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(b)(ii): 20A-7-607 for a local referendum, during the period of time described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(7): The county clerk may not certify a signature under Subsection (6):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(7)(a): on a packet that is not verified in accordance with Subsection (4); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(7)(b): that does not have a date of signature next to the signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8): 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-207; 20A-7-207; 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-307; 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-507; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502; 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-607; 20A-1-1003

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(a)(i)(B): 20A-7-207 90 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(a)(ii): 20A-7-207 for an initiative packet received by the county clerk on or after December 1:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(a)(ii)(B): 20A-7-207 45 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(b): 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-307 A voter who signs a statewide referendum petition may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(b)(ii): 20A-7-307 45 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c): 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-507; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 A voter who signs a local initiative petition may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(i): 30 days after the day on which the voter signs the signature removal statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(ii): 20A-7-507 90 days after the day on which the local clerk posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(iii): 316 days after the day on which the application is filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(iv): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(iv)(A): 20A-7-502 for a county initiative, April 15 immediately before the next regular general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(c)(iv)(B): 20A-7-502 for a municipal initiative, April 15 immediately before the next municipal general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(d): 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-607 A voter who signs a local referendum petition may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(d)(i): 30 days after the day on which the voter signs the statement requesting removal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(d)(ii): 20A-7-607 45 days after the day on which the local clerk posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(e): In order for the signature to be removed, the county clerk must receive the statement described in this Subsection (8) before 5 p.m. no later than the applicable deadline described in this Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(8)(f): 20A-1-1003 A county clerk shall analyze a signature, for purposes of removing a signature from a petition, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9): 20A-1-1003
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(a): 20A-1-1003 If the county clerk timely receives a statement requesting signature removal under Subsection (8) and determines that the signature should be removed from the petition under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(a)(i): ensure that the voter's name, voter identification number, and date of signature are not included in the posting described in Subsection (6)(a)(ii)(B) or (iii)(B); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(a)(ii): remove the voter's signature from the signature packets and signature packet totals.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(b): The county clerk shall comply with Subsection (9)(a) before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(b)(i): the deadline described in Subsection (6)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(b)(ii): two business days after the day on which the county clerk receives a statement requesting signature removal under Subsection (8).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(10): A person may not retrieve a packet from a county clerk, or make any alterations or corrections to a packet, after the packet is submitted to the county clerk.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105 Manual petition processes -- Obtaining signatures -- Verification -- Submitting the petition -- Certification of signatures -- Transfer to lieutenant governor -- Removal of signature.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"You signed a petition for the following initiative:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process and the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a): "Local petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a)(i): a manual local initiative petition described in Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(a)(ii): a manual local referendum petition described in Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(b): "Packet" means an initiative packet or referendum packet.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(c): "Petition" means a local petition or statewide petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d): "Statewide petition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d)(i): a manual statewide initiative petition described in Part 2, Statewide Initiatives; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(2)(d)(ii): a manual statewide referendum petition described in Part 3, Statewide Referenda.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(a): A Utah voter may sign a statewide petition if the voter is a legal voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b): A Utah voter may sign a local petition if the voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b)(i): is a legal voter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(3)(b)(ii): resides in the local jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a): The sponsors shall ensure that the individual in whose presence each signature sheet was signed:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(i): is at least 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(ii): verifies each signature sheet by completing the verification printed on the last page of each packet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii): is informed that each signer is required to read and understand:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii)(A): for an initiative petition, the law proposed by the initiative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(a)(iii)(B): for a referendum petition, the law that the referendum seeks to overturn.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(4)(b): An individual may not sign the verification printed on the last page of a packet if the individual signed a signature sheet in the packet.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-604; 20A-7-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502; 20A-7-604 The sponsors, or an agent of the sponsors, shall submit a signed and verified packet to the county clerk of the county in which the packet was circulated before 5 p.m. no later than the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i): 20A-7-202 for a statewide initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the initiative packet;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(B): 316 days after the day on which the application for the initiative petition is filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(i)(C): 20A-7-202 the February 15 immediately before the next regular general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii): for a statewide referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the referendum packet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(ii)(B): 60 days after the day on which the legislative session at which the law passed ends;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 for a local initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the initiative packet;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(B): 316 days after the day on which the application is filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(C): 20A-7-502 the April 15 immediately before the next regular general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii)(D): 20A-7-502 the April 15 immediately before the next municipal general election immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv): 20A-7-604 for a local referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv)(A): 30 days after the day on which the first individual signs the referendum packet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iv)(B): 20A-7-604 45 days after the day on which the sponsors receive the items described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(b): A person may not submit a packet after the applicable deadline described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c): Before delivering an initiative packet to the county clerk under this Subsection (5), the sponsors shall send an email to each individual who provides a legible, valid email address on the signature sheet that includes the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c)(i): the subject of the email shall include the following statement, "Notice Regarding Your Petition Signature"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(c)(ii): the body of the email shall include the following statement in 12-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d): 20A-7-105 For a statewide initiative, the sponsors shall, no later than 5 p.m. on the day on which the sponsors submit the last initiative packet to the county clerk, submit to the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i): a list containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i)(A): the name and email address of each individual the sponsors sent, or caused to be sent, the email described in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(i)(B): the date the email was sent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(ii): a copy of the email described in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(d)(iii): 20A-7-105 the following written verification, completed and signed by each of the sponsors:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(e): For a local initiative, the sponsors shall, no later than 5 p.m. on the day on which the sponsors submit the last initiative packet to the local clerk, submit to the local clerk the items described in Subsection (5)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(5)(f): Signatures gathered for an initiative petition are not valid if the sponsors do not comply with Subsection (5)(c), (d), or (e).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6): 20A-1-1002; 20A-7-106; 20A-7-507; 20A-7-607
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a): 20A-1-1002; 20A-7-106 Within 21 days after the day on which the county clerk receives the packet, the county clerk shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(A): certify on the petition whether each name is that of a legal voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(B): post the name, voter identification number, and date of signature of each legal voter certified under Subsection (6)(a)(ii)(A) on the lieutenant governor's website, in a conspicuous location designated by the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(ii)(C): deliver the verified packet to the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii): for a local initiative or a local referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii)(A): certify on the petition whether each name is that of a legal voter who is registered in the jurisdiction to which the initiative or referendum relates;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(6)(b): 20A-7-507; 20A-7-607 For a local initiative or local referendum, the local clerk shall post a link in a conspicuous location on the local government's website to the posting described in Subsection (6)(a)(iii)(B):

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-105(9)(b)(ii): two business days after the day on which the county clerk receives a statement requesting signature removal under Subsection (8).
