Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106 Petition signature or removal for an individual with a disability.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1): If a voter who desires to sign a petition is, due to a qualifying disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act, unable to fill out the signature sheet or to sign the voter's name consistently, the voter may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(a): inform the individual gathering signatures that, due to a qualifying disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the voter is unable to fill out the signature sheet or to sign the voter's name consistently; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(b): direct the individual gathering signatures to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(b)(i): fill out the form on the signature sheet with the information provided by the voter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(b)(ii): in place of the registered voter's signature:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(b)(ii)(A): place the initials "AV" to indicate that the county clerk must use an alternate verification process to verify the validity of the voter's signature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(1)(b)(ii)(B): place next to the initials described in Subsection (1)(b)(ii)(A) a phone number, email address, or other method that the county clerk may use to contact the voter to verify the identity of the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(2): 20A-1-1003 If a voter who desires to remove the voter's signature from a petition is, due to a qualifying disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act, unable to sign the voter's name consistently, the voter may, instead of signing the statement described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(2)(a): place the initials "AV" to indicate that the county clerk must use an alternate verification process to verify the validity of the voter's signature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(2)(b): include in the statement a phone number, email address, or other method that the county clerk may use to contact the voter to verify the identity of the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(3): 20A-3a-401 The alternate verification process described in this section includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(3)(a): 20A-3a-401 the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-106(3)(b): another process established by rule, made by the director of elections within the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201 Statewide initiatives -- Signature requirements -- Submission to the Legislature or to a vote of the people.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1): 20A-7-202(2)(c)(i); (1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(a): A person seeking to have an initiative submitted to the Legislature for approval or rejection shall, after filing an initiative application, obtain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(a)(i): legal signatures equal to 4% of the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(a)(ii): from at least 26 Utah State Senate districts, legal signatures equal to 4% of the number of active voters in that district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(b): 20A-7-202(2)(c)(i); (1)(a); (1)(c) If, at any time not less than 10 days before the beginning of the next annual general session of the Legislature, the lieutenant governor declares that an initiative petition designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(c): (1)(b) The lieutenant governor shall prepare a cover sheet for a petition declared sufficient under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(c)(i): the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(c)(ii): the number of active voters in each Utah State Senate district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(c)(iii): the total number of certified signatures obtained for the initiative petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(1)(c)(iv): the total number of certified signatures obtained from each Utah State Senate district for the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2): (2)(a); 20A-7-202; 20A-7-203
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(a): A person seeking to have an initiative submitted to a vote of the people for approval or rejection shall, after filing an initiative application, obtain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(a)(i): legal signatures equal to 8% of the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(a)(ii): from at least 26 Utah State Senate districts, legal signatures equal to 8% of the number of active voters in that district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(b): (2)(a); 20A-7-202; 20A-7-203 If an initiative petition meets the requirements of this part and the lieutenant governor declares that the initiative petition is signed by a sufficient number of voters to meet the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(b)(i): 20A-7-202 immediately after the application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(2)(b)(ii): 20A-7-203 specified on the petition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(3): The lieutenant governor shall provide the following information to any interested person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(3)(a): the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-201(3)(b): for each Utah State Senate district, the number of active voters in that district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202 Statewide initiative process -- Initiative application procedures -- Time to gather signatures -- Grounds for rejection.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(1): Individuals wishing to circulate an initiative petition shall file an initiative application with the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2): 20A-7-201(1); 20A-7-201(2) The initiative application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(a): the name and residence address of at least five sponsors of the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(b): a statement indicating that each of the sponsors is registered to vote in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(c): 20A-7-201(1); 20A-7-201(2) a statement indicating whether the initiative will be presented to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(c)(i): 20A-7-201(1) the Legislature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(c)(ii): 20A-7-201(2) a vote of the people under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(d): the signature of each of the sponsors, attested to by a notary public;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(e): a copy of the proposed law that includes, in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(e)(i): the title of the proposed law, that clearly expresses the subject of the law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(e)(ii): a description of all proposed sources of funding for the costs associated with the proposed law, including the proposed percentage of total funding from each source; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(e)(iii): the text of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(f): if the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement, "This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(2)(g): a statement indicating whether persons gathering signatures for the initiative petition may be paid for gathering signatures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(3): (2); 20A-2-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(3)(a): (2); 20A-2-105 An individual's status as a resident, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(3)(b): The initiative application and the initiative application's contents are public when filed with the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(4): 20A-7-201(2)(b) If the initiative petition fails to qualify for the ballot of the election described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(4)(a): submit a new initiative application;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(4)(b): obtain new signature sheets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(4)(c): collect signatures again.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5): 20A-7-204.1(5); (6) The lieutenant governor shall reject an initiative application or an initiative application addendum filed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a): (6) the proposed law:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a)(i): is patently unconstitutional;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a)(ii): is nonsensical;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a)(iii): could not become law if passed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a)(iv): (6) contains more than one subject as evaluated in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(a)(v): is identical or substantially similar to a law proposed by an initiative for which signatures were submitted to the county clerks and lieutenant governor for certification within two years preceding the date on which the initiative application for the new initiative is filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(5)(b): the subject of the proposed law is not clearly expressed in the law's title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202(6): (5)(a)(iv) To evaluate whether the proposed law contains more than one subject under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5 Initial fiscal impact statement -- Preparation of statement -- Challenge to statement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"The Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst estimates that the law proposed by this initiative would have no significant fiscal impact and would not result in either an increase or decrease in taxes or debt."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(1): Within three working days after the day on which the lieutenant governor receives an initiative application, the lieutenant governor shall submit a copy of the initiative application to the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2): 20A-7-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a): 20A-7-202 The Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst shall prepare an unbiased, good faith initial fiscal impact statement for the proposed law, not exceeding 100 words plus 100 words per revenue source created or impacted by the proposed law, that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(i): a description of the total estimated fiscal impact of the proposed law over the time period or time periods determined by the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst to be most useful in understanding the estimated fiscal impact of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(ii): if the proposed law would increase taxes, decrease taxes, or impose a new tax, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease for each type of tax affected under the proposed law, a dollar amount showing the estimated amount of a new tax, and a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in taxes under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(iii): if the proposed law would increase a particular tax or tax rate, the tax percentage difference and the tax percentage increase for each tax or tax rate increased;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(iv): if the proposed law would result in the issuance or a change in the status of bonds,  notes, or other debt instruments, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in public debt under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(v): a dollar amount representing the estimated cost or savings, if any, to state or local government entities under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(vi): if the proposed law would increase costs to state government, a listing of all sources of funding for the estimated costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(a)(vii): 20A-7-202 a concise description and analysis titled "Funding Source," not to exceed 100 words for each funding source, of the funding source information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(2)(b): If the proposed law is estimated to have no fiscal impact, the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal impact statement in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(3): Within 25 calendar days after the day on which the lieutenant governor delivers a copy of the initiative application, the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(3)(a): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact statement to the lieutenant governor's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(3)(b): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact statement to the first five sponsors named in the initiative application.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(a): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(a)(i): Three or more of the sponsors of the initiative petition may, within 20 calendar days after the day on which the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst delivers the initial fiscal impact statement to the lieutenant governor's office, file a petition with the appropriate court, alleging that the initial fiscal impact statement, taken as a whole, is an inaccurate estimate of the fiscal impact of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(a)(ii): 20A-11-801 After receipt of the appeal, the court shall direct the lieutenant governor to send notice of the petition filed with the court to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(a)(ii)(A): any person or group that has filed an argument with the lieutenant governor's office for or against the initiative that is the subject of the challenge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(a)(ii)(B): 20A-11-801 any political issues committee established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(b)(i): There is a presumption that the initial fiscal impact statement prepared by the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst is based upon reasonable assumptions, uses reasonable data, and applies accepted analytical methods to present the estimated fiscal impact of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(b)(ii): The court may not revise the contents of, or direct the revision of, the initial fiscal impact statement unless the plaintiffs rebut the presumption by clear and convincing evidence that establishes that the initial fiscal impact statement, taken as a whole, is an inaccurate statement of the estimated fiscal impact of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(b)(iii): The court may refer an issue related to the initial fiscal impact statement to a master to examine the issue and make a report in accordance with Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 53.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.5(4)(c): The court shall certify to the lieutenant governor a fiscal impact statement for the initiative that meets the requirements of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7 Posting initiative information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1): 20A-7-202.5(3)(a) Within one business day after the day on which the lieutenant governor receives the initial fiscal impact statement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1)(a): the initiative application;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1)(b): the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1)(c): the text of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1)(d): the initial fiscal impact statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(1)(e): information describing how an individual may remove the individual's signature from the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(2): (1); (1) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(2)(a): (1) promptly update the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-202.7(2)(b): (1) maintain the information described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203 Manual initiative process -- Form of initiative petition and signature sheets.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"INITIATIVE PETITION To the Honorable ____, Lieutenant Governor:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(2)(a): Each proposed initiative petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(2)(b): If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement shall appear, in at least 14-point, bold type, immediately following the information described in Subsection (2)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(2)(c): The sponsors of an initiative or an agent of the sponsors shall attach a copy of the proposed law to each initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 Each initiative signature sheet shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(a): be printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line three-fourths inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(c): include the title of the initiative printed below the horizontal line, in at least 14-point, bold type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d): include a table immediately below the title of the initiative, and beginning .5 inch from the left side of the paper, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(i): the first column shall be .5 inch wide and include three rows;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(ii): the first row of the first column shall be .85 inch tall and contain the words "For Office Use Only" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(iii): the second row of the first column shall be .35 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(iv): the third row of the first column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(v): the second column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(vi): the first row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(vii): the second row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(viii): the third row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Street Address, City, Zip Code" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(ix): the fourth row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(x): the third column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xi): the first row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Signature of Registered Voter" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xv): the fourth column shall be one inch wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following statement, "By signing this initiative petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law proposed by this initiative petition." in 12-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(e): the table described in Subsection (3)(d) shall be repeated, leaving sufficient room at the bottom of the sheet for the information described in Subsection (3)(f); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(f): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 at the bottom of the sheet, include in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(f)(i): the words "Fiscal Impact of" followed by the title of the initiative, in at least 12-point, bold type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(f)(ii): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 except as provided in Subsection (5), the initial fiscal impact statement issued by the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(f)(iii): if the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement in 12-point, bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(f)(iv): the word "Warning," in 12-point, bold type, followed by the following statement in not less than eight-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(4): The final page of each initiative packet shall contain the following printed or typed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(5): 20A-7-204.1 If the initial fiscal impact statement described in Subsection (3)(f)(ii), as updated in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(6): If the forms described in this section are substantially followed, the initiative petitions are sufficient, notwithstanding clerical and merely technical errors.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203 Manual initiative process -- Form of initiative petition and signature sheets.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"INITIATIVE PETITION To the Honorable ____, Lieutenant Governor:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(2)(a): Each proposed initiative petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-203(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following statement, "By signing this initiative petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law proposed by this initiative petition." in 12-point type;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204 Manual initiative process -- Circulation requirements -- Lieutenant governor to provide sponsors with materials.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(2): In order to obtain the necessary number of signatures required by this part, the sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, after the sponsors receive the documents described in Subsection (3), circulate initiative packets that meet the form requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3): 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-202.5 The lieutenant governor shall provide the sponsors with a copy of the initiative petition and a signature sheet within three days after the day on which the following conditions are fulfilled:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(a): 20A-7-204.1 the sponsors hold the final hearing required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(b): 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1 the sponsors provide to the Office of the Lieutenant Governor the video tape, audio tape, or comprehensive minutes described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(c): 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-204.1
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(c)(i): 20A-7-204.1 the sponsors give written notice to the Office of the Lieutenant Governor that the sponsors waive the opportunity to change the text of the proposed law under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(d)(i)(B): if applicable, challenge the updated initial fiscal impact statement in court;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(d)(ii)(A): challenging the initial fiscal impact statement in court passes without the sponsors filing a petition to challenge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(d)(ii)(B): if applicable, challenging the updated initial fiscal impact statement in court passes without the sponsors filing a petition to challenge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(d)(iii): if the sponsors timely file a petition challenging the initial fiscal impact statement in court or, if applicable, the updated initial fiscal impact statement in court, and the court's decision becomes final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(3)(e): the sponsors sign an agreement, under Subsection (6)(a), with the Office of the Lieutenant Governor specifying the range of numbers that the sponsors will use to number the initiative packets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(4): The sponsors of the initiative shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(4)(a): arrange and pay for the printing of all documents that are part of the initiative packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(4)(b): ensure that the initiative packets and the documents described in Subsection (4)(a) meet the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(5): 20A-7-204.1
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(5)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may prepare the initiative packets for circulation by creating multiple initiative packets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(5)(b): 20A-7-204.1 The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall create the initiative packets by binding a copy of the initiative petition with the text of the proposed law, including any modification made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(5)(c): An initiative packet is not required to have a uniform number of signature sheets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, before gathering signatures:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(a)(i): contact the lieutenant governor's office to receive a range of numbers that the sponsors may use to number initiative packets;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(a)(ii): sign an agreement with the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, specifying the range of numbers that the sponsors will use to number the initiative packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(a)(iii): number each initiative packet, sequentially, within the range of numbers provided by the lieutenant governor's office, starting with the lowest number in the range.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(b)(i): number an initiative packet in a manner not directed by the lieutenant governor's office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204(6)(b)(ii): circulate or submit an initiative packet that is not numbered in the manner directed by the lieutenant governor's office.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1 Public hearings to be held before initiative petitions are circulated -- Changes to a proposed law or an initial fiscal impact statement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1): 20A-7-202.5(3)(b); 20A-7-202.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a): After issuance of the initial fiscal impact statement by the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst and before circulating initiative packets for signature statewide, sponsors of the initiative shall hold at least seven public hearings throughout Utah as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(i): one in the Bear River region -- Box Elder, Cache, or Rich County;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(ii): one in the Southwest region -- Beaver, Garfield, Iron, Kane, or Washington County;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(iii): one in the Mountain region -- Summit, Utah, or Wasatch County;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(iv): one in the Central region -- Juab, Millard, Piute, Sanpete, Sevier, or Wayne County;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(v): one in the Southeast region -- Carbon, Emery, Grand, or San Juan County;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(vi): one in the Uintah Basin region -- Daggett, Duchesne, or Uintah County; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(a)(vii): one in the Wasatch Front region -- Davis, Morgan, Salt Lake, Tooele, or Weber County.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(b): Of the seven public hearings, the sponsors of the initiative shall hold at least two of the public hearings in a first or second class county, but not in the same county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(c): 20A-7-202.5(3)(b); 20A-7-202.5 The sponsors may not hold a public hearing described in this section until the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(c)(i): 20A-7-202.5(3)(b) one day after the day on which a sponsor receives a copy of the initial fiscal impact statement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(1)(c)(ii): 20A-7-202.5 if three or more sponsors file a petition for an action challenging the accuracy of the initial fiscal impact statement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2): 45-1-101; (2)(a); (2)(a); 63G-30-102; (2)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(a): 45-1-101 The sponsors shall, before 5 p.m. at least 10 calendar days before the date of the public hearing, provide written notice of the public hearing, including the date, time, and location of the public hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(a)(i): to the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(a)(ii): to the county clerk of each county in the region where the public hearing will be held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(a)(iii): each state senator, state representative, and county commission or county council member who is elected in whole or in part from the region where the public hearing will be held; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(a)(iv): 45-1-101 in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(b): (2)(a) The lieutenant governor shall post the notice described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(c)(i): (2)(a); 63G-30-102 shall post the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(2)(c)(ii): (2)(c)(i) may bill the sponsors of the initiative for the cost of preparing, printing, and posting the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(3): (2) If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the written notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(a): During the public hearing, the sponsors shall either:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(a)(i): video tape or audio tape the public hearing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(a)(ii): take comprehensive minutes of the public hearing, detailing the names and titles of each speaker and summarizing each speaker's comments.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(b): The lieutenant governor shall make copies of the tapes or minutes available to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(c): For each public hearing, the sponsors shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(c)(i): during the entire time that the public hearing is held, post a copy of the initial fiscal impact statement in a conspicuous location at the entrance to the room where the sponsors hold the public hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(c)(ii): place at least 50 copies of the initial fiscal impact statement, for distribution to public hearing attendees, in a conspicuous location at the entrance to the room where the sponsors hold the public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(d): Regardless of whether an individual is present to observe or speak at a public hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(d)(i): the sponsors may not end the public hearing until at least one hour after the public hearing begins; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(4)(d)(ii): the sponsors shall provide at least one hour at the public hearing that is open for public comment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5): (1)(a); 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202(5); 20A-7-202.5

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5)(a)(i): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202(5) a change to the text is:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5)(a)(i)(B): 20A-7-202(5) consistent with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5)(a)(ii): each sponsor signs, attested to by a notary public, an application addendum to change the text of the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5)(b): 20A-7-202.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-204.1(5)(b)(i): Within three working days after the day on which the lieutenant governor receives an application addendum to change the text of the proposed law for an initiative, the lieutenant governor shall submit a copy of the application addendum to the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(1): In relation to the manual initiative process, when the lieutenant governor receives an initiative packet from a county clerk, the lieutenant governor shall record the number of the initiative packet received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii); 20A-7-217(4) The county clerk shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(a)(i)(A): for an initiative packet received by the county clerk before December 1, for at least 90 days; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(a)(i)(B): for an initiative packet received by the county clerk on or after December 1, for at least 45 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(a)(ii): update on the lieutenant governor's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update; or

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(b)(i)(A): for a signature received by the county clerk before December 1, for at least 90 days; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(b)(i)(B): for a signature received by the county clerk on or after December 1, for at least 45 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(2)(b)(ii): update on the lieutenant governor's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(3): (3)(b); 20A-7-201(2)(b); (3)(a); 20A-7-201; 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-201 The lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(3)(a): (3)(b); 20A-7-201(2)(b) shall, except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(3)(b)(iii): a requirement of this part has not been met.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(4)(c): The lieutenant governor shall immediately notify any one of the sponsors of the lieutenant governor's finding.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(5): After an initiative petition is declared insufficient, a person may not submit additional signatures to qualify the initiative for the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(6)(a): If the lieutenant governor refuses to declare an initiative petition sufficient that a voter believes is legally sufficient, the voter may, no later than May 15, apply to the appropriate court for an order finding the initiative petition legally sufficient.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(6)(b): If the court determines that the initiative petition is legally sufficient, the lieutenant governor shall mark the petition "sufficient" and consider the declaration of sufficiency effective as of the date on which the initiative petition should have been declared sufficient by the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(6)(c): If the court determines that the initiative petition is not legally sufficient, the court may enjoin the lieutenant governor and all other officers from certifying or printing the ballot title and numbers of that measure on the official ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-207(7): An initiative petition determined to be sufficient in accordance with this section is qualified for the ballot.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209 Short title and summary of initiative -- Duties of lieutenant governor and Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate.".Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(1): On or before June 5 before the regular general election, the lieutenant governor shall deliver a copy of all of the proposed laws that have qualified for the ballot to the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2): 20A-6-107; 20A-6-107; 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-308
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a): 20A-6-107 The Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a)(i): 20A-6-107 entitle each statewide initiative that has qualified for the ballot "Proposition Number __" and give it a number as assigned under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a)(ii): prepare for each initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a)(ii)(A): an impartial short title, not exceeding 25 words, that generally describes the subject of the initiative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a)(ii)(B): an impartial summary of the contents of the initiative, not exceeding 125 words; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(a)(iii): provide each short title, and summary to the lieutenant governor on or before June 26.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(b): The short title and summary may be distinct from the title of the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(c): If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel shall include the following statement, in bold, in the summary:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d): 20A-6-107; 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 Subject to Subsection (4), for each statewide initiative, the official ballot shall show, in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(i): 20A-6-107 the number of the initiative, determined in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(ii): the short title;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(iii): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 except as provided in Subsection (2)(e):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(iii)(A): the summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(iii)(B): the text of the proposed law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(iii)(C): 20A-7-202; 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 a link to a location on the lieutenant governor's website where a voter may review additional information relating to each initiative, including the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(d)(iv): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 the initial fiscal impact statement prepared under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(e): Unless the information described in Subsection (2)(d)(iii) is shown on the official ballot, the election officer shall include with the ballot a separate ballot proposition insert that includes the short title and summary for each initiative on the ballot and a link to a location on the lieutenant governor's website where a voter may review the additional information described in Subsection (2)(d)(iii)(C).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(2)(f): 20A-7-308 Unless the information described in Subsection (2)(d)(iii) for all initiatives on the ballot, and the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(3): On or before June 27, the lieutenant governor shall send a copy of the short title and summary to any sponsor of the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(a): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(a)(i): At least three of the sponsors of the petition may, on or before July 6, challenge the wording of the short title and summary prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel to the appropriate court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(a)(ii): 20A-11-801 After receipt of the challenge, the court shall direct the lieutenant governor to send notice of the challenge to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(a)(ii)(A): any person or group that has filed an argument for or against the initiative that is the subject of the challenge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(a)(ii)(B): 20A-11-801 any political issues committee established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(b)(i): There is a presumption that the short title prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel is an impartial description of the contents of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(b)(ii): The court may not revise the wording of the short title unless the plaintiffs rebut the presumption by clearly and convincingly establishing that the short title is false or biased.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(b)(iii): There is a presumption that the summary prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel is an impartial summary of the contents of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(b)(iv): The court may not revise the wording of the summary unless the plaintiffs rebut the presumption by clearly and convincingly establishing that the summary is false or biased.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(c): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(c)(i): examine the short title and summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(c)(ii): hear arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(c)(iii): enter an order consistent with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-209(4)(d): The lieutenant governor shall, in accordance with the court's order, certify the short title and summary to the county clerks for inclusion in the ballot or ballot proposition insert, as required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-210 Form of ballot -- Manner of voting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-210(1): 20A-7-209(2)(d) A county clerk shall ensure that the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-210(2): A voter desiring to vote in favor of enacting the law proposed by the initiative petition shall mark the square adjacent to the word "For," and a voter desiring to vote against enacting the law proposed by the initiative petition shall mark the square adjacent to the word "Against."


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211 Return and canvass -- Conflicting measures -- Law effective on proclamation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(1): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 3, Canvassing Returns The votes on the law proposed by the initiative petition shall be counted, canvassed, and delivered as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(2): After the state board of canvassers completes the canvass, the lieutenant governor shall certify to the governor the vote for and against the law proposed by the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3): 20A-7-212(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3)(a): 20A-7-212(2) The governor shall immediately issue a proclamation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3)(a)(i): gives the total number of votes cast in the state for and against each law proposed by an initiative petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3)(a)(ii): 20A-7-212(2) declares those laws proposed by an initiative petition that are approved by majority vote to be in full force and effect on the date described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3)(b): When the governor believes that two proposed laws, or that parts of two proposed laws approved by the people at the same election are entirely in conflict, the governor shall proclaim as law the initiative that receives the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in the majorities which those initiatives receive.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(3)(c): Within 10 days after the day of the governor's proclamation, any qualified voter who signed the initiative petition proposing the law that is declared by the governor to be superseded by another initiative approved at the same election may bring an action in the appropriate court to review the governor's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(4): (3)(c); 20A-7-212(2) Within 10 days after the day on which the court issues an order in an action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(4)(a): proclaim as law all initiatives approved by the people that the court determines are not entirely in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-211(4)(b): 20A-7-212(2) of the initiatives approved by the people that the court determines to be entirely in conflict, proclaim as law, regardless of the difference in majorities, the law that receives the greatest number of affirmative votes, to be in full force and effect on the date described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212 Effective date.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(1): A proposed law submitted to the Legislature by initiative petition and passed by the Legislature takes effect 60 days after the last day of the session of the Legislature in which the law passed, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(1)(a): a later effective date is included in the proposed law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(1)(b): an earlier effective date is included in the proposed law and the proposed law passes the Legislature by a two-thirds vote of the members elected to each house of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2): (2)(b); (e); (2)(d); (e); (2)(b)(ii); Title 59, Chapter 6, Mineral Production Tax Withholding; Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act; (2)(d); (e); (2)(c)(ii); (2)(b)(ii)(A); (D); (2)(e); Title 59, Chapter 2, Property Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 3, Tax Equivalent Property Act; Title 59, Chapter 4, Privilege Tax; (2)(a); (d) A proposed law submitted to the people by initiative petition that is approved by the voters at an election takes effect:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(a): (2)(b); (e) except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b): (2)(d); (e); (2)(b)(ii); Title 59, Chapter 6, Mineral Production Tax Withholding; Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(i): (2)(b)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(ii): Title 59, Chapter 6, Mineral Production Tax Withholding; Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act at the beginning of the applicable taxable year that begins on or after January 1 of the year after the general session of the Legislature next following the election, for a tax described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(ii)(A): Title 59, Chapter 6, Mineral Production Tax Withholding
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(ii)(B): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(ii)(C): Title 59, Chapter 8, Gross Receipts Tax on Certain Corporations Not Required to Pay Corporate Franchise or Income Tax Act
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(b)(ii)(D): Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(c): (2)(d); (e); (2)(c)(ii); (2)(b)(ii)(A); (D) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(c)(i): (2)(c)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(c)(ii): (2)(b)(ii)(A); (D) for a tax described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(d): (2)(e); Title 59, Chapter 2, Property Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 3, Tax Equivalent Property Act; Title 59, Chapter 4, Privilege Tax except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(d)(ii): Title 59, Chapter 3, Tax Equivalent Property Act
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(d)(iii): Title 59, Chapter 4, Privilege Tax
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(2)(e): (2)(a); (d) if the proposed law specifies a special effective date that is after the otherwise applicable effective date described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3)(a): The governor may not veto a law adopted by the people.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3)(b): The Legislature may amend any initiative approved by the people at any legislative session.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212 Effective date of initiative -- Deference given to law passed by initiative.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(1)(a): a later effective date is included in the proposed law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(1)(b): an earlier effective date is included in the proposed law and the proposed law passes the Legislature by a two-thirds vote of the members elected to each house of the Legislature.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3)(b): (3)(b)(i) If, during the general session next following the passage of a law submitted to the people by initiative petition, the Legislature amends the law, the Legislature:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3)(b)(i): shall give deference to the initiative by amending the law in a manner that, in the Legislature's determination, leaves intact the general purpose of the initiative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-212(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i) notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1): 20A-7-105; 20A-7-216 It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(a): 20A-7-105; 20A-7-216 sign any name other than the individual's own to an initiative petition or a statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same initiative at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed an initiative petition signed the initiative petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(d): sign an initiative petition knowing the individual is not a legal voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2): 20A-21-201 It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for an initiative packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the initiative petition is not the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures of those individuals whose signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(c): one or more individuals who signed the initiative petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(a): pay an individual to sign an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(c): accept payment to sign an initiative petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from an initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1): 20A-7-105; 20A-7-216; 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(a): 20A-7-105; 20A-7-216 sign any name other than the individual's own to an initiative petition or a statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same initiative at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed an initiative petition signed the initiative petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(d): sign an initiative petition knowing the individual is not a legal voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 on behalf of a voter described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e)(i): does not obtain the voluntary direction or consent of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e)(ii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter lacks the mental capacity to give the voter's direction or consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e)(iii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter does not understand the purpose or nature of the action taken by the individual on behalf of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e)(iv): intentionally or knowingly deceives the voter into providing the direction or consent of the voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(e)(v): intentionally or knowingly enters false information on the signature sheet or statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(1)(f): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2): 20A-21-201(10) It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for an initiative packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the initiative petition is not the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures of those individuals whose signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(2)(c): one or more individuals who signed the initiative petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(a): pay an individual to sign an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(c): accept payment to sign an initiative petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from an initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-213(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214 Fiscal review -- Repeal, amendment, or resubmission.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1): 20A-7-202.5(2) No later than 60 days after the date of an election in which the voters approve an initiative, the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(a): 20A-7-202.5(2) for each initiative approved by the voters, prepare a final fiscal impact statement, using current financial information and containing the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b): deliver a copy of the final fiscal impact statement to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b)(i): the president of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b)(ii): the minority leader of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b)(iii): the speaker of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b)(iv): the minority leader of the House of Representatives; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(1)(b)(v): the first five sponsors listed on the initiative application.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(2): If the final fiscal impact statement exceeds the estimate in the initial fiscal impact statement by 25% or more, the Legislature shall review the final fiscal impact statement and may, in any legislative session following the election in which the voters approve the initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(2)(a): repeal the law established by passage of the initiative;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(2)(b): amend the law established by passage of the initiative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-214(2)(c): pass a joint or concurrent resolution informing the voters that they may file an initiative petition to repeal the law enacted by passage of the initiative.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"This INITIATIVE PETITION is addressed to the Honorable ____, Lieutenant Governor:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(1): This section applies only to the electronic initiative process.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(2)(a): The first screen presented on the approved device shall include the following statement:

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(5): 20A-7-202.5; 20A-7-204.1 Subsequent screens shall be presented on the device in the following order, with the individual viewing the device being required, before advancing to the next screen, to click a link at the bottom of the screen with the following statement: "By clicking here, I attest that I have read and understand the information presented on this screen.":
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(5)(a): a description of all proposed sources of funding for the costs associated with the proposed law, including the proposed percentage of total funding from each source;

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(5)(b)(ii): if the initiative does not propose a tax increase, the following statement, "This initiative does not propose a tax increase.";

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(5)(e): the following statement, followed by links where the individual may click "yes" or "no":

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-215(6)(b): 20A-21-201 If the individual clicks "yes" in response to the question described in Subsection (5)(e), the website, or the application that accesses the website, shall take the signature-gatherer and the individual signing the initiative petition through the signature process described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216 Electronic initiative process -- Obtaining signatures -- Request to remove signature.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(1): This section applies to the electronic initiative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(2): A Utah voter may sign an initiative petition if the voter is a legal voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(3): 20A-2-105 The sponsors shall ensure that the signature-gatherer who collects a signature from an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(3)(a): 20A-2-105 verifies that the individual is at least 18 years old and meets the residency requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(3)(b): is informed that each signer is required to read and understand the law proposed by the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4): 20A-1-1003; 20A-7-217; 20A-7-217 A voter who signs an initiative petition may have the voter's signature removed from the initiative petition by, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4)(a): 20A-7-217 for an electronic signature gathered before December 1:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4)(a)(i): 30 days after the day on which the voter signs the signature removal statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4)(a)(ii): 20A-7-217 90 days after the day on which the county clerk posts the voter's name under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4)(b)(i): 30 days after the day on which the voter signs the signature removal statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(4)(b)(ii): 20A-7-217 45 days after the day on which the county clerk posts the voter's name under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(5): 20A-21-201; 20A-1-1003

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-216(5)(b): A person may only remove an electronic signature from an initiative petition in accordance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301 Referendum -- Signature requirements -- Submission to voters.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1): (1)(a); 20A-1-203
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(a): A person seeking to have a law passed by the Legislature submitted to a vote of the people shall, after filing a referendum application, obtain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(a)(i): legal signatures equal to 8% of the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(a)(ii): from at least 15 Senate districts, legal signatures equal to 8% of the number of active voters in that Senate district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(b): (1)(a); 20A-1-203 When the lieutenant governor declares that a referendum petition is signed by a sufficient number of voters to meet the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(b)(i): directs that the referendum be submitted to the voters at the next regular general election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(1)(b)(ii): 20A-1-203 calls a special election according to the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(2): When the lieutenant governor declares that a referendum petition is signed by a sufficient number of voters, the law that is the subject of the petition does not take effect unless and until it is approved by a vote of the people at a regular general election or a statewide special election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(3): The lieutenant governor shall provide the following information to any interested person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(3)(a): the number of active voters in the state on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-301(3)(b): for each county, the number of active voters in that Senate district on January 1 immediately following the last regular general election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302 Referendum process -- Application procedures.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(1): Individuals wishing to circulate a referendum petition shall file a referendum application with the lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. within five calendar days after the day on which the legislative session at which the law passed ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2): The referendum application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2)(a): the name and residence address of at least five sponsors of the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2)(b): a statement indicating that each of the sponsors is registered to vote in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2)(c): a statement indicating whether persons gathering signatures for the referendum petition may be paid for gathering signatures;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2)(d): the signature of each of the sponsors, attested to by a notary public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-302(2)(e): a copy of the law that is the subject of the proposed referendum.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303 Manual referendum process -- Form of referendum petition and signature sheets.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"REFERENDUM PETITION To the Honorable ____, Lieutenant Governor:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(1): This section applies only to the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(2)(a): Each proposed referendum petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(2)(b): The sponsors of a referendum or an agent of the sponsors shall attach a copy of the law that is the subject of the referendum to each referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3): Each referendum signature sheet shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(a): be printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line three-fourths inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(c): include the title of the referendum printed below the horizontal line, in at least 14-point, bold type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d): include a table immediately below the title of the referendum, and beginning .5 inch from the left side of the paper, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(i): the first column shall be .5 inch wide and include three rows;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(ii): the first row of the first column shall be .85 inch tall and contain the words "For Office Use Only" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(iii): the second row of the first column shall be .35 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(iv): the third row of the first column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(v): the second column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(vi): the first row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(vii): the second row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(viii): the third row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Street Address, City, Zip Code" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(ix): the fourth row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(x): the third column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xi): the first row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Signature of Registered Voter" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xv): the fourth column shall be one inch wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following words "By signing this referendum petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law that this referendum petition seeks to overturn." in 12-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(e): the table described in Subsection (3)(d) shall be repeated, leaving sufficient room at the bottom of the sheet for the information described in Subsection (3)(f); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(3)(f): at the bottom of the sheet, include the word "Warning," in 12-point, bold type, followed by the following statement in not less than eight-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(4): The final page of each referendum packet shall contain the following printed or typed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-303(5): If the forms described in this section are substantially followed, the referendum petitions are sufficient, notwithstanding clerical and merely technical errors.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304 Manual referendum process -- Circulation requirements -- Lieutenant governor to provide sponsors with materials.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a copy of the referendum petition andUtah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(1): This section applies only to the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(2): (3) In order to obtain the necessary number of signatures required by this part, the sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, after the sponsors receive the documents described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(3): (6)(a) The lieutenant governor shall provide the sponsors with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(4): (4)(a) The sponsors of the referendum petition shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(4)(a): arrange and pay for the printing of all documents that are part of the referendum packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(4)(b): (4)(a) ensure that the referendum packets and the documents described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(5)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may prepare the referendum packets for circulation by creating multiple referendum packets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(5)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall create referendum packets by binding a copy of the referendum petition with the text of the law that is the subject of the referendum and no more than 50 signature sheets together at the top in a manner that the referendum packets may be conveniently opened for signing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(5)(c): A referendum packet is not required to have a uniform number of signature sheets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, before gathering signatures:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(a)(i): contact the lieutenant governor's office to receive a range of numbers that the sponsors may use to number referendum packets;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(a)(ii): sign an agreement with the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, specifying the range of numbers that the sponsor will use to number the referendum packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(a)(iii): number each referendum packet, sequentially, within the range of numbers provided by the lieutenant governor's office, starting with the lowest number in the range.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(b)(i): number a referendum packet in a manner not directed by the lieutenant governor's office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-304(6)(b)(ii): circulate or submit a referendum packet that is not numbered in the manner directed by the lieutenant governor's office.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307 Evaluation by the lieutenant governor.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(1): In relation to the manual referendum process, when the lieutenant governor receives a referendum packet from a county clerk, the lieutenant governor shall record the number of the referendum packet received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii); 20A-7-315(4) The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(a): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii) in relation to the manual referendum process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(a)(i): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii) post the names, voter identification numbers, and dates of signatures described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(a)(ii): update on the lieutenant governor's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(b): 20A-7-315(4) in relation to the electronic referendum process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(b)(i): 20A-7-315(4) post the names, voter identification numbers, and dates of signatures described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(2)(b)(ii): update on the lieutenant governor's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3): (3)(b); (3)(a); 20A-7-301; 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-301 The lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3)(a): (3)(b) shall, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3)(b): (3)(a); 20A-7-301; 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-301 may declare the referendum petition to be insufficient before the day described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3)(b)(i): 20A-7-301 in relation to the manual referendum process, the total of all valid signatures on timely and lawfully submitted referendum packets that have been certified by the county clerks, plus the number of signatures on timely and lawfully submitted referendum packets that have not yet been evaluated for certification, is less than the number of names required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3)(b)(ii): 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-301 in relation to the electronic referendum process, the total of all timely and lawfully submitted valid signatures that have been certified by the county clerks, plus the number of timely and lawfully submitted valid signatures received under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(3)(b)(iii): a requirement of this part has not been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(4): (3); 20A-7-301; (3); 20A-7-301
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(4)(a): (3); 20A-7-301 If the total number of names certified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(4)(b): (3); 20A-7-301 If the total number of names certified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(4)(c): The lieutenant governor shall immediately notify any one of the sponsors of the lieutenant governor's finding.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(4)(d): After a referendum petition is declared insufficient, a person may not submit additional signatures to qualify the referendum for the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(5)(a): If the lieutenant governor refuses to declare a referendum petition sufficient that a voter believes is legally sufficient, the voter may, no later than 10 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the petition insufficient, apply to the appropriate court for an order finding the referendum petition legally sufficient.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(5)(b): If the court determines that the referendum petition is legally sufficient, the lieutenant governor shall mark the referendum petition "sufficient" and consider the declaration of sufficiency effective as of the date on which the referendum petition should have been declared sufficient by the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(5)(c): If the court determines that a referendum petition filed is not legally sufficient, the court may enjoin the lieutenant governor and all other officers from certifying or printing the ballot title and numbers of that measure on the official ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-307(6): A referendum petition determined to be sufficient in accordance with this section is qualified for the ballot.
