Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308 Short title and summary of referendum -- Duties of lieutenant governor and Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(1): Whenever a referendum petition is declared sufficient for submission to a vote of the people, the lieutenant governor shall deliver a copy of the referendum petition and the law to which the referendum relates to the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2): 20A-6-107; 20A-6-107; 20A-7-302; 20A-7-209
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a): 20A-6-107 The Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a)(i): 20A-6-107 entitle each statewide referendum that qualifies for the ballot "Proposition Number __" and assign a number to the referendum in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a)(ii): prepare for each referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a)(ii)(A): an impartial short title, not exceeding 25 words, that generally describes the law to which the referendum relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a)(ii)(B): an impartial summary of the contents of the law to which the referendum relates, not exceeding 125 words; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(a)(iii): submit the short title and summary to the lieutenant governor within 15 days after the day on which the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel receives the petition under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(b): The short title and summary may be distinct from the title of the law that is the subject of the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c): 20A-6-107; 20A-7-302 Subject to Subjection (4), for each statewide referendum, the official ballot shall show, in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(i): 20A-6-107 the number of the referendum, determined in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(ii): the short title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(iii): 20A-7-302 except as provided in Subsection (2)(d):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(iii)(A): the summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(iii)(B): a copy of the law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(c)(iii)(C): 20A-7-302 a link to a location on the lieutenant governor's website where a voter may review additional information relating to each referendum, including the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(d): Unless the information described in Subsection (2)(c)(iii) is shown on the official ballot, the election officer shall include with the ballot a separate ballot proposition insert that includes the short title and summary for each referendum on the ballot and a link to a location on the lieutenant governor's website where a voter may review the additional information described in Subsection (2)(c)(iii)(C).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(2)(e): 20A-7-209 Unless the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(3): Immediately after the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel submits the short title and summary to the lieutenant governor, the lieutenant governor shall mail or email a copy of the short title and summary to any of the sponsors of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(a): 20A-11-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(a)(i): At least three of the sponsors of the referendum petition may, within 15 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor sends the short title and summary, challenge the wording of the short title and summary prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel to the appropriate court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(a)(ii): 20A-11-801 After receipt of the appeal, the court shall direct the lieutenant governor to send notice of the appeal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(a)(ii)(A): any person or group that has filed an argument for or against the law to which the referendum relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(a)(ii)(B): 20A-11-801 any political issues committee established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(b)(i): There is a presumption that the short title prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel is an impartial description of the contents of the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(b)(ii): The court may not revise the wording of the short title unless the plaintiffs rebut the presumption by clearly and convincingly establishing that the short title is false or biased.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(b)(iii): There is a presumption that the summary prepared by the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel is an impartial summary of the contents of the law to which the referendum relates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(b)(iv): The court may not revise the wording of the summary unless the plaintiffs rebut the presumption by clearly and convincingly establishing that the summary is false or biased.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(c): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(c)(i): examine the short title and summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(c)(ii): hear arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(c)(iii): enter an order consistent with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-308(4)(d): The lieutenant governor shall, in accordance with the court's order, certify the short title and summary to the county clerks for inclusion in the ballot or ballot proposition insert, as required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309 Form of ballot -- Manner of voting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(1): A county clerk shall ensure that the number and ballot title certified by the lieutenant governor are presented upon the official ballot with, immediately adjacent to the number and ballot title, the words "For" and "Against," each word presented with an adjacent square in which a voter may indicate the voter's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(a)(i): A voter desiring to vote in favor of the law that is the subject of the referendum shall mark the square adjacent to the word "For."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(a)(ii): The law that is the subject of the referendum takes effect if a majority of voters mark "For."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(b)(i): A voter desiring to vote against the law that is the subject of the referendum shall mark the square adjacent to the word "Against."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-309(2)(b)(ii): The law that is the subject of the referendum does not take effect if a majority of voters mark "Against."


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310 Return and canvass -- Conflicting measures.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(1): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 3, Canvassing Returns The votes on the law that is the subject of the referendum petition shall be counted, canvassed, and delivered as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(2): After the state board of canvassers completes its canvass, the lieutenant governor shall certify to the governor the vote for and against the law that is the subject of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(3): 20A-7-311
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(3)(a): 20A-7-311 The governor shall immediately issue a proclamation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(3)(a)(i): gives the total number of votes cast in the state for and against each law that is the subject of a referendum petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(3)(a)(ii): 20A-7-311 declares those laws that are the subject of a referendum petition that are approved by majority vote to be in full force and effect as the law of Utah on the effective date described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(3)(b): When the governor determines that two laws, or that parts of two laws approved by the people at the same election are entirely in conflict, the governor shall proclaim to be law the law that received the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in the majorities which those approved laws received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(4): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(4)(a): (3) Within 10 days after the day on which the governor issues the proclamation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(4)(b): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(4)(b)(i): consider the matter and decide whether the approved laws are in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(4)(b)(ii): enter an order consistent with the court's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(5): (4)(b)(ii) Within 10 days after the day on which the court enters an order described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(5)(a): proclaim as law all those laws approved by the people that the court determines are not in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-310(5)(b): of all those laws approved by the people as law that the court determines to be in conflict, proclaim as law the one that receives the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of difference in majorities.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311 Temporary stay -- Effective date -- Effect of repeal by Legislature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1): 20A-7-307 If, at the time during the counting period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(a): issue an order temporarily staying the law from going into effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(b): continue the process of certifying signatures and removing signatures as required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2): (1); 20A-7-310 The temporary stay described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2)(a): if the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient, five days after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2)(b): 20A-7-310 if the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition sufficient, the day on which governor issues the proclamation described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3): A law submitted to the people by referendum that is approved by the voters at an election takes effect the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3)(a): five days after the date of the official proclamation of the vote by the governor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3)(b): the effective date specified in the approved law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4): (1)(a) If, after the lieutenant governor issues a temporary stay order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4)(a): five days after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4)(b): the effective date specified in the law that is the subject of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5)(a): The governor may not veto a law approved by the people.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5)(b): The Legislature may amend any laws approved by the people at any legislative session after the people approve the law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(6): If the Legislature repeals a law challenged by referendum petition under this part, the referendum petition is void and no further action on the referendum petition is required.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311 Temporary stay -- Effective date -- Effect of repeal by Legislature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1): 20A-7-307
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(a): Within 35 calendar days after the day on which the legislative session at which the law passed ends, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(a)(i): determine whether, within 30 calendar days after the day on which the legislative session at which the law passed ends, the sponsors have submitted signatures to the county clerks equal to at least 25% of the number of signatures required to qualify the referendum for placement on the ballot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(a)(ii): issue a written statement of the results of the determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(b): 20A-7-307 If the lieutenant governor determines that the sponsors have met the 25% threshold described in Subsection (1)(a), the effective date of the law challenged by the referendum changes to the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(b)(i): the effective date of the law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(1)(b)(ii): 20A-7-307 the day after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition sufficient or insufficient under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2): (1); 20A-7-307 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2)(a): issue an order temporarily staying the law from going into effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(2)(b): continue the process of certifying signatures and removing signatures as required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3): 20A-7-310 The temporary stay described in Subsection (2) remains in effect, regardless of whether a future count falls below the signature threshold, until the day on which:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3)(a): if the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient, five days after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(3)(b): 20A-7-310 if the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition sufficient, the day on which governor issues the proclamation described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4): A law submitted to the people by referendum that is approved by the voters at an election takes effect the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4)(a): five days after the date of the official proclamation of the vote by the governor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(4)(b): the effective date specified in the approved law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5): If, after the lieutenant governor issues a temporary stay order under Subsection (2)(a), the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient, the law that is the subject of the referendum petition takes effect the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5)(a): five days after the day on which the lieutenant governor declares the referendum petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(5)(b): the effective date specified in the law that is the subject of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(6)(a): The governor may not veto a law approved by the people.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(6)(b): The Legislature may amend any laws approved by the people at any legislative session after the people approve the law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-311(7): If the Legislature repeals a law challenged by referendum petition under this part, the referendum petition is void and no further action on the referendum petition is required.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(a): sign any name other than the person's own to a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(b): knowingly sign the person's name more than once for the same referendum petition at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(c): knowingly indicate that a person who signed a referendum petition signed the referendum petition on a date other than the date that the person signed the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(d): sign a referendum petition knowing the person is not a legal voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(e): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2): 20A-21-201 It is unlawful for any person to sign the verification for a referendum packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(a): the signature date associated with the person's signature for the referendum petition is not the date that the person signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(b): the person has not witnessed the signatures of those persons whose signatures the person collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(c): one or more individuals who sign the referendum petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(a): pay a person to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(b): pay a person to remove the person's signature from a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(c): accept payment to sign a referendum petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(d): accept payment to have the person's name removed from a referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(4): Any person violating this section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(a): sign any name other than the person's own to a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(b): knowingly sign the person's name more than once for the same referendum petition at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(c): knowingly indicate that a person who signed a referendum petition signed the referendum petition on a date other than the date that the person signed the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(d): sign a referendum petition knowing the person is not a legal voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(1)(e): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2): 20A-21-201(10) It is unlawful for any person to sign the verification for a referendum packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(a): the signature date associated with the person's signature for the referendum petition is not the date that the person signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(b): the person has not witnessed the signatures of those persons whose signatures the person collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(2)(c): one or more individuals who sign the referendum petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(a): pay a person to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(b): pay a person to remove the person's signature from a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(c): accept payment to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(d): accept payment to have the person's name removed from a referendum petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 on behalf of a voter described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e)(i): does not obtain the voluntary direction or consent of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e)(ii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter lacks the mental capacity to give the voter's direction or consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e)(iii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter does not understand the purpose or nature of the action taken by the individual on behalf of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e)(iv): intentionally or knowingly deceives the voter into providing the direction or consent of the voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(3)(e)(v): intentionally or knowingly enters false information on the signature sheet or statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-312(4): Any person violating this section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3 Voter participation areas.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(1): 20A-7-501; 20A-7-601
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(1)(a)(i): a city of the first or second class or a county of the first or second class shall, no later than January 1, 2020, again on January 1, 2022, and January 1 each 10 years after 2022, divide the city or county into eight contiguous and compact voter participation areas of substantially equal population; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(1)(a)(ii): a city of the third or fourth class or a county of the third or fourth class shall, no later than January 1, 2020, again on January 1, 2022, and January 1 each 10 years after 2022, divide the city or county into four contiguous and compact voter participation areas of substantially equal population.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(1)(b): 20A-7-501; 20A-7-601 A city or county shall use the voter participation areas described in Subsection (1)(a) or (2)(b) for the purpose described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(2)(a): This section does not apply to a county of the fifth or sixth class, a city of the fifth class, or a town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-401.3(2)(b): A city or county that has established council districts that are not at-large districts may, regardless of the number of council districts that are not at-large districts, use the council districts as voter participation areas under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402 Local voter information pamphlet -- Notice -- Contents -- Limitations -- Preparation -- Statement on front cover.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(1): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(1)(a): The county or municipality that is subject to a ballot proposition shall prepare a local voter information pamphlet that complies with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(1)(b): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4 Each county or municipality that contains all or part of a proposed new school district or a reorganized new school district that will appear on a regular general election ballot under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2): 63G-30-102; 63G-30-102
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(a): 63G-30-102 Within the time requirements described in Subsection (2)(c)(i), a municipality described in Subsection (1) shall provide a notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection (2)(c)(ii) to the municipality's residents by publishing the notice for the municipality, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(b): 63G-30-102 A county described in Subsection (1) shall publish a notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection (2)(c)(ii) for the county, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c): A municipality or county that publishes a notice under Subsection (2)(a) or (b) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(i): publish the notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(i)(A): not less than 90 days before the date of the election at which a special local ballot proposition will be voted upon; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(i)(B): if the requirements of Subsection (2)(c)(i)(A) cannot be met, as soon as practicable after the special local ballot proposition is approved to be voted upon in an election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(ii): ensure that the notice contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(ii)(A): the ballot title for the special local ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(ii)(B): instructions on how to file a request under Subsection (2)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(c)(ii)(C): the deadline described in Subsection (2)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(d): Except as provided in Subsection (13), to prepare a written argument for or against a special local ballot proposition, an eligible voter shall file a request with the election officer before 5 p.m. no later than 64 days before the day of the election at which the special local ballot proposition is to be voted on.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(e): If more than one eligible voter requests the opportunity to prepare a written argument for or against a special local ballot proposition, the election officer shall make the final designation in accordance with the following order of priority:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(e)(i): sponsors have priority in preparing an argument regarding a special local ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(e)(ii): members of the local legislative body have priority over others if a majority of the local legislative body supports the written argument.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(f): Except as provided in Subsection (13), the election officer shall grant a request described in Subsection (2)(d) or (e) no later than 60 days before the day of the election at which the ballot proposition is to be voted on.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(g)(i): A sponsor of a special local ballot proposition may prepare a written argument in favor of the special local ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(g)(ii): Subject to Subsection (2)(e), an eligible voter opposed to the special local ballot proposition who submits a request under Subsection (2)(d) may prepare a written argument against the special local ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h): An eligible voter who submits a written argument under this section in relation to a special local ballot proposition shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h)(i): ensure that the written argument does not exceed 500 words in length, not counting the information described in Subsection (2)(h)(ii) or (iv);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h)(ii): list, at the end of the argument, at least one, but no more than five, names as sponsors;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h)(iii): except as provided in Subsection (13), submit the written argument to the election officer before 5 p.m. no later than 55 days before the election day on which the ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h)(iv): list in the argument, immediately after the eligible voter's name, the eligible voter's residential address; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(h)(v): submit with the written argument the eligible voter's name, residential address, postal address, email address if available, and phone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(2)(i): An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish an argument submitted after the deadline described in Subsection (2)(h)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(a): An election officer who timely receives the written arguments in favor of and against a special local ballot proposition shall, within one business day after the day on which the election office receives both written arguments, send, via mail or email:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(a)(i): a copy of the written argument in favor of the special local ballot proposition to the eligible voter who submitted the written argument against the special local ballot proposition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(a)(ii): a copy of the written argument against the special local ballot proposition to the eligible voter who submitted the written argument in favor of the special local ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(b): The eligible voter who submitted a timely written argument in favor of the special local ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(b)(i): may submit to the election officer a written rebuttal argument of the written argument against the special local ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(b)(ii): shall ensure that the written rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length, not counting the information described in Subsection (2)(h)(ii) or (iv); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(b)(iii): except as provided in Subsection (13), shall submit the written rebuttal argument before 5 p.m. no later than 45 days before the election day on which the special local ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(c): The eligible voter who submitted a timely written argument against the special local ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(c)(i): may submit to the election officer a written rebuttal argument of the written argument in favor of the special local ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(c)(ii): shall ensure that the written rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length, not counting the information described in Subsection (2)(h)(ii) or (iv); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(c)(iii): except as provided in Subsection (13), shall submit the written rebuttal argument before 5 p.m. no later than 45 days before the election day on which the special local ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(3)(d): An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish a written rebuttal argument in relation to a special local ballot proposition that is submitted after the deadline described in Subsection (3)(b)(iii) or (3)(c)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (4)(b), in relation to a special local ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(a)(i): an eligible voter may not modify a written argument or a written rebuttal argument after the eligible voter submits the written argument or written rebuttal argument to the election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(a)(ii): a person other than the eligible voter described in Subsection (4)(a)(i) may not modify a written argument or a written rebuttal argument.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(b): The election officer, and the eligible voter who submits a written argument or written rebuttal argument in relation to a special local ballot proposition, may jointly agree to modify a written argument or written rebuttal argument in order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(b)(i): correct factual, grammatical, or spelling errors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(b)(ii): reduce the number of words to come into compliance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(4)(c): An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish a written argument or written rebuttal argument in relation to a special local ballot proposition if the eligible voter who submits the written argument or written rebuttal argument fails to negotiate, in good faith, to modify the written argument or written rebuttal argument in accordance with Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(5): In relation to a special local ballot proposition, an election officer may designate another eligible voter to take the place of an eligible voter described in this section if the original eligible voter is, due to injury, illness, death, or another circumstance, unable to continue to fulfill the duties of an eligible voter described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(6): 20A-7-401.5 Sponsors whose written argument in favor of a standard local ballot proposition is included in a proposition information pamphlet under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(6)(a): may, if a written argument against the standard local ballot proposition is included in the proposition information pamphlet, submit a written rebuttal argument to the election officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(6)(b): shall ensure that the written rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(6)(c): shall submit the written rebuttal argument no later than 45 days before the election day on which the standard local ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7): 20A-7-401.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7)(a): 20A-7-401.5 A county or municipality that submitted a written argument against a standard local ballot proposition that is included in a proposition information pamphlet under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7)(a)(i): may, if a written argument in favor of the standard local ballot proposition is included in the proposition information pamphlet, submit a written rebuttal argument to the election officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7)(a)(ii): shall ensure that the written rebuttal argument does not exceed 250 words in length; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7)(a)(iii): shall submit the written rebuttal argument no later than 45 days before the election day on which the ballot proposition will be submitted to the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(7)(b): If a county or municipality submits more than one written rebuttal argument under Subsection (7)(a)(i), the election officer shall select one of the written rebuttal arguments, giving preference to a written rebuttal argument submitted by a member of a local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(8)(a): An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish a written rebuttal argument that is submitted after the deadline described in Subsection (6)(c) or (7)(a)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(8)(b): Before an election officer publishes a local voter information pamphlet under this section, a written rebuttal argument is a draft for purposes of Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(8)(c): An election officer who receives a written rebuttal argument described in this section may not, before publishing the local voter information pamphlet described in this section, disclose the written rebuttal argument, or any information contained in the written rebuttal argument, to any person who may in any way be involved in preparing an opposing rebuttal argument.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (9)(b), a person may not modify a written rebuttal argument after the written rebuttal argument is submitted to the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(b): The election officer, and the person who submits a written rebuttal argument, may jointly agree to modify a written rebuttal argument in order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(b)(i): correct factual, grammatical, or spelling errors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(b)(ii): reduce the number of words to come into compliance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(c): An election officer shall refuse to accept and publish a written rebuttal argument if the person who submits the written rebuttal argument:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(c)(i): fails to negotiate, in good faith, to modify the written rebuttal argument in accordance with Subsection (9)(b); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(c)(ii): does not timely submit the written rebuttal argument to the election officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(9)(d): An election officer shall make a good faith effort to negotiate a modification described in Subsection (9)(b) in an expedited manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(10): An election officer may designate another person to take the place of a person who submits a written rebuttal argument in relation to a standard local ballot proposition if the person is, due to injury, illness, death, or another circumstance, unable to continue to fulfill the person's duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(11): 20A-7-502.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(11)(a): 20A-7-502.5 The local voter information pamphlet shall include a copy of the initial fiscal impact estimate and the legal impact statement prepared for each initiative under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(11)(b): If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the local voter information pamphlet shall include the following statement in bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12): 20A-7-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a): In preparing the local voter information pamphlet, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(i): ensure that the written arguments are printed on the same sheet of paper upon which the ballot proposition is also printed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(ii): ensure that the following statement is printed on the front cover or the heading of the first page of the printed written arguments:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(iii): pay for the printing and binding of the local voter information pamphlet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(iv): not less than 15 days before, but not more than 45 days before, the election at which the ballot proposition will be voted on, distribute, by mail or carrier, to each registered voter entitled to vote on the ballot proposition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(iv)(A): a voter information pamphlet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(a)(iv)(B): the notice described in Subsection (12)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(b)(i): If the language of the ballot proposition exceeds 500 words in length, the election officer may summarize the ballot proposition in 500 words or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(b)(ii): The summary shall state where a complete copy of the ballot proposition is available for public review.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(c): 20A-7-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(c)(i): The election officer may distribute a notice printed on a postage prepaid, preaddressed return form that a person may use to request delivery of a voter information pamphlet by mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(c)(ii): 20A-7-801 The notice described in Subsection (12)(c)(i) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(c)(ii)(A): 20A-7-801 the address of the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(12)(c)(ii)(B): the phone number a voter may call to request delivery of a voter information pamphlet by mail or carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(13): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4 For 2024 only, in relation to an election that will appear on the regular general election ballot to create a new school district under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(13)(a): the deadline to file a request described in Subsection (2)(d) is before 5 p.m. no later than five business days after the notice is published;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(13)(b): the deadline to grant a request under Subsection (2)(f) is no later than seven business days after the notice is published;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(13)(c): the deadline to submit the written argument to the election officer under Subsection (2)(h)(iii) is before 5 p.m. no later than 12 business days after the notice is published; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-402(13)(d): the deadline to submit the written rebuttal argument under Subsection (3)(b)(iii) or (c)(iii) is no later than 17 business days after the notice is published.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405 Public meeting.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(1): A county or municipality may not discuss a proposed initiative, an initiative, a proposed referendum, or a referendum at a public meeting unless the county or municipality complies with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2): The legislative body of a county or municipality may hold a public meeting to discuss a proposed initiative, an initiative, a proposed referendum, or a referendum if the legislative body:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2)(a): allows equal time, within a reasonable limit, for presentations on both sides of the proposed initiative, initiative, proposed referendum, or referendum;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2)(b): provides interested parties an opportunity to present oral testimony within reasonable time limits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2)(c): holds the public meeting:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2)(c)(i): during the legislative body's normal meeting time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(2)(c)(ii): for a meeting time other than the legislative body's normal meeting time, beginning at or after 6 p.m.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-405(3): This section does not prohibit a working group meeting from being held before 6 p.m.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-406 Informational materials.
--------------------------------------------------------
The lieutenant governor shall create and publish to the lieutenant governor's website instructions on how a person may:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-406(1): Part 5, Local Initiatives - Procedures qualify a local initiative for the ballot under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-406(2): Part 6, Local Referenda - Procedures qualify a local referendum for the ballot under


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501 Initiatives -- Signature requirements -- Time requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(1): 20A-7-401.3 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(1)(a): "Number of active voters" means the number of active voters in the county, city, or town on the immediately preceding January 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(1)(b): 20A-7-401.3 "Voter participation area" means an area described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2): An eligible voter seeking to have an initiative submitted to a local legislative body or to a vote of the people for approval or rejection shall, after filing an initiative application, obtain legal signatures equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(a): for a county of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(a)(i): 7.75% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(a)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 7.75% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(b): for a city of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(b)(i): 7.5% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(b)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 7.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(c): for a county of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(c)(i): 8% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(c)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 8% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(d): for a city of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(d)(i): 8.25% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(d)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 8.25% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(e): for a county of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(e)(i): 9.5% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(e)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 9.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(f): for a city of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(f)(i): 10% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(f)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 10% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(g): for a county of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(g)(i): 11.5% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(g)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 11.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(h): for a city of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(h)(i): 11.5% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(h)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 11.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(i): for a city of the fifth class or a county of the fifth class, 25% of the number of active voters in the city or county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(2)(j): for a town or a county of the sixth class, 35% of the number of active voters in the town or county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(3): If the total number of certified signatures collected for the initiative petition equals or exceeds the number of signatures required by this section, the clerk or recorder shall deliver the proposed law to the local legislative body at the local legislative body's next meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(a): The local legislative body shall either adopt or reject the proposed law without change or amendment within 30 days after the day on which the local legislative body receives the proposed law under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(b): The local legislative body may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(b)(i): adopt the proposed law and refer the proposed law to the people;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(b)(ii): adopt the proposed law without referring the proposed law to the people; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(b)(iii): reject the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(c): If the local legislative body adopts the proposed law but does not refer the proposed law to the people, the proposed law is subject to referendum as with other local laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(d): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(d)(i): 20A-7-502 If a county legislative body rejects a proposed law, or takes no action on a proposed law, the county clerk shall submit the proposed law to the voters of the county at the next regular general election immediately after the initiative application for the proposed law is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(d)(ii): 20A-7-502 If a local legislative body of a municipality rejects a proposed law, or takes no action on a proposed law, the municipal recorder or clerk shall submit the proposed law to the voters of the municipality at the next municipal general election immediately after the initiative application is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(e)(i): If a local legislative body rejects a proposed law, or takes no action on a proposed law, the local legislative body may adopt a competing local law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(e)(ii): The local legislative body shall prepare and adopt the competing local law within the 30-day period described in Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(e)(iii): If a local legislative body adopts a competing local law, the clerk or recorder shall refer the competing local law to the voters of the county or municipality at the same election at which the law proposed by initiative is submitted under Subsection (4)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-501(4)(f): If conflicting local laws are submitted to the people at the same election and two or more of the conflicting measures are approved by the people, the proposed law that receives the greatest number of affirmative votes shall control all conflicts.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502 Local initiative process -- Application procedures.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(1): Individuals wishing to circulate an initiative petition shall file an initiative application with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2): The initiative application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(a): the name and residence address of at least five sponsors of the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(b): a statement indicating that each of the sponsors is registered to vote in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(c): the signature of each of the sponsors, acknowledged by a notary public;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(d): a copy of the proposed law that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(d)(i): the title of the proposed law that clearly expresses the subject of the law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(d)(ii): a description of all proposed sources of funding for the costs associated with the proposed law, including the proposed percentage of total funding from each source; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(d)(iii): the text of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(e): if the initiative petition proposes a tax increase, the following statement, "This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(2)(f): a statement indicating whether persons gathering signatures for the initiative petition may be paid for gathering signatures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502(3): A proposed law submitted under this section may not contain more than one subject to the same extent that a bill may not pass containing more than one subject as provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5 Initial fiscal and legal impact statement -- Preparation of statement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"The (title of the local budget officer) estimates that the law proposed by this initiative would have no significant fiscal impact and would not result in either an increase or decrease in taxes or debt."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(1): Within three business days after the day on which the local clerk receives an initiative application, the local clerk shall submit a copy of the initiative application to the county, city, or town's budget officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a): The budget officer, together with legal counsel, shall prepare an unbiased, good faith initial fiscal and legal impact statement for the proposed law that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(i): a dollar amount representing the total estimated fiscal impact of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(ii): if the proposed law would increase or decrease taxes, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease for each type of tax affected under the proposed law and a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in taxes under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(iii): if the proposed law would increase taxes, the tax percentage difference and the tax percentage increase;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(iv): if the proposed law would result in the issuance or a change in the status of bonds, notes, or other debt instruments, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in public debt under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(v): a listing of all sources of funding for the estimated costs associated with the proposed law showing each source of funding and the percentage of total funding provided from each source;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vi): a dollar amount representing the estimated costs or savings, if any, to state and local government entities under the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii): the proposed law's legal impact, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii)(A): any significant effects on a person's vested property rights;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii)(B): any significant effects on other laws or ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii)(C): any significant legal liability the city, county, or town may incur; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii)(D): any other significant legal impact as determined by the budget officer and the legal counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(viii): a concise explanation, not exceeding 100 words, of the information described in this Subsection (2)(a) and of the estimated fiscal impact, if any, under the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(b)(i): If the proposed law is estimated to have no fiscal impact, the local budget officer shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(b)(ii): If the proposed law is estimated to have a fiscal impact, the local budget officer shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(b)(iii): If the estimated fiscal impact of the proposed law is highly variable or is otherwise difficult to reasonably express in a summary statement, the local budget officer may include in the summary statement a brief explanation that identifies those factors affecting the variability or difficulty of the estimate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(2)(b)(iv): If the proposed law would increase taxes, the local budget officer shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(3): 20A-7-402 The budget officer shall prepare an unbiased, good faith estimate of the cost of printing and distributing information related to the initiative petition in the voter information pamphlet as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(4): Within 20 calendar days after the day on which the local clerk submits a copy of the proposed law under Subsection (1), the budget officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(4)(a): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact and legal statement to the local clerk's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.5(4)(b): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact and legal statement to the first three sponsors named in the initiative application.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6 Posting initiative information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1): 20A-7-502.5(4)(a) Within one business day after the day on which the local clerk's office receives the initial fiscal impact and legal statement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1)(a): the initiative application;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1)(b): the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1)(c): the text of the proposed law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1)(d): the initial fiscal impact and legal statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(1)(e): information describing how an individual may remove the individual's signature from the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(2): (1); (1) The local clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(2)(a): (1) promptly update the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.6(2)(b): (1) maintain the information described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7 Referability to voters.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(1): 20A-7-502 Within 20 days after the day on which an eligible voter files an initiative application under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(1)(a): review the proposed law that is the subject of the initiative application to determine whether the law is legally referable to voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(1)(b): notify the first three sponsors, in writing, whether the proposed law is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(1)(b)(i): legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(1)(b)(ii): rejected as not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502 A proposed law that is the subject of an initiative application is legally referable to voters unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a): 20A-7-502 the proposed law:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a)(i): is patently unconstitutional;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a)(ii): is nonsensical;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a)(iii): is administrative, rather than legislative, in nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a)(iv): could not become law if passed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(a)(v): 20A-7-502 contains more than one subject as evaluated in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(b): 20A-7-502 is identical or substantially similar to a legally referable proposed law sought by an initiative application submitted to the local clerk, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(c): the subject of the proposed law is not clearly expressed in the law's title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(2)(d): the initiative application was not timely filed or does not comply with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(3): After the end of the 20-day period described in Subsection (1), a county, city, or town may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(3)(a): reject a proposed initiative as not legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(3)(b): bring a legal action, other than to appeal a court decision, challenging a proposed initiative on the grounds that the proposed initiative is not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(4): If a county, city, or town rejects a proposed initiative, a sponsor of the proposed initiative may, within 10 days after the day on which a sponsor is notified under Subsection (1)(b), appeal the decision to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(4)(a): district court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(4)(b): the Supreme Court, if the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction over the appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-502.7(5): 20A-7-504; 20A-21-101 If, on appeal, the court determines that the law proposed by the initiative application is legally referable to voters, the local clerk shall comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503 Manual initiative process -- Form of initiative petition and signature sheet.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"INITIATIVE PETITION To the Honorable ____, County Clerk/City Recorder/Town Clerk:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(2)(a): Each proposed initiative petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(2)(b): If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement shall appear, in at least 14-point, bold type, immediately following the information described in Subsection (2)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(2)(c): The sponsors of an initiative or an agent of the sponsors shall attach a copy of the proposed law to each initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3): 20A-7-502.5; 20A-7-502.5 Each initiative signature sheet shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(a): be printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line three-fourths inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(c): include the title of the initiative printed below the horizontal line, in at least 14-point, bold type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d): include a table immediately below the title of the initiative, and beginning .5 inch from the left side of the paper, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(i): the first column shall be .5 inch wide and include three rows;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(ii): the first row of the first column shall be .85 inch tall and contain the words "For Office Use Only" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(iii): the second row of the first column shall be .35 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(iv): the third row of the first column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(v): the second column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(vi): the first row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(vii): the second row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(viii): the third row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Street Address, City, Zip Code" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(ix): the fourth row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(x): the third column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xi): the first row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Signature of Registered Voter" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xv): the fourth column shall be one inch wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following words "By signing this initiative petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law proposed by this initiative petition." in 12-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(e): the table described in Subsection (3)(d) shall be repeated, leaving sufficient room at the bottom of the sheet for the information described in Subsection (3)(f); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(f): 20A-7-502.5; 20A-7-502.5 at the bottom of the sheet, include in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(f)(i): the words "Fiscal and legal impact of" followed by the title of the initiative, in at least 12-point, bold type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(f)(ii): 20A-7-502.5; 20A-7-502.5 the summary statement in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement issued by the budget officer in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(f)(iii): if the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement in 12-point, bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(3)(f)(iv): the word "Warning," in 12-point, bold type, followed by the following statement in not less than eight-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(4): The final page of each initiative packet shall contain the following printed or typed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(5): If the forms described in this section are substantially followed, the initiative petitions are sufficient, notwithstanding clerical and merely technical errors.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503 Manual initiative process -- Form of initiative petition and signature sheet.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"INITIATIVE PETITION To the Honorable ____, County Clerk/City Recorder/Town Clerk:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-503(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.
