Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504 Manual initiative process -- Circulation requirements -- Local clerk to provide sponsors with materials.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(1): This section applies only to the manual initiative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(2): 20A-7-401.5 In order to obtain the necessary number of signatures required by this part, the sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, after the sponsors receive the documents described in Subsections (3) and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(3): 20A-7-502.7; 20A-7-401.5(4)(b) Within five days after the day on which a county, city, town, or court determines, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(3)(a): a copy of the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(3)(b): a signature sheet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(3)(c): 20A-7-401.5(4)(b) a copy of the proposition information pamphlet provided to the sponsors under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(4): The sponsors of the initiative shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(4)(a): arrange and pay for the printing of all documents that are part of the initiative packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(4)(b): ensure that the initiative packets and the documents described in Subsection (4)(a) meet the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(5): 20A-7-401.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(5)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may prepare the initiative packets for circulation by creating multiple initiative packets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(5)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall create initiative packets by binding a copy of the initiative petition with the text of the proposed law and no more than 50 signature sheets together at the top in a manner that the initiative packets may be conveniently opened for signing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(5)(c): An initiative packet is not required to have a uniform number of signature sheets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(5)(d): 20A-7-401.5 The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall include, with each initiative packet, a copy of the proposition information pamphlet provided to the sponsors under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, before gathering signatures:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(a)(i): contact the county clerk to receive a range of numbers that the sponsors may use to number initiative packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(a)(ii): number each initiative packet, sequentially, within the range of numbers provided by the county clerk, starting with the lowest number in the range.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(b)(i): number an initiative packet in a manner not directed by the county clerk; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(b)(ii): circulate or submit an initiative packet that is not numbered in the manner directed by the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-504(6)(c): The county clerk shall keep a record of the number range provided under Subsection (6)(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507 Evaluation by the local clerk.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(1): In relation to the manual initiative process, when a local clerk receives an initiative packet from a county clerk, the local clerk shall record the number of the initiative packet received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii); 20A-7-516(4) The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(a): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii) in relation to the manual initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(a)(i): 20A-7-105(6)(a)(iii) post the names, voter identification numbers, and dates of signatures described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(a)(ii): update on the local government's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(b): 20A-7-516(4) in relation to the electronic initiative process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(b)(i): 20A-7-516(4) post the names, voter identification numbers, and dates of signatures described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(2)(b)(ii): update on the local government's website the number of signatures certified as of the date of the update.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3): (3)(b); 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii); 20A-7-516(2); (3)(a); 20A-7-501; 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-501 The local clerk:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(a): (3)(b); 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii); 20A-7-516(2) shall, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(a)(i): 20A-7-105(5)(a)(iii) in relation to the manual initiative process, no later than 21 days after the day of the applicable deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(a)(ii): 20A-7-516(2) in relation to the electronic initiative process, no later than 21 days after the day of the applicable deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(b): (3)(a); 20A-7-501; 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-501 may declare the initiative petition to be insufficient before the day described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(b)(i): 20A-7-501 in relation to the manual initiative process, the total of all valid signatures on timely and lawfully submitted initiative packets that have been certified by the county clerks, plus the number of signatures on timely and lawfully submitted initiative packets that have not yet been evaluated for certification, is less than the number of names required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(b)(ii): 20A-21-201(6)(b); 20A-7-501 in relation to the electronic initiative process, the total of all timely and lawfully submitted valid signatures that have been certified by the county clerks, plus the number of timely and lawfully submitted valid signatures received under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(3)(b)(iii): a requirement of this part has not been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(4): (3); 20A-7-501; (3); 20A-7-501
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(4)(a): (3); 20A-7-501 If the total number of names certified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(4)(b): (3); 20A-7-501 If the total number of names certified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(4)(c): The local clerk shall immediately notify any one of the sponsors of the local clerk's finding.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(4)(d): After an initiative petition is declared insufficient, a person may not submit additional signatures to qualify the initiative for the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(5): If the local clerk finds the total number of certified signatures for the initiative petition to be insufficient, any sponsor may file a written demand with the local clerk for a recount of the signatures collected for the initiative petition in the presence of any sponsor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-507(6): An initiative petition determined to be sufficient in accordance with this section is qualified for the ballot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508 Short title and summary of initiative -- Duties of local clerk and local attorney.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"This initiative seeks to increase the current (insert name of tax) rate by (insert the tax percentage difference) percent, resulting in a(n) (insert the tax percentage increase) percent increase in the current tax rate.".Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(1): Upon receipt of an initiative petition, the local clerk shall deliver a copy of the initiative petition and the proposed law to the local attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2): 20A-6-107 The local attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(a): 20A-6-107 entitle each county or municipal initiative that has qualified for the ballot "Proposition Number __" and give it a number as assigned under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(b): prepare for each initiative:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(b)(i): an impartial short title, not exceeding 25 words, that generally describes the subject of the initiative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(b)(ii): an impartial summary of the contents of the initiative, not exceeding 125 words;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(c): file the proposed short title, summary, and the numbered initiative titles with the local clerk within 20 days after the day on which an eligible voter submits the initiative petition to the local clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(d): promptly provide notice of the filing of the proposed short title and summary to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(d)(i): the sponsors of the initiative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(2)(d)(ii): the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the initiative petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3)(a): The short title and summary may be distinct from the title of the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3)(b): In preparing a short title, the local attorney shall, to the best of the local attorney's ability, give a true and impartial description of the subject of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3)(c): In preparing a summary, the local attorney shall, to the best of the local attorney's ability, give a true and impartial summary of the contents of the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3)(d): The short title and summary may not intentionally be an argument, or likely to create prejudice, for or against the initiative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(3)(e): If the initiative proposes a tax increase, the local attorney shall include the following statement, in bold, in the summary:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502.5; 20A-7-608
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(a): Within five calendar days after the date the local attorney files a proposed short title and summary under Subsection (2)(c), the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the initiative petition was circulated and the sponsors of the initiative may file written comments in response to the proposed short title and summary with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(b): Within five calendar days after the last date to submit written comments under Subsection (4)(a), the local attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(b)(i): review any written comments filed in accordance with Subsection (4)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(b)(ii): prepare a final short title and summary that meets the requirements of Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(b)(iii): return the initiative petition and file the short title and summary with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502.5 Subject to Subsection (6), for each county or municipal initiative, the following shall be printed on the official ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c)(i): the short title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c)(ii): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502.5 except as provided in Subsection (4)(d):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c)(ii)(A): the summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c)(ii)(B): a copy of the proposed law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(c)(ii)(C): 20A-7-502; 20A-7-502.5 a link to a location on the election officer's website where a voter may review additional information relating to each initiative, including the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(d): Unless the information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii) is printed on the official ballot, the election officer shall include with the ballot a separate ballot proposition insert that includes the short title and summary for each initiative on the ballot and a link to a location on the election officer's website where a voter may review the additional information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii)(C).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(4)(e): 20A-7-608 Unless the information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii) for all initiatives on the ballot, and the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(5): Immediately after the local attorney files a copy of the short title and summary with the local clerk, the local clerk shall send a copy of the short title and summary to the sponsors of the initiative and the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the initiative petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(a): If the short title or summary furnished by the local attorney is unsatisfactory or does not comply with the requirements of this section, the decision of the local attorney may be appealed to the appropriate court by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(a)(i): at least three sponsors of the initiative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(a)(ii): a majority of the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the initiative petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(b): The court:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(b)(i): shall examine the short title and summary and consider arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(b)(ii): enter an order consistent with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-508(6)(c): The local clerk shall include the short title and summary in the ballot or ballot proposition insert, as required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-509 Form of ballot -- Manner of voting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-509(1): The local clerk shall ensure that the number and ballot title are presented upon the official ballot with, immediately adjacent to them, the words "For" and "Against," each word presented with an adjacent square in which the voter may indicate the voter's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-509(2): Voters desiring to vote in favor of enacting the law proposed by the initiative petition shall mark the square adjacent to the word "For," and voters desiring to vote against enacting the law proposed by the initiative petition shall mark the square adjacent to the word "Against."


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510 Return and canvass -- Conflicting measures -- Law effective on proclamation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(1): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 3, Canvassing Returns The votes on the law proposed by the initiative petition shall be counted, canvassed, and delivered as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(2): After the local board of canvassers completes the canvass, the local clerk shall certify to the local legislative body the vote for and against the law proposed by the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(a): The local legislative body shall immediately issue a proclamation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(a)(i): gives the total number of votes cast in the local jurisdiction for and against each law proposed by an initiative petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(a)(ii): declares those laws proposed by an initiative petition that are approved by majority vote to be in full force and effect as the law of the local jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(b): When the local legislative body determines that two proposed laws, or that parts of two proposed laws approved by the people at the same election are entirely in conflict, the local legislative body shall proclaim as law the initiative that received the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in the majorities which those initiatives have received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(c)(i): Within 10 days after the day on which the local legislative body issues the proclamation, any qualified voter who signed the initiative petition proposing the law that is declared by the local legislative body to be superseded by another initiative approved at the same election may bring an action in the appropriate court to review the decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(c)(ii): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(c)(ii)(A): consider the matter and decide whether the proposed laws are entirely in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(3)(c)(ii)(B): issue an order, consistent with the court's decision, to the local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(4): (3)(c)(ii) Within 10 days after the day on which the court enters an order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(4)(a): proclaim as law all initiatives approved by the people that the court determines are not in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-510(4)(b): for the initiatives approved by the people as law that the court determines to be in conflict, proclaim as law the initiative that received the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in majorities.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-511 Effective date.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-511(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-511(1)(a): Any proposed law submitted to the people by initiative petition that is approved by the voters at any election takes effect on the date specified in the initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-511(1)(b): If the initiative petition does not specify an effective date, a law approved by the voters at any election takes effect five days after the date of the official proclamation of the vote by the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-511(2): The local legislative body may amend any laws approved by the people at any meeting after the law has taken effect.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1): 20A-7-105(8); 20A-7-515 It is unlawful for any individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(a): 20A-7-105(8); 20A-7-515 sign any name other than the individual's own name to an initiative petition or a statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same initiative at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed an initiative petition signed the initiative petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(d): sign an initiative petition knowing the individual is not a legal voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(e): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2): 20A-21-201 It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for an initiative packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the initiative petition is not the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures of the individuals whose signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(c): one or more individuals who signed the initiative petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(a): pay an individual to sign an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(c): accept payment to sign an initiative petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from an initiative petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1): 20A-7-105(8); 20A-7-515 It is unlawful for any individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(a): 20A-7-105(8); 20A-7-515 sign any name other than the individual's own name to an initiative petition or a statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same initiative at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed an initiative petition signed the initiative petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(d): sign an initiative petition knowing the individual is not a legal voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(1)(e): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2): 20A-21-201(10) It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for an initiative packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the initiative petition is not the date that the individual signed the initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures of the individuals whose signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(2)(c): one or more individuals who signed the initiative petition are not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(a): pay an individual to sign an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(c): accept payment to sign an initiative petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from an initiative petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 on behalf of a voter described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e)(i): does not obtain the voluntary direction or consent of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e)(ii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter lacks the mental capacity to give the voter's direction or consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e)(iii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter does not understand the purpose or nature of the action taken by the individual on behalf of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e)(iv): intentionally or knowingly deceives the voter into providing the direction or consent of the voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(3)(e)(v): intentionally or knowingly enters false information on the signature sheet or statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-512(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513 Fiscal review -- Repeal, amendment, or resubmission.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1): 20A-7-502.5(2); 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii) No later than 60 days after the date of an election in which the voters approve an initiative, the budget officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1)(a): 20A-7-502.5(2); 20A-7-502.5(2)(a)(vii) for each initiative approved by the voters, prepare a final fiscal impact statement, using current financial information and containing the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1)(b): deliver a copy of the final fiscal impact statement to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1)(b)(i): the local legislative body of the jurisdiction where the initiative was circulated;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1)(b)(ii): the local clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(1)(b)(iii): the first three sponsors listed on the initiative application.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(2): If the final fiscal impact statement exceeds the estimate in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement by 25% or more, the local legislative body shall review the final fiscal impact statement and may, by a majority vote:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(2)(a): repeal the law established by passage of the initiative;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(2)(b): amend the law established by the passage of the initiative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-513(2)(c): pass a resolution informing the voters that they may file an initiative petition to repeal the law enacted by passage of the initiative.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601 Referenda -- General signature requirements -- Signature requirements for land use laws, subjurisdictional laws, and transit area land use laws -- Time requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1): 17B-2a-802; 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1; 63N-3-602; 20A-7-401.3 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(a): "Number of active voters" means the number of active voters in the county, city, or town on the immediately preceding January 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(b): 17B-2a-802 "Qualifying county" means a county that has created a small public transit district, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(c): 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1; 63N-3-602 "Qualifying transit area" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(c)(i): 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1; 10-9a-403.1 a station area, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(c)(ii): 63N-3-602 a housing and transit reinvestment zone, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(d): "Subjurisdiction" means an area comprised of all precincts and subprecincts in the jurisdiction of a county, city, or town that are subject to a subjurisdictional law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(e)(i): "Subjurisdictional law" means a local law or local obligation law passed by a local legislative body that imposes a tax or other payment obligation on property in an area that does not include all precincts and subprecincts under the jurisdiction of the county, city, or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(e)(ii): "Subjurisdictional law" does not include a land use law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(f): "Transit area land use law" means a land use law that relates to the use of land within a qualifying transit area.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(1)(g): 20A-7-401.3 "Voter participation area" means an area described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2): Except as provided in Subsections (3) through (5), an eligible voter seeking to have a local law passed by the local legislative body submitted to a vote of the people shall, after filing a referendum application, obtain legal signatures equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(a): for a county of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(a)(i): 7.75% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(a)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 7.75% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(b): for a city of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(b)(i): 7.5% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(b)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 7.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(c): for a county of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(c)(i): 8% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(c)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 8% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(d): for a city of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(d)(i): 8.25% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(d)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 8.25% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(e): for a county of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(e)(i): 9.5% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(e)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 9.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(f): for a city of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(f)(i): 10% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(f)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 10% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(g): for a county of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(g)(i): 11.5% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(g)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 11.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(h): for a city of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(h)(i): 11.5% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(h)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 11.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(i): for a city of the fifth class or a county of the fifth class, 25% of the number of active voters in the city or county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(2)(j): for a town or a county of the sixth class, 35% of the number of active voters in the town or county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3): Except as provided in Subsection (4) or (5), an eligible voter seeking to have a land use law or local obligation law passed by the local legislative body submitted to a vote of the people shall, after filing a referendum application, obtain legal signatures equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(a): for a county of the first, second, third, or fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(a)(i): 16% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(a)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 16% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(b): for a county of the fifth or sixth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(b)(i): 16% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(b)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 16% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(c): for a city of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(c)(i): 15% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(c)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 15% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(d): for or a city of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(d)(i): 16% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(d)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 16% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(e): for a city of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(e)(i): 27.5% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(e)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 27.5% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(f): for a city of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(f)(i): 29% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(f)(ii): beginning on January 1, 2020, 29% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(g): for a city of the fifth class, 35% of the number of active voters in the city; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(3)(h): for a town, 40% of the number of active voters in the town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4): A person seeking to have a subjurisdictional law passed by the local legislative body submitted to a vote of the people shall, after filing a referendum application, obtain legal signatures of the residents in the subjurisdiction equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(a): 10% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters exceeds 25,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(b): 12-1/2% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters does not exceed 25,000 but is more than 10,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(c): 15% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters does not exceed 10,000 but is more than 2,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(d): 20% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters does not exceed 2,500 but is more than 500;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(e): 25% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters does not exceed 500 but is more than 250; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(4)(f): 30% of the number of active voters in the subjurisdiction if the number of active voters does not exceed 250.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5): An eligible voter seeking to have a transit area land use law passed by the local legislative body submitted to a vote of the people shall, after filing a referendum application, obtain legal signatures equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(a): for a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(a)(i): 20% of the number of active voters in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(a)(ii): 21% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the county's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(b): for a city of the first class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(b)(i): 20% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(b)(ii): 20% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(c): for a city of the second class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(c)(i): 20% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(c)(ii): 21% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(d): for a city of the third class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(d)(i): 34% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(d)(ii): 34% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(e): for a city of the fourth class:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(e)(i): 36% of the number of active voters in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(e)(ii): 36% of the number of active voters in at least 75% of the city's voter participation areas; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(5)(f): for a city of the fifth class or a town, 40% of the number of active voters in the city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(6): Sponsors of any referendum petition challenging, under Subsection (2), (3), (4), or (5), any local law passed by a local legislative body shall file the application before 5 p.m. within five days after the day on which the local law was passed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-601(7): Nothing in this section authorizes a local legislative body to impose a tax or other payment obligation on a subjurisdiction in order to benefit an area outside of the subjurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602 Local referendum process -- Application procedures.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(1): Individuals wishing to circulate a referendum petition shall file a referendum application with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2): The referendum application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(a): the name and residence address of at least five sponsors of the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(b): a statement indicating that each of the sponsors is registered to vote in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(c): a statement indicating whether persons gathering signatures for the referendum petition may be paid for gathering signatures;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(d): the signature of each of the sponsors, acknowledged by a notary public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(e)(i): if the referendum challenges an ordinance or resolution, a copy of the ordinance or resolution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602(2)(e)(ii): if the referendum challenges a local law that is not an ordinance or resolution, a written description of the local law, including the result of the vote on the local law.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5 Initial fiscal and legal impact statement -- Preparation of statement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"The (title of the local budget officer) estimates that repealing the law this referendum proposes to repeal would have no significant fiscal impact and would not result in either an increase or decrease in taxes or debt."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(1): Within three business days after the day on which the local clerk receives a referendum application, the local clerk shall submit a copy of the referendum application to the county, city, or town's budget officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a): The budget officer, together with legal counsel, shall prepare an unbiased, good faith initial fiscal and legal impact statement for repealing the law the referendum proposes to repeal that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(i): a dollar amount representing the total estimated fiscal impact of repealing the law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(ii): if repealing the law would increase or decrease taxes, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease for each type of tax that would be impacted by the law's repeal and a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in taxes that would result from the law's repeal;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(iii): if repealing the law would result in the issuance or a change in the status of bonds, notes, or other debt instruments, a dollar amount representing the total estimated increase or decrease in public debt that would result;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(iv): a listing of all sources of funding for the estimated costs that would be associated with the law's repeal, showing each source of funding and the percentage of total funding that would be provided from each source;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(v): a dollar amount representing the estimated costs or savings, if any, to state and local government entities if the law were repealed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vi): the legal impacts that would result from repealing the law, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vi)(A): any significant effects on a person's vested property rights;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vi)(B): any significant effects on other laws or ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vi)(C): any significant legal liability the city, county, or town may incur; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vi)(D): any other significant legal impact as determined by the budget officer and the legal counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(a)(vii): a concise explanation, not exceeding 100 words, of the information described in this Subsection (2)(a) and of the estimated fiscal impact, if any, if the law were repealed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(b)(i): If repealing the law would have no fiscal impact, the local budget officer shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal impact and legal statement in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(b)(ii): If repealing the law is estimated to have a fiscal impact, the local budget officer shall include a summary statement in the initial fiscal and legal impact statement describing the fiscal impact.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(2)(b)(iii): If the estimated fiscal impact of repealing the law is highly variable or is otherwise difficult to reasonably express in a summary statement, the local budget officer may include in the summary statement a brief explanation that identifies those factors impacting the variability or difficulty of the estimate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(3): Within 20 calendar days after the day on which the local clerk submits a copy of the application under Subsection (1), the budget officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(3)(a): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact and legal statement to the local clerk's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.5(3)(b): send a copy of the initial fiscal impact and legal statement to the first three sponsors named in the referendum application.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7 Referability to voters of local law other than land use law.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(1): 20A-7-602 Within 20 days after the day on which an eligible voter files a referendum application under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(1)(a): review the referendum application to determine whether the proposed referendum is legally referable to voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(1)(b): notify the first three sponsors, in writing, whether the proposed referendum is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(1)(b)(i): legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(1)(b)(ii): rejected as not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(2): For a local law other than a land use law, a proposed referendum is legally referable to voters unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(2)(a): the proposed referendum challenges an action that is administrative, rather than legislative, in nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(2)(b): the proposed referendum challenges more than one law passed by the local legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(2)(c): the referendum application was not timely filed or does not comply with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(3): After the end of the 20-day period described in Subsection (1), a county, city, or town may not, for a local law other than a land use law:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(3)(a): reject a proposed referendum as not legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(3)(b): except as provided in Subsection (4), challenge, in a legal action or otherwise, a proposed referendum on the grounds that the proposed referendum is not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(4)(a): If, under Subsection (1)(b)(ii), a county, city, or town rejects a proposed referendum concerning a local law other than a land use law, a sponsor of the proposed referendum may, within 10 days after the day on which a sponsor is notified under Subsection (1)(b), challenge or appeal the decision to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(4)(a)(i): the Supreme Court, by means of an extraordinary writ, if possible; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(4)(a)(ii): a district court, if the sponsor is prohibited from pursuing an extraordinary writ under Subsection (4)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(4)(b): Failure of a sponsor to timely challenge or appeal a rejection under Subsection (4)(a) terminates the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.7(5): 20A-7-604; 20A-21-101 If, on a challenge or appeal, the court determines that the proposed referendum described in Subsection (4) is legally referable to voters, the local clerk shall comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8 Referability to voters of local land use law.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(1): 20A-7-602 Within 20 days after the day on which a referendum eligible voter files an application under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(1)(a): review the referendum application to determine whether the proposed referendum is legally referable to voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(1)(b): notify the first three sponsors, in writing, whether the proposed referendum is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(1)(b)(i): legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(1)(b)(ii): rejected as not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103; 20A-7-101; 20A-7-601
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(a): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103 Subject to Subsection (2)(b), for a land use law, a proposed referendum is legally referable to voters unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(a)(i): the proposed referendum challenges an action that is administrative, rather than legislative, in nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(a)(ii): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103 the proposed referendum challenges a land use decision, rather than a land use regulation, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(a)(iii): the proposed referendum challenges more than one law passed by the local legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(a)(iv): the referendum application was not timely filed or does not comply with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(b): 20A-7-101; 20A-7-601 In addition to the limitations of Subsection (2)(a), a proposed referendum is not legally referable to voters for a:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(b)(i): 20A-7-101 municipal land use law, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(2)(b)(ii): 20A-7-601 transit area land use law, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(3): After the end of the 20-day period described in Subsection (1), a county, city, or town may not, for a land use law:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(3)(a): reject a proposed referendum as not legally referable to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(3)(b): except as provided in Subsection (4), challenge, in a legal action or otherwise, a proposed referendum on the grounds that the proposed referendum is not legally referable to voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(4)(a): If a county, city, or town rejects a proposed referendum concerning a land use law, a sponsor of the proposed referendum may, within seven days after the day on which a sponsor is notified under Subsection (1)(b), challenge or appeal the decision to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(4)(a)(i): the Supreme Court, by means of an extraordinary writ, if possible; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(4)(a)(ii): a district court, if the sponsor is prohibited from pursuing an extraordinary writ under Subsection (4)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(4)(b): Failure of a sponsor to timely challenge or appeal a rejection under Subsection (4)(a) terminates the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-602.8(5): 20A-7-604; 20A-21-101 If, on challenge or appeal, the court determines that the proposed referendum is legally referable to voters, the local clerk shall comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603 Manual referendum process -- Form of referendum petition and signature sheet.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"REFERENDUM PETITION To the Honorable ____, County Clerk/City Recorder/Town Clerk:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(1): This section applies only to the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2)(a): Each proposed referendum petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2)(b): The sponsors of a referendum or an agent of the sponsors shall attach a copy of the law that is the subject of the referendum to each referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3): Each referendum signature sheet shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(a): be printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line three-fourths inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(c): include the title of the referendum printed below the horizontal line, in at least 14-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d): include a table immediately below the title of the referendum, and beginning .5 inch from the left side of the paper, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(i): the first column shall be .5 inch wide and include three rows;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(ii): the first row of the first column shall be .85 inch tall and contain the words "For Office Use Only" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(iii): the second row of the first column shall be .35 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(iv): the third row of the first column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(v): the second column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(vi): the first row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(vii): the second row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(viii): the third row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Street Address, City, Zip Code" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(ix): the fourth row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(x): the third column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xi): the first row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Signature of Registered Voter" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xv): the fourth column shall be one inch wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following words, "By signing this referendum petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law that this referendum petition seeks to overturn." in 12-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(e): the table described in Subsection (3)(d) shall be repeated, leaving sufficient room at the bottom of the sheet or the information described in Subsection (3)(f); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(f): at the bottom of the sheet, include the word "Warning," in 12-point, bold type, followed by the following statement in not less than eight-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(4): The final page of each referendum packet shall contain the following printed or typed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(5): If the forms described in this section are substantially followed, the referendum petitions are sufficient, notwithstanding clerical and merely technical errors.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603 Manual referendum process -- Form of referendum petition and signature sheet.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"REFERENDUM PETITION To the Honorable ____, County Clerk/City Recorder/Town Clerk:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(1): This section applies only to the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2)(a): Each proposed referendum petition shall be printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(2)(b): The sponsors of a referendum or an agent of the sponsors shall attach a copy of the law that is the subject of the referendum to each referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3): Each referendum signature sheet shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(a): be printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line three-fourths inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(c): include the title of the referendum printed below the horizontal line, in at least 14-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d): include a table immediately below the title of the referendum, and beginning .5 inch from the left side of the paper, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(i): the first column shall be .5 inch wide and include three rows;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(ii): the first row of the first column shall be .85 inch tall and contain the words "For Office Use Only" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(iii): the second row of the first column shall be .35 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(iv): the third row of the first column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(v): the second column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(vi): the first row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(vii): the second row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(viii): the third row of the second column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Street Address, City, Zip Code" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(ix): the fourth row of the second column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(x): the third column shall be 2.75 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xi): the first row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Signature of Registered Voter" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xii): the second row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xiii): the third row of the third column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Email Address (optional, to receive additional information)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xiv): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xv): the fourth column shall be one inch wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xvi): the first row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Date Signed" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xvii): the second row of the fourth column shall be .5 inch tall;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xviii): the third row of the fourth column shall be .35 inch tall and contain the words "Birth Date or Age (optional)" in 10-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xix): the fourth row of the third column shall be .5 inch tall; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(d)(xx): the fifth row of the entire table shall be the width of the entire table, .4 inch tall, and contain the following words, "By signing this referendum petition, you are stating that you have read and understand the law that this referendum petition seeks to overturn." in 12-point type;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(e): the table described in Subsection (3)(d) shall be repeated, leaving sufficient room at the bottom of the sheet or the information described in Subsection (3)(f); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(3)(f): at the bottom of the sheet, include the word "Warning," in 12-point, bold type, followed by the following statement in not less than eight-point type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(4): The final page of each referendum packet shall contain the following printed or typed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-603(5): If the forms described in this section are substantially followed, the referendum petitions are sufficient, notwithstanding clerical and merely technical errors.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604 Manual referendum process -- Circulation requirements -- Local clerk to provide sponsors with materials.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(1): This section applies only to the manual referendum process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(2): 20A-7-401.5 In order to obtain the necessary number of signatures required by this part, the sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, after the sponsors receive the documents described in Subsections (3) and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(3): 20A-7-602.7; 20A-7-401.5 Within five days after the day on which a county, city, town, or court determines, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(3)(a): a copy of the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(3)(b): a signature sheet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(3)(c): 20A-7-401.5 a copy of the proposition information pamphlet provided to the sponsors under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(4): The sponsors of the referendum petition shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(4)(a): arrange and pay for the printing of all documents that are part of the referendum packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(4)(b): ensure that the referendum packets and the documents described in Subsection (4)(a) meet the form requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(5): 20A-7-401.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(5)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may prepare the referendum packets for circulation by creating multiple referendum packets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(5)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall create referendum packets by binding a copy of the referendum petition with the text of the law that is the subject of the referendum and no more than 50 signature sheets together at the top in a manner that the referendum packets may be conveniently opened for signing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(5)(c): A referendum packet is not required to have a uniform number of signature sheets.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(5)(d): 20A-7-401.5 The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall include, with each packet, a copy of the proposition information pamphlet provided to the sponsors under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(a): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors shall, before gathering signatures:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(a)(i): contact the county clerk to receive a range of numbers that the sponsors may use to number referendum packets;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(a)(ii): sign an agreement with the local clerk, specifying the range of numbers that the sponsor will use to number the referendum packets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(a)(iii): number each referendum packet, sequentially, within the range of numbers provided by the county clerk, starting with the lowest number in the range.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(b): The sponsors or an agent of the sponsors may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(b)(i): number a referendum packet in a manner not directed by the county clerk; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-604(6)(b)(ii): circulate or submit a referendum packet that is not numbered in the manner directed by the county clerk.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-607(4)(d): After a referendum petition is declared insufficient, a person may not submit additional signatures to qualify the referendum for the ballot.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-607(5)(b): If the court determines that the referendum petition is legally sufficient, the local clerk shall mark the referendum petition "sufficient" and consider the declaration of sufficiency effective as of the date on which the referendum petition should have been declared sufficient by the local clerk's office.
