Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608 Short title and summary of referendum -- Duties of local clerk and local attorney.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(1): Upon receipt of a referendum petition, the local clerk shall deliver a copy of the referendum petition and the law to which the referendum relates to the local attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2): 20A-6-107 The local attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(a): 20A-6-107 entitle each county or municipal referendum that qualifies for the ballot "Proposition Number __" and give the referendum a number assigned in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(b): prepare for the referendum:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(b)(i): an impartial short title, not exceeding 25 words, that generally describes the subject of the law to which the referendum relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(b)(ii): an impartial summary of the contents of the law to which the referendum relates, not exceeding 125 words;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(c): file the proposed short title, summary, and the numbered referendum title with the local clerk within 20 days after the day on which an eligible voter submits the referendum petition to the local clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(d): promptly provide notice of the filing of the proposed short title and summary to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(d)(i): the sponsors of the petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(2)(d)(ii): the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the referendum petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(3)(a): The short title and summary may be distinct from the title of the law that is the subject of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(3)(b): In preparing a short title, the local attorney shall, to the best of the local attorney's ability, give a true and impartial description of the subject of the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(3)(c): In preparing a summary, the local attorney shall, to the best of the local attorney's ability, give a true and impartial summary of the contents of the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(3)(d): The short title and summary may not intentionally be an argument, or likely to create prejudice, for or against the referendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4): 20A-7-602; 20A-7-508
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(a): Within five calendar days after the day on which the local attorney files a proposed short title and summary under Subsection (2)(c), the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the referendum petition was circulated and the sponsors of the referendum petition may file written comments in response to the proposed short title and summary with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(b): Within five calendar days after the last date to submit written comments under Subsection (4)(a), the local attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(b)(i): review any written comments filed in accordance with Subsection (4)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(b)(ii): prepare a final short title and summary that meets the requirements of Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(b)(iii): return the referendum petition and file the short title and summary with the local clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c): 20A-7-602 Subject to Subsection (6), for each county or municipal referendum, the following shall be printed on the official ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c)(i): the short title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c)(ii): 20A-7-602 except as provided in Subsection (4)(d):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c)(ii)(A): the summary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c)(ii)(B): a copy of the ordinance, resolution, or written description of the local law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(c)(ii)(C): 20A-7-602 a link to a location on the election officer's website where a voter may review additional information relating to each referendum, including the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(d): Unless the information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii) is printed on the official ballot, the election officer shall include with the ballot a separate ballot proposition insert that includes the short title and summary for each referendum on the ballot and a link to a location on the election officer's website where a voter may review the additional information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii)(C).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(4)(e): 20A-7-508 Unless the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(5): Immediately after the local attorney files a copy of the short title and summary with the local clerk, the local clerk shall send a copy of the short title and summary to the sponsors of the referendum petition and the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the referendum petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(a): If the short title or summary provided by the local attorney is unsatisfactory or does not comply with the requirements of this section, the decision of the local attorney may be appealed to the appropriate court by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(a)(i): at least three sponsors of the referendum petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(a)(ii): a majority of the local legislative body for the jurisdiction where the referendum petition was circulated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(b): The court:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(b)(i): shall examine the short title and summary and consider the arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(b)(ii): enter an order consistent with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-608(6)(c): The local clerk shall include the short title and summary in the ballot or ballot proposition insert, as required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609 Form of ballot -- Manner of voting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(1): The local clerk shall ensure that the number and ballot title are presented upon the official ballot with, immediately adjacent to them, the words "For" and "Against," each word presented with an adjacent square in which the elector may indicate the elector's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2): (2)(c)(i); 20A-7-609.5; (2)(c)(ii); 20A-7-609.5; 20A-7-609.5; 20A-7-609.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2)(a): (2)(c)(i); 20A-7-609.5 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2)(b): (2)(c)(ii); 20A-7-609.5 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2)(c): 20A-7-609.5; 20A-7-609.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2)(c)(i): 20A-7-609.5 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(2)(c)(ii): 20A-7-609.5 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(a)(i): A voter desiring to vote in favor of the law that is the subject of the referendum shall mark the square adjacent to the word "For."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(a)(ii): The law that is the subject of the referendum is effective if a majority of voters mark "For."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(b)(i): A voter desiring to vote against the law that is the subject of the referendum shall mark the square following the word "Against."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609(3)(b)(ii): The law that is the subject of the referendum is not effective if a majority of voters mark "Against."


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5 Election on referendum challenging local tax law conducted entirely by mail.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(1): An election officer may administer an election on a referendum challenging a local tax law entirely by mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2): (2)(b); (1); (2)(a); 20A-7-401.5; (2)(b)(vii)(A) For purposes of an election conducted under this section, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(a): (2)(b) designate as the election day the day that is 30 days after the day on which the election officer complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b): (1); (2)(a); 20A-7-401.5; (2)(b)(vii)(A) within 30 days after the day on which the referendum described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(i): a manual ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(ii): a statement that there will be no polling place for the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(iii): (2)(a) a statement specifying the election day described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(iv): a business reply mail envelope;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(v): instructions for returning the ballot that include an express notice about any relevant deadlines that the voter must meet in order for the voter's vote to be counted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(vi): a warning, on a separate page of colored paper in boldface print, indicating that if the voter fails to follow the instructions included with the manual ballot, the voter will be unable to vote in that election because there will be no polling place for the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(vii): 20A-7-401.5; (2)(b)(vii)(A)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(vii)(A): 20A-7-401.5 a copy of the proposition information pamphlet relating to the referendum if a proposition information pamphlet relating to the referendum was published under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(2)(b)(vii)(B): (2)(b)(vii)(A) a website address where an individual may view a copy of the proposition information pamphlet described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(3): An election officer who administers an election under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(3)(a)(i): obtain, in person, the signatures of each voter within that voting precinct before the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(3)(a)(ii): obtain the signature of each voter within the voting precinct from the county clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(3)(b): maintain the signatures on file in the election officer's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4)(a): Upon receiving a returned manual ballot under this section, the election officer shall compare the signature on each return envelope with the voter's signature that is maintained on file and verify that the signatures are the same.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4)(b): If the election officer questions the authenticity of the signature on the return envelope, the election officer shall immediately contact the voter to verify the signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4)(c): If there is not a signature on the return envelope or if the election officer determines that the signature on the return envelope does not match the voter's signature that is maintained on file, the election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4)(c)(i): disqualify the ballot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-609.5(4)(c)(ii): notify the voter of the disqualification and the reason for the disqualification.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610 Return and canvass -- Conflicting measures -- Law effective on proclamation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(1): Title 20A, Chapter 4, Part 3, Canvassing Returns The votes on the law that is the subject of the referendum petition shall be counted, canvassed, and delivered as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(2): After the local board of canvassers completes the canvass, the local clerk shall certify to the local legislative body the vote for and against the law that is the subject of the referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(3): 20A-7-611
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(3)(a): 20A-7-611 The local legislative body shall immediately issue a proclamation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(3)(a)(i): gives the total number of votes cast in the local jurisdiction for and against each law that is the subject of a referendum petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(3)(a)(ii): 20A-7-611 in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(3)(b): When the local legislative body determines that two laws, or that parts of two laws approved by the people at the same election are entirely in conflict, the local legislative body shall proclaim to be law the law that received the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in the majorities which those approved laws received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(4): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(4)(a): (3) Within 10 days after the day on which the local legislative body issues the proclamation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(4)(b): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(4)(b)(i): consider the matter and decide whether the approved laws are entirely in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(4)(b)(ii): issue an order, consistent with the court's decision, to the local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(5): (4)(b)(ii) Within 10 days after the day on which the court enters an order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(5)(a): proclaim as law all those laws approved by the people that the court determines are not in conflict; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-610(5)(b): of all those laws approved by the people as law that the court determines to be in conflict, proclaim as law the one that receives the greatest number of affirmative votes, regardless of the difference in majorities.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611 Temporary stay -- Effective date -- Effect of repeal by local legislative body.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(1): Any law submitted to the people by referendum petition that is rejected by the voters at any election is repealed as of the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(2): 20A-7-607(2) If, at the time during the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(2)(a): issue an order temporarily staying the law from going into effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(2)(b): continue the process of certifying signatures and removing signatures as required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(3): (2); 20A-7-610 The temporary stay described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(3)(a): if the local clerk declares the referendum petition insufficient, five days after the day on which the local clerk declares the referendum petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(3)(b): 20A-7-610 if the local clerk declares the referendum petition sufficient, the day on which the local legislative body issues the proclamation described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(4): A law submitted to the people by referendum that is approved by the voters at an election takes effect the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(4)(a): five days after the date of the official proclamation of the vote by the local legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(4)(b): the effective date specified in the approved law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(5): (2)(a) If, after the local clerk issues a temporary stay order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(5)(a): five days after the day on which the local clerk declares the petition insufficient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(5)(b): the effective date specified in the proposed law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(6)(a): A law approved by the people under this part is not subject to veto.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(6)(b): The local legislative body may amend any laws approved by the people under this part after the people approve the law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-611(7): If the local legislative body repeals a law challenged by referendum petition under this part, the referendum petition is void and no further action on the referendum petition is required.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(a): sign a name other than the individual's own name to any referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same referendum at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed a referendum petition signed the referendum petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(d): sign a referendum petition knowing that the individual is not a legal voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(e): in connection with circulating a referendum petition, represent that a document is an official government document if the individual knows or has reason to know that the document is not an official government document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(f): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2): 20A-21-201 It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for a referendum packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the referendum petition is not the date that the individual signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(c): one or more individuals whose signatures appear in the referendum packet is not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(a): pay an individual to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(c): accept payment to sign a referendum petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from a referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(5): The county attorney or municipal attorney shall prosecute any violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612 Misconduct of electors and officers -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1): It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(a): sign a name other than the individual's own name to any referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(b): knowingly sign the individual's name more than once for the same referendum at one election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(c): knowingly indicate that an individual who signed a referendum petition signed the referendum petition on a date other than the date that the individual signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(d): sign a referendum petition knowing that the individual is not a legal voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(e): in connection with circulating a referendum petition, represent that a document is an official government document if the individual knows or has reason to know that the document is not an official government document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(1)(f): knowingly and willfully violate any provision of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2): 20A-21-201(10) It is unlawful for an individual to sign the verification for a referendum packet, or to electronically sign the verification for a signature under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(a): the signature date associated with the individual's signature for the referendum petition is not the date that the individual signed the referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(b): the individual has not witnessed the signatures the individual collects or submits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(2)(c): one or more individuals whose signatures appear in the referendum packet is not registered to vote in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(a): pay an individual to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(b): pay an individual to remove the individual's signature from a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(c): accept payment to sign a referendum petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(d): accept payment to have the individual's name removed from a referendum petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e): 20A-7-106; 20A-7-106 on behalf of a voter described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e)(i): does not obtain the voluntary direction or consent of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e)(ii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter lacks the mental capacity to give the voter's direction or consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e)(iii): believes or has reason to believe that the voter does not understand the purpose or nature of the action taken by the individual on behalf of the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e)(iv): intentionally or knowingly deceives the voter into providing the direction or consent of the voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(3)(e)(v): intentionally or knowingly enters false information on the signature sheet or statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(4): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-612(5): The county attorney or municipal attorney shall prosecute any violation of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-614(2)(a): The first screen presented on the approved device shall include the following statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-614(2)(b): An individual may not advance to the second screen until the individual clicks a link at the bottom of the first screen stating, "By clicking here, I attest that I have read and understand the information presented on this screen."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-701 Voter information pamphlet to be prepared.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-701(1): The lieutenant governor shall cause to be prepared a voter information pamphlet designed to inform the voters of the state of the content, effect, operation, fiscal impact, and the supporting and opposing arguments of any measure submitted to the voters by the Legislature or by a statewide initiative or referendum petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-701(2): The pamphlet shall also include a separate section prepared, analyzed, and submitted by the Judicial Council describing the judicial selection and retention process.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-701(3): 20A-7-402 Voter information pamphlets prepared in association with a local initiative or a local referendum shall be prepared in accordance with the procedures and requirements of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702 Voter information pamphlet -- Form -- Contents.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The voter information pamphlet shall contain the following items in this order:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(1): a cover title page;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(2): an introduction to the pamphlet by the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(3): a table of contents;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(4): a list of all candidates for constitutional offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(5): a list of candidates for each legislative district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(6): a 100-word statement of qualifications for each candidate for the office of governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, state auditor, or state treasurer, if submitted by the candidate to the lieutenant governor's office before 5 p.m. on the first business day in August before the date of the election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7): 20A-7-103; 20A-7-103; 20A-7-202.5 information pertaining to all measures to be submitted to the voters, beginning a new page for each measure and containing, in the following order for each measure:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(a): a copy of the number and ballot title of the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(b): the final vote cast by the Legislature on the measure if it is a measure submitted by the Legislature or by referendum;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(c): 20A-7-103; 20A-7-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(c)(i): 20A-7-103 for a measure other than a measure described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(c)(ii): 20A-7-103 for a measure described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(d): the arguments in favor of the measure, the rebuttal to the arguments in favor of the measure, the arguments against the measure, and the rebuttal to the arguments against the measure, with the name and title of the authors at the end of each argument or rebuttal;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(e): for each constitutional amendment, a complete copy of the text of the constitutional amendment, with all new language underlined, and all deleted language placed within brackets;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(f): 20A-7-202.5 for each initiative qualified for the ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(f)(i): 20A-7-202.5 a copy of the initiative as certified by the lieutenant governor and a copy of the initial fiscal impact statement prepared according to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(f)(ii): if the initiative proposes a tax increase, the following statement in bold type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(7)(g): for each referendum qualified for the ballot, a complete copy of the text of the law being submitted to the voters for their approval or rejection, with all new language underlined and all deleted language placed within brackets, as applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8): 78A-12-205; 78A-12-205; 78A-12-206; 78A-12-205 a description provided by the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission of the selection and retention process for judges, including, in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(a): a description of the judicial selection process;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(b): a description of the judicial performance evaluation process;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(c): a description of the judicial retention election process;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(d): a list of the criteria of the judicial performance evaluation and the certification standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(e): the names of the judges standing for retention election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f): 78A-12-205; 78A-12-205; 78A-12-206; 78A-12-205 for each judge:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(i): a list of the counties in which the judge is subject to retention election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(ii): a short biography of professional qualifications and a recent photograph;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(iii): a narrative concerning the judge's performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(iv): 78A-12-205; 78A-12-205 for each certification standard under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(v): a statement that the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(v)(A): has determined that the judge meets or exceeds minimum performance standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(v)(B): has determined that the judge does not meet or exceed minimum performance standards; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(v)(C): has not made a determination regarding whether the judge meets or exceeds minimum performance standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(vi): 78A-12-206 any statement, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(vii): 78A-12-205 in a bar graph, the average of responses to each survey category, displayed with an identification of the minimum acceptable score as set by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(8)(f)(viii): a website address that contains the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission's report on the judge's performance evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(9): for each judge, a statement provided by the Utah Supreme Court identifying the cumulative number of informal reprimands, when consented to by the judge in accordance with Title 78A, Chapter 11, Judicial Conduct Commission, formal reprimands, and all orders of censure and suspension issued by the Utah Supreme Court under Utah Constitution, Article VIII, Section 13, during the judge's current term and the immediately preceding term, and a detailed summary of the supporting reasons for each violation of the Code of Judicial Conduct that the judge has received;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(10): an explanation of ballot marking procedures prepared by the lieutenant governor, indicating the ballot marking procedure used by each county and explaining how to mark the ballot for each procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(11): voter registration information, including information on how to obtain a ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(12): a list of all county clerks' offices and phone numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(13): the address of the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website, with a statement indicating that the election officer will post on the website any changes to the location of a polling place and the location of any additional polling place;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(14): a phone number that a voter may call to obtain information regarding the location of a polling place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702(15): on the back cover page, a printed copy of the following statement signed by the lieutenant governor:


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702.5 Publication of voter information pamphlet.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702.5(1): 20A-7-801 No earlier than 75 days, and no later than 15 days, before the day on which voting commences, the lieutenant governor shall make all information provided in the voter information pamphlet available on the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website Program described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-702.5(2): 20A-7-801 The lieutenant governor may distribute a voter information pamphlet at a location frequented by a person who cannot easily access the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website authorized by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703 Analysis of initiative or referendum -- Determination of fiscal effects.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(1): The director of the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel, after the approval of the legislative general counsel as to legal sufficiency, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(1)(a): prepare an impartial analysis of each measure submitted to the voters by initiative or referendum petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(1)(b): submit the impartial analysis to the lieutenant governor no later than the day that falls 90 days before the date of the election in which the measure will appear on the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2): The director shall ensure that the impartial analysis:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(a): is not more than 1,000 words long;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(b): is prepared in clear and concise language that will easily be understood by the average voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(c): avoids the use of technical terms as much as possible;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(d): shows the effect of the measure on existing law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(e): identifies any potential conflicts with the United States or Utah Constitutions raised by the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(f): fairly describes the operation of the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(g): identifies the measure's fiscal effects over the time period or time periods determined by the director to be most useful in understanding the estimated fiscal impact of the proposed law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(2)(h): identifies the amount of any increase or decrease in revenue or cost to state or local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(3)(a): In determining the fiscal effects of a measure, the director shall confer with the legislative fiscal analyst.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(3)(b): The director shall consider any measure that requires implementing legislation in order to take effect to have no financial effect, unless implementing legislation has been enacted that will become effective upon adoption of the measure by the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703(4): If the director requests the assistance of any state department, agency, or official in preparing the director's analysis, that department, agency, or official shall assist the director.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1 Analysis of measure submitted to voters by Legislature -- Determination of fiscal effects.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(1): 20A-7-103 The presiding officers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(1)(a): 20A-7-103 prepare an analysis of each measure, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(1)(b): submit the analysis to the lieutenant governor no later than the day that falls 90 days before the date of the election in which the measure will appear on the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2): The presiding officers shall ensure that the analysis:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(a): is not more than 1,000 words long;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(b): is prepared in clear and concise language that will easily be understood by the average voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(c): to the extent possible, avoids the use of technical terms;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(d): shows the effect of the measure on existing law;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(e): describes the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(f): identifies the measure's fiscal effects over the time period or time periods determined by the presiding officers to be most useful in understanding the estimated fiscal impact of the measure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(2)(g): identifies the amount of any increase or decrease in revenue or cost to state or local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(3): The presiding officers shall analyze the measure as the measure is proposed to be adopted, without considering any implementing legislation, unless the implementing legislation has been enacted and will become effective upon the adoption of the measure by the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(4)(a): In determining the fiscal effects of a measure, the presiding officers shall confer with the legislative fiscal analyst.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(4)(b): The presiding officers shall consider any measure that requires implementing legislation in order to take effect to have no financial effect, unless implementing legislation has been enacted that will become effective upon adoption of the measure by the voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-703.1(5): If the presiding officers request the assistance of any state department, agency, or official in preparing the analysis described in this section, that department, agency, or official shall assist the presiding officers.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704 Initiative measures -- Arguments for and against -- Voters' requests for argument -- Ballot arguments.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(1)(a): Before 5 p.m. no later than July 1 of the regular general election year, a sponsor of any initiative petition that has been declared sufficient by the lieutenant governor may deliver to the lieutenant governor a written notice that the sponsor intends to submit a written argument for adoption of the measure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(1)(b): (1)(a) If two or more sponsors timely submit a notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(2)(a): Before 5 p.m. no later than July 1 of the regular general election year, a member of the Legislature may deliver to the speaker of the House and the president of the Senate a written notice that the legislator intends to submit a written argument against adoption of an initiative petition that has been declared sufficient by the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(2)(b): (2)(a) If two or more legislators timely submit a notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(3): (5) The sponsors and the legislators submitting arguments shall ensure that each argument:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(3)(a): (5) does not exceed 500 words in length, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(3)(b): is delivered to the lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. no later than July 10.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4): (3)(b); (4)(b); (4)(b); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(c); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a): (3)(b); (4)(b); (4)(b); (4)(a)(ii) If an argument for or against a measure to be submitted to the voters by initiative petition has not been filed within the time required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a)(i): (4)(b); (4)(b) the Office of the Lieutenant Governor shall immediately:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a)(i)(A): (4)(b) send an electronic notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a)(i)(B): (4)(b) post a notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a)(ii): any voter may, before 5 p.m. no later than July 15, deliver written notice to the lieutenant governor that the voter intends to submit a written argument for the side on which no argument has been filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(a)(iii): (4)(a)(ii) if two or more voters timely submit the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(b): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(c) A notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(b)(i): the ballot title for the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a)(ii) instructions on how to submit a request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(b)(iii): (4)(a)(ii); (4)(c) the deadlines described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(4)(c): (4) Any argument prepared under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(5): The lieutenant governor may not accept a ballot argument submitted under this section unless the argument lists:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(5)(a): the name and address of the individual submitting the argument, if the argument is submitted by an individual voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(5)(b): the name and address of the organization and the names and addresses of at least two of the organization's principal officers, if the argument is submitted on behalf of an organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6): (6)(c); (d); (6)(c); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(a): (6)(c); (d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(b): (6)(c); (d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(c): The lieutenant governor and the authors of an argument described in this section may jointly modify the argument after the argument is submitted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(c)(i): the lieutenant governor and the authors jointly agree that changes to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(c)(i)(A): the argument must be made to correct spelling or grammatical errors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(c)(i)(B): properly characterize the position of a state entity, if the argument mischaracterizes the position of a state entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(c)(ii): the argument has not yet been submitted for typesetting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(d): If, after the lieutenant governor determines that an argument described in this section mischaracterizes the position of a state entity, the lieutenant governor and the authors of the argument cannot jointly agree on a change to the argument, the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(d)(i): shall publish the argument with the mischaracterization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-704(6)(d)(ii): may, immediately following the argument, publish a brief description of the position of the state entity.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705 Measures to be submitted to voters and referendum measures -- Preparation of argument of adoption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(1): (4)(e); (4)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(1)(a): Whenever the Legislature submits any measure to the voters or whenever an act of the Legislature is referred to the voters by referendum petition, the presiding officer of the house of origin of the measure shall appoint the sponsor of the measure or act and one member of either house who voted with the majority to pass the act or submit the measure to draft an argument for the adoption of the measure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(1)(b): (4)(e); (4)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(1)(b)(i): (4)(e) The argument may not exceed 500 words in length, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(1)(b)(ii): (4)(e) If the sponsor of the measure or act desires separate arguments to be written in favor by each person appointed, separate arguments may be written but the combined length of the two arguments may not exceed 500 words, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(2): (4)(e); (4)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(2)(a): If a measure or act submitted to the voters by the Legislature or by referendum petition was not adopted unanimously by the Legislature, the presiding officer of each house shall, at the same time as appointments to an argument in its favor are made, appoint one member who voted against the measure or act from their house to write an argument against the measure or act.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(2)(b): (4)(e); (4)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(2)(b)(i): (4)(e) The argument may not exceed 500 words, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(2)(b)(ii): (4)(e) If those members appointed to write an argument against the measure or act desire separate arguments to be written in opposition to the measure or act by each person appointed, separate arguments may be written, but the combined length of the two arguments may not exceed 500 words, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3): (3)(d); (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(a): The legislators appointed by the presiding officer of the Senate or House of Representatives to submit arguments shall submit the arguments to the lieutenant governor not later than the day that falls 150 days before the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(b): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(c): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(d): The lieutenant governor and the authors of an argument may jointly modify an argument after it is submitted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(d)(i): they jointly agree that changes to the argument must be made to correct spelling or grammatical errors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(3)(d)(ii): the argument has not yet been submitted for typesetting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4): (4)(b); (4)(b); (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(d); (4)(a)(ii); (4); (4)(h); (4)(h)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(a): (4)(b); (4)(b); (4)(a)(i) If an argument for or an argument against a measure submitted to the voters by the Legislature or by referendum petition has not been filed by a member of the Legislature within the time required by this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(a)(i): (4)(b); (4)(b) the lieutenant governor shall immediately:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(a)(i)(A): (4)(b) send an electronic notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(a)(i)(B): (4)(b) post a notice that complies with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(a)(ii): (4)(a)(i) any voter may, before 5 p.m. no later than seven days after the day on which the lieutenant governor provides the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(b): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(ii); (4)(d) A notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(b)(i): the ballot title for the measure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a)(ii) instructions on how to submit a request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(b)(iii): (4)(a)(ii); (4)(d) the deadlines described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(c): (4)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(c)(i): The presiding officer of the house of origin shall grant permission unless two or more voters timely request permission to submit arguments on the same side of a measure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(c)(ii): (4)(a)(ii) If two or more voters timely request permission to submit arguments on the same side of a measure, the presiding officer shall, no later than four calendar days after the day of the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(d): (4) Any argument prepared under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(e): The lieutenant governor may not accept a ballot argument submitted under this section unless the ballot argument lists:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(e)(i): the name and address of the individual submitting the argument, if the argument is submitted by an individual voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(e)(ii): the name and address of the organization and the names and addresses of at least two of the organization's principal officers, if the argument is submitted on behalf of an organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(f): (4)(h) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(g): (4)(h) Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(h)(i)(A): correct spelling or grammatical errors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-705(4)(h)(i)(B): properly characterize the position of a state entity, if the argument mischaracterizes the position of a state entity; and
