Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706 Copies of arguments to be sent to opposing authors -- Rebuttal arguments.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(1): When the lieutenant governor has received the arguments for and against a measure to be submitted to the voters, the lieutenant governor shall immediately send copies of the arguments in favor of the measure to the authors of the arguments against and copies of the arguments against to the authors of the arguments in favor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(2): 20A-7-705(4)(e) The authors may prepare and submit rebuttal arguments not exceeding 250 words, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3): (3)(d); (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a): The rebuttal arguments shall be filed with the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a)(i): for constitutional amendments and referendum petitions, before 5 p.m. no later than 120 days before the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a)(ii): for initiatives, before 5 p.m. no later than July 30.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(b): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(c): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d): The lieutenant governor and the authors of a rebuttal argument may jointly modify a rebuttal argument after it is submitted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d)(i): they jointly agree that changes to the rebuttal argument must be made to correct spelling or grammatical errors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d)(ii): the rebuttal argument has not yet been submitted for typesetting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4): The lieutenant governor shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4)(a): rebuttal arguments are printed in the same manner as the direct arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4)(b): each rebuttal argument follows immediately after the direct argument which it seeks to rebut.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706 Copies of arguments to be sent to opposing authors -- Rebuttal arguments.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(1): When the lieutenant governor has received the arguments for and against a measure to be submitted to the voters, the lieutenant governor shall immediately send copies of the arguments in favor of the measure to the authors of the arguments against and copies of the arguments against to the authors of the arguments in favor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(2): 20A-7-705(4)(e) The authors may prepare and submit rebuttal arguments not exceeding 250 words, not counting the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3): (3)(d); (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a): The rebuttal arguments shall be filed with the lieutenant governor:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a)(i): for constitutional amendments and referendum petitions, before 5 p.m. no later than 100 days before the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(a)(ii): for initiatives, before 5 p.m. no later than July 30.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(b): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(c): (3)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d): The lieutenant governor and the authors of a rebuttal argument may jointly modify a rebuttal argument after it is submitted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d)(i): they jointly agree that changes to the rebuttal argument must be made to correct spelling or grammatical errors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(3)(d)(ii): the rebuttal argument has not yet been submitted for typesetting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4): The lieutenant governor shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4)(a): rebuttal arguments are printed in the same manner as the direct arguments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-706(4)(b): each rebuttal argument follows immediately after the direct argument which it seeks to rebut.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801 Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website Program -- Duties of the lieutenant governor -- Content -- Duties of local election officials -- Deadlines -- Frequently asked voter questions -- Other elections.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(1): There is established the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website Program administered by the lieutenant governor in cooperation with the county clerks for general elections and municipal authorities for municipal elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(2): 20A-3a-401.5 In accordance with this section, and as resources become available, the lieutenant governor, in cooperation with county clerks, shall develop, establish, and maintain a state-provided Internet website designed to help inform the voters of the state of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(2)(a): the offices and candidates up for election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(2)(b): the content, effect, operation, fiscal impact, and supporting and opposing arguments of ballot propositions submitted to the voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(2)(c): 20A-3a-401.5 the status of a voter's trackable ballot, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3): (6); Chapter 7, Part 7, Voter Information Pamphlet; Title 78A, Chapter 12, Part 2, Judicial Performance Evaluation; 20A-12-201; (4); 20A-3a-703; 20A-1-308(2); 20A-3a-401.5 Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(a): Chapter 7, Part 7, Voter Information Pamphlet all information currently provided in the Utah voter information pamphlet under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(b): on the homepage of the website, a link to the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission's website, judges.utah.gov;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(c): Title 78A, Chapter 12, Part 2, Judicial Performance Evaluation; 20A-12-201 a link to the retention recommendation made by the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(d): (4) all information submitted by election officers under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(e): 20A-3a-703 a list that contains the name of a political subdivision that operates an election day voting center under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(f): other information determined appropriate by the lieutenant governor that is currently being provided by law, rule, or ordinance in relation to candidates and ballot questions;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(g): 20A-1-308(2) any differences in voting method, time, or location designated by the lieutenant governor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(h): 20A-3a-401.5 an online ballot tracking system by which a voter can view the status of the voter's trackable ballot, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(h)(i): when a ballot has been mailed to the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(h)(ii): when an election official has received the voter's ballot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(3)(h)(iii): when the voter's ballot has been counted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4): (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(d); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a): An election official shall submit the following information for each ballot under the election official's direct responsibility under this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(i): a list of all candidates for each office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii): if submitted by the candidate to the election official's office before 5 p.m. no later than 45 days before the primary election or before 5 p.m. no later than 60 days before the general election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(A): a statement of qualifications, not exceeding 200 words in length, for each candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B): the following current biographical information if desired by the candidate, current:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B)(I): age;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B)(II): occupation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B)(III): city of residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B)(IV): years of residence in current city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(B)(V): email address; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(ii)(C): a single web address where voters may access more information about the candidate and the candidate's views; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(iii): factual information pertaining to all ballot propositions submitted to the voters, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(iii)(A): a copy of the number and ballot title of each ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(iii)(B): the final vote cast for each ballot proposition, if any, by a legislative body if the vote was required to place the ballot proposition on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(iii)(C): a complete copy of the text of each ballot proposition, with all new language underlined and all deleted language placed within brackets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(a)(iii)(D): other factual information determined helpful by the election official.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(a) The information under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(c): The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(c)(i): review the information submitted under this section, to determine compliance under this section, prior to placing it on the website;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(c)(ii): refuse to post information submitted under this section on the website if it is not in compliance with the provisions of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(c)(iii): organize, format, and arrange the information submitted under this section for the website.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(d): The lieutenant governor may refuse to include information the lieutenant governor determines is not in keeping with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(d)(i): Utah voter needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(d)(ii): public decency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(d)(iii): the purposes, organization, or uniformity of the website.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(4)(e): (4)(d); (5) A refusal under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5): (4); (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5)(a): (4); (5)(a) A person whose information is refused under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5)(a)(i): a listing of each objection to the lieutenant governor's determination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5)(a)(ii): the basis for each objection.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5)(b): The lieutenant governor shall review the notice of appeal and shall issue a written response within 10 business days after the day on which the notice of appeal is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(5)(c): An appeal of the response of the lieutenant governor shall be made to the district court, which shall review the matter de novo.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(a): The lieutenant governor shall ensure that each voter will be able to conveniently enter the voter's address information on the website to retrieve information on which offices, candidates, and ballot propositions will be on the voter's ballot at the next general election or municipal election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b): The information on the website will anticipate and answer frequent voter questions including the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(i): what offices are up in the current year for which the voter may cast a vote;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(ii): who is running for what office and who is the incumbent, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(iii): what address each candidate may be reached at and how the candidate may be contacted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(iv): for partisan races only, what, if any, is each candidate's party affiliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(v): what qualifications have been submitted by each candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(vi): where additional information on each candidate may be obtained;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(vii): what ballot propositions will be on the ballot; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(6)(b)(viii): what judges are up for retention election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(7): 20A-3a-401.5 The lieutenant governor shall ensure that each voter may conveniently enter the voter's name, date of birth, and address information on the website to retrieve information on the status of the voter's ballot if the voter's ballot is trackable under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-7-801(8): As resources are made available and in cooperation with the county clerks, the lieutenant governor may expand the electronic voter information website program to include the same information as provided under this section for special elections and primary elections.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 8 - Political Party Formation and Procedures
**************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(1): "Continuing political party" means an organization of voters that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(1)(a): participated in the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(1)(b): in at least one of the last two regular general elections, polled a total vote for any of its candidates for any office equal to 2% or more of the total votes cast for all candidates for the United States House of Representatives in the same regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(2): "County political party" means, for each registered political party, all of the persons within a single county who, under definitions established by the county political party, are members of the registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(3): "Newly registered political party" means a statewide organization of voters that has complied with the petition and organizing procedures of this chapter to become a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(4): 53B-16-301 "Public institution of higher education" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(5): "Registered political party" means an organization of voters that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(5)(a)(i): participated in the last regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(5)(a)(ii): in at least one of the last two regular general elections, polled a total vote for any of its candidates for any office equal to 2% or more of the total votes cast for all candidates for the United States House of Representatives in the same regular general election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(5)(b): has complied with the petition and organizing procedures of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-101(6): "State political party" means, for each registered political party, all of the persons in Utah who, under definitions established by the state political party, are members of the registered political party.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-102 Organization of newly registered political parties -- Rights.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-102(1): Any organization of voters whose organization did not participate in the last regular general election, or whose organization polled a total vote equivalent to less than 2% of the total vote cast for all candidates for the United States House of Representatives for any of its candidates in both of the last two regular general elections shall comply with the requirements of this chapter to become a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-102(2)(a): Unless an organization of registered voters is a registered political party under this chapter, it may not place the names of candidates representing that organization upon the primary and regular general election ballots under the common organization name.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-102(2)(b): Nothing in this subsection prohibits an organization of voters from qualifying candidates as independent candidates or as write-in candidates.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103 Petition procedures -- Criminal penalty -- Removal of signature.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"It is a class A misdemeanor for anyone to knowingly sign a political party registration petition signature sheet with any name other than the individual's own name or more than once for the same party or if the individual is not registered to vote in this state and does not intend to become registered to vote in this state before the petition is submitted to the lieutenant governor.";Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(1): As used in this section, the proposed name or emblem of a registered political party is "distinguishable" if a reasonable person of average intelligence will be able to perceive a difference between the proposed name or emblem and any name or emblem currently being used by another registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2): (2)(b); 20A-9-406 To become a registered political party, an organization of registered voters that is not a continuing political party shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(a): circulate a petition seeking registered political party status beginning no earlier than the date of the statewide canvass held after the last regular general election and ending before 5 p.m. no later than November 30 of the year before the year in which the next regular general election will be held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(b): file a petition with the lieutenant governor that is signed, with a holographic signature, by at least 2,000 registered voters before 5 p.m. no later than November 30 of the year in which a regular general election will be held; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(c): (2)(b); 20A-9-406 file, with the petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(c)(i): the identity of one or more registered political parties whose members may vote for the organization's candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(c)(ii): whether unaffiliated voters may vote for the organization's candidates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(2)(c)(iii): 20A-9-406 whether, for the next election, the organization intends to nominate the organization's candidates in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3): (3)(c); (3)(e) The petition shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(a): be on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(b): be ruled with a horizontal line 3/4 inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(c): contain the name of the political party and the words "Political Party Registration Petition" printed directly below the horizontal line;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(d): (3)(c) contain the word "Warning" printed directly under the words described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(e): contain, to the right of the word "Warning," the following statement printed in not less than eight-point, single leaded type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(f): (3)(e) contain the following statement directly under the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g): be vertically divided into columns as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(i): the first column shall appear at the extreme left of the sheet, be 5/8 inch wide, be headed with "For Office Use Only," and be subdivided with a light vertical line down the middle;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(ii): the next column shall be 2-1/2 inches wide, headed "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(iii): the next column shall be 2-1/2 inches wide, headed "Holographic Signature of Registered Voter";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(iv): the next column shall be one inch wide, headed "Birth Date or Age (Optional)";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(v): the final column shall be 4-3/8 inches wide, headed "Street Address, City, Zip Code"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(g)(vi): at the bottom of the sheet, contain the following statement: "Birth date or age information is not required, but it may be used to verify your identity with voter registration records.  If you choose not to provide it, your signature may not be certified as a valid signature if you change your address before petition signatures are certified or if the information you provide does not match your voter registration records.";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(h): have a final page bound to one or more signature sheets that are bound together that contains the following printed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(i): be bound to a cover sheet that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(i)(i): identifies the political party's name, which may not exceed four words, and the emblem of the party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(i)(ii): states the process that the organization will follow to organize and adopt a constitution and bylaws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(3)(i)(iii): is signed by a filing officer, who agrees to receive communications on behalf of the organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(4): (3)(i)(iii); 20A-2-105 The filing officer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(4)(a): is at least 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(4)(b): 20A-2-105 meets the residency requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(4)(c): verifies each signature sheet by completing the verification bound to one or more signature sheets that are bound together.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(5): An individual may not sign the verification if the individual signed a signature sheet bound to the verification.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(6): 20A-1-1002; (3)(i)(iii) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(6)(a): 20A-1-1002 use the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(6)(b): review the proposed name and emblem to determine if they are "distinguishable" from the names and emblems of other registered political parties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(6)(c): (3)(i)(iii) certify the lieutenant governor's findings to the filing officer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(7): (3)(i)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(7)(a): (3)(i)(iii) If the lieutenant governor determines that the petition meets the requirements of this section, and that the proposed name and emblem are distinguishable, the lieutenant governor shall authorize the filing officer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(7)(b): If the lieutenant governor finds that the name, emblem, or both are not distinguishable from the names and emblems of other registered political parties, the lieutenant governor shall notify the filing officer that the filing officer has seven days to submit a new name or emblem to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(8): A registered political party may not change its name or emblem during the regular general election cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9): 20A-2-105; (9)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a): 20A-2-105 It is unlawful for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(i): knowingly sign a political party registration petition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(i)(A): with any name other than the individual's own name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(i)(B): more than once for the same political party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(i)(C): if the individual is not registered to vote in this state and does not intend to become registered to vote in this state before the petition is submitted to the lieutenant governor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(ii): 20A-2-105 sign the verification of a political party registration petition signature sheet if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(ii)(A): 20A-2-105 does not meet the residency requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(ii)(B): has not witnessed the signing by those individuals whose names appear on the political party registration petition signature sheet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(a)(ii)(C): knows that an individual whose signature appears on the political party registration petition signature sheet is not registered to vote in this state and does not intend to become registered to vote in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(9)(b): (9) An individual who violates this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(10): (10)(a); 20A-1-1003(2); 20A-1-1003(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(10)(a): A voter who signs a petition under this section may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, no later than three business days after the day on which the petition is filed with the lieutenant governor, submitting to the lieutenant governor a statement requesting that the voter's signature be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(10)(b): (10)(a); 20A-1-1003(2) A statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-103(10)(c): 20A-1-1003(3) The lieutenant governor shall use the procedures described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106 Organization as a political party -- Certification procedures.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(1): Before 5 p.m. no later than March 1 of the regular general election year, the prospective political  party's officers or governing board shall file the names of the  party officers or governing board with the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(2): After reviewing the information and determining that all proper procedures have been completed, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(2)(a): issue a certificate naming the organization as a registered political party in Utah and designating its official name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(2)(b): inform each county clerk that the organization is a registered political party in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(3): All election officers and state officials shall consider the organization to be and shall treat the organization as a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(4): The newly registered political party shall comply with all the provisions of Utah law governing political parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(5)(a): If the newly registered political party does not hold a national party convention, the governing board of the political party may designate the names of the party's candidates for the offices of President and Vice President of the United States and the names of the party's presidential electors to the lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. no later than August 15.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-106(5)(b): If the party chooses to designate names, the governing board shall certify those names.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401 Registered political parties -- Bylaws -- Report name of midterm vacancy candidate.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(1)(a): Each new or unregistered state political party that seeks to become a registered political party under the authority of this chapter shall file a copy of the party's proposed constitution and bylaws at the time the party files the party's registration information.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(1)(b): Each registered state political party shall file revised copies of the party's constitution or bylaws with the lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. within 15 days after the day on which the constitution or bylaws are adopted or amended.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2): 20A-1-508 Each state political party, each new political party seeking registration, and each unregistered political party seeking registration shall ensure that the party's constitution or bylaws contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a): provisions establishing party organization, structure, membership, and governance that include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(i): a description of the position, selection process, qualifications, duties, and terms of each party officer and committees defined by constitution and bylaws;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(ii): a provision requiring a designated party officer to serve as liaison with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(ii)(A): the lieutenant governor on all matters relating to the political party's relationship with the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(ii)(B): each county legislative body on matters relating to the political party's relationship with a county;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(iii): a description of the requirements for participation in party processes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(iv): the dates, times, and quorum of any regularly scheduled party meetings, conventions, or other conclaves; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(a)(v): a mechanism for making the names of delegates, candidates, and elected party officers available to the public shortly after they are selected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(b): a procedure for selecting party officers that allows active participation by party members;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(c): a procedure for selecting party candidates at the federal, state, and county levels that allows active participation by party members;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(d)(i): a procedure for selecting electors who are pledged to cast their votes in the electoral college for the party's candidates for president and vice president of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(d)(ii): a procedure for filling vacancies in the office of presidential elector because of death, refusal to act, failure to attend, ineligibility, or any other cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(e): 20A-1-508 a procedure for filling vacancies in the office of representative or senator or a county office, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(f): a provision requiring the governor and lieutenant governor to run as a joint ticket;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(g): a procedure for replacing party candidates who die, acquire a disability that prevents the candidate from continuing the candidacy, or are disqualified before a primary or regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(h): provisions governing the deposit and expenditure of party funds, and governing the accounting for, reporting, and audit of party financial transactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(i): provisions governing access to party records;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(j): a procedure for amending the constitution or bylaws that allows active participation by party members or their representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(k): a process for resolving grievances against the political party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l): if desired by the political party, a process for consulting with, and obtaining the opinion of, the political party's Utah Senate and Utah House members about:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(i): the performance of the two United States Senators from Utah, including specifically:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(i)(A): their views and actions regarding the defense of state's rights and federalism; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(i)(B): their performance in representing Utah's interests;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(ii): the members' opinion about, or rating of, and support or opposition to the policy positions of any candidates for United States Senate from Utah, including incumbents, including specifically:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(ii)(A): their views and actions regarding the defense of state's rights and federalism; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(ii)(B): their performance in representing Utah's interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(2)(l)(iii): the members' collective or individual endorsement or rating of a particular candidate for United States Senate from Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-401(3): 20A-11-101; 20A-1-503; 20A-1-504 If, in accordance with a political party's constitution or bylaws, a person files a declaration or otherwise notifies the party of the person's candidacy as a legislative office candidate or state office candidate, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402 Political party officers -- Submission of names of officers to the lieutenant governor.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(1): Each state political party shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(1)(a): designate a party officer to act as liaison with:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(1)(a)(i): the lieutenant governor's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(1)(a)(ii): each county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(1)(b): before 5 p.m. no later than seven days after the day on which the party makes a change in the party liaison, submit the name of the new liaison to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(2): Each state political party and each county political party shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(2)(a): submit the name, address, and phone number of each officer to the lieutenant governor within seven days after the officers are selected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402(2)(b): before 5 p.m. no later than seven days after the day on which the party makes a change in party officers, submit the name, address, and phone number of each new officer to the lieutenant governor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402.5 Notification of political convention dates.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402.5(1): Before 5 p.m. no later than the first Monday of October of each odd-numbered year, a registered political party shall notify the lieutenant governor of the dates of each political convention that will be held by the registered political party the following year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-402.5(2): (1) If, after providing the notice described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-403 Political parties -- Certification.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
When this title requires that a registered political party certify information to the lieutenant governor, the registered political party has met that requirement if the information is signed by the registered political party's designated liaison or the registered political party's chair.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404 Use of public meeting buildings by political parties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(1): The legislative body of a county, municipality, school district, or public institution of higher education shall make all meeting facilities in buildings under its control available to registered political parties, without discrimination, to be used for political party activities if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(1)(a): the political party requests the use of the meeting facility before 5 p.m. no later than 30 calendar days before the day on which the use by the political party will take place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(1)(b): the meeting facility is not already scheduled for another purpose at the time of the proposed use.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(2): (3); (1) Subject to the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(3): (1) The charge imposed for the use of a meeting facility described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(3)(a): custodial services for cleaning the meeting facility after the use by the political party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(3)(b): any service requested by the political party and provided by the meeting facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(4): (1) An entity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-8-404(5): This section does not apply to a publicly owned or operated convention center, sports arena, or other facility at which conventions, conferences, and other gatherings are held and whose primary business or function is to host such conventions, conferences, and other gatherings.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 9 - Candidate Qualifications and Nominating Procedures
************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1): 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(a): 20A-9-202 "Candidates for elective office" means persons who file a declaration of candidacy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(b): "Candidates for elective office" does not mean candidates for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(b)(i): justice or judge of court of record or not of record;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(b)(ii): presidential elector;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(b)(iii): any political party offices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(1)(b)(iv): municipal or special district offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(2): "Constitutional office" means the state offices of governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, state auditor, and state treasurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(3): 20A-8-101 "Continuing political party" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(a): "County office" means an elective office where the officeholder is selected by voters entirely within one county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b): "County office" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b)(i): the office of justice or judge of any court of record or not of record;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b)(ii): the office of presidential elector;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b)(iii): any political party offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b)(iv): any municipal or special district offices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(4)(b)(v): the office of United States Senator and United States Representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5); 20A-21-201; 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5); 20A-9-408; 20A-21-201 "Electronic candidate qualification process" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(a): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5); 20A-21-201 as it relates to a registered political party that is not a qualified political party, the process for gathering signatures electronically to seek the nomination of a registered political party, described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(a)(i): 20A-9-403 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(a)(ii): 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5) Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(a)(iii): 20A-21-201 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(b): 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5); 20A-9-408; 20A-21-201 as it relates to a qualified political party, the process, for gathering signatures electronically to seek the nomination of a registered political party, described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(b)(i): 20A-9-405; 20A-9-405(3); (5) Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(b)(ii): 20A-9-408 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(5)(b)(iii): 20A-21-201 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(6): "Federal office" means an elective office for United States Senator and United States Representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7): (7)(c); (d) "Filing officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(a): the lieutenant governor, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(a)(i): the office of United States Senator and United States Representative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(a)(ii): all constitutional offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(b): (7)(c); (d) for the office of a state senator, state representative, or the state school board, the lieutenant governor or the applicable clerk described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(c): the county clerk, for county offices and local school district offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(d): the county clerk in the filer's county of residence, for multicounty offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(e): the city or town clerk, for municipal offices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(7)(f): the special district clerk, for special district offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(8): "Local government office" includes county offices, municipal offices, and special district offices and other elective offices selected by the voters from a political division entirely within one county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(9): "Manual candidate qualification process" means the process for gathering signatures to seek the nomination of a registered political party, using paper signature packets that a signer physically signs.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(a): "Multicounty office" means an elective office where the officeholder is selected by the voters from more than one county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b): "Multicounty office" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(i): a county office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(ii): a federal office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(iii): the office of justice or judge of any court of record or not of record;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(iv): the office of presidential elector;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(v): any political party offices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(10)(b)(vi): any municipal or special district offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(11): "Municipal office" means an elective office in a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(12)(a): "Political division" means a geographic unit from which an officeholder is elected and that an officeholder represents.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(12)(b): "Political division" includes a county, a city, a town, a special district, a school district, a legislative district, and a county prosecution district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408; 20A-9-406; 20A-8-103; 20A-9-406 "Qualified political party" means a registered political party that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(a)(i): permits a delegate for the registered political party to vote on a candidate nomination in the registered political party's convention remotely; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(a)(ii): provides a procedure for designating an alternate delegate if a delegate is not present at the registered political party's convention;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(b): does not hold the registered political party's convention before the fourth Saturday in March of an even-numbered year;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(c): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 permits a member of the registered political party to seek the registered political party's nomination for any elective office by the member choosing to seek the nomination by either or both of the following methods:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(c)(i): 20A-9-407 seeking the nomination through the registered political party's convention process, in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(c)(ii): 20A-9-408 seeking the nomination by collecting signatures, in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(d): 20A-9-406; 20A-8-103; 20A-9-406
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(d)(i): 20A-9-406 if the registered political party is a continuing political party, no later than 5 p.m. on the first Monday of October of an odd-numbered year, certifies to the lieutenant governor that, for the election in the following year, the registered political party intends to nominate the registered political party's candidates in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(13)(d)(ii): 20A-8-103; 20A-9-406 if the registered political party is not a continuing political party, certifies at the time that the registered political party files the petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(14): 20A-9-405(3); 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(A); 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(B) "Signature," as it relates to a petition for a candidate to seek the nomination of a registered political party, means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(14)(a): 20A-9-405(3) when using the manual candidate qualification process, a holographic signature collected physically on a nomination petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(14)(b): 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(A); 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(B) when using the electronic candidate qualification process:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(14)(b)(i): 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(A) an electronic signature collected under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(14)(b)(ii): 20A-21-201(6)(c)(ii)(B) a holographic signature collected electronically under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-101(15): "Special district office" means an elected office in a special district.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201 Declarations of candidacy -- Candidacy for more than one office or of more than one political party prohibited with exceptions -- General filing and form requirements -- Affidavit of impecuniosity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"State of Utah, County of ____Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1): Before filing a declaration of candidacy for election to any office, an individual shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1)(a): be a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1)(b): meet the legal requirements of that office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1)(c): if seeking a registered political party's nomination as a candidate for elective office, state:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1)(c)(i): the registered political party of which the individual is a member; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(1)(c)(ii): that the individual is not a member of a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2): 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), an individual may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(a)(i): file a declaration of candidacy for, or be a candidate for, more than one office in Utah during any election year;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(a)(ii): appear on the ballot as the candidate of more than one political party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(a)(iii): file a declaration of candidacy for a registered political party of which the individual is not a member, except to the extent that the registered political party permits otherwise in the registered political party's bylaws.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(b): 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(b)(i): An individual may file a declaration of candidacy for, or be a candidate for, president or vice president of the United States and another office, if the individual resigns the individual's candidacy for the other office after the individual is officially nominated for president or vice president of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(b)(ii): An individual may file a declaration of candidacy for, or be a candidate for, more than one justice court judge office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(2)(b)(iii): 20A-9-202 An individual may file a declaration of candidacy for lieutenant governor even if the individual filed a declaration of candidacy for another office in the same election year if the individual withdraws as a candidate for the other office in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3): 53-6-206; 53-13-103; 20A-11-1603
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(a): Except for a candidate for president or vice president of the United States, before the filing officer may accept any declaration of candidacy, the filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(a)(i): read to the individual the constitutional and statutory qualification requirements for the office that the individual is seeking;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(a)(ii): require the individual to state whether the individual meets the requirements described in Subsection (3)(a)(i);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(a)(iii): if the declaration of candidacy is for a county office, inform the individual that an individual who holds a county elected office may not, at the same time, hold a municipal elected office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(a)(iv): if the declaration of candidacy is for a legislative office, inform the individual that Utah Constitution, Article VI, Section 6, prohibits a person who holds a public office of profit or trust, under authority of the United States or Utah, from being a member of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(b): Before accepting a declaration of candidacy for the office of county attorney, the county clerk shall ensure that the individual filing that declaration of candidacy is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(b)(i): a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(b)(ii): an attorney licensed to practice law in the state who is an active member in good standing of the Utah State Bar;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(b)(iii): a registered voter in the county in which the individual is seeking office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(b)(iv): a current resident of the county in which the individual is seeking office and either has been a resident of that county for at least one year before the date of the election or was appointed and is currently serving as county attorney and became a resident of the county within 30 days after appointment to the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(c): Before accepting a declaration of candidacy for the office of district attorney, the county clerk shall ensure that, as of the date of the election, the individual filing that declaration of candidacy is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(c)(i): a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(c)(ii): an attorney licensed to practice law in the state who is an active member in good standing of the Utah State Bar;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(c)(iii): a registered voter in the prosecution district in which the individual is seeking office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(c)(iv): a current resident of the prosecution district in which the individual is seeking office and either will have been a resident of that prosecution district for at least one year before the date of the election or was appointed and is currently serving as district attorney and became a resident of the prosecution district within 30 days after receiving appointment to the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d): 53-6-206; 53-13-103 Before accepting a declaration of candidacy for the office of county sheriff, the county clerk shall ensure that the individual filing the declaration:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(i): is a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(ii): is a registered voter in the county in which the individual seeks office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(iii): 53-6-206
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(iii)(A): has successfully met the standards and training requirements established for law enforcement officers under Title 53, Chapter 6, Part 2, Peace Officer Training and Certification Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(iii)(B): 53-6-206 has met the waiver requirements in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(iv): 53-13-103 is qualified to be certified as a law enforcement officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(d)(v): before the date of the election, will have been a resident of the county in which the individual seeks office for at least one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(3)(e): 20A-11-1603 Before accepting a declaration of candidacy for the office of governor, lieutenant governor, state auditor, state treasurer, attorney general, state legislator, or State Board of Education member, the filing officer shall ensure that the individual filing the declaration of candidacy also makes the conflict of interest disclosure described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(4): If an individual who files a declaration of candidacy does not meet the qualification requirements for the office the individual is seeking, the filing officer may not accept the individual's declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5): 20A-11-204; 20A-11-303; 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-9-206 If an individual who files a declaration of candidacy meets the requirements described in Subsection (3), the filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a): 20A-11-204; 20A-11-303 inform the individual that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(i): the individual's name will appear on the ballot as the individual's name is written on the individual's declaration of candidacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(ii): the individual may be required to comply with state or local campaign finance disclosure laws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(iii): 20A-11-204; 20A-11-303 the individual is required to file a financial statement before the individual's political convention under:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(iii)(A): 20A-11-204 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(iii)(B): 20A-11-303 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(a)(iii)(C): local campaign finance disclosure laws, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(b): except for a presidential candidate, provide the individual with a copy of the current campaign financial disclosure laws for the office the individual is seeking and inform the individual that failure to comply will result in disqualification as a candidate and removal of the individual's name from the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c): 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(i): 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801 provide the individual with a copy of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(ii): 20A-7-801 inform the individual that the individual must provide the filing officer with an email address that the individual actively monitors:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(ii)(A): to receive a communication from a filing officer or an election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(ii)(B): 20A-7-801 if the individual wishes to display a candidate profile on the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website, to submit to the website the biographical and other information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(iii): inform the individual that the email address described in Subsection (5)(c)(ii) is not a record under Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(c)(iv): obtain from the individual the email address described in Subsection (5)(c)(ii);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(d): 20A-9-206 provide the candidate with a copy of the pledge of fair campaign practices described under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(d)(i): signing the pledge is voluntary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(d)(ii): signed pledges shall be filed with the filing officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(e): accept the individual's declaration of candidacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(5)(f): if the individual has filed for a partisan office, provide a certified copy of the declaration of candidacy to the chair of the county or state political party of which the individual is a member.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(6): If the candidate elects to sign the pledge of fair campaign practices, the filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(6)(a): accept the candidate's pledge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(6)(b): if the candidate has filed for a partisan office, provide a certified copy of the candidate's pledge to the chair of the county or state political party of which the candidate is a member.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7): 20A-9-202; 20A-9-408.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(a): Except for a candidate for president or vice president of the United States, the form of the declaration of candidacy shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(a)(i): be substantially as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(a)(ii): require the candidate to state, in the sworn statement described in Subsection (7)(a)(i):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(a)(ii)(A): the registered political party of which the candidate is a member; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(a)(ii)(B): that the candidate is not a member of a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(7)(b): 20A-9-202; 20A-9-408.5 An agent designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8): 76-8-503; 76-8-504; 20A-1-609; 20A-1-609
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(a): Except for a candidate for president or vice president of the United States, the fee for filing a declaration of candidacy is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(a)(i): $50 for candidates for the local school district board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(a)(ii): $50 plus 1/8 of 1% of the total salary for the full term of office legally paid to the person holding the office for all other federal, state, and county offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(b): Except for presidential candidates, the filing officer shall refund the filing fee to any candidate:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(b)(i): who is disqualified; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(b)(ii): who the filing officer determines has filed improperly.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(c)(i): The county clerk shall immediately pay to the county treasurer all fees received from candidates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(c)(ii): The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(c)(ii)(A): apportion to and pay to the county treasurers of the various counties all fees received for filing of nomination certificates or acceptances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(c)(ii)(B): ensure that each county receives that proportion of the total amount paid to the lieutenant governor from the congressional district that the total vote of that county for all candidates for representative in Congress bears to the total vote of all counties within the congressional district for all candidates for representative in Congress.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d): 76-8-503; 76-8-504; 20A-1-609; 20A-1-609
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(i): A person who is unable to pay the filing fee may file a declaration of candidacy without payment of the filing fee upon a prima facie showing of impecuniosity as evidenced by an affidavit of impecuniosity filed with the filing officer and, if requested by the filing officer, a financial statement filed at the time the affidavit is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(ii): A person who is able to pay the filing fee may not claim impecuniosity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(iii): 76-8-503; 76-8-504; 20A-1-609
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(iii)(A): 76-8-503; 76-8-504 False statements made on an affidavit of impecuniosity or a financial statement filed under this section shall be subject to the criminal penalties provided under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(iii)(B): 20A-1-609 Conviction of a criminal offense under Subsection (8)(d)(iii)(A) shall be considered an offense under this title for the purposes of assessing the penalties provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(iv): The filing officer shall ensure that the affidavit of impecuniosity is printed in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(v): 20A-1-609 The filing officer shall provide to a person who requests an affidavit of impecuniosity a statement printed in substantially the following form, which may be included on the affidavit of impecuniosity:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(8)(d)(vi): The filing officer may request that a person who makes a claim of impecuniosity under this Subsection (8)(d) file a financial statement on a form prepared by the election official.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(9): An individual who fails to file a declaration of candidacy or certificate of nomination within the time provided in this chapter is ineligible for nomination to office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201(10): A declaration of candidacy filed under this section may not be amended or modified after the final date established for filing a declaration of candidacy.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5 Declaration of candidacy filing period for a qualified political party.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(1): In 2022, for a qualified political party, the filing period to file a declaration of candidacy for an elective office that is to be filled at the next regular general election begins at 8 a.m. on February 28, 2022, and ends at 5 p.m. on March 4, 2022.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(2): Beginning on January 1, 2024, for a qualified political party, the filing period to file a declaration of candidacy for an elective office that is to be filled at the next regular general election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(2)(a): begins at 8:00 a.m. on the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(2)(a)(i): January 2 of the year in which the next regular general election is held; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(2)(a)(ii): if January 2 is not a business day, the first business day after January 2; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-201.5(2)(b): ends at 5 p.m. on the fourth business day after the day on which the filing period begins.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202 Declarations of candidacy for regular general elections.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1): (1)(c); 20A-9-405; 20A-9-201(7)(b); 20A-9-201(5)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(a): (1)(c); 20A-9-405 An individual seeking to become a candidate for an elective office that is to be filled at the next regular general election shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(a)(i): (1)(c); 20A-9-405 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(a)(ii): pay the filing fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(b): Unless expressly provided otherwise in this title, for a registered political party that is not a qualified political party, the deadline for filing a declaration of candidacy for an elective office that is to be filled at the next regular general election is 5 p.m. on the first Monday after the fourth Saturday in April.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(c): 20A-9-201(7)(b); 20A-9-201(5) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(c)(i): the individual is located outside of the state during the entire filing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(c)(ii): the designated agent appears in person before the filing officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(c)(iii): the individual communicates with the filing officer using an electronic device that allows the individual and filing officer to see and hear each other; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(c)(iv): 20A-9-201(5) the individual provides the filing officer with an email address to which the filing officer may send the individual the copies described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(d): Each county clerk who receives a declaration of candidacy from a candidate for multicounty office shall transmit the filing fee and a copy of the candidate's declaration of candidacy to the lieutenant governor within one business day after the candidate files the declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(e): Each day during the filing period, each county clerk shall notify the lieutenant governor electronically or by telephone of candidates who have filed a declaration of candidacy with the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(1)(f): Each individual seeking the office of lieutenant governor, the office of district attorney, or the office of president or vice president of the United States shall comply with the specific declaration of candidacy requirements established by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(2): 20A-9-405

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(3)(b)(i): A candidate for lieutenant governor who fails to timely file is disqualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(3)(b)(ii): If a candidate for lieutenant governor is disqualified, another candidate may file to replace the disqualified candidate.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5): 20A-9-409(4)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(a): 20A-9-409(4)(c) A declaration of candidacy filed under this section is valid unless a written objection is filed with the clerk or lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. on the last business day that is at least 10 days before the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(b): If an objection is made, the clerk or lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(b)(i): mail or personally deliver notice of the objection to the affected candidate immediately; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(b)(ii): decide any objection within 48 hours after it is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(c): If the clerk or lieutenant governor sustains the objection, the candidate may cure the problem by amending the declaration or petition before 5 p.m. within three days after the day on which the objection is sustained or by filing a new declaration before 5 p.m. within three days after the day on which the objection is sustained.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(d)(i): The clerk's or lieutenant governor's decision upon objections to form is final.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(d)(ii): The clerk's or lieutenant governor's decision upon substantive matters is reviewable by a district court if prompt application is made to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(5)(d)(iii): The decision of the district court is final unless the Supreme Court, in the exercise of its discretion, agrees to review the lower court decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-202(6): Any person who filed a declaration of candidacy may withdraw as a candidate by filing a written affidavit with the clerk.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203 Declarations of candidacy -- Municipal general elections -- Nomination petition -- Removal of signature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"I, (print name) ____, being first sworn and under penalty of perjury, say that I reside at ____ Street, City of ____, County of ____, state of Utah, Zip Code ____, Telephone Number (if any) ____; that I am a registered voter; and that I am a candidate for the office of ____ (stating the term).  I will meet the legal qualifications required of candidates for this office. If filing via a designated agent, I attest that I will be out of the state of Utah during the entire candidate filing period. I will file all campaign financial disclosure reports as required by law and I understand that failure to do so will result in my disqualification as a candidate for this office and removal of my name from the ballot.  I request that my name be printed upon the applicable official ballots.  (Signed) _______________Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(1): An individual may become a candidate for any municipal office if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(1)(a): the individual is a registered voter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(1)(b)(i): the individual has resided within the municipality in which the individual seeks to hold elective office for the 12 consecutive months immediately before the date of the election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(1)(b)(ii): the territory in which the individual resides was annexed into the municipality, the individual has resided within the annexed territory or the municipality the 12 consecutive months immediately before the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(2): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(2)(a): For purposes of determining whether an individual meets the residency requirement of Subsection (1)(b)(i) in a municipality that was incorporated less than 12 months before the election, the municipality is considered to have been incorporated 12 months before the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(2)(b): In addition to the requirements of Subsection (1), each candidate for a municipal council position shall, if elected from a district, be a resident of the council district from which the candidate is elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(2)(c): 20A-2-101.3; 20A-2-101.5 In accordance with Utah Constitution, Article IV, Section 6, a mentally incompetent individual, an individual convicted of a felony, or an individual convicted of treason or a crime against the elective franchise may not hold office in this state until the right to hold elective office is restored under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3): 20A-9-404; 10-3-301; 10-3-301
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(a): 20A-9-404; 10-3-301 An individual seeking to become a candidate for a municipal office shall, regardless of the nomination method by which the individual is seeking to become a candidate:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(a)(i): 20A-9-404; 10-3-301 except as provided in Subsection (3)(b) or Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, and subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(a)(ii): pay the filing fee, if one is required by municipal ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(b): Subject to Subsection (5)(b), an individual may designate an agent to file a declaration of candidacy with the city recorder or town clerk if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(b)(i): the individual is located outside of the state during the entire filing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(b)(ii): the designated agent appears in person before the city recorder or town clerk;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(b)(iii): the individual communicates with the city recorder or town clerk using an electronic device that allows the individual and city recorder or town clerk to see and hear each other; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(b)(iv): the individual provides the city recorder or town clerk with an email address to which the city recorder or town clerk may send the individual the copies described in Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(c): 10-3-301 Any resident of a municipality may nominate a candidate for a municipal office by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(c)(i): 10-3-301 except as provided in Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, filing a nomination petition with the city recorder or town clerk during the office hours described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(c)(i)(A): 25 registered voters who reside in the municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(c)(i)(B): 20% of the registered voters who reside in the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(3)(c)(ii): paying the filing fee, if one is required by municipal ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4): 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-9-206
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(a): Before the filing officer may accept any declaration of candidacy or nomination petition, the filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(a)(i): read to the prospective candidate or individual filing the petition the constitutional and statutory qualification requirements for the office that the candidate is seeking;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(a)(ii): require the candidate or individual filing the petition to state whether the candidate meets the requirements described in Subsection (4)(a)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(a)(iii): inform the candidate or the individual filing the petition that an individual who holds a municipal elected office may not, at the same time, hold a county elected office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(b): If the prospective candidate does not meet the qualification requirements for the office, the filing officer may not accept the declaration of candidacy or nomination petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c): 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801; 20A-9-206 If it appears that the prospective candidate meets the requirements of candidacy, the filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(i): inform the candidate that the candidate's name will appear on the ballot as it is written on the declaration of candidacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(ii): provide the candidate with a copy of the current campaign financial disclosure laws for the office the candidate is seeking and inform the candidate that failure to comply will result in disqualification as a candidate and removal of the candidate's name from the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(iii): 20A-7-801; 20A-7-801 provide the candidate with a copy of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(iv): 20A-7-801 inform the candidate that the candidate must provide the filing officer with an email address that the candidate actively monitors:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(iv)(A): to receive a communication from a filing officer or an election officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(iv)(B): 20A-7-801 if the candidate wishes to display a candidate profile on the Statewide Electronic Voter Information Website, to submit to the website the biographical and other information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(v): inform the candidate that the email address described in Subsection (4)(c)(iv) is not a record under Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(vi): obtain from the candidate the email address described in Subsection (4)(c)(iv);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(vii): 20A-9-206 provide the candidate with a copy of the pledge of fair campaign practices described under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(vii)(A): signing the pledge is voluntary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(vii)(B): signed pledges shall be filed with the filing officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(c)(viii): accept the declaration of candidacy or nomination petition.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(d)(i): accept the candidate's pledge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(4)(d)(ii): if the candidate has filed for a partisan office, provide a certified copy of the candidate's pledge to the chair of the county or state political party of which the candidate is a member.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(5)(c)(ii): The remainder of the petition shall contain lines and columns for the signatures of individuals signing the petition and each individual's address and phone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(6): If the declaration of candidacy or nomination petition fails to state whether the nomination is for the two-year or four-year term, the clerk shall consider the nomination to be for the four-year term.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(9): Except as provided in Subsection (10)(c), an individual may not amend a declaration of candidacy or nomination petition filed under this section after the candidate filing period ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(a): A declaration of candidacy or nomination petition that an individual files under this section is valid unless a person files a written objection with the clerk before 5 p.m. within 10 days after the last day for filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(b): If a person files an objection, the clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(b)(i): mail or personally deliver notice of the objection to the affected candidate immediately; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(b)(ii): decide any objection within 48 hours after the objection is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(c): If the clerk sustains the objection, the candidate may, before 5 p.m. within three days after the day on which the clerk sustains the objection, correct the problem for which the objection is sustained by amending the candidate's declaration of candidacy or nomination petition, or by filing a new declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(d)(i): The clerk's decision upon objections to form is final.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(d)(ii): The clerk's decision upon substantive matters is reviewable by a district court if prompt application is made to the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203(10)(d)(iii): The decision of the district court is final unless the Supreme Court, in the exercise of its discretion, agrees to review the lower court decision.
