Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203.5 Requirement to post candidate information on website.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The clerk of a county or a municipality shall, within three business days after the day on which the clerk accepts a declaration of candidacy, post the following information on the website of the county or municipality:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203.5(1): the name and campaign contact information of the candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-203.5(2): the office that the candidate is seeking.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-204 Inducements not to become candidate.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-204(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-204(1)(a): It is unlawful for any person to pay or reward, or promise to pay or reward, another in any manner or form for the purpose of inducing that other person to be, or to refrain from or cease being, a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-204(1)(b): It is unlawful for any person to solicit any payment, promise, or reward from another for the purpose of inducing that other person to be, or to refrain from or cease being, a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-204(2): Any person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206 Fair campaign practices -- Voluntary pledge -- Pledge is a public record -- Retention requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"PLEDGE OF FAIR CAMPAIGN PRACTICESUtah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(1): Each person seeking to become a candidate for any elective office that is to be filled at the next election shall be provided with a copy of the pledge of fair campaign practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(2): The pledge shall be in the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(3): The filing officer shall print, or cause to be printed, blank forms of the pledge to be distributed to persons filing a declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(4): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act A pledge that is submitted for filing by a candidate is a public record under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(5): The filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(5)(a): accept all signed pledges that are submitted for filing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(5)(b): retain each filed pledge for public inspection for 30 calendar days after the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-206(6): A candidate may not be required to subscribe to, endorse, or sign the pledge of fair campaign practices.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207 Withdrawal of candidacy -- Notice.
------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this section:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(1): "Public office" means the offices of governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, state auditor, state treasurer, state senator, state representative, state school board, or an elective office of a local political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(2): "Public office candidate" means a person who files a declaration of candidacy for a public office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3): If a public office candidate withdraws as a candidate, an election officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(a): no later than two business days after the day on which the election officer receives notice of the withdrawal, notify every opposing candidate for the public office that the public office candidate has withdrawn;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(b): subject to Subsection (4), upon notice of a withdrawal that occurs 65 or fewer days before the date of the election, send an email notification to each voter who is eligible to vote in the public office race for whom the election officer has an email address informing the voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(b)(i): that the public office candidate has withdrawn; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(b)(ii): that a vote cast for the public office candidate will not be counted, regardless of whether the public office candidate's name appears on the ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(c): post notice of the withdrawal on a public website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(d): if practicable, include with the ballot, including a military or overseas ballot, a written notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(d)(i): contains the information described in Subsections (3)(b)(i) and (ii); or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(3)(d)(ii): directs the voter to a public website to inform the voter whether a candidate on the ballot has withdrawn.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(4): 20A-3a-202 An election officer shall send the email notification described in Subsection (3)(b) on or before the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(4)(a): 20A-3a-202 the next day on which the election officer mails ballots in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-207(4)(b): two business days before the date of the election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-401 Primary elections.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-401(1): This part shall be construed liberally so as to ensure full opportunity for persons to become candidates and for voters to express their choice.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-401(2): This part may not be construed to govern or regulate the internal procedures of a registered political party.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-402 General requirements for all primary elections.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-402(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-402(2): Title 20A, Election Code If there is any conflict between any provision of this part and any other sections in


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403 Regular primary elections.
----------------------------------------------------------
"Notice is given that a primary election will be held Tuesday, June ____, ________(year), to nominate party candidates for the parties and candidates for nonpartisan local school board positions listed on the primary ballot.  The polling place for voting precinct ____ is ____.  The polls will open at 7 a.m. and continue open until 8 p.m. of the same day.  Attest: county clerk."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(1): 20A-1-201.5; 20A-9-501; 20A-9-601; 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(1)(a): 20A-1-201.5; 20A-9-501; 20A-9-601 Candidates for elective office that are to be filled at the next regular general election shall be nominated in a regular primary election by direct vote of the people in the manner prescribed in this section.  The regular primary election is held on the date specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(1)(b): Each registered political party that chooses to have the names of the registered political party's candidates for elective office featured with party affiliation on the ballot at a regular general election shall comply with the requirements of this section and shall nominate the registered political party's candidates for elective office in the manner described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(1)(c): 20A-9-202 A filing officer may not permit an official ballot at a regular general election to be produced or used if the ballot denotes affiliation between a registered political party or any other political group and a candidate for elective office who is not nominated in the manner prescribed in this section or in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(1)(d): Unless noted otherwise, the dates in this section refer to those that occur in each even-numbered year in which a regular general election will be held.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2): 20A-8-103; 20A-8-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(a): Each registered political party, in a statement filed with the lieutenant governor, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(a)(i): either declare the registered political party's intent to participate in the next regular primary election or declare that the registered political party chooses not to have the names of the registered political party's candidates for elective office featured on the ballot at the next regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(a)(ii): if the registered political party participates in the upcoming regular primary election, identify one or more registered political parties whose members may vote for the registered political party's candidates and whether individuals identified as unaffiliated with a political party may vote for the registered political party's candidates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(b): 20A-8-103; 20A-8-103
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(b)(i): A registered political party that is a continuing political party shall file the statement described in Subsection (2)(a) with the lieutenant governor no later than 5 p.m. on November 30 of each odd-numbered year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(2)(b)(ii): 20A-8-103; 20A-8-103 An organization that is seeking to become a registered political party under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3): 20A-9-202; 20A-9-405; 20A-9-408; 20A-21-201; 20A-9-202; 20A-21-201; 20A-1-1002; 20A-9-202; 20A-6-305
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(a): 20A-9-202; 20A-9-405 Except as provided in Subsection (3)(e), an individual who submits a declaration of candidacy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(a)(i): 20A-9-405 circulated and completed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(a)(ii): signed by at least 2% of the registered political party's members who reside in the political division of the office that the individual seeks.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(b)(i): A candidate for elective office shall submit signatures for a nomination petition to the appropriate filing officer for verification and certification no later than 5 p.m. on the final day in March.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(b)(ii): A candidate may supplement the candidate's submissions at any time on or before the filing deadline.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(c): 20A-9-408
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(c)(i): 20A-9-408 The lieutenant governor shall determine for each elective office the total number of signatures that must be submitted under Subsection (3)(a)(ii) or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(c)(ii): The lieutenant governor shall publish the determination for each elective office no later than November 30 of each odd-numbered year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(d): 20A-21-201; 20A-9-202; 20A-21-201; 20A-1-1002 The filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(d)(i): 20A-21-201 except as otherwise provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(d)(v): 20A-21-201; 20A-1-1002 except as otherwise provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(e): 20A-9-202 Notwithstanding any other provision in this Subsection (3), a candidate for lieutenant governor may appear on the regular primary ballot of a registered political party without submitting nomination petitions if the candidate files a declaration of candidacy and complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(f): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the director of elections, within the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, may make rules that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(f)(i): provide for the use of statistical sampling procedures that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(f)(i)(A): filing officers are required to use to verify signatures under Subsection (3)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(f)(i)(B): reflect a bona fide effort to determine the validity of a candidate's entire submission, using widely recognized statistical sampling techniques; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(f)(ii): provide for the transparent, orderly, and timely submission, verification, and certification of nomination petition signatures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(g): 20A-6-305 The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(g)(i): review the declarations of candidacy filed by candidates for local boards of education to determine if more than two candidates have filed for the same seat;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(g)(ii): place the names of all candidates who have filed a declaration of candidacy for a local board of education seat on the nonpartisan section of the ballot if more than two candidates have filed for the same seat; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(3)(g)(iii): 20A-6-305 determine the order of the local board of education candidates' names on the ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4): 20A-9-409; 20A-6-305
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4)(a): 20A-9-409; 20A-6-305 Before the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4)(a)(i): 20A-6-305 a list of the names of all candidates for federal, constitutional, multi-county, single county, and county offices who have received certifications under Subsection (3), along with instructions on how those names shall appear on the primary election ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4)(a)(ii): a list of unopposed candidates for elective office who have been nominated by a registered political party under Subsection (5)(c) and instruct the county clerks to exclude the unopposed candidates from the primary election ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4)(b): A candidate for lieutenant governor and a candidate for governor campaigning as joint-ticket running mates shall appear jointly on the primary election ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(4)(c): After the county clerk receives the certified list from the lieutenant governor under Subsection (4)(a), the county clerk shall post or publish a primary election notice in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(a): A candidate who, at the regular primary election, receives the highest number of votes cast for the office sought by the candidate is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(a)(i): nominated for that office by the candidate's registered political party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(a)(ii): for a nonpartisan local school board position, nominated for that office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(b): If two or more candidates are to be elected to the office at the regular general election, those party candidates equal in number to positions to be filled who receive the highest number of votes at the regular primary election are the nominees of the candidates' party for those positions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(c)(i): As used in this Subsection (5)(c), a candidate is "unopposed" if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(c)(i)(A): no individual other than the candidate receives a certification under Subsection (3) for the regular primary election ballot of the candidate's registered political party for a particular elective office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(c)(i)(B): for an office where more than one individual is to be elected or nominated, the number of candidates who receive certification under Subsection (3) for the regular primary election of the candidate's registered political party does not exceed the total number of candidates to be elected or nominated for that office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(5)(c)(ii): A candidate who is unopposed for an elective office in the regular primary election of a registered political party is nominated by the party for that office without appearing on the primary election ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(6): The expense of providing all ballots, blanks, or other supplies to be used at any primary election provided for by this section, and all expenses necessarily incurred in the preparation for or the conduct of that primary election shall be paid out of the treasury of the county or state, in the same manner as for the regular general elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-403(7): An individual may not file a declaration of candidacy for a registered political party of which the individual is not a member, except to the extent that the registered political party permits otherwise under the registered political party's bylaws.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404 Municipal primary elections.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1): 20A-1-201.5; 53G-3-302; 53G-3-302
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(a): Except as otherwise provided in this section or Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, candidates for municipal office in all municipalities shall be nominated at a municipal primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(b): 20A-1-201.5 Municipal primary elections shall be held:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(b)(i): 20A-1-201.5 consistent with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(b)(ii): whenever possible, at the same polling places as the regular municipal election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(c): 53G-3-302 Subsections (3) through (5) do not apply to an election to elect local school board members under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(1)(d): 53G-3-302 Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, does not apply to an election to elect local school board members under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(2): Except as otherwise provided in Chapter 4, Part 6, Municipal Alternate Voting Methods Pilot Project, if the number of candidates for a particular municipal office does not exceed twice the number of individuals needed to fill that office, a primary election for that office may not be held and the candidates are considered nominated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3): 20A-9-203; 20A-9-601
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(a): For purposes of this Subsection (3), "convention" means an organized assembly of voters or delegates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(b)(i): By ordinance adopted before the May 1 that falls before a regular municipal election, any third, fourth, or fifth class city or town may exempt itself from a primary election by providing that the nomination of candidates for municipal office to be voted upon at a municipal election be nominated by a municipal party convention or committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(b)(ii): The municipal party convention or committee described in Subsection (3)(b)(i) shall be held on or before May 30 of an odd-numbered year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(b)(iii): Any primary election exemption ordinance adopted under this Subsection (3) remains in effect until repealed by ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(c)(i): A convention or committee may not nominate more than one candidate for each of the municipal offices to be voted upon at the municipal election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(c)(ii): A convention or committee may not nominate an individual who has accepted the nomination of a different convention or committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(c)(iii): A municipal party may not have more than one group of candidates placed upon the ballot and may not group the same candidates on different tickets by the same party under a different name or emblem.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d): 20A-9-203
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(i): On or before May 31 of an odd-numbered year, a convention or committee shall prepare and submit to the filing officer a certificate of nomination for each individual nominated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii): The certificate of nomination shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(A): contain the name of the office for which each individual is nominated, the name, post office address, and, if in a city, the street number of residence and place of business, if any, of each individual nominated;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(B): designate in not more than five words the party that the convention or committee represents;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(C): contain a copy of the resolution passed at the convention that authorized the committee to make the nomination;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(D): contain a statement certifying that the name of the candidate nominated by the political party will not appear on the ballot as a candidate for any other political party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(E): be signed by the presiding officer and secretary of the convention or committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(ii)(F): contain a statement identifying the residence and post office address of the presiding officer and secretary and certifying that the presiding officer and secretary were officers of the convention or committee and that the certificates are true to the best of their knowledge and belief.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(iii): 20A-9-203 A candidate nominated by a municipal party convention or committee shall file a declaration with the filing officer in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(iii)(A): the name of the municipal party or convention that nominated the candidate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(d)(iii)(B): the office for which the convention or committee nominated the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(e): 20A-9-601 A committee appointed at a convention, if authorized by an enabling resolution, may also make nominations or fill vacancies in nominations made at a convention if the committee makes the nomination before the deadline for a write-in candidate to file a declaration of candidacy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(3)(f): The election ballot shall substantially comply with the form prescribed in Chapter 6, Part 4, Ballot Form Requirements for Municipal Elections, but the party name shall be included with the candidate's name.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4): 20A-7-303; 20A-1-1002; 20A-6-401; 20A-6-401.1
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(a): Any third, fourth, or fifth class city or a town may adopt an ordinance before the May 1 that falls before the regular municipal election that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(a)(i): exempts the city or town from the other methods of nominating candidates to municipal office provided in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(a)(ii): provides for a municipal partisan convention method of nominating candidates as provided in this Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b): 20A-7-303; 20A-1-1002
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(i): Any party that was a registered political party at the last regular general election or regular municipal election is a municipal political party under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(ii): 20A-7-303 Any political party may qualify as a municipal political party by presenting a petition to the city recorder that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(ii)(A): is signed, with a holographic signature, by registered voters within the municipality equal to at least 20% of the number of votes cast for all candidates for mayor in the last municipal election at which a mayor was elected;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(ii)(B): is filed with the city recorder or town clerk before 5 p.m. no later than the day before the day on which the municipal party holds a convention to nominate a candidate under this Subsection (4);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(ii)(C): 20A-7-303 is substantially similar to the form of the signature sheets described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(ii)(D): contains the name of the municipal political party using not more than five words.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(b)(iii): 20A-1-1002 With the assistance of the county clerk, the city recorder or town clerk shall use the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(c)(i): If the number of candidates for a particular office does not exceed twice the number of offices to be filled at the regular municipal election, no primary election for that office shall be held and the candidates are considered to be nominated.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(c)(ii): If the number of candidates for a particular office exceeds twice the number of offices to be filled at the regular municipal election, those candidates for municipal office shall be nominated at a municipal primary election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(d): 20A-6-401; 20A-6-401.1 The clerk shall ensure that the partisan municipal primary ballot is similar to the ballot forms required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(e): After marking a municipal primary ballot, the voter shall deposit the ballot in the blank ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(4)(f): Immediately after the canvass, the election judges shall, without examination, destroy the tickets deposited in the blank ballot box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(5): 20A-1-1003; 20A-1-1003
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(5)(a): A voter who signs a petition under Subsection (4)(b)(ii) may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, no later than three business days after the day on which the petition is filed with the city recorder or town clerk, submitting to the city recorder or town clerk a statement requesting that the voter's signature be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(5)(b): 20A-1-1003 A statement described in Subsection (5)(a) shall comply with the requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-404(5)(c): 20A-1-1003 With the assistance of the county clerk and using the procedures described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405 Nomination petitions for regular primary elections.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Warning: It is a class A misdemeanor for anyone to knowingly sign a nomination petition with any name other than the person's own name, or more than once for the same candidate, or if the person is not registered to vote in this state."; andUtah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(1): 20A-9-403(3)(a) This section applies to the form and circulation of nomination petitions for regular primary elections described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(2): 20A-9-202(1) A candidate for elective office, and the agents of the candidate, may not circulate nomination petitions until the candidate has submitted a declaration of candidacy in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3): For the manual candidate qualification process, the nomination petitions shall be in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(a): the petition shall be printed on paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(b): the petition shall be ruled with a horizontal line 3/4 inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for purposes of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(c): the petition shall be headed by a caption stating the purpose of the petition and the name of the proposed candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(d): the petition shall feature the word "Warning" followed by the following statement in no less than eight-point, single leaded type: "It is a class A misdemeanor for anyone to knowingly sign a nomination petition with any name other than the person's own name, or more than once for the same candidate, or if the person is not registered to vote in this state.";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(e): the petition shall feature 10 lines spaced one-half inch apart and consecutively numbered one through 10;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f): the signature portion of the petition shall be divided into columns headed by the following titles:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(i): Registered Voter's Printed Name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(ii): Signature of Registered Voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(iii): Party Affiliation of Registered Voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(iv): Birth Date or Age (Optional);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(v): Street Address, City, Zip Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(f)(vi): Date of Signature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(3)(g): a photograph of the candidate may appear on the nomination petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4): 20A-21-201 For the electronic candidate qualification process, the lieutenant governor shall design an electronic form, using progressive screens, that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(a): the following warning:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b): 20A-21-201 the following information for each individual who signs the petition:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(i): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(ii): party affiliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(iii): date of birth or age, (optional);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(iv): street address, city, zip code;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(v): date of signature;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(vi): 20A-21-201 other information required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(4)(b)(vii): other information required by the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(5): For the manual candidate qualification process, if one or more nomination petitions are bound together, a page shall be bound to the nomination petition(s) that features the following printed verification statement to be signed and dated by the petition circulator:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(6): The lieutenant governor shall prepare and make public model nomination petition forms and associated instructions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(7): A nomination petition circulator must be at least 18 years old and a resident of the state, but may affiliate with any political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8): 20A-9-408; 20A-2-105 It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(a): 20A-9-408 knowingly sign the nomination petition described in this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(a)(i): with any name other than the person's own name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(a)(ii): more than once for the same candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(a)(iii): if the person is not registered to vote in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(b): 20A-2-105 sign the verification of a signature for a nomination petition if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(b)(i): 20A-2-105 does not meet the residency requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(b)(ii): has not witnessed the signing by those persons whose names appear on the nomination petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(b)(iii): knows that a person whose signature appears on the nomination petition is not registered to vote in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(c): pay compensation to any person to sign a nomination petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(8)(d): pay compensation to any person to circulate a nomination petition, if the compensation is based directly on the number of signatures submitted to a filing officer rather than on the number of signatures verified or on some other basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(9): (8) Any person violating Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-405(10): Withdrawal of petition signatures is prohibited.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406 Qualified political party -- Requirements and exemptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The following provisions apply to a qualified political party:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(1): the qualified political party shall, no later than 5 p.m. on the first Monday of October of each odd-numbered year, certify to the lieutenant governor the identity of one or more registered political parties whose members may vote for the qualified political party's candidates and whether unaffiliated voters may vote for the qualified political party's candidates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(2): 20A-9-403(1); (3)(b); (3)(d); (4)(a); 20A-9-403(5)(c); 20A-9-405 the following provisions do not apply to a nomination for the qualified political party:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(2)(a): 20A-9-403(1); (3)(b); (3)(d); (4)(a) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(2)(b): 20A-9-403(5)(c) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(2)(c): 20A-9-405 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(3): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 an individual may only seek the nomination of the qualified political party by using a method described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(4): 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408; 20A-9-409 the qualified political party shall comply with the provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(5): 20A-6-301(1)(a); (1)(e); (2)(a); 20A-6-301; (1) notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(5)(a): under the qualified political party's name  , if any; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(5)(b): (1) under the title of the qualified registered political party as designated by the qualified political party in the certification described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(6): 20A-6-302(1)(a) notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(7): 20A-6-304(1)(e) notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(8): 20A-9-101(1)(a); 20A-9-407; 20A-9-408 "candidates for elective office," defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-406(9): 20A-9-201(1)(c) an individual who is nominated by, or seeking the nomination of, the qualified political party is not required to comply with Subsection

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-407(1): This section describes the requirements for a member of a qualified political party who is seeking the nomination of a qualified political party for an elective office through the qualified political party's convention process.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408 Signature-gathering process to seek the nomination of a qualified political party -- Removal of signature.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(1): This section describes the requirements for a member of a qualified political party who is seeking the nomination of the qualified political party for an elective office through the signature-gathering process described in this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(7): 20A-9-701(2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8): 20A-9-405(3) A member of a qualified political party may seek the nomination of the qualified political party for an elective office by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(a): complying with the requirements described in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b): 20A-9-405(3) collecting signatures, on a form approved by the lieutenant governor that complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(i): for a statewide race, 28,000 signatures of registered voters in the state who are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(ii): for a congressional district race, 7,000 signatures of registered voters who are residents of the congressional district and are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(iii): for a state Senate district race, 2,000 signatures of registered voters who are residents of the state Senate district and are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(iv): for a state House district race, 1,000 signatures of registered voters who are residents of the state House district and are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(v): for a State Board of Education race, the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(v)(A): 2,000 signatures of registered voters who are residents of the State Board of Education district and are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(v)(B): 3% of the registered voters of the qualified political party who are residents of the applicable State Board of Education district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-408(8)(b)(vi): for a county office race, signatures of 3% of the registered voters who are residents of the area permitted to vote for the county office and are permitted by the qualified political party to vote for the qualified political party's candidates in a primary election.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-411 Signing multiple nomination petitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-411(1): 20A-9-403; 20A-9-408 An individual who signs a petition, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-411(2): (1) If an individual signs more than one petition in violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501 Candidates not affiliated with a party -- General requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501(1)(a): Candidates for public office who do not wish to affiliate with a registered political party may obtain a position on the ballot by following the procedures and requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501(1)(b): Upon compliance with the provisions of this part, the unaffiliated candidate is entitled to all the rights and subject to all the penalties of candidates selected by a registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501(2): A candidate who has filed a declaration of candidacy may not file a certificate of nomination as an unaffiliated candidate in the same year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-501(3): The courts shall construe this part liberally so as to give unaffiliated candidates for public office every reasonable opportunity to make their candidacy effective.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502 Certificate of nomination -- Contents -- Circulation -- Verification -- Criminal penalty -- Removal of petition signature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"State of Utah, County of ______________________________________________Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1): The candidate shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(a): prepare a certificate of nomination in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b): for each signature packet, bind signature sheets to a copy of the certificate of nomination and the circulator verification, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(i): are printed on sheets of paper 8-1/2 inches long and 11 inches wide;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(ii): are ruled with a horizontal line 3/4 inch from the top, with the space above that line blank for the purpose of binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(iii): contain the name of the proposed candidate and the words "Unaffiliated Candidate Certificate of Nomination Petition" printed directly below the horizontal line;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(iv): contain the word "Warning" printed directly under the words described in Subsection (1)(b)(iii);
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(v): contain, to the right of the word "Warning," the following statement printed in not less than eight-point, single leaded type:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(vi): contain the following statement directly under the statement described in Subsection (1)(b)(v):
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(vii): contain horizontally ruled lines, 3/8 inch apart under the statement described in Subsection (1)(b)(vi); and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii): be vertically divided into columns as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(A): the first column shall appear at the extreme left of the sheet, be 5/8 inch wide, be headed with "For Office Use Only," and be subdivided with a light vertical line down the middle;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(B): the next column shall be 2-1/2 inches wide, headed "Registered Voter's Printed Name (must be legible to be counted)";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(C): the next column shall be 2-1/2 inches wide, headed "Holographic Signature of Registered Voter";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(D): the next column shall be one inch wide, headed "Birth Date or Age (Optional)";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(E): the final column shall be 4-3/8 inches wide, headed "Street Address, City, Zip Code"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(b)(viii)(F): at the bottom of the sheet, contain the following statement: "Birth date or age information is not required, but it may be used to verify your identity with voter registration records.  If you choose not to provide it, your signature may not be certified as a valid signature if you change your address before petition signatures are certified or if the information you provide does not match your voter registration records."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(1)(c): bind a final page to one or more signature sheets that are bound together that contains, except as provided by Subsection (3), the following printed statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(2): 20A-9-503 An agent designated to file a certificate of nomination under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(3)(a): The candidate shall circulate the nomination petition and ensure that the person in whose presence each signature sheet is signed:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(3)(a)(i): is at least 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(3)(a)(ii): verifies each signature sheet by completing the verification bound to one or more signature sheets that are bound together.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(3)(b): A person may not sign the circulator verification if the person signed a signature sheet bound to the verification.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a): It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(i): knowingly sign a certificate of nomination signature sheet:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(i)(A): with any name other than the person's own name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(i)(B): more than once for the same candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(i)(C): if the person is not registered to vote in this state and does not intend to become registered to vote in this state before the county clerk certifies the signatures; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(ii): sign the verification of a certificate of nomination signature sheet if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(ii)(A): has not witnessed the signing by those persons whose names appear on the certificate of nomination signature sheet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(a)(ii)(B): knows that a person whose signature appears on the certificate of nomination signature sheet is not registered to vote in this state and does not intend to become registered to vote in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(4)(b): Any person violating this Subsection (4) is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5): 20A-9-201.5; 20A-9-503; 20A-1-1002
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(a): 20A-9-201.5; 20A-9-503 To qualify for placement on the general election ballot, the candidate shall, no earlier than the start of the declaration of candidacy period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(a)(i): 20A-9-503 comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(a)(ii): submit each signature packet to the county clerk where the majority of the signatures in the packet were collected, with signatures totaling:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(a)(ii)(A): at least 1,000 registered voters residing within the state when the nomination is for an office to be filled by the voters of the entire state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(a)(ii)(B): at least 300 registered voters residing within a political division or at least 5% of the registered voters residing within a political division, whichever is less, when the nomination is for an office to be filled by the voters of any political division smaller than the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(b): A candidate has not complied with Subsection (5)(a)(ii), unless the county clerks verify that each required signature is a valid signature of a registered voter who is eligible to sign the signature packet and has not signed a signature packet to nominate another candidate for the same office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(c): In reviewing the signature packets, the county clerk shall count and certify only those persons who signed with a holographic signature, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(c)(i): are registered voters within the political division that the candidate seeks to represent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(c)(ii): did not sign any other certificate of nomination for that office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(d): The county clerk shall count and certify the number of registered voters who validly signed a signature packet, no later than 30 days after the day on which the candidate submits the signature packet.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(e): The candidate may supplement the signatures or amend the certificate of nomination or declaration of candidacy at any time on or before 5 p.m. on June 15 of the year in which the election will be held.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(5)(f): 20A-1-1002 The county clerk shall use the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(6): 20A-1-1003; 20A-1-1003
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(6)(a): A voter who signs a signature packet under this section may have the voter's signature removed from the signature packet by, no later than three business days after the day on which the candidate submits the signature packet to the county clerk, submitting to the county clerk a statement requesting that the voter's signature be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(6)(b): 20A-1-1003 A statement described in Subsection (6)(a) shall comply with the requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-502(6)(c): 20A-1-1003 The county clerk shall use the procedures described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503 Certificate of nomination -- Filing -- Fees.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(1): 20A-9-502 A candidate shall, in accordance with the deadline described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(1)(a): file the certificate of nomination and the applicable declaration of candidacy, in person unless otherwise provided in statute, with the filing officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(1)(b): pay the filing fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2): 20A-9-502
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2)(a): The provisions of this Subsection (2) do not apply to an individual who files a certificate of nomination and declaration of candidacy for president of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2)(b): 20A-9-502 Subject to Subsections (5) and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2)(b)(i): the individual is located outside of the state during the entire filing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2)(b)(ii): the designated agent appears in person before the filing officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(2)(b)(iii): the individual communicates with the filing officer using an electronic device that allows the individual and filing officer to see and hear each other.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(3)(a): At the time of filing, and before accepting the certificate of nomination and declaration of candidacy, the filing officer shall read the constitutional and statutory requirements for candidacy to the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(3)(b): If the candidate states that the candidate does not meet the requirements, the filing officer may not accept the certificate of nomination and declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(4): An individual filing a certificate of nomination for president of the United States under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(4)(a): shall pay a filing fee of $500; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(4)(b): may use a designated agent to file the nomination petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-503(5): An agent designated to file a certificate of nomination under Subsection (2)(b) or (4)(b) may not sign the certificate of nomination form.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504 Unaffiliated candidates -- Governor and president of the United States.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(1)(a): Each unaffiliated candidate for governor shall, before 5 p.m. no later than June 15 of the regular general election year, select a running mate to file as an unaffiliated candidate for the office of lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(1)(b): The unaffiliated lieutenant governor candidate shall, before 5 p.m. no later than June 15 of the regular general election year, file as an unaffiliated candidate by following the procedures and requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(2): 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(2)(a): Each unaffiliated candidate for president of the United States shall, before 5 p.m. no later than August 15 of a regular general election year, select a running mate to file as an unaffiliated candidate for the office of vice president of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-504(2)(b): 20A-9-202 Before 5 p.m. no later than August 15 of a regular general election year, the unaffiliated candidate for vice president of the United States described in Subsection (2)(a) shall comply with the requirements of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601 Qualifying as a write-in candidate.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
"State of Utah, County of ____Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), an individual who wishes to become a valid write-in candidate shall file a declaration of candidacy in person, or through a designated agent for a candidate for president or vice president of the United States, with the appropriate filing officer before 5 p.m. no later than 65 days before the date of the regular general election or the municipal general election in which the individual intends to be a write-in candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b)(i): The provisions of this Subsection (1)(b) do not apply to an individual who files a declaration of candidacy for president of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b)(ii): Subject to Subsection (2)(d), an individual may designate an agent to file a declaration of candidacy with the appropriate filing officer if:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b)(ii)(A): the individual is located outside of the state during the entire filing period;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b)(ii)(B): the designated agent appears in person before the filing officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(1)(b)(ii)(C): the individual communicates with the filing officer using an electronic device that allows the individual and filing officer to see and hear each other.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(2): 20A-9-202
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(2)(a): The form of the declaration of candidacy for a write-in candidate for all offices, except president or vice president of the United States, is substantially as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(2)(b): The form of the declaration of candidacy for a write-in candidate for president of the United States is substantially as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(2)(c): 20A-9-202 A declaration of candidacy for a write-in candidate for vice president of the United States shall be in substantially the same form as a declaration of candidacy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(2)(d): An agent described in Subsection (1)(a) or (b) may not sign the form described in Subsection (2)(a) or (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3)(a): The filing officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3)(a)(i): read to the candidate the constitutional and statutory requirements for the office;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3)(a)(ii): ask the candidate whether the candidate meets the requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3)(a)(iii): if the declaration of candidacy is for a legislative office, inform the individual that Utah Constitution, Article VI, Section 6, prohibits a person who holds a public office of profit or trust, under authority of the United States or Utah, from being a member of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(3)(b): If the candidate cannot meet the requirements of office, the filing officer may not accept the write-in candidate's declaration of candidacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(4): 20A-9-201; 20A-9-201; 20A-9-803
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(4)(a): 20A-9-201 Except as provided in Subsection (4)(b), a write-in candidate is subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(4)(b): 20A-9-201; 20A-9-803 A write-in candidate for president of the United States is subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-601(5): By November 1 of each regular general election year, the lieutenant governor shall certify to each county clerk the names of all write-in candidates who filed their declaration of candidacy with the lieutenant governor.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In elections for county attorney or district attorney that meet the requirements of Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-701 Certification of party candidates to county clerks -- Display on ballot.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-701(1): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) No later than August 31 of each regular general election year, the lieutenant governor shall certify to each county clerk, for offices to be voted upon at the regular general election in that county clerk's county:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-701(1)(a): 20A-9-202(4); 20A-9-403(5) the names of each candidate nominated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-701(1)(b): the names of the candidates for president and vice president that are certified by the registered political party as the party's nominees.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-701(2): The names shall be certified by the lieutenant governor and shall be displayed on the ballot as they are provided on the candidate's declaration of candidacy.  No other names may appear on the ballot as affiliated with, endorsed by, or nominated by any other registered political party, political party, or other political group.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "registered political party" means a political party that has complied with the requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802 Presidential primary election established -- Other ballot items prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1): Chapter 1, General Provisions; Chapter 2, Voter Registration; Chapter 3a, Voting; Chapter 4, Election Returns and Election Contests; Chapter 5, Election Administration; Chapter 6, Ballot Form
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(a): There is established a presidential primary election held on the first Tuesday in March in the year in which a presidential election will be held.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b): Chapter 1, General Provisions; Chapter 2, Voter Registration; Chapter 3a, Voting; Chapter 4, Election Returns and Election Contests; Chapter 5, Election Administration; Chapter 6, Ballot Form Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, county clerks shall administer the presidential primary election according to the provisions of this title, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(i): Chapter 1, General Provisions
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(ii): Chapter 2, Voter Registration
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(iii): Chapter 3a, Voting
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(iv): Chapter 4, Election Returns and Election Contests
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(v): Chapter 5, Election Administration
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(b)(vi): Chapter 6, Ballot Form
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(c)(i): The county clerks shall ensure that the ballot voted by the voters at the presidential primary election contains only the names of candidates for President of the United States who have qualified as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(1)(c)(ii): The county clerks may not present any other items to the voters to be voted upon at this election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(2): Registered political parties, and candidates for President of the United States who are affiliated with a registered political party, may participate in the presidential primary election established by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(3): As a condition for using the state's election system, each registered political party wishing to participate in the presidential primary election held under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(3)(a): declare the political party's intent to participate in the presidential primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(3)(b): identify one or more registered political parties whose members may vote for the registered political party's candidates and whether individuals identified as unaffiliated with a political party may vote for the registered political party's candidates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802(3)(c): certify that information to the lieutenant governor no later than 5 p.m. on August 10 of the year before the year in which the presidential primary election will be held.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802.5 Presidential primary required.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802.5(1): A presidential primary election shall be held under this part each year in which a presidential election will be held.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802.5(2): A registered political party that wishes to nominate a presidential candidate for the general election may participate in a presidential primary election conducted under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-802.5(3): The Legislature shall appropriate sufficient funds to administer each presidential primary election conducted under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803 Declaration of candidacy -- Filing fee -- Form.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(1): Candidates for president of the United States who are affiliated with a registered political party that has elected to participate in the presidential primary election and who wish to participate in the primary election shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(1)(a): file a declaration of candidacy, in person or via a designated agent, with the lieutenant governor between August 15 of the year before the primary election will be held and 5 p.m. on December 1 of the year before the primary election will be held;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(1)(b): identify the registered political party whose nomination the candidate is seeking;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(1)(c): provide a letter from the registered political party certifying that the candidate may participate as a candidate for that party in that party's presidential primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(1)(d): pay the filing fee of $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(2): The lieutenant governor shall develop a declaration of candidacy form for presidential candidates participating in the primary.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-803(3): (2) An agent designated to file a declaration of candidacy may not sign the form described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805 Closed primary -- Determining party affiliation -- Changing party affiliation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(1): 20A-9-802(3)(b) If a registered political party has restricted voting for its presidential candidates as authorized by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(2): 20A-2-107; 20A-9-808
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(2)(a): For each individual who registers to vote, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(2)(a)(i): record the party affiliation designated by the individual on the voter registration form as the individual's party affiliation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(2)(a)(ii): if no political party affiliation is designated by the individual on the voter registration form, record the individual's party affiliation as "unaffiliated."
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-805(2)(b): 20A-2-107; 20A-9-808 Any registered voter may designate or change the voter's political party affiliation by complying with the procedures and requirements of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806 Ballots.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(1): Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403 The lieutenant governor, together with county clerks, suppliers of election materials, and representatives of registered political parties, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(1)(a): develop manual ballots, mechanical ballots, return envelopes and provisional ballot envelopes to be used in a presidential primary election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(1)(b): Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots ensure that the ballots, return envelopes, and provisional ballot envelopes comply generally with the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(1)(c): 20A-5-403 provide voting booths, election records and supplies, and ballot boxes for each voting precinct as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2): (1)(b); (c); Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403; (2); (2); 20A-6-101; 20A-6-102; (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(a): (1)(b); (c); Chapter 6, Part 1, General Requirements for All Ballots; 20A-5-403 Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(a)(i): facilitate the distribution, voting, and tallying of ballots in a closed primary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(a)(ii): simplify the task of poll workers, particularly in determining a voter's party affiliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(a)(iii): minimize the possibility of spoiled ballots due to voter confusion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(a)(iv): protect against fraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(b): (2) To accomplish the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(b)(i): mark ballots as being for a particular registered political party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(b)(ii): instruct persons counting the ballots to count only those votes for candidates from the registered political party whose ballot the voter received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(c): (2); 20A-6-101; 20A-6-102; (2)(a) To accomplish the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(c)(i): 20A-6-101; 20A-6-102 notwithstanding the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(c)(ii): place ballots for each registered political party in different voting booths and direct voters to the particular voting booth for the political party whose ballot they are voting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-806(2)(c)(iii): (2)(a) consider other means of accomplishing the objectives described in Subsection

-----------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-808 Voting.
---------------------------------------
Voting in a presidential primary election shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-809 Counting votes -- Canvass -- Certification of results to parties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-809(1): Chapter 4, Election Returns and Election Contests Votes shall be counted, results tabulated, returns transmitted, ballots reviewed and retained, returns canvassed, and recounts and election contests conducted as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-9-809(2): After the canvass is complete and the report is prepared, the lieutenant governor shall transmit a copy of the report to each registered political party that participated in the presidential primary election.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 11 - Campaign and Financial Reporting Requirements
********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(1)(a): "Address" means the number and street where an individual resides or where a reporting entity has its principal office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(1)(b): "Address" does not include a post office box.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2): "Agent of a reporting entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2)(a): a person acting on behalf of a reporting entity at the direction of the reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2)(b): a person employed by a reporting entity in the reporting entity's capacity as a reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2)(c): the personal campaign committee of a candidate or officeholder;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2)(d): a member of the personal campaign committee of a candidate or officeholder in the member's capacity as a member of the personal campaign committee of the candidate or officeholder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(2)(e): a political consultant of a reporting entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(3): "Ballot proposition" includes initiatives, referenda, proposed constitutional amendments, and any other ballot propositions submitted to the voters that are authorized by the Utah Code Annotated 1953.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(4): "Candidate" means any person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(4)(a): files a declaration of candidacy for a public office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(4)(b): receives contributions, makes expenditures, or gives consent for any other person to receive contributions or make expenditures to bring about the person's nomination or election to a public office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(5): 20A-11-1501 "Chief election officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(5)(a): 20A-11-1501 the lieutenant governor for state office candidates, legislative office candidates, officeholders, political parties, political action committees, corporations, political issues committees, state school board candidates, judges, and labor organizations, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(5)(b): the county clerk for local school board candidates.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a): "Contribution" means any of the following when done for political purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(i): a gift, subscription, donation, loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value given to the filing entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(ii): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make a gift, subscription, donation, unpaid or partially unpaid loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value to the filing entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(iii): any transfer of funds from another reporting entity to the filing entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(iv): compensation paid by any person or reporting entity other than the filing entity for personal services provided without charge to the filing entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(v): remuneration from:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(v)(A): any organization or its directly affiliated organization that has a registered lobbyist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(v)(B): any agency or subdivision of the state, including school districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(vi): a loan made by a candidate deposited to the candidate's own campaign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(a)(vii): in-kind contributions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(b): "Contribution" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(b)(i): services provided by individuals volunteering a portion or all of their time on behalf of the filing entity if the services are provided without compensation by the filing entity or any other person;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(b)(ii): money lent to the filing entity by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(b)(iii): goods or services provided for the benefit of a political entity at less than fair market value that are not authorized by or coordinated with the political entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(6)(b)(iv): data or information described in Subsection (24)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(7): "Coordinated with" means that goods or services provided for the benefit of a political entity are provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(7)(a): with the political entity's prior knowledge, if the political entity does not object;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(7)(b): by agreement with the political entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(7)(c): in coordination with the political entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(7)(d): using official logos, slogans, and similar elements belonging to a political entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(a): "Corporation" means a domestic or foreign, profit or nonprofit, business organization that is registered as a corporation or is authorized to do business in a state and makes any expenditure from corporate funds for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(a)(i): the purpose of expressly advocating for political purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(a)(ii): the purpose of expressly advocating the approval or the defeat of any ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(b): "Corporation" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(b)(i): a business organization's political action committee or political issues committee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(8)(b)(ii): a business entity organized as a partnership or a sole proprietorship.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(9): "County political party" means, for each registered political party, all of the persons within a single county who, under definitions established by the political party, are members of the registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(10): 20A-8-402 "County political party officer" means a person whose name is required to be submitted by a county political party to the lieutenant governor in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11): "Detailed listing" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(a): for each contribution or public service assistance:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(a)(i): the name and address of the individual or source making the contribution or public service assistance, except to the extent that the name or address of the individual or source is unknown;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(a)(ii): the amount or value of the contribution or public service assistance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(a)(iii): the date the contribution or public service assistance was made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(b): for each expenditure:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(b)(i): the amount of the expenditure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(b)(ii): the goods or services acquired by the expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(11)(b)(iii): the date the expenditure was made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(12)(a): "Donor" means a person that gives money, including a fee, due, or assessment for membership in the corporation, to a corporation without receiving full and adequate consideration for the money.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(12)(b): "Donor" does not include a person that signs a statement that the corporation may not use the money for an expenditure or political issues expenditure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(13): "Election" means each:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(13)(a): regular general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(13)(b): regular primary election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(13)(c): special election at which candidates are eliminated and selected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(14): "Electioneering communication" means a communication that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(14)(a): has at least a value of $10,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(14)(b): clearly identifies a candidate or judge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(14)(c): is disseminated through the Internet, newspaper, magazine, outdoor advertising facility, direct mailing, broadcast, cable, or satellite provider within 45 days of the clearly identified candidate's or judge's election date.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15): 20A-11-1702
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a): 20A-11-1702 "Expenditure" means any of the following made by a reporting entity or an agent of a reporting entity on behalf of the reporting entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(i): any disbursement from contributions, receipts, or from the separate bank account required by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(ii): a purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value made for political purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(iii): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make any purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value for political purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(iv): compensation paid by a filing entity for personal services rendered by a person without charge to a reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(v): a transfer of funds between the filing entity and a candidate's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(vi): goods or services provided by the filing entity to or for the benefit of another reporting entity for political purposes at less than fair market value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(a)(vii): 20A-11-1702 an independent expenditure, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(b): "Expenditure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(b)(i): services provided without compensation by individuals volunteering a portion or all of their time on behalf of a reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(b)(ii): money lent to a reporting entity by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(15)(b)(iii): anything listed in Subsection (15)(a) that is given by a reporting entity to candidates for office or officeholders in states other than Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(16): "Federal office" means the office of president of the United States, United States Senator, or United States Representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(17): "Filing entity" means the reporting entity that is required to file a financial statement required by this chapter or Chapter 12, Part 2, Judicial Retention Elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(18): "Financial statement" includes any summary report, interim report, verified financial statement, or other statement disclosing contributions, expenditures, receipts, donations, or disbursements that is required by this chapter or Chapter 12, Part 2, Judicial Retention Elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(19): "Governing board" means the individual or group of individuals that determine the candidates and committees that will receive expenditures from a political action committee, political party, or corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(20): "Incorporation" means the process established by Title 10, Chapter 2a, Municipal Incorporation, by which a geographical area becomes legally recognized as a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(21): 10-2a-210 "Incorporation election" means the election conducted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(22): 10-2a-208 "Incorporation petition" means a petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(23): "Individual" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(24): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(24)(a): "In-kind contribution" means anything of value, other than money, that is accepted by or coordinated with a filing entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(24)(b): "In-kind contribution" does not include survey results, voter lists, voter contact information, demographic data, voting trend data, or other information that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(24)(b)(i): is not commissioned for the benefit of a particular candidate or officeholder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(24)(b)(ii): is offered at no cost to a candidate or officeholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(25): "Interim report" means a report identifying the contributions received and expenditures made since the last report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(26): "Legislative office" means the office of state senator, state representative, speaker of the House of Representatives, president of the Senate, and the leader, whip, and assistant whip of any party caucus in either house of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(27): "Legislative office candidate" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-101(27)(a): files a declaration of candidacy for the office of state senator or state representative;
