Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1401 Title.
----------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Voluntary Contributions Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1): (1)(b)(iii) As used in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(a): "Ballot proposition" includes constitutional amendments, initiatives, referenda, judicial retention questions, opinion questions, or other questions submitted to the voters for their approval or rejection.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(b): (1)(b)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(b)(i): "Labor organization" means a lawful organization of any kind that is composed, in whole or in part, of employees and that exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with employers concerning grievances, labor disputes, wages, rates of pay, hours of employment, or other terms and conditions of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(iii) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(b)(iii): "Labor organization" does not include organizations governed by the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq. or the Railroad Labor Act, 45 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(c): "Political fund" means a separate segregated fund established by a labor organization for political purposes that meets the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(d): "Political purposes" means an act done with the intent or in a way to influence or tend to influence, directly or indirectly, any person to refrain from voting or to vote for or against any candidate for public office at any caucus, political convention, primary, or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(1)(e): "Union dues" means dues, fees, money, or other assessments required as a condition of membership or participation in a labor organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1402(2): 20A-11-101 Other terms defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1403 Prohibition of required contributions for political purposes.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A labor organization may not require any contribution to a candidate, personal campaign committee, political action committee, political issues committee, registered political party, ballot proposition, or political fund as a condition of membership or participation in the labor organization.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404 Establishment and administration of political fund.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(1): A labor organization wishing to make expenditures for political purposes shall establish a political fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(2): Each labor organization that establishes a political fund shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(2)(a): maintain the political fund as a separate, segregated account apart from any account containing money received by a labor organization as union dues;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(2)(b): ensure that each contribution to the political fund is voluntary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(2)(c): register the political fund as a political action committee or political issues committee as required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(3)(a): Except as otherwise provided in this part, a labor organization may only make expenditures for political purposes from a political fund established in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(3)(b): A labor organization may not expend union dues for political purposes or transfer union dues to a political fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(4): Nothing in this part precludes a labor organization from making expenditures of union dues to communicate directly with its own members about political candidates or political issues.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(5): Nothing in this part precludes a labor organization from making expenditures of union dues either for the establishment and administration of a political fund or to solicit contributions from its members to a political fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1404(6): Nothing in this part is intended to, or may be construed to, preempt any requirement of federal law.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406 Enforcement of part -- Attorney general.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(1): (2); (3) Subject to the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(2): (1) Before bringing an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(2)(a): notify the labor organization in writing of the precise nature of the violation of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(2)(b): give the labor organization 10 days to cease and desist the violation of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(3): (1) The attorney general may not bring an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(3)(a): ceases and desists from violating this part within 10 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1406(3)(b): provides the attorney general with written confirmation that the labor organization has ceased from engaging in the conduct the attorney general determined to be a violation of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1501 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1501(1): "Labor organization" means a lawful organization of any kind that is composed, in whole or in part, of employees and that exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with employers concerning grievances, labor disputes, wages, rates of pay, hours of employment, or other terms and conditions of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1501(2): "Labor organization" includes an employee association and union for employees of public and private sector employers.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502 Campaign financial reporting of expenditures -- Filing requirements -- Statement contents.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1): (1)(a)(ii); (iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(a): Each labor organization that has made expenditures for political purposes or political issues expenditures on current or proposed ballot issues that total at least $750 during a calendar year shall file a verified financial statement with the lieutenant governor's office:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(a)(i): on January 10, reporting expenditures as of December 31 of the previous year;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(a)(ii): seven days before the regular primary election date;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(a)(iii): on September 30; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(a)(iv): seven days before the regular general election date.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(b): (1)(a)(ii); (iv) The labor organization shall report:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(b)(i): a detailed listing of all expenditures made since the last statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(b)(ii): (1)(a)(ii); (iv) for a financial statement described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(c): The labor organization is not required to file a financial statement under this section if the labor organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(c)(i): made no expenditures during the reporting period; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(1)(c)(ii): reports the labor organization's expenditures during the reporting period under another part of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(2): The financial statement shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(2)(a): the name and address of each reporting entity that received an expenditure or political issues expenditure of more than $50 from the labor organization, and the amount of each expenditure or political issues expenditure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(2)(b): the total amount of expenditures disbursed by the labor organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1502(2)(c): a statement by the labor organization's treasurer or chief financial officer certifying the accuracy of the financial statement.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503 Criminal penalties -- Fines.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(1): Within 60 days after a deadline for the filing of a financial statement required by this part, the lieutenant governor shall review each filed financial statement to ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(1)(a): each labor organization that is required to file a financial statement has filed one; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(1)(b): each financial statement contains the information required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(2): 20A-11-1005 If it appears that any labor organization has failed to file a financial statement, if it appears that a filed financial statement does not conform to the law, or if the lieutenant governor has received a written complaint alleging a violation of the law or the falsity of a financial statement, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(2)(a): 20A-11-1005 impose a fine against the labor organization in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(2)(b): within five days of discovery of a violation or receipt of a written complaint, notify the labor organization of the violation or written complaint and direct the labor organization to file a financial statement correcting the problem.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(3): (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(b); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(3)(a): It is unlawful for any labor organization to fail to file or amend a financial statement within seven days after receiving notice from the lieutenant governor under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(3)(b): (3)(a) Each labor organization that violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(3)(c): (3)(a) The lieutenant governor shall report all violations of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1503(3)(d): (3)(b); (3)(a) In addition to the criminal penalty described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1601 Title.
----------------------------------------
This part is known as "Conflict of Interest Disclosures."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(1): "Conflict of interest" means an action that is taken by a regulated officeholder that the officeholder reasonably believes may cause direct financial benefit or detriment to the officeholder, a member of the officeholder's immediate family, or an individual or entity that the officeholder is required to disclose under the provisions of this section, if that benefit or detriment is distinguishable from the effects of that action on the public or on the officeholder's profession, occupation, or association generally.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(2): 20A-11-1604 "Conflict of interest disclosure" means a disclosure, on the website, of all information required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(3): "Entity" means a corporation, a partnership, a limited liability company, a limited partnership, a sole proprietorship, an association, a cooperative, a trust, an organization, a joint venture, a governmental entity, an unincorporated organization, or any other legal entity, regardless of whether it is established primarily for the purpose of gain or economic profit.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4): 20A-11-1604 "Local official" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(a): an elected officer of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(a)(i): a municipality under Title 10, Chapter 3, Part 13, Municipal Officers' and Employees' Ethics Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(a)(ii): a county under Title 17, Chapter 16a, County Officers and Employees Disclosure Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(b): a special public officer under Title 67, Chapter 16, Utah Public Officers' and Employees' Ethics Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(c): 20A-11-1604 another individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(c)(i): who is not a regulated officeholder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(4)(c)(ii): 20A-11-1604 who is required to annually make a conflict of interest disclosure in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(5): "Filing officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(5)(a): the lieutenant governor, for the office of a state constitutional officer or State Board of Education member; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(5)(b): the lieutenant governor or the county clerk in the county of the candidate's residence, for a state legislative office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(6): "Immediate family" means the regulated officeholder's spouse, a child living in the regulated officeholder's immediate household, or an individual claimed as a dependent for state or federal income tax purposes by the regulated officeholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(7): "Income" means earnings, compensation, or any other payment made to an individual for gain, regardless of source, whether denominated as wages, salary, commission, pay, bonus, severance pay, incentive pay, contract payment, interest, per diem, expenses, reimbursement, dividends, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(a): "Owner or officer" means an individual who owns an ownership interest in an entity or holds a position where the person has authority to manage, direct, control, or make decisions for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(a)(i): the entity or a portion of the entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(a)(ii): an employee, agent, or independent contractor of the entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(b): "Owner or officer" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(b)(i): a member of a board of directors or other governing body of an entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(8)(b)(ii): a partner in any type of partnership.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(9): "Preceding year" means the year immediately preceding the day on which the regulated officeholder makes a conflict of interest disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(10): "Regulated officeholder" means an individual who is required to make a conflict of interest disclosure under the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(11): "State constitutional officer" means the governor, the lieutenant governor, the state auditor, the state treasurer, or the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602(12): 20A-11-1602.5 "Website" means the Candidate and Officeholder Conflict of Interest Disclosure Website described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5 Candidate and Officeholder Conflict of Interest Disclosure Website.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(1): The lieutenant governor shall, in cooperation with the county clerks, establish and administer a Candidate and Officeholder Conflict of Interest Disclosure Website.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2): The website shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(a): permit a candidate or officeholder to securely access the website for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(a)(i): complying with the conflict of interest disclosure requirements described in this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(a)(ii): editing conflict of interest disclosures;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(b): contain a record of all conflict of interest disclosures and edits made by the candidate or officeholder for at least the preceding four years;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(c): permit any person to view a conflict of interest disclosure made by a candidate or officeholder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1602.5(2)(d): contain a link to the conflict of interest disclosure made by a local official.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603 Conflict of interest disclosure -- Required when filing for candidacy -- Public availability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1): (1)(c); (1)(a); (1)(a); (1)(c)(i); 20A-11-1604; (1)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(a): (1)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(a)(i): state constitutional officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(a)(ii): state legislator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(a)(iii): State Board of Education member.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(b): (1)(a) A candidate who fails to comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(c): (1)(a); (1)(c)(i); 20A-11-1604; (1)(c)(ii) A candidate is not required to comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(c)(i): currently holds the office for which the candidate is seeking reelection;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(c)(ii): (1)(c)(i); 20A-11-1604 already, that same year, filed the conflict of interest disclosure for the office described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(1)(c)(iii): (1)(c)(ii) at the time the candidate files the declaration of candidacy, indicates, in writing, that the conflict of interest disclosure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(2): (1)(c); (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(2)(a): (1)(a); (1)(b) shall provide electronic notice to a candidate who fails to comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(2)(b): (1)(a) may not accept a declaration of candidacy for an office listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(3): (1)(a); 20A-11-1604 The conflict of interest disclosure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1603(4): The lieutenant governor shall make the complete conflict of interest disclosure made by each candidate available for public inspection on the website.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604 Failure to disclose conflict of interest -- Failure to comply with reporting requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(1)(a): Before or during the execution of any order, settlement, declaration, contract, or any other official act of office in which a state constitutional officer has actual knowledge that the state constitutional officer has a conflict of interest that is not stated in the conflict of interest disclosure, the state constitutional officer shall publicly declare that the state constitutional officer may have a conflict of interest and what that conflict of interest is.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(1)(b): Before or during any vote on legislation or any legislative matter in which a legislator has actual knowledge that the legislator has a conflict of interest that is not stated in the conflict of interest disclosure, the legislator shall orally declare to the committee or body before which the matter is pending that the legislator may have a conflict of interest and what that conflict is.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(1)(c): Before or during any vote on any rule, resolution, order, or any other board matter in which a member of the State Board of Education has actual knowledge that the member has a conflict of interest that is not stated in the conflict of interest disclosure, the member shall orally declare to the board that the member may have a conflict of interest and what that conflict of interest is.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(2): (1) Any public declaration of a conflict of interest that is made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(2)(a): on the official record of the action taken, for a state constitutional officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(2)(b): in the minutes of the committee meeting or in the Senate or House Journal, as applicable, for a legislator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(2)(c): in the minutes of the meeting or on the official record of the action taken, for a member of the State Board of Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(3): A state constitutional officer shall make a complete conflict of interest disclosure on the website:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(3)(a)(i): no sooner than January 1 each year, and before January 11 each year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(3)(a)(ii): if the state constitutional officer takes office after January 10, within 10 days after the day on which the state constitutional officer takes office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(3)(b): each time the state constitutional officer changes employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(4): A legislator shall make a complete conflict of interest disclosure on the website:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(4)(a)(i): no sooner than January 1 each year, and before January 11 each year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(4)(a)(ii): if the legislator takes office after January 10, within 10 days after the day on which the legislator takes office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(4)(b): each time the legislator changes employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(5): A member of the State Board of Education shall make a complete conflict of interest disclosure on the website:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(5)(a)(i): no sooner than January 1 each year, and before January 11 each year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(5)(a)(ii): if the member takes office after January 10, within 10 days after the day on which the member takes office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(5)(b): each time the member changes employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6): (3); (4); (5); (6)(b); (7); (6)(d); (f); (6)(b) A conflict of interest disclosure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(a): the regulated officeholder's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(b): the name and address of each of the regulated officeholder's current employers and each of the regulated officeholder's employers during the preceding year;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(c): (6)(b) for each employer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(d): for each entity in which the regulated officeholder is an owner or officer, or was an owner or officer during the preceding year:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(d)(i): the name of the entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(d)(ii): a brief description of the type of business or activity conducted by the entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(d)(iii): the regulated officeholder's position in the entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(e): (7) in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(e)(i): the name of the individual or entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(e)(ii): a brief description of the type of business or activity conducted by the individual or entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(f): for each entity in which the regulated officeholder holds any stocks or bonds having a fair market value of $5,000 or more as of the date of the disclosure form or during the preceding year, but excluding funds that are managed by a third party, including blind trusts, managed investment accounts, and mutual funds:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(f)(i): the name of the entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(f)(ii): a brief description of the type of business or activity conducted by the entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(g): (6)(d); (f) for each entity not listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(g)(i): the name of the entity or organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(g)(ii): a brief description of the type of business or activity conducted by the entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(g)(iii): the type of position held by the regulated officeholder;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(h): at the option of the regulated officeholder, a description of any real property in which the regulated officeholder holds an ownership or other financial interest that the regulated officeholder believes may constitute a conflict of interest, including a description of the type of interest held by the regulated officeholder in the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(i): the name of the regulated officeholder's spouse and any other adult residing in the regulated officeholder's household who is not related by blood or marriage, as applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(j): (6)(b) for the regulated officeholder's spouse, the information that a regulated officeholder is required to provide under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(k): a brief description of the employment and occupation of each adult who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(k)(i): resides in the regulated officeholder's household; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(k)(ii): is not related to the regulated officeholder by blood or marriage;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(l): at the option of the regulated officeholder, a description of any other matter or interest that the regulated officeholder believes may constitute a conflict of interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(m): the date the form was completed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(n): a statement that the regulated officeholder believes that the form is true and accurate to the best of the regulated officeholder's knowledge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(6)(o): the signature of the regulated officeholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(7): (6)(e); (6)(e); (6)(e) In making the disclosure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(8): The disclosure requirements described in this section do not prohibit a regulated officeholder from voting or acting on any matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(9): A regulated officeholder may amend a conflict of interest disclosure described in this part at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(10): (1) A regulated officeholder who violates the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(11): (1); (11)(a); (1)

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1604(11)(b): (11)(a); (1) In addition to the criminal penalty described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1605 Failure to file -- Penalties.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1606 Link to conflict of interest disclosure on Legislature's website.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature's website shall include, for each legislative officeholder, a link to the conflict of interest disclosure on the website maintained by the lieutenant governor in relation to that legislative officeholder.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1701 Title.
----------------------------------------
This part is known as "Independent Expenditures."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(1): "Clearly identified" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(1)(a): the name of the candidate appears;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(1)(b): a photograph or drawing of the candidate appears; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(1)(c): the identity of the candidate or ballot proposition is apparent by unambiguous reference.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2): (2)(a); (2)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a): "Independent expenditure" means an expenditure by a person expressly advocating the success or defeat of a clearly identified candidate or ballot proposition if the expenditure is not made in coordination with, or at the request or suggestion of:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(i): a candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(ii): a candidate's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(iii): a member of a candidate's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(iv): a political action committee for which the candidate is an officer with primary decision making authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(v): an agent of a candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(a)(vi): a political issues committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(b): (2)(a); (2)(b)(i) "Independent expenditure" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(b)(i): the cost of creating and disseminating material for a public communication, including design and production costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(2)(b)(ii): (2)(a); (2)(b)(i) a contract or other promise to make an expenditure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(a): "Public communication" means a communication by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(a)(i): broadcast, cable, satellite communication, newspaper, magazine, outdoor advertising facility, mass mailing, or telephone bank; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(a)(ii): another medium used for political advertising to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(b): "Public communication" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(b)(i): a news story, a commentary, or an editorial disseminated by a broadcasting station, including a cable television operator, programmer, or producer, satellite television or radio provider, website, newspaper, magazine, or other periodical publication, that is not controlled by a candidate or political party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(3)(b)(ii): a candidate debate or forum.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1702(4): "Telephone bank" means 500 or more identical or substantially similar telephone calls within any 30-day period.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703 Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(1): A registered political party is not required to comply with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(2): (2)(a); 20A-11-1704 A reporting entity is not required to report an independent expenditure under this part if the reporting party:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(2)(a): reports the expenditure under another part in this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(2)(b): (2)(a); 20A-11-1704 in the report described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(2)(b)(i): identifies the expenditure as an independent expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1703(2)(b)(ii): 20A-11-1704 provides the information, described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704 Independent expenditure report.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(1): 20A-11-1703 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(2): 20A-11-1703 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3): An independent expenditure report shall include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(a): if the person who made the independent expenditures is an individual, the person's name, address, and phone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(b): if the person who made the independent expenditures is not an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(b)(i): the person's name, address, and phone number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(b)(ii): the name, address, and phone number of an individual who may be contacted by the chief election officer in relation to the independent expenditure report; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c): for each independent expenditure made by the person during the current election cycle that was not reported in a previous independent expenditure report:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(i): the date of the independent expenditure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(ii): the amount of the independent expenditure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(iii): the candidate or ballot proposition for which the independent expenditure expressly advocates the success or defeat and a description of whether the independent expenditure supports or opposes the candidate or ballot proposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(iv): the identity, address, and phone number of the person to whom the independent expenditure was made;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(v): a description of the goods or services obtained by the independent expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(vi): for each person who, for political purposes, made cumulative donations of $1,000 or more during the current election cycle to the filer of the independent expenditure report:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(vi)(A): the identity, address, and phone number of the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(vi)(B): the date of the donation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(3)(c)(vi)(C): the amount of the donation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(4): (4)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(4)(a): If the person filing an independent expenditure report is an individual, the person shall sign the independent expenditure report and certify that the information contained in the report is complete and accurate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(4)(b): (4)(b)(i) If the person filing an independent expenditure report is not an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(4)(b)(i): the person filing the independent expenditure report shall designate an authorized individual to sign the independent expenditure report on behalf of the person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(4)(b)(ii): (4)(b)(i) the individual designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(5): (3)(a); (b) If a person who files an independent expenditure report previously filed an independent expenditure report during, or in relation to, the same election cycle that includes information, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1704(6): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act An independent expenditure report is a public record under


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1705 Detailed records.
---------------------------------------------------
A person who files an independent expenditure report shall keep records of all independent expenditures made by the person, including receipts, and all donations described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1706 Penalties.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1706(1): The chief election officer shall impose a $100 fine against an individual who fails to file an independent expenditure report, that includes the information required for the report, within the time period required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1706(2): The chief election officer shall impose a $1000 fine against a person who is not an individual who fails to file an independent expenditure report, that includes the information required for the report, within the time period required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-11-1706(3): The chief election officer shall deposit fines collected under this chapter into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 12 - Selection and Election of Judges
*******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201 Judicial appointees -- Retention elections.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Visit judges.utah.gov to learn about the Judicial Performance Evaluation Commission's recommendations for each judge"; andUtah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(1)(a): Each judicial appointee to a court is subject to an unopposed retention election at the first general election held more than three years after the judge or justice was appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(1)(b): After the first retention election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(1)(b)(i): each Supreme Court justice shall be on the regular general election ballot for an unopposed retention election every tenth year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(1)(b)(ii): each judge of other courts shall be on the regular general election ballot for an unopposed retention election every sixth year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(a): Each justice or judge of a court of record who wishes to retain office shall, in the year the justice or judge is subject to a retention election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(a)(i): file a declaration of candidacy with the lieutenant governor, or with the county clerk in the candidate's county of residence, within the period beginning on July 1 and ending at 5 p.m. on July 15 in the year of a regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(a)(ii): pay a filing fee of $50.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b)(i): Each justice court judge who wishes to retain office shall, in the year the justice court judge is subject to a retention election:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b)(i)(A): file a declaration of candidacy with the lieutenant governor, or with the county clerk in the candidate's county of residence, within the period beginning on July 1 and ending at 5 p.m. on July 15 in the year of a regular general election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b)(i)(B): pay a filing fee of $25 for each judicial office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b)(ii): If a justice court judge is appointed or elected to more than one judicial office, the declaration of candidacy shall identify all of the courts included in the same general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(2)(b)(iii): If a justice court judge is appointed or elected to more than one judicial office, filing a declaration of candidacy in one county in which one of those courts is located is valid for the courts in any other county.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(3)(a): The lieutenant governor shall, no later than August 31 of each regular general election year:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(3)(a)(i): transmit a certified list containing the names of the justices of the Supreme Court, judges of the Court of Appeals, and judges of the Business and Chancery Court declaring their candidacy to the county clerk of each county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(3)(a)(ii): transmit a certified list containing the names of judges of other courts declaring their candidacy to the county clerk of each county in the geographic division in which the judge filing the declaration holds office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(3)(b): Each county clerk shall place the names of justices and judges standing for retention election in the nonpartisan section of the ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(4): 78A-7-102
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(4)(a): At the general election, the ballots shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(4)(a)(i): at the beginning of the judicial retention section of the ballot, the following statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(4)(a)(ii): as to each justice or judge of any court to be voted on in the county, the following question:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(4)(b): 78A-7-102 If a justice court exists by means of an interlocal agreement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(5)(a): If the justice or judge receives more yes votes than no votes, the justice or judge is retained for the term of office provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(5)(b): If the justice or judge does not receive more yes votes than no votes, the justice or judge is not retained, and a vacancy exists in the office on the first Monday in January after the regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(6): A justice or judge not retained is ineligible for appointment to the office for which the justice or judge was defeated until after the expiration of that term of office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(7): 10-2-301; 10-2-301
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(7)(a): 10-2-301 If a justice court judge is standing for retention for one or more judicial offices in a county in which the judge is a county justice court judge or a municipal justice court judge in a town or municipality of the fourth or fifth class, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-201(7)(b): 10-2-301 If a justice court judge is standing for retention for one or more judicial offices in a municipality of the first, second, or third class, as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a): "Contribution" means any of the following when done for political purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a)(i): a gift, subscription, donation, loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value given to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a)(ii): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make a gift, subscription, donation, unpaid or partially unpaid loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a)(iii): any transfer of funds from another reporting entity or a corporation to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a)(iv): compensation paid by any person or reporting entity other than the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee for personal services provided without charge to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(a)(v): goods or services provided to or for the benefit of the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee at less than fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(b): "Contribution" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(b)(i): services provided without compensation by individuals volunteering a portion or all of their time on behalf of the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(1)(b)(ii): money lent to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(2): 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(2)(a): "Corporation" means a domestic or foreign, profit or nonprofit, business organization that is registered as a corporation or is authorized to do business in a state and makes any expenditure from corporate funds for political purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(2)(b): 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101 "Corporation" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(2)(b)(i): 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101 a business organization's political action committee as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(2)(b)(ii): a business entity organized as a partnership or a sole proprietorship.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3): "Detailed listing" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(a): for each contribution:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(a)(i): the name and address of the individual or source making the contribution, to the extent that the name or address of the individual or source is known;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(a)(ii): the amount or value of the contribution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(a)(iii): the date the contribution was made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(b): for each expenditure:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(b)(i): the amount of the expenditure;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(b)(ii): the person or entity to whom it was disbursed;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(b)(iii): the specific purpose, item, or service acquired by the expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(3)(b)(iv): the date the expenditure was made.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a): "Expenditure" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(i): any disbursement from contributions or from the separate bank account required by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(ii): a purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value made for political purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(iii): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make any purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value for political purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(iv): compensation paid by a corporation or reporting entity for personal services rendered by a person without charge to the judge or the judge's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(v): a transfer of funds between the judge's personal campaign committee and another judge's personal campaign committee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(a)(vi): goods or services provided by the judge's personal campaign committee to or for the benefit of another judge for political purposes at less than fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(b): "Expenditure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(b)(i): services provided without compensation by individuals volunteering a portion or all of their time on behalf of the judge or judge's personal campaign committee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(4)(b)(ii): money lent to a judge's personal campaign committee by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(5): "Individual" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(6): "Interim report" means a report identifying the contributions received and expenditures made since the last report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(7): "Personal campaign committee" means the committee appointed by a judge to act for the judge as provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(8): "Political purposes" means an act done with the intent or in a way to influence or tend to influence, directly or indirectly, any person to refrain from voting or to vote for or against any judge standing for retention at any election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(9): "Reporting entity" means a judge, judge's personal campaign committee, candidate, a candidate's personal campaign committee, an officeholder, and a party committee, a political action committee, and a political issues committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301(10): "Summary report" means the year-end report containing the summary of a reporting entity's contributions and expenditures.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301.5 Disclosure of actual source or recipient required.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301.5(1): As used in this section, "transactional intermediary" means a person, including a credit card company, a financial institution, or a money transfer service, that pays or transfers money to a person on behalf of another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301.5(2): When, under this chapter, a person makes a detailed listing, discloses or reports the source of a contribution, discloses or reports the person or entity to whom a disbursement is made, or discloses or reports the identity of a donor, the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301.5(2)(a): shall reveal the actual source of the contribution, the actual person or entity to whom the disbursement is ultimately made, or the actual identity of the donor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-301.5(2)(b): may not merely list, disclose, or report the transactional intermediary.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302 Campaign committee required.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(1)(a): When permitted to do so by the Code of Judicial Conduct promulgated by the Utah Supreme Court, and if the judge chooses to solicit contributions or make expenditures to promote his retention, the judge may establish no more than one retention election personal campaign committee, consisting of one or more persons, to receive contributions, make expenditures, and shall file reports connected with the judge's retention election campaign.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(1)(b): A judge or person acting in concert with or with the knowledge of the judge may not receive any contributions or make any expenditures other than through the personal campaign committee established under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(2)(a): The judge shall file with the lieutenant governor a signed written statement containing the name and address of each member and the secretary of the judge's personal campaign committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(2)(b): The judge may change the membership of the personal campaign committee at any time by filing with the lieutenant governor a signed statement containing the name and address of any additional members and identifying any members that have been removed from the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(2)(c): The judge or the judge's personal campaign committee may not make any expenditures on behalf of the judge until the statement has been filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(3)(a): The judge's personal campaign committee may not make an expenditure of more than $1,000 unless the judge or the secretary of the personal campaign committee authorizes the expenditure in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(3)(b): A judge or the judge's personal campaign committee may not make any expenditures prohibited by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-302(4): 20A-12-304 A judge's personal campaign committee is dissolved on the date that the summary report required by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303 Separate account for campaign funds -- Reporting contributions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(1): The judge or the judge's personal campaign committee shall deposit each contribution in one or more separate personal campaign accounts in a financial institution.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(2): The judge or the judge's personal campaign committee may not deposit or mingle any contributions received into a personal or business account.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3): (3); 20A-12-305; (3)(b); (3)(b); (3)(b); (3)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(a): (3); 20A-12-305 As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(a)(i): for a cash contribution, that the cash is given to a judge or the judge's personal campaign committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(a)(ii): for a contribution that is a negotiable instrument or check, that the negotiable instrument or check is negotiated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(a)(iii): for any other type of contribution, that any portion of the contribution's benefit inures to the judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(b): The judge or the judge's personal campaign committee shall report to the lieutenant governor each contribution received by the judge, within 31 days after the day on which the contribution is received.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(c): (3)(b); (3)(b); (3)(b) For each contribution that a judge fails to report within the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(c)(i): (3)(b) 10% of the amount of the contribution if the judge reports the contribution within 60 days after the day on which the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(c)(ii): (3)(b) 20% of the amount of the contribution, if the judge fails to report the contribution within 60 days after the day on which the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d): (3)(c) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(i): (3)(c) deposit money received under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(ii): report on the lieutenant governor's website, in the location where reports relating to each judge are available for public access:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(ii)(A): each fine imposed by the lieutenant governor against the judge;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(ii)(B): the amount of the fine;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(ii)(C): the amount of the contribution to which the fine relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(3)(d)(ii)(D): the date of the contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-303(4): Within 31 days after receiving a contribution that is cash or a negotiable instrument, exceeds $50, and is from an unknown source, a judge or the judge's personal campaign committee shall disburse the amount of the contribution to an organization that is exempt from federal income taxation under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304 Judicial retention election candidates -- Financial reporting requirements -- Year-end summary report.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(1): The judge's personal campaign committee shall file a summary report with the lieutenant governor by January 10 of the year after the regular general election year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a): Each summary report shall include the following information as of December 31 of the last regular general election year:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(i): a single figure equal to the total amount of contributions reported on the interim report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(ii): a single figure equal to the total amount of expenditures reported on the interim report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(iii): a detailed listing of each contribution received since the last summary report that has not been reported in detail on the interim report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(iv): for each nonmonetary contribution, the fair market value of the contribution;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(v): a detailed listing of each expenditure made since the last summary report that has not been reported in detail on the interim report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(vi): for each nonmonetary expenditure, the fair market value of the expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(a)(vii): the net balance for the year, consisting of all contributions minus all expenditures.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(b)(i): For all single contributions of $50 or less, an aggregate figure may be reported without a separate detailed listing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(b)(ii): Two or more contributions from the same source for a total of more than $50 may not be reported in the aggregate, but shall be reported in the detailed listing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(2)(c): A check or negotiable instrument received by a judge or the judge's personal campaign committee on or before December 31 of the previous year shall be reported in the summary report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-304(3): The judge shall certify in the summary report that, to the best of the judge's knowledge, all contributions and all expenditures have been reported as of December 31 of the last regular general election year and that there are no financial obligations outstanding except as set forth in the report.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305 Judicial retention election candidates -- Financial reporting requirements -- Interim report.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(1): The judge's personal campaign committee shall file an interim report with the lieutenant governor on the date seven days before the regular general election date.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2): Each interim report shall include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2)(a): a detailed listing of each contribution received since the last financial statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2)(b): for each nonmonetary contribution, the fair market value of the contribution;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2)(c): a detailed listing of each expenditure made since the last summary report;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2)(d): for each nonmonetary expenditure, the fair market value of the expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(2)(e): a net balance for the year consisting of all contributions since the last summary report minus all expenditures since the last summary report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(3)(a): For all individual contributions of $50 or less, a single aggregate figure may be reported without separate detailed listings.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(3)(b): Two or more contributions from the same source that have an aggregate total of more than $50 may not be reported in the aggregate, but shall be reported separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(4): In preparing each interim report, all contributions and expenditures shall be reported as of five days before the required filing date of the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-305(5): A negotiable instrument or check received by a judge or the judge's personal campaign committee more than five days before the required filing date of a report required by this section shall be included in the interim report.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306 Judges -- Failure to file reports -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1): 20A-11-1005; (1)(a); (1)(b); 20A-11-103; (1)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a): 20A-11-1005 If a judge's personal campaign committee fails to file the interim report due before the regular general election, the lieutenant governor shall, after making a reasonable attempt to discover if the report was timely filed:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(i): inform the county clerk and other appropriate election officials who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(i)(A): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(i)(A)(I): shall, if practicable, remove the name of the judge from the ballots before the ballots are delivered to voters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(i)(A)(II): shall, if removing the judge's name from the ballot is not practicable, inform the voters by any practicable method that the judge has been disqualified and that votes cast for the judge will not be counted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(i)(B): may not count any votes for that judge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(a)(ii): 20A-11-1005 impose a fine against the filing entity in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(b): Any judge who fails to file timely a financial statement required by this part is disqualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(c): (1)(a); (1)(b); 20A-11-103; (1)(c)(ii) Notwithstanding Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(c)(i): 20A-11-103 the candidate timely files the reports required by this section in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(c)(ii): the reports are completed, detailing accurately and completely the information required by this part except for inadvertent omissions or insignificant errors or inaccuracies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(1)(c)(iii): (1)(c)(ii) the omissions, errors, or inaccuracies described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2): (2)(c)(i); (2)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(a): Within 30 days after a deadline for the filing of a summary report, the lieutenant governor shall review each filed summary report to ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(a)(i): each judge that is required to file a summary report has filed one; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(a)(ii): each summary report contains the information required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(b): If it appears that any judge has failed to file the summary report required by law, if it appears that a filed summary report does not conform to the law, or if the lieutenant governor has received a written complaint alleging a violation of the law or the falsity of any summary report, the lieutenant governor shall, within five days of discovery of a violation or receipt of a written complaint, notify the judge of the violation or written complaint and direct the judge to file a summary report correcting the problem.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(c): (2)(c)(i); (2)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(c)(i): It is unlawful for any judge to fail to file or amend a summary report within 14 days after receiving notice from the lieutenant governor under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(c)(ii): (2)(c)(i) Each judge who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-12-306(2)(c)(iii): (2)(c)(i) The lieutenant governor shall report all violations of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 13 - Elections to Federal Offices
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(1): "Census block" means any one of the 71,207 individual geographic areas into which the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce has divided the state of Utah, to each of which the Bureau of the Census has attached a discrete population tabulation from the 2020 decennial census.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(2): "Congressional block equivalency file" means the electronic file designated as HB2004_BEF.txt that assigns each of Utah's 71,207 census blocks to a particular Congressional district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(3): "Congressional shapefile" means the electronic shapefile that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(3)(a): is the resulting projection of the Congressional block equivalency file; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(3)(b): stores the boundary of each of the four United States Congressional district boundaries for Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.1(4): "Shapefile" means the digital vector storage format for storing geometric location and associated attribute information.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5 Representatives to the United States Congress -- Four representative districts -- When elected -- District boundaries.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(1)(a): The state of Utah is divided into four districts for the election of representatives to the Congress of the United States, with one member to be elected from each Congressional district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(1)(b): At the general election to be held in 2022, and biennially thereafter, one representative from each Congressional district shall be elected to serve in the Congress of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(2): The Legislature adopts the official census population figures and maps of the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce developed in connection with the taking of the 2020 national decennial census as the official data for establishing Congressional district boundaries.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(3)(a): The Legislature enacts the district numbers and boundaries of the Congressional districts designated in the Congressional block equivalency file and resulting Congressional shapefile that is the electronic component of Laws of Utah 2021, Second Special Session, Chapter 2:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(3)(a)(i): for purposes of nominating and electing members of the United States Congress beginning January 1, 2022; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(3)(a)(ii): for all other purposes beginning January 3, 2023.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-101.5(3)(b): The Legislature shall ensure that the Congressional shapefile, and Congressional boundaries generated from the Congressional shapefile, are accessible on the Utah Legislature's website.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102 Congressional districts -- Filing -- Legal boundaries.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(1)(a): The Legislature shall file a copy of the Congressional block equivalency file enacted by the Legislature and the resulting Congressional shapefile with the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(1)(b): The legal boundaries of Utah's Congressional districts are contained in the Congressional shapefile on file with the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2)(a): (1) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2)(a)(i): (1) verify the Congressional block equivalency file that the Legislature files under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2)(a)(ii): generate maps of each Congressional district from the Congressional shapefile; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2)(a)(iii): ensure that the district maps are available for viewing on the lieutenant governor's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102(2)(b): If there is any inconsistency between the district maps and the Congressional shapefile resulting from the Congressional block equivalency file, the Congressional shapefile is controlling.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2 County clerk, Utah Geospatial Resource Center, and lieutenant governor responsibilities -- Maps and voting precinct boundaries.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(1): As used in this section, "redistricting boundary data" means the Congressional shapefile in the possession of the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(2): Each county clerk shall obtain a copy of the redistricting boundary data for the clerk's county from the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(a): A county clerk may create one or more county maps that identify the boundaries of Utah's Congressional districts as generated from the redistricting boundary data.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(b): Before publishing or distributing any map or data created by the county clerk that identifies the boundaries of Utah's Congressional districts within the county, the county clerk shall submit the county map and data to the lieutenant governor and to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center for review.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(c): Within 30 days after receipt of a county map and data from a county clerk, the Utah Geospatial Resource Center shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(c)(i): review the county map and data to evaluate if the county map and data accurately reflect the boundaries of Utah's Congressional districts established by the Legislature in the redistricting boundary data;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(c)(ii): determine whether the county map and data are correct or incorrect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(c)(iii): communicate those findings to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(d): The lieutenant governor shall either notify the county clerk that the county map and data are correct or notify the county clerk that the county map and data are incorrect.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(e): (3) If the county clerk receives notice from the lieutenant governor that the county map and data submitted are incorrect, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(e)(i): make the corrections necessary to conform the county map and data to the redistricting boundary data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(3)(e)(ii): (3) resubmit the corrected county map and data to the lieutenant governor and to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center for a new review under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4): (4); 20A-5-303; 20A-5-303; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(a): (4); 20A-5-303 Subject to the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(b): 20A-5-303 Within five working days after approval of voting precincts and polling places by the county legislative body as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(c): Within 30 days after receipt of a map from a county clerk, the Utah Geospatial Resource Center shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(c)(i): review the voting precinct map to evaluate if the voting precinct map accurately reflects the boundaries of Utah's Congressional districts established by the Legislature in the redistricting boundary data;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(c)(ii): determine whether the voting precinct map is correct or incorrect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(c)(iii): communicate those findings to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(d): The lieutenant governor shall either notify the county clerk that the voting precinct map is correct or notify the county clerk that the map is incorrect.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(e): (4) If the county clerk receives notice from the lieutenant governor that the voting precinct map is incorrect, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(e)(i): make the corrections necessary to conform the voting precinct map to the redistricting boundary data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-102.2(4)(e)(ii): (4) resubmit the corrected voting precinct map to the lieutenant governor and to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center for a new review under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-103 Omissions from maps -- How resolved.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-103(1): (2); (3) If any area of the state is omitted from a Congressional district in the Congressional shapefile in the possession of the lieutenant governor's office, the county clerk of the affected county, upon discovery of the omission, shall attach the area to the appropriate Congressional district according to the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-103(2): If the omitted area is surrounded by a single Congressional district, the county clerk shall attach the area to that district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-103(3): If the omitted area is contiguous to two or more Congressional districts, the county clerk shall attach the area to the district that has the least population, as determined by the Utah Population Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-103(4): The county clerk shall certify in writing and file with the lieutenant governor any attachment made under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104 Uncertain boundaries -- How resolved.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(1): As used in this section, "affected party" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(1)(a): a representative whose Congressional district boundary is uncertain because the boundary in the Congressional shapefile used to establish the district boundary has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified or who is uncertain about whether the representative or another individual resides in a particular Congressional district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(1)(b): a candidate for Congressional representative whose Congressional district boundary is uncertain because the boundary in the Congressional shapefile used to establish the district boundary has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified or who is uncertain about whether the candidate or another individual resides in a particular Congressional district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(1)(c): an individual who is uncertain about which Congressional district contains the individual's residence because the boundary in the Congressional shapefile used to establish the district boundary has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2): (2)(a)(i); (ii); (2)(a); (2)(b); 63A-16-505
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(a): (2)(a)(i); (ii) An affected party may file a written request petitioning the lieutenant governor to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(a)(i): the precise location of the Congressional district boundary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(a)(ii): the number of the Congressional district in which an individual resides; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(i); (ii) both Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(b): (2)(a) In order to make the determination required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(b)(i): the Congressional block equivalency file and the resulting Congressional shapefile; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(b)(ii): any other relevant data such as aerial photographs, aerial maps, or other data about the area.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(c): (2)(b) Within five days of receipt of the request, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(c)(i): (2)(b) complete the review described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(c)(ii): make a determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d): 63A-16-505 When the lieutenant governor determines the location of the Congressional district boundary, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d)(i): prepare a certification identifying the appropriate boundary and attaching a map, if necessary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d)(ii): 63A-16-505 send a copy of the certification to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d)(ii)(A): the affected party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d)(ii)(B): the county clerk of the affected county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(d)(ii)(C): 63A-16-505 the Utah Geospatial Resource Center created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(e): If the lieutenant governor determines the number of the Congressional district in which a particular individual resides, the lieutenant governor shall send a letter identifying that district by number to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(e)(i): the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(e)(ii): the affected party who filed the petition, if different than the individual whose Congressional district number was identified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-104(2)(e)(iii): the county clerk of the affected county.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-201 Senators -- When elected.
----------------------------------------------------------
At the general election in November, 1932, and at each general election immediately preceding the expiration of the term of office of a United States senator from Utah, there shall be elected one United States senator to serve for a period of six years.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301 Presidential elections -- Effect of vote.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(1)(a): Each registered political party shall choose individuals to act as presidential electors and to fill vacancies in the office of presidential electors for their party's candidates for president and vice president of the United States according to the procedures established in their bylaws.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(1)(b): Each registered political party shall certify to the lieutenant governor the names and addresses of the individuals selected by the political party as the party's presidential electors before 5 p.m. no later than August 31.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(1)(c): An unaffiliated candidate or write-in candidate for the office of president of the United States shall, no later than 5 p.m. ten days after the day on which the candidate files a declaration of candidacy, certify to the lieutenant governor the names and addresses of each individual selected by the candidate as a presidential elector for the candidate and each individual selected by the candidate to fill a vacancy in the office of presidential elector for the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(2): (2)(b); (1)(c) The highest number of votes cast for candidates for president and vice president of the United States elects the presidential electors for:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(2)(a): (2)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-301(2)(b): (1)(c) if the candidates receiving the highest number of votes are unaffiliated candidates or write-in candidates, the presidential electors selected for those candidates under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-302 Certificate of election.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-302(1): 20A-13-301 The lieutenant governor shall transmit certificates of election to each of the electors selected under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-302(1)(a): if the candidates for president and vice president of the United States who receive the highest number of votes in the state are unaffiliated candidates or write-in candidates, by the candidate for president; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-302(1)(b): if the candidates for president and vice president of the United States who receive the highest number of votes in the state are the nominees of a registered political party, by the registered political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-302(2): Presidential electors may not receive compensation for their services.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-303 Filling vacancies.
---------------------------------------------------
If there is a vacancy in the office of presidential elector because of death, refusal to act, failure to attend, ineligibility, or any other cause, the individual or political party represented by the elector who caused the vacancy shall immediately fill the vacancy.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-304 Meeting to ballot -- Casting ballot for individual not nominated by elector's candidate or party.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
