Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-304(1): The electors shall meet at the office of the lieutenant governor at the state capitol at noon of the first Wednesday of the January after their election, or at noon of any other day designated by the Congress of the United States of America.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-304(2): After convening, the electors shall perform their duties in conformity with the United States Constitution and laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-13-304(3): Any elector who casts an electoral ballot for an individual not nominated by the individual, or by the party of which the elector is an elector, except in the cases of death or felony conviction of a candidate, is considered to have resigned from the office of elector, the elector's vote may not be recorded, and the remaining electors shall appoint another individual to fill the vacancy.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 14 - Nomination and Election of State and Local School Boards
*******************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(1): "Board" means the State Board of Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(2): "Board block equivalency file" means the electronic file designated as SB2005S07_BEF.txt that assigns each of Utah's 71,207 census blocks to a particular State Board of Education district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(3): "Board shapefile" means the electronic shapefile that:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(3)(a): is the resulting projection of the Board block equivalency file; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(3)(b): stores the boundary of each of the 15 State Board of Education districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(4): "Census block" means any one of the 71,207 individual geographic areas into which the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce has divided the state of Utah, to each of which the Bureau of the Census has attached a discrete population tabulation from the 2020 decennial census.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.1(5): "Shapefile" means the digital vector storage format for storing geometric location and associated attribute information.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5 State Board of Education -- Number of members -- State Board of Education district boundaries.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(1): The State Board of Education shall consist of 15 members, with one member to be elected from each State Board of Education district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(2): The Legislature adopts the official census population figures and maps of the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce developed in connection with the taking of the 2020 national decennial census as the official data for establishing State Board of Education district boundaries.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(3)(a): (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(3)(a)(i): for purposes of nominating and electing certain members of the State Board of Education beginning January 1, 2022; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(3)(a)(ii): for all other purposes beginning January 2, 2023.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-101.5(3)(b): The Legislature shall ensure that the Board shapefile, and the State Board of Education district boundaries generated from the Board shapefile, are accessible on the Utah Legislature's website.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102 State Board of Education districts -- Filing -- Legal boundaries.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(1)(a): The Legislature shall file a copy of the Board block equivalency file enacted by the Legislature and the resulting Board shapefile with the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(1)(b): The legal boundaries of State Board of Education districts are contained in the Board shapefile on file with the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2)(a): (1) The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2)(a)(i): (1) verify the Board block equivalency file that the Legislature files under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2)(a)(ii): generate maps of each State Board of Education district from the Board shapefile; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2)(a)(iii): ensure that the district maps are available for viewing on the lieutenant governor's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102(2)(b): If there is any inconsistency between the district maps and the Board shapefile resulting from the Board block equivalency file, the Board shapefile is controlling.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.1 Omissions from maps -- How resolved.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.1(1): (2); (3) If any area of the state is omitted from a State Board of Education district in the Board shapefile in the possession of the lieutenant governor's office, the county clerk of the affected county, upon discovery of the omission, shall attach the area to the appropriate State Board of Education district according to the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.1(2): If the omitted area is surrounded by a single State Board of Education district, the county clerk shall attach the area to that district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.1(3): If the omitted area is contiguous to two or more State Board of Education districts, the county clerk shall attach the area to the district that has the least population, as determined by the Utah Population Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.1(4): The county clerk shall certify in writing and file with the lieutenant governor any attachment made under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2 Uncertain boundaries -- How resolved.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1)(a): "Affected party" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1)(a)(i): a state school board member whose State Board of Education district boundary is uncertain because the feature used to establish the district boundary in the Board shapefile has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified or who is uncertain about whether the member or another individual resides in a particular State Board of Education district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1)(a)(ii): a candidate for state school board whose State Board of Education district boundary is uncertain because the feature used to establish the district boundary in the Board shapefile has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified or who is uncertain about whether the candidate or another individual resides in a particular State Board of Education district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1)(a)(iii): an individual who is uncertain about which State Board of Education district contains the individual's residence because the feature used to establish the district boundary in the Board shapefile has been removed, modified, or is unable to be identified.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(1)(b): "Feature" means a geographic or other tangible or intangible mark such as a road or political subdivision boundary that is used to establish a State Board of Education district boundary.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2): (2)(a)(i); (ii); (2)(a); (2)(b); 63A-16-505
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(a): (2)(a)(i); (ii) An affected party may file a written request petitioning the lieutenant governor to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(a)(i): the precise location of the State Board of Education district boundary;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(a)(ii): the number of the State Board of Education district in which an individual resides; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(i); (ii) both Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(b): (2)(a) In order to make the determination required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(b)(i): the Board block equivalency file and the resulting Board shapefile; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(b)(ii): any other relevant data such as aerial photographs, aerial maps, or other data about the area.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(c): (2)(b) Within five days of receipt of the request, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(c)(i): (2)(b) complete the review described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(c)(ii): make a determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d): 63A-16-505 If the lieutenant governor determines the precise location of the State Board of Education district boundary, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d)(i): prepare a certification identifying the appropriate State Board of Education district boundary and attaching a map, if necessary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d)(ii): 63A-16-505 send a copy of the certification to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d)(ii)(A): the affected party;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d)(ii)(B): the county clerk of the affected county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(d)(ii)(C): 63A-16-505 the Utah Geospatial Resource Center created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(e): If the lieutenant governor determines the number of the State Board of Education district in which a particular individual resides, the lieutenant governor shall send a letter identifying that district by number to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(e)(i): the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(e)(ii): the affected party who filed the petition, if different than the individual whose State Board of Education district number was identified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.2(2)(e)(iii): the county clerk of the affected county.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3 County clerk, Utah Geospatial Resource Center, and lieutenant governor responsibilities -- Maps and voting precinct boundaries.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(1): As used in this section, "redistricting boundary data" means the Board shapefile in the possession of the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(2): Each county clerk shall obtain a copy of the redistricting boundary data for the clerk's county from the lieutenant governor's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(a): A county clerk may create one or more county maps that identify the boundaries of State Board of Education districts as generated from the redistricting boundary data.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(b): Before publishing or distributing any map or data created by the county clerk that identifies the boundaries of State Board of Education districts within the county, the clerk shall submit the county map and data to the lieutenant governor and to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center for review.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(c): Within 30 days after receipt of a county map and data from a county clerk, the Utah Geospatial Resource Center shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(c)(i): review the county map and data to evaluate if the county map and data accurately reflect the boundaries of State Board of Education districts established by the Legislature in the redistricting boundary data;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(c)(ii): determine whether the county map and data are correct or incorrect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(c)(iii): communicate those findings to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(d): The lieutenant governor shall either notify the county clerk that the county map and data are correct or inform the county clerk that the county map and data are incorrect.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(e): (3) If the county clerk receives notice from the lieutenant governor that the county map and data submitted are incorrect, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(e)(i): make the corrections necessary to conform the county map and data to the redistricting boundary data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(3)(e)(ii): (3) resubmit the corrected county map and data to the lieutenant governor for a new review under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4): (4); 20A-5-303; 20A-5-303; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(a): (4); 20A-5-303 Subject to the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(b): 20A-5-303 Within five working days after approval of voting precincts and polling places by the county legislative body as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(c): Within 30 days after receipt of a voting precinct map from a county clerk, the Utah Geospatial Resource Center shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(c)(i): review the voting precinct map to evaluate if the voting precinct map accurately reflects the boundaries of State Board of Education districts established by the Legislature in the redistricting boundary data;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(c)(ii): determine whether the voting precinct map is correct or incorrect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(c)(iii): communicate those findings to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(d): The lieutenant governor shall either notify the county clerk that the voting precinct map is correct or notify the county clerk that the voting precinct map is incorrect.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(e): (4) If the county clerk receives notice from the lieutenant governor that the voting precinct map is incorrect, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(e)(i): make the corrections necessary to conform the voting precinct map to the redistricting boundary data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-102.3(4)(e)(ii): (4) resubmit the corrected voting precinct map to the lieutenant governor and to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center for a new review under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103 State Board of Education members -- Term -- Requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(1): (2); (1)(a)(ii) Unless otherwise provided by law and except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(1)(a): voters in the following districts, as designated in the Senate block equivalency file, shall elect a State Board of Education member for a term of four years:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(1)(a)(i): at the 2022 General Election, State Board of Education Districts 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 11, and 14; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(1)(a)(ii): at the 2024 General Election, State Board of Education Districts 3, 6, 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, and 15; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(1)(b): (1)(a)(ii) a State Board of Education member representing a district described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2): (2); (2)(b); 20A-5-101
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(a): (2) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(b): If one of the incumbent State Board of Education members from District 6 files written notice with the lieutenant governor by close of business on January 3, 2022, that the member will not seek election to the State Board of Education from District 6:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(b)(i): the filing incumbent member may serve until January 2, 2023, in representation of the district to which the member was elected at the 2020 General Election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(b)(ii): the other incumbent member from District 6 shall serve out the term for which the member was elected, in representation of District 6, which is until January 6, 2025.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(c): (2)(b); 20A-5-101 If neither or both incumbent State Board of Education members in District 6 file the written notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(c)(i): the incumbent members may serve until January 2, 2023, in representation of the district to which the members were elected at the 2020 General Election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(c)(ii): 20A-5-101 the lieutenant governor shall designate District 6 as an office to be filled in the 2022 General Election in the notice of election required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(c)(iii): the State Board of Education member elected from District 6 at the 2022 General Election shall be elected to serve a term of office of two years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(2)(c)(iv): the State Board of Education member elected from District 6 at the 2024 General Election shall be elected to serve a term of office of four years.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(3): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(3)(a): A person seeking election to the State Board of Education shall have been a resident of the State Board of Education district in which the person is seeking election for at least one year as of the date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(3)(b): (3) A person who has resided within the State Board of Education district, as the boundaries of the district exist on the date of the election, for one year immediately preceding the date of the election shall be considered to have met the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(4): A State Board of Education member shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(4)(a): be and remain a registered voter in the State Board of Education district from which the member was elected or appointed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(4)(b): maintain the member's primary residence within the State Board of Education district from which the member was elected or appointed during the member's term of office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-103(5): A State Board of Education member may not, during the member's term of office, also serve as an employee of the State Board of Education.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1 State Board of Education -- Candidacy.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1(1): 20A-9-201; 20A-9-202; 20A-9-501; 20A-9-502; 20A-9-503; 20A-9-601; 20A-9-602 A person interested in becoming a candidate for the office of State Board of Education member shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1(1)(a): 20A-9-201; 20A-9-202 file a declaration of candidacy in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1(1)(b): 20A-9-501; 20A-9-502; 20A-9-503 file a certificate of nomination in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1(1)(c): 20A-9-601; 20A-9-602 seek placement on the ballot as a write-in candidate in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-104.1(2): The office of State Board of Education member may be filled by an individual running as a member of a political party, as unaffiliated, or as a write-in candidate.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201 Boards of education -- School board districts -- Creation -- Redistricting.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(1): 20A-14-202 The county legislative body, for local school districts whose boundaries encompass more than a single municipality, and the municipal legislative body, for local school districts contained completely within a municipality, shall divide the local school district into local school board districts as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(2): The county and municipal legislative bodies shall divide the school district so that the local school board districts are substantially equal in population and are as contiguous and compact as practicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4; 20A-14-202 County and municipal legislative bodies shall redistrict local school board districts to meet the population, compactness, and contiguity requirements of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(a): at least once every 10 years;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(b): 53G-3-301.1; 53G-3-301.3; 53G-3-301.4 for a new school district or a reorganized new school district that is approved by the voters at a regular general election under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(c): whenever school districts are consolidated;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(d): whenever a school district loses more than 20% of the population of the entire school district to another school district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(e): whenever a school district loses more than 50% of the population of a local school board district to another school district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(f): whenever a school district receives new residents equal to at least 20% of the population of the school district at the time of the last redistricting because of a transfer of territory from another school district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(3)(g): 20A-14-202 whenever it is necessary to increase the membership of a board as a result of changes in student membership under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(4): If a school district receives territory containing less than 20% of the population of the transferee district at the time of the last redistricting, the local school board may assign the new territory to one or more existing school board districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(5): 53G-3-302(1)(b)(ii) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(a): After redistricting, representation in a local school board district shall be determined as provided in this Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(b): If, after redistricting, only one board member whose term extends beyond redistricting lives within a local school board district, that board member shall represent that local school board district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(c): If, after redistricting, two or more members whose terms extend beyond redistricting live within a local school board district, the members involved shall select one member by lot to represent the local school board district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(d): The other members shall serve at-large for the remainder of their terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(e): The at-large board members shall serve in addition to the designated number of board members for the board in question for the remainder of their terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(6)(f): If there is no board member living within a local school board district whose term extends beyond redistricting, the seat shall be treated as vacant and filled as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(7)(a): If, before an election affected by redistricting, the county or municipal legislative body that conducted the redistricting determines that one or more members shall be elected to terms of two years to meet this part's requirements for staggered terms, the legislative body shall determine by lot which of the redistricted local school board districts will elect members to two-year terms and which will elect members to four-year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(7)(b): All subsequent elections are for four-year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(8): 63A-16-505 Within 10 days after any local school board district boundary change, the county or municipal legislative body making the change shall send an accurate map or plat of the boundary change to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-201(9): Subsections (4) through (7) do not apply to a redistricting that occurs under Subsection (3)(b).


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202 Local boards of education -- Membership -- When elected -- Qualifications -- Avoiding conflicts of interest.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1): (1)(d)(i)(B); (1)(b); (c); (d); 20A-14-201; 20A-14-203; (1)(a); (d); (1)(h)(iii); (1)(h)(ii); (1)(b); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(a): The board of education of a school district with a student population of less than 10,000 students comprises five members.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(b): The board of education of a school district with a student population of 10,000 or more students but fewer than 50,000 students comprises seven members.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(c): Before January 1, 2023, the board of education of a school district with a student population of 50,000 or more students comprises seven members.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(d): (1)(d)(i)(B) Beginning on January 1, 2023:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(d)(i): (1)(d)(i)(B) the board of education of a school district with a student population of 50,000 or more students but fewer than 100,000 students:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(d)(i)(A): (1)(d)(i)(B) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(d)(i)(B): comprises nine members if the board of education of the school district, by majority vote, increases the board to nine members; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(d)(ii): the board of education of a school district with a student population of 100,000 or more students comprises nine members.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(e): Student population is based on the October 1 student count submitted by districts to the State Board of Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(f): (1)(b); (c); (d); 20A-14-201; 20A-14-203 If the number of members of a local school board changes under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(g): (1)(a); (d) Notwithstanding Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h): (1)(h)(iii); (1)(h)(ii); (1)(b); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(i): Members of a local board of education shall be elected at each regular general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(ii): (1)(h)(iii) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(ii)(A): no more than three members of a local board of education may be elected to a five-member board;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(ii)(B): no more than four members of a local board of education may be elected to a seven-member board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(ii)(C): no more than five members of a local board of education may be elected to a nine-member board.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(h)(iii): (1)(h)(ii); (1)(b); (d) A number of members, in excess of the maximums described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(1)(i): One member of the local board of education shall be elected from each local school board district.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(2)(a): An individual seeking election to a local school board shall have been a resident of the local school board district in which the person is seeking election for at least one year immediately preceding the day of the general election at which the board position will be filled.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(2)(b): (2) A person who has resided within the local school board district, as the boundaries of the district exist on the date of the general election, for one year immediately preceding the date of the election shall be considered to have met the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(3): A member of a local school board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(3)(a): be and remain a registered voter in the local school board district from which the member is elected or appointed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(3)(b): maintain the member's primary residence within the local school board district from which the member is elected or appointed during the member's term of office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-202(4): A member of a local school board may not, during the member's term in office, also serve as an employee of that board.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203 Becoming a member of a local board of education -- Declaration of candidacy -- Election.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(1): 20A-9-201.5; 20A-9-202 An individual may become a candidate for a local school board by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(1)(a): 20A-9-201.5 filing a declaration of candidacy with the county clerk during the declaration of candidacy filing period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(1)(b): 20A-9-202 paying the fee described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(2)(a): The term of office for an individual elected to a local board of education is four years, beginning on the first Monday in January after the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(2)(b): A member of a local board of education shall serve until a successor is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(2)(b)(i): elected; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-203(2)(b)(ii): appointed and takes or signs the constitutional oath of office.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-204 Effect of transfer of a district on composition of local school board.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a portion of one school district becomes part of another school district, any member of the board of education residing within the transferred portion becomes a member of the board of the transferee district and shall serve the remainder of the term to which the member was elected.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-205 Vacancies on local school boards.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Vacancies on local school boards shall be filled as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206 Student petition for student member on local school board.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(1): A student petition requesting that a local school board appoint a nonvoting student member to the board may be submitted to the board under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(2): The petition shall have the signatures of at least 500 students regularly enrolled in high school in the district or at least 10% of the number of students regularly enrolled in high school in the district, whichever is less.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(3)(a): Upon receipt of the petition, the board may appoint a nonvoting student member to serve a one-year term on the local school board as an addition to the number of regular members authorized by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(3)(b): A student member's term begins July 1 and ends on June 30 of the following year.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(4): A student board member shall be enrolled in a high school in the district and may be less than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(5): A student member may participate in all board meetings, except executive sessions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(6): 53G-4-204
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(6)(a): 53G-4-204 A student board member shall receive the same expense allowance granted other board members under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-14-206(6)(b): A student member is not liable for any acts of the governing board.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 15 - Convention to Ratify Amendments to the Constitution of the United States
***********************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101 Scope and application of chapter.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(1): The procedures contained in this section govern when the Congress of the United States:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(1)(a): proposes an amendment to the Constitution of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(1)(b): directs that the amendment be ratified by conventions in each state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(2): If Congress prescribes the manner in which the conventions shall be constituted and does not except those states that have established procedures for constituting ratification conventions:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(2)(a): this chapter is inoperative;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(2)(b): the convention shall be constituted and shall operate as the congressional resolution or Act of Congress directs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-101(2)(c): all state officers who are authorized or directed to take any action to constitute a ratification convention in Utah shall do so.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102 Election to elect convention delegates.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102(1): The governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102(1)(a): issue a proclamation establishing the date of an election to elect 21 delegates to Utah's ratification convention from the state at large;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102(1)(b): ensure that the election is held at least as soon as the next regular general election occurring more than three months after the amendment has been proposed by Congress; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102(1)(c): either call a special election or schedule the election to be held at the same time as a regular or municipal general election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-102(2): Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, the election shall be conducted according to the procedures for a regular general election contained in this title.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103 Delegates -- Candidacy -- Qualifications -- Nominating procedures -- Removal of petition signature.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(1): Candidates for the office of delegate to the ratification convention shall be citizens, residents of Utah, and at least 21 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(2): Persons wishing to be delegates to the ratification convention shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(2)(a): circulate a nominating petition meeting the requirements of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(2)(b): obtain the signature of at least 100 registered voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(a): A single nominating petition may nominate any number of candidates up to 21, the total number of delegates to be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(b): Nominating petitions may not contain anything identifying a candidate's party or political affiliation.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(c): Each nominating petition shall contain a written statement signed by each nominee, indicating either that the candidate will:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(c)(i): vote for ratification of the proposed amendment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(c)(ii): vote against ratification of the proposed amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(3)(d): A nominating petition containing the names of more than one nominee may not contain the name of any nominee whose stated position in the nominating petition is inconsistent with that of any other nominee listed in the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4): 20A-1-1002
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(a): Candidates shall file their nominating petitions with the lieutenant governor before 5 p.m. no later than 40 days before the proclaimed date of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(b): 20A-1-1002 Within 10 days after the last day for filing the petitions, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(b)(i): 20A-1-1002 use the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(b)(ii): declare nominated the 21 nominees in favor of ratification and the 21 nominees against ratification whose nominating petitions have been signed by the largest number of registered voters;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(b)(iii): decide any ties by lot drawn by the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(4)(b)(iv): certify the nominated candidates of each group to the county clerk of each county within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(5): (5)(a); 20A-1-1003(2); 20A-1-1003(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(5)(a): A voter who signs a nomination petition under this section may have the voter's signature removed from the petition by, no later than three business days after the last day for filing the petitions, submitting to the lieutenant governor a statement requesting that the voter's signature be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(5)(b): (5)(a); 20A-1-1003(2) A statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-103(5)(c): 20A-1-1003(3) The lieutenant governor shall use the procedures described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104 Ballot -- Form -- Manner of marking and voting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"OFFICIAL BALLOT for delegates to convention to ratify or reject proposed amendment to the Constitution of the United States. The Congress has proposed an amendment to the Constitution of the United States that provides: (insert here the text of the proposed amendment).Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(1): The requirements of this section govern the form of the ballot and the specific procedures for electing delegates to the ratification convention.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2): Each county clerk shall ensure that the ballot to select delegates to the ratification convention:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(a): is separate from and printed on different color stock than any other ballot to be used at the same election;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b): contains the following information in this order:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(i): the text of the proposed amendment;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(ii): instructions to the voter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(iii): three perpendicular columns of equal width;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(iv): at the head of the first perpendicular column, in plain type, the words "For Ratification of Proposed Change in Constitution of the United States";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(v): at the head of the second perpendicular column, in plain type, the words "Against Ratification of Proposed Change in Constitution of the United States";
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(vi): no heading or names at the head of the third perpendicular column;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(vii): in the column headed "For Ratification of Proposed Change in Constitution of the United States," the names of the nominees nominated as in favor of ratification;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(viii): in the column headed "Against Ratification of Proposed Change in Constitution of the United States," the names of the nominees nominated as against ratification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(b)(ix): in the column without heading, spaces permitting the voter to write in other names; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(2)(c): is arranged so that the voter may, by making a single mark, vote for the entire group of nominees whose names are contained in any column.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(3): Each county clerk shall ensure that the ballot to select delegates to the ratification convention is in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4): If the election of delegates to the ratification convention is held at the same time as the regular general election, the county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4)(a): give the same ballot number to a regular general election ballot and a ballot to elect delegates to a ratification convention;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4)(b): direct the election judges to:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4)(b)(i): hand to each voter the general election ballot and the ratification convention ballot with identical ballot numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4)(b)(ii): instruct the voter to mark each ballot and deposit each ballot in the ballot box; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(4)(b)(iii): mark any ballot "void" that the voter declines to use and return it to the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-104(5): Each voter shall indicate the voter's choice by making one or more cross-marks in the appropriate spaces provided on the ballot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201 Convening -- Vacancies -- Election of officers -- Journal of proceedings.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(1): The delegates to the convention shall convene at the state capitol at noon on the 28th day after their election to pass upon the question of whether or not the proposed amendment shall be ratified.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(2)(a): If, at the time the convention convenes, there is a vacancy in the convention, the delegates from the group from which the delegate creating the vacancy was elected shall, by majority vote, appoint a person to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(2)(b): If the convention contains no other delegates from the group from which the delegate creating the vacancy was elected, the governor shall appoint a person to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(3): The convention may:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(3)(a): elect a president, secretary, and other officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(3)(b): adopt its own rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(4): The convention shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(4)(a): keep a journal of its proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(4)(b): record in the journal the vote of each delegate on the question of ratification of the proposed amendment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(4)(c): file the journal  with the lieutenant governor after the convention adjourns.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5)(a): Delegates to the ratification convention shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5)(a)(i): serve without pay;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5)(a)(ii): receive a per diem of $4 per day while the convention is in session; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5)(a)(iii): receive  mileage at the rate of 10 cents per mile for the distance necessarily traveled in going to and returning from the place of meeting by the most usual route.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-201(5)(b): The lieutenant governor shall pay the per diem and mileage, together with the necessary expenses of the convention for printing and stenographic services, from the state treasury.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-202 Certificate of ratification.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-202(1): If the convention agrees, by vote of a majority of the total number of delegates, to ratify the proposed amendment, the president and secretary of the convention shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-202(1)(a): prepare and sign a certificate to that effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-202(1)(b): transmit it to the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-15-202(2): Upon receipt of a ratification certificate, the lieutenant governor shall transmit the certificate under the great seal of the state to the Secretary of State of the United States.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 16 - Uniform Military and Overseas Voters Act
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1): 20A-2-105 "Covered voter" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(a): satisfies Utah's voter eligibility requirements that do not relate to residency;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(b): is not registered to vote in a state other than Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(c): is absent from the United States on the day of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d): 20A-2-105
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(i): 20A-2-105 is a resident of Utah under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(i)(A): is a uniformed service voter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(i)(B): temporarily resides outside the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(ii): is a foreign United States citizen who:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(ii)(A): before establishing a principal place of residence outside the United States, established a principal place of residence in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(ii)(B): did not, after leaving Utah, register to vote in a state other than Utah or establish a principal place of residence in a state other than Utah; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(iii): is a foreign United States citizen:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(iii)(A): who has never registered to vote in a state other than Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(iii)(B): who has never established a principal place of residence in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(1)(d)(iii)(C): whose parent, legal guardian, spouse, or domestic partner established the parent's, legal guardian's, spouse's, or domestic partner's most recent United States principal place of residence in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(2): "Dependent" means an individual recognized as a dependent by a uniformed service.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(3): "Federal postcard application" means the application prescribed under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 52 U.S.C. Sec. 20301(b)(2).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(4): "Federal write-in absentee ballot" means the ballot described in the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 52 U.S.C. Sec. 20303(a)(1).
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(5): "Foreign United States citizen" means a citizen of the United States whose principal place of residence is outside the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(6): "Military-overseas ballot" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(6)(a): a federal write-in absentee ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(6)(b): a ballot specifically prepared or distributed for use by a covered voter in accordance with this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(6)(c): a ballot cast by a covered voter in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(7): "Overseas voter" means a United States citizen who, on the day of the applicable election, is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(7)(a): voting age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(7)(b): absent from the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(8): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, or American Samoa.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(9): 68-3-12.5 "Uniformed service" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(9)(a): 68-3-12.5 active and reserve components of the armed forces as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(9)(b): the Merchant Marine, the commissioned corps of the Public Health Service, or the commissioned corps of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(9)(c): the National Guard.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(10): (10)(a); (c) "Uniformed-service voter" means an individual who is qualified to vote and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(10)(a): a member of the active or reserve components of the armed forces who is on active duty;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(10)(b): a member of the Merchant Marine, the commissioned corps of the Public Health Service, or the commissioned corps of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(10)(c): a member on activated status of the National Guard; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(10)(d): (10)(a); (c) a spouse or dependent of a member referred to in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-102(11): "United States," when used in the territorial sense, means the several states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, and American Samoa.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-103 Application to elections -- Voting by foreign United States citizen.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-103(1): The voting procedures in this chapter apply to an election authorized by this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-103(2): A covered voter who is a foreign United States citizen may only vote in a federal election and may only vote for candidates for federal office.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-103(3): 20A-16-102(1)(d)(ii) A covered voter described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-103(4): 20A-16-102(1)(d)(iii) A covered voter described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201 Duties of lieutenant governor.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The lieutenant governor shall:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(1): implement this chapter and the state's responsibilities under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 52 U.S.C. 20301 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(2): make available to covered voters information regarding voter registration procedures for covered voters and procedures for casting military-overseas ballots;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(3): establish an electronic transmission system through which a covered voter may apply for and receive voter registration materials, military-overseas ballots, and other information under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(4)(a): develop standardized absentee-voting materials, including privacy and transmission envelopes and electronic equivalents of the envelopes, authentication materials, and voting instructions, to be used with the military-overseas ballot of a voter authorized to vote in any jurisdiction in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(4)(b): (4)(a) to the extent reasonably possible, coordinate with other states on the development required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(5): prescribe the form and content of a declaration:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(5)(a): for use by a covered voter to swear or affirm specific representations pertaining to the voter's identity, eligibility to vote, status as a covered voter, and timely and proper completion of an overseas-military ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(5)(b): that is based on the declaration prescribed to accompany a federal write-in absentee ballot, as modified to be consistent with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-201(5)(c): that is a prominent part of all balloting materials for which the declaration is required, including an indication of the date of execution of the declaration.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-202 Report on ballots.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-202(1): No later than 60 days after each regular general election date, each county clerk shall submit a report to the lieutenant governor indicating:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-202(1)(a): the number of ballots sent to covered voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-202(1)(b): the number of ballots returned by covered voters that were counted.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-202(2): (1) No later than 90 days after each regular general election date, the lieutenant governor shall submit a statewide report to the Election Assistance Commission that includes the information required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-301 Overseas voter's registration address.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to SectionUtah Code Annotated § 20A-16-301(1): use and be assigned to the voting precinct of the address of the last place of residence of the voter in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-301(2): (1) if the address described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302 Methods of registering to vote.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(1): To apply to register to vote, in addition to any other approved method, a covered voter may use a federal postcard application or the application's electronic equivalent.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(2)(a): A covered voter may use the declaration accompanying a federal write-in absentee ballot to apply to register to vote simultaneously with the submission of the federal write-in absentee ballot, if the declaration is received before the day of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(2)(b): If the declaration is received on or after the day of the election, the declaration shall be treated as an application to register to vote for subsequent elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(3): 20A-16-201(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(3)(a): 20A-16-201(3) The lieutenant governor shall ensure that the electronic transmission system described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-302(3)(b): The voter may use the electronic transmission system or any other approved method to register to vote.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401 Methods of applying for military-overseas ballots.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(1): A covered voter who is registered to vote in the state may apply for a military-overseas ballot:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(1)(a): via  the federal postcard application;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(1)(b): via  the federal postcard application's electronic equivalent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(1)(c): by otherwise making a request in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(2): 20A-16-302 A covered voter who is not registered to vote in this state may use a federal postcard application or the federal postcard application's electronic equivalent to apply simultaneously to register to vote under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(3): 20A-16-201(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(3)(a): 20A-16-201(3) The lieutenant governor shall ensure that the electronic transmission system described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(3)(b): The voter may use the electronic transmission system or any other approved method to apply for a military-overseas ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(4): A covered voter may use the declaration accompanying a federal write-in absentee ballot as an application for a military-overseas ballot simultaneously with the submission of the federal write-in absentee ballot, if the declaration is received by the appropriate election official before the day of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(5): To receive the benefits of this chapter, a covered voter shall inform the appropriate election official that the voter is a covered voter by:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(5)(a): the use of a federal postcard application or federal write-in absentee ballot;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(5)(b): the use of an overseas address on an approved voter registration application or ballot application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(5)(c): the inclusion on an approved voter registration application or ballot application of other information sufficient to identify the voter as a covered voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-401(6): This chapter does not preclude a covered voter from voting via a manual ballot by mail.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-402 Timeliness and scope of application for military-overseas ballot.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-402(1): An application for a military-overseas ballot is timely if received before the day of the election.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-402(2): An application for a military-overseas ballot for a regular primary election or municipal primary election, whether or not timely, is effective as an application for a military-overseas ballot for the regular general election or municipal general election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403 Transmission of unvoted ballots.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(1): 20A-1-104 For an election for which the state has not received a waiver pursuant to the Military and Overseas Voter Empowerment Act, 52 U.S.C. Sec. 20302(g)(2), not later than 45 days before the election or, notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2)(a): A covered voter who requests that a ballot and balloting materials be sent to the voter by electronic transmission may choose:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2)(a)(i): facsimile transmission;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2)(a)(ii): email delivery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2)(a)(iii): if offered by the voter's jurisdiction, Internet delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(2)(b): The election official in each jurisdiction charged with distributing a ballot and balloting materials shall transmit the ballot and balloting materials to the voter using the means of transmission chosen by the voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-403(3): If a ballot application from a covered voter arrives after the jurisdiction begins transmitting ballots and balloting materials to voters, the official charged with distributing a ballot and balloting materials shall transmit the ballot and balloting materials to the voter no later than two business days after the day on which the application arrives.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-404 Timely casting of ballot.
----------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided by SectionUtah Code Annotated § 20A-16-404(1): received by the appropriate election officer not later than the close of the polls; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-404(2): submitted for mailing, electronic transmission, or other authorized means of delivery not later than 12:01 a.m., at the place where the voter completes the ballot, on the date of the election.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-405 Federal write-in absentee ballot.
------------------------------------------------------------------
A covered voter may use a federal write-in absentee ballot to vote for all applicable offices and ballot propositions in an election.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-408 Receipt of voted ballot.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-408(1): 20A-1-308; 20A-16-404 Except as provided by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-408(2): Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 5, Falsification in Official Matters If, at the time of completing a military-overseas ballot and balloting materials, the voter has declared under penalty of perjury as provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-409 Declaration.
---------------------------------------------
A military-overseas ballot shall include or be accompanied by:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-409(1): Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 5, Falsification in Official Matters a declaration signed by a covered voter that a material misstatement of fact in completing the ballot may be grounds for a conviction of perjury under the laws of the United States or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-409(2): the following statement if the military-overseas ballot is electronically transmitted: "I understand that by electronically transmitting my voted ballot I am voluntarily waiving my right to a secret ballot.  Signature of voter ________________ Date _______".


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-410 Confirmation of receipt of application and voted ballot.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The lieutenant governor, in coordination with an election officer, shall implement an electronic free-access system by which a covered voter may determine by telephone, electronic mail, or Internet:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-410(1): whether the voter's federal postcard application or other registration or military-overseas ballot application has been received and accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-410(2): whether the voter's military-overseas ballot has been received; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-410(3): the current status of the ballot.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501 Use of voter's email address.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(1): An election officer shall request an email address from each covered voter who registers to vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(2): 63G-2-302; 20A-3a-401.5 An email address provided by a covered voter:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(2)(a): 63G-2-302 is a private record under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(2)(b): 20A-3a-401.5 may be used only for official communication with the covered voter about the voting process, including transmitting military-overseas ballots and election materials if the voter has requested electronic transmission, verifying the voter's mailing address and physical location, and informing the voter of the status of the voter's ballot in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(3): 20A-3a-401.5 The request for an email address shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(3)(a): describe the purposes for which the email address may be used;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(3)(b): include a statement that any other use or disclosure of the email address is prohibited; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(3)(c): 20A-3a-401.5 describe how a voter may sign up to receive ballot status notifications via the ballot tracking system described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(4): (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(4)(a): A covered voter who provides an email address may request that the covered voter's application for a military-overseas ballot be considered a standing request for electronic delivery of a ballot for all elections held through December 31 of the year following the calendar year of the date of the application or another shorter period the covered voter specifies.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(4)(b): An election official shall provide a military-overseas ballot to a covered voter who makes a standing request for each election to which the request is applicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-501(4)(c): (4) A covered voter who is entitled to receive a military-overseas ballot for a primary election under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502 Publication of election notice.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(1): At least 100 days before the day of an election, other than a statewide special election or local special election, and as soon as practicable before a statewide special election or local special election, the election officer shall prepare an election notice for the election officer's jurisdiction, to be used in conjunction with a federal write-in absentee ballot.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(2): The election notice must contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(2)(a): a list of all of the ballot propositions and federal, state, and local offices that as of that date the election officer expects to be on the ballot on the date of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(2)(b): specific instructions for how a covered voter is to indicate on the federal write-in absentee ballot the covered voter's choice for each office to be filled and for each ballot proposition to be contested.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(3)(a): A covered voter may request a copy of an election notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(3)(b): The election officer shall send the notice to the covered voter by facsimile, email, or regular mail, as the covered voter requests.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(4): Chapter 3a, Voting; (1) As soon as the ballot is certified, and not later than the date ballots are required to be transmitted to voters under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-502(5): A political subdivision that maintains a website shall make the election notice prepared under this section and updated versions of the election notice regularly available on the website.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503 Prohibition of nonsubstantive requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(1)(a): If a covered voter's mistake or omission in the completion of a document under this chapter does not prevent determining whether a covered voter is eligible to vote, the mistake or omission does not invalidate the document.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(1)(b): Failure to satisfy a nonsubstantive requirement, including requirements to use paper or envelopes of a specified size or weight, does not invalidate a document submitted under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(1)(c): In a write-in ballot authorized by this chapter or in a vote for a write-in candidate on a regular ballot, if the intention of the covered voter is discernable under this state's uniform definition of what constitutes a vote, an abbreviation, misspelling, or other minor variation in the form of the name of a candidate or a political party is a valid vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(2): 20A-16-409
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(2)(a): Notarization is not required for the execution of a document under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(2)(b): 20A-16-409
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(2)(b)(i): 20A-16-409 An authentication, other than the declaration described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-503(2)(b)(ii): The declaration and any information in the declaration may be compared with information on file to ascertain the validity of the document.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-504 Equitable relief.
--------------------------------------------------
A court may issue an injunction or grant other equitable relief appropriate to ensure substantial compliance with, or enforce, this chapter on application by:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-504(1): a covered voter alleging a grievance under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-504(2): an election officer.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-505 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-16-506 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, and supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 17 - Political Campaign Signs
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Political Campaign Signs."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102 Campaign signs.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(1)(a): advocating the election or defeat of a candidate for public office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(1)(b): advocating the approval or defeat of a ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(2): (1); (1); (1)(a); (1)(b) A person is not guilty of a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(2)(a): (1)(a) as it relates to a sign described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(2)(b): (1)(b) as it relates to a sign described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(2)(c): a property owner of property on which the sign is placed or the property owner's agent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-102(2)(d): a public official who removes the sign in accordance with an official duty of the public official.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103 Posting political signs on public property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1): 17B-1-102; 17D-1-102; 17D-2-102; 17D-3-102; 63E-1-102; 63E-1-102; Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 8, Public Transit District Act; (1)(a)(i); (xii) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a): 17B-1-102; 17D-1-102; 17D-2-102; 17D-3-102; 63E-1-102; 63E-1-102; Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 8, Public Transit District Act; (1)(a)(i); (xii) "Local government entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(i): a county, municipality, or other political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(ii): 17B-1-102 a special district, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(iii): 17D-1-102 a special service district, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(iv): 17D-2-102 a local building authority, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(v): 17D-3-102 a conservation district, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(vi): 63E-1-102 an independent entity, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(vii): 63E-1-102 a public corporation, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(viii): Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 8, Public Transit District Act a public transit district, organized under
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(ix): a school district;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(x): a public school, including a charter school or other publicly funded school;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(xi): a state institution of higher education;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(xii): an entity that expends public funds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(a)(xiii): (1)(a)(i); (xii) each office, agency, or other division of an entity described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(b): "Political sign" means any sign or document that advocates:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(b)(i): the election or defeat of a candidate for public office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(b)(ii): the approval or defeat of a ballot proposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(c)(i): "Public property" means any real property, building, or structure owned or leased by a local government entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(1)(c)(ii): "Public property" does not include any real property, building, or structure during a period of time that the real property, building, or structure is rented out by a government entity to a private party for a meeting, convention, or similar event.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(2): A local government entity, a local government officer, a local government employee, or another person with authority or control over public property that posts or permits a person to post a political sign on public property:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(2)(a): shall permit any other person to post a political sign on the public property, subject to the same requirements and restrictions imposed on all other political signs permitted to be posted on the public property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-17-103(2)(b): may not impose a requirement or restriction on the posting of a political sign if the requirement or restriction is not politically neutral and content neutral.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 18 - Article V Convention
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101 Article V convention delegates.
----------------------------------------------------------------
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that to the best of my abilities, I will, as a delegate to an Article V convention, uphold the Constitution and laws of the United States of America and of the State of Utah, and that I will act at all times in accordance with the Article V application and the legislative instructions given to me as a delegate.  I will not act in a manner that supports or approves the proposing of an unauthorized amendment or change to the United States Constitution by the convention."Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1)(a): "Article V application" means an application or resolution passed by the Legislature applying to Congress to call an Article V convention.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1)(b): "Article V convention" means a convention called for the purpose of proposing an amendment to the United States Constitution as provided in the United States Constitution, Article V.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1)(c): "Delegate" means an individual elected by the Legislature, or by any other method provided by law, to represent the state at an Article V convention.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1)(d): "Legislative instructions" means instruction given by the Legislature to a delegate before or during an Article V convention.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(1)(e): "Unauthorized amendment" means a proposed amendment or change to the United States Constitution that is outside the scope of the Article V application and legislative instructions.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(2): A delegate from the state to an Article V convention may not act in a manner that supports or approves the proposing of an unauthorized amendment or change to the United States Constitution by the convention.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(3)(a): (2) A delegate who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(3)(b): An alternate selected by the Legislature has the same duties and is subject to the same requirements and penalties as a delegate.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(4): Upon selection by the Legislature, or by any other method provided by law, a delegate from the state to an Article V convention shall take the following oath:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(5): (2); (2) The Legislature shall certify in writing to the Article V convention:
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(5)(a): the selection of delegates and alternates;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(5)(b): if a delegate is recalled, the recall and replacement of the delegate with an alternate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(5)(c): (2); (2) if a delegate from the state violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-18-101(6): A delegate who violates this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 20A - Chapter 20 - Utah Independent Redistricting Commission
****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Independent Redistricting Commission."

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(1): 20A-20-201 "Commission" means the Utah Independent Redistricting Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(2): "Committee" means the Legislature's redistricting committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(3): "Decennial year" means a year during which the United States Bureau of Census conducts a national decennial census.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(4): "Linked PL94-171 data" means legacy file decennial census data for Utah, published by the United States Bureau of Census, that, after publication, is linked to Utah geographic data files in a manner that the data can be used to draw maps for the purpose of redistricting.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(5): "Regular decennial redistricting" means redistricting required due to a national decennial census.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-102(6): "Special redistricting" means redistricting that is not a regular decennial redistricting.


Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-103 Review by interim committee.
-------------------------------------------------------------
During the 2022 Legislative interim, the Government Operations Interim Committee shall conduct a review of the commission and the commission's role in relation to the redistricting process.

Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201 Utah Independent Redistricting Commission -- Creation -- Membership -- Term -- Quorum -- Action -- Meetings -- Staffing -- Website.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(1)(a): There is created the Utah Independent Redistricting Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(1)(b): The commission is housed in the Department of Government Operations for budgetary purposes only.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(1)(c): The commission is not under the direction or control of the Department of Government Operations or any executive director, director, or other employee of the Department of Government Operations or any other government entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(a): one member appointed by the governor, which member shall serve as chair of the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(b): one member appointed by the president of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(c): one member appointed by the speaker of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(d): one member appointed by the legislative leader of the largest minority political party in the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(e): one member appointed by the legislative leader of the largest minority political party in the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 20A-20-201(2)(f): one member appointed jointly by the president of the Senate and the speaker of the House of Representatives; and
